sections.title: QBH MAT Emergency Management Plan Final 6 17

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health (QBH) shall be prepared at all times to respond to emergency situations affecting normal facility operations.  QBH maintains a 24-hour telephone answering capability to respond to facility emergencies. A record of consumers and medication dosages is accessible to the staff person on call for verification purposes.
To conduct a hazardous vulnerability analysis annually (1 year from last event plus or minus 30 days)
To conduct at least one emergency drill to assess readiness of the plan annually (1 year from last event plus or minus 30 days)
To evaluate all actual occurrences of plan implementation and drills using all sections of the drill evaluation form to identify improvement opportunities.
To evaluate that all staff are knowledgeable about their roles during implementation of the plan.
To oversee all consumers, staff and visitors are accounted for during an emergency event.
To assign job responsibilities during emergency drills.
To assign Emergency Codes.

To establish a functional Contingency Plan and Disaster Recovery Plan that will sustain operation of the information system, and PHI/ePHI information, in particular, in whatever circumstance triggers operationalization of the plan.  To provide guidelines for the staff to clearly understand and initiate their roles in operationalizing the plan components in a consistent manner.  This plan applies to all paper and electronic forms of PHI, including email.
All staff and consumers are educated about emergency situations and their roles in responding to emergency drills or actual occurrences in annual in-services/updates.
The following situations could arise and would require implementation of this plan to varying degrees:
Fire/Explosion-Code Red-  [See Fire Safety Plan]
Severe Weather-Code Brown
Bomb Threat-Code Black-
Loss of Utilities-Code Yellow- (electricity, gas, water, telephone) [See Utilities
Management Plan]
Earthquake-Code Green
Flood-Code Blue
Chemicals/Hazardous Materials spill White
The following are codes which shall be used to indicate emergency situations on the intercom:
CODE RED 1: Fire. Area evacuation is required.
CODE RED 2: Fire. Full facility evacuation is required.
CODE GREEN: Consumer or visitor behavior control problem. Staff assistance required.
CODE BLUE: CPR required. Staff assistance required.
CODE YELLOW:  Out of control person. Staff assistance required.
Staff will demonstrate knowledge of Emergency Preparedness Plan procedures as evidenced by post-test and evaluation of drills.
CEO or designee:
Establishes a control center in the administrative office
Determines the extent that the Emergency Preparedness Plan will be activated.
Communications
Telephones are located at all sites. If site is safe to leave, staff can go use the nearest pay phone or use a cell phone

Maintains an up-to-date plan for emergency administration of medications in case the program must be closed temporarily. The plan includes a mechanism for informing consumers of these emergency arrangements.
CEO or designee:
Notifies external authorities and coordinates activities with them as needed.
Determines if off-duty staff is to be contacted.
Assigns staff to maintain grounds security as indicated.
Assigns staff to notify scheduled consumers of changes in appointments.
Assigns staff to establish communication by phone or messenger, if possible.
Determines how many staff is in the field doing treatment and assign staff to keep abreast of their location and circumstances.
Staff at the site:
Oversee that security of any clinical records, in whatever form, from fire/weather-related damage or theft is maintained, if possible.
Keep control center informed about activities.
Provide for the safety of all consumers, staff and visitors.
Account for all staff, visitors, and consumers.
Office Manager/designee will be the person in charge until community responders arrive (community responders will take charge when they arrive).
Office Manager/designee will assign duties to other staff.  Duties will include:
Calling 911
Making sure consumers, visitors and staff are all accounted for
Shutting off utilities if applicable and/or opening windows if you smell gas or hear a hissing sound
Checking for injuries and providing first aid if needed
Contacting the CEO
Moving staff, consumers, and visitors to a safe area (only move a seriously injured person if they are in immediate danger of death or further injury)
Staff out in the field should communicate their location and situation to the command center as soon as possible.
Off duty staff should remain home near their phone so they can be contacted for assistance as needed.
Evacuation of Consumers, Staff and Visitors
The CEO or designee and community emergency personnel will determine the extent of evacuation necessary and will notify each location with appropriate instructions.
In the event of an evacuation, supervisors for each area will move consumers, staff, and visitors in an orderly manner to a safe area. Evacuation routes are posted in
each area of the facility.
Staff will be responsible to account for each consumer when moved to a safe area, and staff from that area will provide continuing care for consumers needs to the extent possible.
Mitigation
Special procedures are defined as the following situations:
Fire/Explosion (See Life Safety (Fire) Plan).
Severe Weather.
Bomb Threat
Loss of Utilities (See Utilities Management Plan)
Earthquake
Flood - Flooding occurs when heavy rainfall resulting in water leaking into the
building around doors
Chemicals/Hazardous material spill
Pandemic (Flu) (See Infection Control Plan)
Preparedness
Evacuation routes are posted in each area of the facility.
Fire drills are performed monthly (4 times a year), once per quarter to adequately prepare staff, consumers, and visitors.
Emergency drills are performed at least once every twelve months (1 year from last event plus or minus 30 days) to adequately prepare staff, consumers, and visitors.
Response
In the event of a severe storm, staff should contact the Administrative Assistant to determine if    services should be continued.
In the event a Tornado Warning is issued:

Move all occupants into the center of an interior room (get beside a desk if in a room) or into a hallway. Use your hands and arms to protect your head and neck. If occupants are in a home with a basement, then all occupants should move into the basement.
Stay away from windows (do not open windows).
If major structural damage has occurred, consumers will be evacuated from the area if possible.
Establish additional security for the facility, if needed.
In the event of a bomb threat
Individual receiving Bomb Threat:
Remain calm. Prolong the conversation as long as possible and attempt to record every word spoken.
Note distinguishing background noises and voice characteristics such as age, sex, pitch, accent, speech impediments, etc.
Ask where and when the bomb will explode.
Inform caller that innocent people will be hurt if they are not moved.
Note if the caller indicates knowledge of the facility by how the location is described
Alert someone to notify the Administrative Assistant without alarming the caller or others in the facility, if able.
Staff
Notifies the Police and Fire Department – Dial 911.
Evacuates any current staff and/or consumers from the building.
Notifies Administrative Assistant.
In the event of an Earthquake
If evacuation is required, refer to Evacuation of Consumers section. DO NOT
evacuate without prior approval unless there is a life-threatening situation.
Advise co-workers, consumers, and visitors to do the same.
Move away from the windows that might shatter and from tall shelves and other objects that might topple.
Watch for falling objects such as light fixtures or pieces of ceiling.
The Administrative Assistant will instruct staff on need for evacuation of consumers
Take shelter, if possible.
Get under a strong table, counter, or desk if possible.
Sometimes these furnishings move. Be ready to move with them.
Do not stand in a doorway. Interior doorways are not safer than anywhere else.

If outside when the shaking begins, stay there. Get away from buildings and electrical power lines. Avoid over-hanging structures. Many injuries are caused 	by pieces of building falling on passersby.
Follow your Community’s Evacuation Plan.
In the event of Flooding:
Staff should determine if clinical records, in whatever form, are in danger of water damage and move them to higher surfaces if able.
Staff should contact the Administrative Assistant to inform them of the problem.
In the event of chemicals/hazardous gases:
Community Emergency Personnel will be posted along evacuation routes in each community.
Follow instructions of Community Emergency Personnel.
Recovery
The Administrative Assistant and Clinical Director would determine to what extent that staff is needed to resume services.
Utilities will be assessed by maintenance to assess functionality for use of the building.
All other services can be resumed, as they are ready.
Immediately after an earthquake:
Check for people who might be trapped. Leave doors open.
Check to see if power is on. Get flashlights if necessary.
Staff should calm consumers.
Check potential for chemical hazards or broken water lines.
Assess injuries and administer treatment or summon medical assistance.
Implement the Contingency and/or Disaster Recovery PHI/ePHI plans appropriate to situation.
The areas from which such records might need to be evacuated are:
Reception area and record storage area at site offices
Electronic media workstations

The first responsibility is for consumers and personnel safety.  If personnel are not in immediate danger and an area fire breaks out, tornado watch/warning is issued, earthquake, or bomb threat received the following procedure is to be followed.
The Office Manager will oversee the removal of records/electronic media. If this person is not available, a pre-assigned, trained designee will assume oversight.
In the case of a fire:
All available clinical staff (at site) will be responsible for removing any current records located in their area or in filing cabinet(s) and any electronic media used to store ePHI/IIHI.
The Office Manager or designee will be responsible for coordinating the removal of records/electronic media from their area/reception area/workstations.
If removal is not possible, the Office Manager or designee will see that doors and windows to these area(s) are closed and locked.
Non-Fire Disaster Requiring Evacuation
First responsibility is for consumers and personnel safety.
The clinical staff will be responsible for removal of records/electronic media in their areas to the nearest viable office.

The Office Manager or designee will be responsible for overseeing that records are boxed/file cabinets locked and removed to the nearest viable office and electronic media are safely removed to this area if this can be done without personal endangerment due to the nature of the disaster.
After all current hard copy records have been removed, all closed confidential records will be boxed and removed, if time allows.
If removal of any hard copy records or electronic media is not possible, the Office Manager, or designee, will check that all cabinets, doors and windows are closed and locked.

Once all records and electronic media that can be are removed, they will be stored at the nearest viable QBH office and locked unless other instructions are given by the Clinical Director or Administrative Assistant..
Emergency Mode Operation Plan/Disaster Recovery Plan

Because QBH’s medical record system is not dependent upon a specific location or workstation, consumers care can be resumed immediately from any setting because it is web based.  For Credible, see their Contingency Plan,
Emergency Operations Mode Plan and Disaster Recovery Plan included The QBH HIPAA Policies.
Billing information is saved to an off-site network and is retrievable from any location or workstation as well.

Administrative records are retrievable from the back-up drives as long as these have not been damaged or lost during a disaster or fire.  QBH’s goal, in progress, is to establish most of these as web-based documents as well.
The CEO or Administrative Assistant and community emergency personnel will determine the extent of evacuation necessary and will notify each location with appropriate instructions.
In the event of an evacuation, supervisors for each area will move consumers, staff, and visitors in an orderly manner to a safe area. Evacuation routes are posted in each area of the facility.
Staff will be responsible to account for each consumer when moved to a safe area, and staff from that area will provide continuing care for consumers needs to the extent possible.

The Emergency Preparedness Plan will be evaluated, reviewed, and revised annually by the Safety Officer and presented to the Clinical Committee (CC) for approval. Performance standards for this program are developed and reviewed annually.

At least once annually (1 year from last event plus or minus 30 days), the facility will evaluate the Emergency Preparedness Plan, either through actual implementation in an emergency event, or through a drill. In all instances, the Safety Officer will evaluate the implementation. Documentation in minutes of the CC will reflect problems identified, corrective action taken, and staff participation.
Performance standards have been developed to evaluate plan effectiveness.
100% of staff will be annually tested on their knowledge of Environment of Care which will cover the Emergency Preparedness Plan.
Knowledge of Environment of Care will be indicated with a minimum overall test average of 90%.

sections.title: QBH MAT Environmental Cleaning.policy  FINAL 8 13

blocks.text: Housekeeping services are contracted. Duties include cleaning, washing, maintaining linen inventory; maintaining the facilities in clean and sanitary condition;  following the health and safety, infection control, and security procedures and policies of this Agency.

The contract stipulates that housekeeping staff comply with the environmental cleaning policy and practices set forth here and any other regulatory or accreditation standards that may from time to time be issued.  Additionally, the housekeeping staff will comply with MIOSHA and CDC guidelines.

Compliance with these requirements and others of the contract shall be evaluated by the Safety Officer annually and reported to the Clinical Committee prior to renewal of the contract.  The Safety Officer will monitor their compliance ongoing during the conduct of Safety Surveillance Inspections.
Cleaned Monday through Friday following this procedure:
With a clean cloth, wash the basin and fixtures with germicidal disinfectant cleaner prepared from concentrate.
Wipe handrails, clean mirrors, and check and refill soap dispensers and all paper products as needed.
Sanitize, clean and wipe toilet bowls and urinals with germicidal disinfectant cleaner.  Use a descaler if hard water stains remain.
Remove trashcan liners from trashcans and clean inside of can with clean cloth and germicidal disinfectant cleaner, then replace with a new liner.
Dust air vents using high ceiling duster.
Spot clean walls and clean doors, door knobs, light switches with a germicidal disinfectant cleaner as needed.
Dust mop entire floor using a dustpan and brush to pick up debris; damp mop entire floor using a germicidal disinfectant and dust mopping.
At the end of the day wash cleaning cloths in a washing machine to which 1 cup of bleach and 1 cup of laundry detergent has been added.
Cleaned at least weekly and as needed with deep cleaning at least semi-annually, as follows:
Vacuum all carpets weekly and as needed.
Using a carpet-cleaning machine, spray and shampoo half of carpet area at a time until completed
Place wet floor signs in proper area during and after shampooing till carpet is dry.
Place floor fans on shampooed area to dry the carpets more quickly.
Additional cleaning is done as needed besides the semi-annual timeframes; spot clean as needed and always before shampooing carpets.
Done monthly as follows:
Fill solution tank on the carpet extractor with clean, hot water to proper water level and add one ounce per gallon of extraction cleaner.
Vacuum all carpets, starting at one side of the floor, placing wet floor signs in proper locations; switch to the other side when first side is done.
After extracting carpet section, place a fan in the area to allow it to dry quickly.
Tile flooring is vacuumed and mopped at least twice a week and as needed, using a tile-approved disinfectant cleaner.
To strip and wax tile flooring, as needed, do the following:
Select a time when there is less likely to be traffic in the area to be stripped and waxed; block off the area.
Remove furniture from the area to be stripped and waxed, then dust mop the flooring.
Lay down the stripping solution on half the flooring; wait five minutes for the stripper to work then scrub the floor with the very coarse stripper pad attached to the stripper machine.
Clean up stripping solution with clean water.
Repeat the stripping procedure and again rinse the floor with clean water.
Allow the floor to dry and then apply 3 to 4 coats of wax.
Allow wax to dry and replace all furniture.
Allow wax to cure at least two days then buff with the buffing pad on the buffer.
Dust mop the area then lay down 1 or 2 more coats of the same wax for a glossy shine.
After completion of tile cleaning do the following:
Rinse mop buckets thoroughly and dry.
Rinse and wring out mops thoroughly and place in a plastic bag, then store in designated area of the Housekeeping Closet till end of the day.
At the end of the day wash the mop heads in a washing machine to which 1 cup of bleach and 1 cup of laundry detergent has been added.
Cleaning cloths should be washed in the same fashion but separately from the mop heads.
These are to be cleaned daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Scrub hard water spots off faucets and fountains with stainless steel cleaner, descaling as needed.
With a clean cloth, clean with a germicidal disinfectant; rinse afterwards.
Dry faucet and fountain handles with a clean cloth.
Clean these areas daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Clean and restock bathrooms as directed in this policy.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Dust all counter areas with a germicidal disinfectant cleaner.
Dust all furniture with furniture polish once a week and as needed.
Vacuum all carpet areas and clean as needed following directives in this policy.
Clean doors with a clean cloth and germicidal disinfectant cleaner; clean door windows with a window cleaner.
Clean windows and window seals as needed in each office.
Clean copy machine glass with glass cleaner as needed.
Clean these areas daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Dust all furniture with furniture polish at least once a week and as needed.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Clean counters with germicidal disinfectant cleaner.
Disinfect the exam table using a disinfectant cleaner; staff should clean between each consumer as well.
Clean bathroom as directed in this policy.
Dust mop entire floor area, then mop with germicidal disinfectant cleaner; set wet floor signs out till floor is dry.
Clean these areas daily Monday through Friday as follows:
After meals dust mop the entire floor area.
Sweep entire kitchen, pantry, refrigerator/freezer area, bathroom and dining areas
Damp mop the dining areas and kitchen areas with germicidal disinfectant cleaner; set out wet floor signs till floor dries.
Clean bathrooms as directed in this policy.
Clean this area daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Clean bathroom as directed in this policy.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Dust counters and desktops with germicidal disinfectant, using a clean cloth for each.
Dust mop the entire floor then damp mop with a germicidal disinfectant; place wet floor signs till floor is dry.
Clean this area daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Clean bathrooms as directed in this policy.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Spot wash walls using a clean cloth and germicidal disinfectant cleaner; include door knobs, light switches, and areas around trashcans.
Check aerosol air freshener in bathrooms and replace as needed.
Clean window panels on entrance doors with window cleaner and doors themselves with germicidal disinfectant as needed.
Wipe down Receptionist counter with a clean cloth and germicidal disinfectant.
Dust furniture using furniture polish as needed.
Vacuum the lobby and reception areas and east and west hallways.
Clean drinking fountain as directed in this policy.
Clean these areas daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Empty shredders and replace liners.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Vacuum carpets.
Dust counters and desk tops, copy machines and other office equipment with germicidal disinfectant cleaner; use glass cleaner on copy machine glass.
Clean doors, door knobs, light switches, walls with germicidal disinfectant as needed.
Clean these areas daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Clean bathrooms as directed in this policy.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Dust counters with germicidal disinfectant using a clean cloth.
Dust furniture with furniture polish at least once a week and as needed.
Dust venetian blinds, window sills, and windows as needed with window cleaner.
Vacuum all carpeted areas.
Dry mop and, as needed, wet mop all tile flooring; strip and wax as needed.
Clean all sinks, faucets, fountains as directed in this policy.
Spot clean walls and clean doors, door knobs, light switches with a germicidal disinfectant as needed.
Clean these areas daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Bathrooms
Clean bathrooms as directed in this policy.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Clean showers as follows:
Clean and sanitize entire shower stall using a clean cloth and germicidal disinfectant cleaner, starting at the top and rinsing the cloth frequently.
Staff is to clean and sanitize showers between each consumer’s showers as well.
Refill soap dispensers with enriched shampoo for hair and body use.
Wipe shower curtain with a clean cloth and germicidal disinfectant cleaner.  Once a month machine wash the shower curtain with laundry detergent and 1 cup of bleach.
Dust the TV, TV cabinets, and DVD tops.  Clean the TV screen with window cleaner.
Polish all furniture and wooden surfaces with furniture polish.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Clean drinking fountain as directed in this policy.
Dust vents and ceiling fans.
Vacuum floor; wet mop tile areas as needed.
Spot clean walls and clean doors, door knobs, light switches with a germicidal disinfectant cleaner as needed.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in policy.
Dust all furniture and polish as needed.
Vacuum all carpets in offices and hallways.
Spot clean walls and clean doors, door knobs, light switches with a germicidal disinfectant cleaner as needed.
Dust mop floor and damp mop with germicidal disinfectant cleaner where tile flooring exists.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Spot clean any small areas and vacuum carpeting.
Replace paper towels in dispenser as needed.
Wipe down wooden areas/furniture with furniture polish.
Clean window sills and windows as needed with window cleaner.
Spot clean walls and clean doors, door knobs, light switches with a germicidal disinfectant cleaner as needed.
Dust vents.
Nurses’ Station (Areas of medication storage must be cleaned during scheduled times when a nurse is present to observe staff doing the cleaning.)
Clean bathroom as directed in this policy.
Wipe all counters with a clean cloth using germicidal disinfectant.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.
Clean stainless steel sinks with crème stainless steel cleaner; rinse and dry.
Soak sinks with bleach and water solution every two weeks.
Refill soap dispenser in Medication Room and bathroom with antimicrobial soap as needed.
Refill paper towel dispenser as needed.
Spot clean walls and clean doors, door knobs, light switches with a germicidal disinfectant cleaner as needed.
Dust vents.
Clean refrigerators monthly and as needed; the medication refrigerator will be cleaned by nursing staff.
Cleaning is as follows:
Remove and dispose of all outdated, uncovered, improperly stored foods and beverages; the medication refrigerator should contain no food or beverages.
Wipe down the inside (including inside drawers) and outside of the refrigerator with a germicidal disinfectant using a clean cloth.
Document the refrigerator and freezer temperatures daily on the Temperature Log; notify the Administrator immediately if the refrigerator is outside the range of 37 - 44 degrees.
Freezers should be defrosted at least quarterly and as needed.
Clean freezers as follows:
Wipe out any spills with a clean cloth and germicidal disinfectant as needed; when defrosting, clean the whole area with a clean cloth and germicidal disinfectant cleaner.
Dispose of any outdated, uncovered, improperly stored foods.

When defrosting, remove all contents of the freezer and store in an ice chest while cleaning and defrosting.  Replace once completed.  Wipe out ice chest with germicidal disinfectant prior to and after use.
Record freezer temperature daily on the Temperature Log; notify the Administrator immediately if the freezer is above 0 degrees.
Clean the laundry room daily Monday through Friday as follows:
Wipe inside and outside of all washing machines and all other surfaces with germicidal disinfectant cleaner daily.
Check the lint trap daily and clean as needed.
Staff is to clean the table with germicidal disinfectant after every use.
Dust and wet mop flooring daily.
Spot clean walls and clean doors, door knobs, light switches with a germicidal disinfectant cleaner as needed.
Dust vents.
Remove trashcan liners as directed in this policy.

Staff and housekeepers should check the soiled laundry hamper daily for fullness of the bag.  When the bag is full, it is to be tied and removed from the hamper and replaced with a new bag.  Place the full bag in the designated storage area.
No linen is to be placed on top of the washer or dryer at any time.
No consumer or Agency laundry is to be placed on the floor at any time.
Housekeeping will soak items in a 1:10 bleach solution, when applicable, wipe dry and store in designated locations.
Items that cannot be soaked will be wiped down with a clean cloth, using a germicidal disinfectant cleaner, then stored in designated locations.
Using a shovel/snow blower clear all areas of the sidewalk and drive ways that are used by consumers, visitors or staff.
Lay out salt purposed for snow and ice melt to reduce risk of slipping or falling after clearing sidewalks and drive ways.

Using Environmental Protection Agency guidelines and this policy, the Safety Officer/Infection Control Coordinator will, in collaboration with housekeeping and other applicable staff, inspect and document the following using the IC Inspection Surveillance Form:
All Agency cleaning agents
All cleaning schedules
All areas where cleaning is to occur
All cleaning processes for each area.
Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) Manuals are kept at each location where cleaning agents or other toxic items are stored.  The Safety Officer is responsible to keep these manuals current.
Adequacy of cleaning practices will be monitored during the Safety Officer’s surveillance inspections.
The Safety Officer is to oversee implementation of any corrective actions, establish timeframes for correction, and report results to the Clinical Committee at scheduled times.
Anytime an addition or change in cleaning agents and/or other toxic items is desired, it must first be approved by the Safety Officer and an MSDS Sheet must be added to the MSDS Manual.

The Safety Officer will review this policy annually and make modifications as needed based upon changes in regulations, changes necessary due to nature of services, etc.   Any revisions will be submitted to the Clinical Committee as scheduled.

sections.title: QBH MAT EQUIPMENT MANAGEMENT PLAN.   FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Equipment and furnishings purchase orders or requests are submitted to the CEO. The CEO will confer with the Safety Officer and Infection Control Coordinator for product evaluation before authorizing purchase.  The CEO shall maintain a binder of these product evaluations for at least three years beyond the purchase date.
Equipment used for consumer care, consumer and staff safety, or is of major cost will be identified on the Equipment Maintenance Log.  Examples of equipment to include are:
Blood pressure cuffs
Copiers
Computers
Fire extinguishers
Phones
Desks and chairs

Medical Equipment:  (e.g., otoscope, centrifuge, electronic thermometers, glucometer) purchases will, when possible, include a service contract.  This contract will provide repair or replacement in the event that the equipment malfunctions.
Equipment will be inspected and receive preventive maintenance as scheduled.
The CEO or designee will record such inspection and maintenance on the Equipment Maintenance Log form and inform the Safety Officer if inspections or maintenance are not occurring as scheduled.
Equipment will be tagged and inspected before it is put into use.
No personal electrical equipment will be allowed unless inspected and approved by the Safety Officer or designee.
All items will be U.L. listed, and –equipped with a three prong grounding type plug or be double insulated, and comply with the NFPA Regulations.

Permission from the Safety Officer must be obtained before the personal electrical appliances may be used in areas not intended for normal consumer activity (lounges, offices, etc.) in accordance with the NFPA Regulations.
Tagging of equipment is done when equipment is received at QBH. Items requiring assembly will be tagged upon completion.
The Safety Officer or designee will tag and inspect all equipment.  Records are kept on the Equipment Tagging and Inspection Log and filed in the Finance Department with a copy in the EOC Manual.

Individuals purchasing and receiving equipment through their departments are to contact the Safety Officer to inspect and tag items before they are put into use. Attached labels will have the date of inspection.
All equipment will be inspected no less than once yearly and inspection dates on labels attached accordingly.
Organization staff that brings in any type of electric appliance should contact the Safety Officer to inspect and tag items brought in before being put into use.
A maintenance Request should be filled out by the staff member and sent to the Finance Department.
Problems or malfunctions will be responded to as soon as possible within 24 hours.  The CEO will make arrangements if outside vendor/contractor assistance is required.
The Safety Officer will prioritize maintenance requests in the order of importance.
All staff is trained to monitor for appliance condition anytime they put it to use.  Particular attention should be given to identification and prompt reporting of:
Frayed or worn electric cords.
Electrical shorts.
Weak connection to outlets.
Unusual sounds or performance during operation.
Equipment condition will also be monitored by the Safety Officer or designee:
During scheduled safety surveillance.
During scheduled maintenance activities.
Anytime a staff member submits a maintenance request.
Extension cords and multiple outlet strips shall be considered part of the distribution systems and will be inspected annually (once a year every twelve months plus or minus 30 days).
Housekeeping equipment and appliances will be inspected annually (once yearly every twelve months plus or minus thirty days).
Dietary equipment will be inspected weekly.
All therapeutic and diagnostic equipment will be inspected on an annual basis.
Electrical Cords
If electrical equipment is not working properly make sure plug is unplugged, tag item OUT OF SERVICE (See Lock-out/Tag-out Policy), and report problem to Supervisor.
Electrical Fixtures
Lights, fans, not working correctly turn switch off, tag OUT OF SERVICE.  Report problems to the Supervisor.
Supervisor will assess problem and contact Safety Officer.
All Other Electrical Problems

Supervisor should be informed immediately.  Supervisor will turn off and tag switch if necessary, switch circuit breaker to off position and tag or cut-off all power and lock and tag until maintenance arrives or Administration is notified and electrical contractor arrives to repair.  After repair the Supervisor may remove lock and tag.
Water System
With any problem with water, valves should be turned off and tagged.  Supervisor will be notified.
Safety Officer will be called.
Safety Officer or designee will make sure valves are turned off and tagged, faucets are bled and tagged, water heaters are turned off, bled and tagged.
Maintenance will do repairs or contractor will be called to do repair.

Signs are to be posted where there are appliances warning of their danger.  If there is a problem the plug is to be pulled and the problem reported to the Supervisor in writing.  Item should be tagged OUT OF ORDER.
A staff member, upon observing machinery or a piece of equipment which is locked-out to perform servicing or maintenance, shall not attempt to start, energize, or use that machinery or equipment.
When the servicing or maintenance is completed and the machinery or equipment is ready, the Safety Officer will notify affected staff that the machinery or equipment is ready for use.
The Safety Officer or designee will remove the lockout devices and re-energize the machinery or equipment.
The Safety Officer will record repairs and replacement of equipment on the Equipment Maintenance Log.
Furnishings
Furniture in need or repair or cleaning will be reported via a “maintenance request form” to the Safety Officer.

Safety Officer will inform submitter of completion within two weeks.  If request is unable to be addressed within the two-week time frame, Safety Officer will inform submitter of anticipated time frame for correction.
If necessary, the Safety Officer will contact an outside vendor and three bids will be obtained for needed services.
Bids will receive final approval from the Leadership Committee.
Safety Officer will contact vendor to make appropriate repairs.
Staff will supervise any moving of large furniture items by consumers.
Staff is to observe for use of proper body mechanics in lifting or moving of furniture to prevent and/or reduce back or strain injuries.
Major furniture moves should have approval of CEO who will consider the need for additional assistance to provide adequate safety measures.
Staff should check furniture for repair needs monthly.
Education on the use of equipment will be provided if needed and be documented in the staff member’s personnel file.
The log is to be kept by the Safety Officer.

The log will be reviewed annually by the Safety Officer for trends or patterns that may indicate areas for improvement or problem solving.  The results of this review will be reported to the Clinical Committee.

The Safety Officer will complete a plan evaluation annually. The evaluation will include appropriateness of the defined scope, whether objectives were achieved, performance data, the effectiveness of the plan in reducing/preventing risks and events, and any changes in regulatory and accreditation requirements.
The Safety Officer will review and revise the plan annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) and submit for approval the Clinical Committee (CC).
The CC will review, approve, and submit the Equipment Management Plan to the Board of Directors annually for approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT ETHICAL GOVERNANCE PRACTICES.policy  FINAL  7 17

blocks.text: The Board of Directors shall be bound to the ethical practices as set forth in the Code of Ethics of QBH and by those ethical guidelines specific to being a Board member as committed by their annual signature on the Board Code of Ethics Form and completion of the Conflict-of-Interest Form.
Board members set the bar for ethical standards in the performance of their duties.  They shall:
Remain actively involved and informed in Company decisions, practices and performance results.
Hold the CEO, other leadership and staff accountable to ethical practices in their job performance and oversee that appropriate disciplinary action is taken if ethical breaches occur.
Remove immediately any Board member who is verified to have violated QBH’s and/or the Board’s code of ethics.
Comply with legal, regulatory and accreditation requirements in the performance of their duties as Board members and hold QBH’s personnel to the same requirements as relates to their roles in QBH.
Maintain confidentiality with respect to all Company, staff or consumer information shared at Board meetings, special meetings or by other means of access.
Maintain bylaws governing responsibilities and activities as a Board.
Remember that they represent QBH in their external and internal interactions and behave accordingly.
Hold other Board members, leadership and staff of QBH accountable to ethical practices.
Abide by all elements of the Board Code of Ethics.
The plan is reviewed by the CEO at least annually and submitted to the Board for reviewed and approved.

sections.title: QBH MAT EXPOSURE CONTROL.policy   FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: It is the expectation of Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. (QBH) that all staff shall practice in compliance with infection control standards and regulations and with Organization policies. Treatment and/or emergencies involving blood or other potentially infectious materials including urine, feces, semen, vaginal secretions and all body fluids in situations where it is difficult or impossible to differentiate between body fluids will be managed utilizing strict body substance precautions (universal precautions). According to the concept of universal precautions, these fluids are treated as if known to be infectious for HIV, HBV, Coronavirus, and other blood borne pathogens.

One of the important goals of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) is to promote safe work precautions in an effort to minimize the incidence of the illness and injury experienced by the staff.   In accordance with the OSHA blood borne pathogens standard, the following exposure control policy has been developed.
Work practice controls: means controls that reduce the likelihood of exposure by altering the manner in which a task in performed.

Bloodborne pathogens: pathogenic microorganisms that are present in human blood and cause disease in humans.  They include but are not limited to, Hepatitis B virus, (HBV), and Human Immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

Exposure control:  A system to control or minimize the spread of bloodborne pathogens using universal precautions as well as personal protective equipment. Exposure control has checks and balances and cooperation of all departments.
Standard Precautions/Universal precautions: an approach to infection control designed to prevent transmission of blood-borne diseases such as AIDS, hepatitis B in health care settings.

Personal protective equipment: Equipment used to assist in containment of infectious disease as well as protect the staff from infection. The guidelines for universal precautions include specific recommendations for the use of gloves, masks, and protective eyewear when contact with blood or body secretions containing blood is anticipated.

The following are suggested general principles that should be followed when working with bloodborne pathogens. The risk of exposure to bloodborne pathogens should never be underestimated and universal precautions should be followed when working with bloodborne pathogens.
It is necessary to minimize all exposure to bloodborne pathogens.

QBH will institute universal precautions using personal protective equipment as well as engineering and work practice controls when possible to eliminate or minimize staff exposure to bloodborne pathogens.
An Exposure Control Plan has been implanted to meet the intent of the OSHA Bloodborne Pathogen Standards.  The object of this plan is two-fold:
To protect staff from health hazards associated with bloodborne pathogens.
To provide appropriate treatment and counseling should an staff be exposed to bloodborne pathogens.

subpolicies.title: Category I – Tasks That Involve Exposure To Blood, Body Fluid Or Tissues

blocks.text: All procedures or other job-related tasks that involve an inherent potential of mucous membrane or skin contact with blood, body fluids, or tissues, or a potential for spills or splashes of them, are category I tasks. Tasks include:
Performing or assisting with medical procedures
Administering parental medications
Handling of contaminated instruments/equipment
Cleaning up of blood spills or other infectious diseases
Dressing of wounds
Prepping of lacerations
Handling of soiled contaminated laundry
Repair of contaminated equipment (toilets)
Category I staff are defined as:
Physicians, Physician Assistants, Nurse Practitioners, R.N.s, L.P.N.s, techs
Podiatrists, Dentists, Dental assistants/techs, Psychiatrists
All staff doing or assisting with procedures, tests, cleaning of consumer areas.
QBH Job classifications in which staff have occupational exposure:
Nurses
Behavioral Health Technicians
Physicians/Psychiatrists
Housekeeping
Category II – All Health Care Organization Staff Who Interact With Consumers Or Perform Receptionist Duties
All health care Organization staff that interact and have limited physical contact with consumers belong to Category II and Category II tasks. Tasks include but are not limited to:
Receiving closed specimens
Responding to emergency situations
Assisting consumers into examination rooms
Category II staff are defined as:
Receptionists, Secretaries, Administrative assistants, pharmacists, pharmacist techs, consumer service specialists, consumer representatives.
Job classifications in which staff of QBH have moderate potential for occupational exposure:
Social Workers/Therapists
Drivers
Maintenance Personnel

All other staff that works in a organization or department that does not provide medical services to consumers. Individuals who work in a organization or department which provides medical services to a consumer but who have no face to face or direct contact with consumers.
Category III staff are defined as:
Medical records techs
Consumer care coordinators
Central supply techs
Job classifications in which QBH staff have limited potential for occupational exposure:
Administrators
Clerical Support
List tasks and procedures in which occupational exposure occurs and that are performed by staff in job classifications listed:
Job Classification	Task/Procedure
Nurse/Psychiatrist /Physician                           Administering injections
Nurse/Behavioral Health Technician/          	   Cleaning spills of potentially infectious secretions
Housekeeping                                                      Secretions / handling laundry
A method to minimize exposure to bloodborne pathogens (refer to methods of compliance policy).
Universal precautions shall be utilized to prevent contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials. All blood and other potentially infectious materials will be considered infectious.

The practice of Universal Precautions was instituted to minimize contact with blood and other body fluids. As a result, all human blood, and body fluids are treated as if they are infected with HBV, HIV, and other bloodborne pathogens.
Personal protective equipment as part of Universal precautions will be utilized to prevent contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials.

Personal protective equipment (PPE) is the staff’s “last line of defense” against bloodborne pathogens.  This is because, the organization provides (at no cost to the staff), personal protective equipment needed to protect the staff from such exposure.
Single use PPE is the only equipment QBH uses and past each use the PPE will be disposed in the correct manner.
Personal Protective Equipment includes but is not limited to the following:
Gowns
Gloves
Aprons
Goggles
Face shields/masks
Disposal Mouthpieces to be used in CPR
Booties – shoe covers
Hair covering
Resuscitation bags

The Infection Control Coordinator, working with Administration and other designees, is 			 responsible for overseeing that all departments have the proper personal protective equipment 			 available to them. The ICC is also responsible for the initial, annual and as needed training 			 regarding Personal Protective Equipment.
The ICC along with department managers are responsible to see that all PPE is inspected 			 periodically and replaced as needed to maintain its effectiveness.
The following practices will be implemented when using Personal Protective Equipment.
Staff will use appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE), i.e. gloves, tissues, etc. at all times.  PPE
will be readily accessible in the Medication Room, in a visible location on each unit, in each vehicle that 	transports consumers, and will be replaced as needed to maintain its effectiveness.

Gloves will be worn when it can be reasonably anticipated that the staff may have contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials, (i.e. feces, vomit, urine, etc.), and when handling or touching contaminated items or surfaces. Gloves will not be washed or re-used.  Gloves must be used for the following procedures:
Injections and other invasive procedures
All housekeeping tasks
Cleaning wet spills of potentially infectious fluids
Handling contaminated laundry
Gloves will be worn in the following situations:

When handling or touching contaminated items or surfaces, or when a staff anticipates hand contact with potentially infectious materials. Disposal gloves will be replaced when torn, punctured or when the gloves otherwise lose their ability to function as an “exposure barrier”.
Hypoallergenic gloves will be provided to staff that are allergic to Latex or are allergic to the gloves that Pronghorn Psychiatry provides.
Masks, face shields, goggles, etc will be used whenever splashes or sprays from blood borne materials may occur.
Shoe covers and hair covering, will be worn whenever a “gross contamination” is anticipated or noted.
Protective clothing will be worn whenever a potential exposure to the body is anticipated.
Goggles and/or gown will be used any time a splash or spurt of infectious fluid is anticipated during a procedure or activity.
CPR shields shall be used any time mouth-to-mouth contact is necessary for an emergency procedure.
Sanitizer gel shall always be used before and after any invasive procedure, including injections.
Any garments (such as uniforms, personal clothing, etc) penetrated by blood or other infectious materials will be removed immediately, or at least as soon as possible.
Work practice controls will be used to eliminate or minimize staff exposure. Where exposure remains after institution of these controls, personal protective equipment will also be used.
Work Practice Controls will be adopted by QBH as part of on-going Compliance Program.
Hand washing before and after using PPE. Hand washing facilities are readily accessible to staff. Hand washing sinks are located in all bathrooms, kitchen, medication rooms, and in the staff room.

Soap and water will be used immediately following any contact of body areas with blood or any other infectious materials and immediately after removing gloves. Mucous membranes will be flushed with water.

Contaminated reusable sharps are placed in appropriate sharps containers immediately after use and Contaminated needles and other contaminated sharps are not reused, recapped, bent or needles removed. Containers are puncture resistant, labeled and color-coded, leak proof on the sides and bottom and closable. Contaminated sharps containers are easily accessible and located close to the immediate area where sharps are used.  Containers are located in med carts, ICC area and any other area that is needed.
Consumer or staff food or meals are not to be kept in refrigerators, freezers or countertops or other storage areas where consumer blood or other potentially infectious materials could be stored.

Eating, drinking, smoking, or applying of cosmetics and/or handling of contact lenses are prohibited in the work areas where there is reasonable likelihood of occupational exposure to blood borne pathogens or other potentially infectious materials.
Specimens such as blood, urine, etc, are placed in designated leak proof containers, labeled properly for handling, storage and transport.

In some cases, blood borne pathogen infectious materials will have to be doubled bagged or double containers used. If an outside puncture of the container of a specimen occurs, the container is then placed within another leak proof container for further handling and storage. The second container must also be leak proof and puncture-resistant.

Labels and signs will be used too prevent exposure to blood borne pathogens. For staff the most obvious warning of possible exposure to blood borne pathogens are biohazard labels. Pronghorn Psychiatry has instituted a     comprehensive biohazard warning-label program. Items in the organization that are labeled will include but not be limited to the following:
Containers of regulated waste
Sharps disposal containers
The use of red color-coded containers will be utilized for biohazard waste.

Establishment of appropriate Engineering Controls to eliminate or minimize staff exposure. Engineering Controls is one of the key aspects of the QBH Exposure Control Plan. When necessary, personal protective equipment deemed appropriate will also be used.

QBH uses appropriate engineering controls to minimize staff contact with blood borne pathogens and other infectious materials. Annually QBH reviews the status of areas where Engineering Controls are currently employed, such as hand washing facilities, sanitizer gel, gloves, CPR shields, PPE, sharps containers which are puncture resistant, leak-proof and labeled with biohazard warning labels, personal protective equipment and specimen containers to name a few.

Part of the Exposure Control Plan is to maintain a clean and sanitary organization. To facilitate this housekeeping/laundry will have a schedule for routine periodic cleaning and a schedule for decontamination of infected areas.
As part of the decontamination schedule all equipment and services are cleaned and decontaminated after contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials.

This would include but not be limited to after any spill or blood or infectious materials, immediately when surfaces are contaminated, after completion of medical procedures, at the end of a work shift, after any damaged or broken
equipment (broken glass, etc.).
Hepatitis B Vaccinations and Post-Exposure Evaluation and Follow-Up:

The Organization will make available the hepatitis B vaccine, within 10 working days of assignment, to all staff that has occupational exposure, and post-exposure evaluation and follow-up to all staff who have had an exposure incident at no cost to the staff. (Refer to Hepatitis B Vaccination policy and procedure.)
The employer will establish and maintain an accurate record for each staff with occupational exposure. This record will include:
The name and the social security number of the staff.
A copy of the staff’s hepatitis B vaccination status including the dates of all the Hepatitis B vaccinations, and any medical records relative to the staff’s ability to receive vaccination.
A copy of all results of examinations, medical testing, and follow-up procedures.
The employer’s copy of the healthcare professional’s written opinion.
A copy of the information provided to the healthcare professional.
The employer shall oversee that staff medical records are:
Kept confidential.
Not disclosed or reported without the staff’s express written consent to any person within or outside the workplace except as required by this section or as may be required by law.
The employer shall maintain the records for at least the duration of employment plus 30 years in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.20.
Training records shall include the following information:
The dates of the training sessions;
The contents or a summary of the training sessions;
The names and qualifications of persons conducting the training; and
The names and job titles of all persons attending the training sessions.
Training records shall be maintained for 3 years from the date on which the training occurred.
Training for staff will include the following:
The OSHA standard for Blood borne Pathogens.
Epidemiology and symptomatology of blood borne diseases.
Modes of transmission of blood borne pathogens.
This Exposure Control Policy, i.e. points of the plan, lines of responsibility, how the plan will be implemented, etc.
Procedures that might cause exposure to blood or other potentially infectious materials at this organization.
Control methods which will be used to control exposure to blood or other potentially infectious materials.
Personal protective equipment available and who should be contacted concerning:
Post Exposure evaluation and follow-up.
Signs and labels used at the organization.
Hepatitis B vaccine program.
All staff will receive annual refresher training.
Training materials are located in the nurse’s office.
The Infection Control Practitioner will maintain all records required by the OSHA standard.

This policy will be reviewed annually (once yearly every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) by the Infection Control Coordinator and revised as needed and submitted to the Medical Executive Committee for approved.

sections.title: QBH MAT External Audits of Patient Records.policy  FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: Notification is received by QBH that an audit has been scheduled or a need identified that requires production of consumer records for an off/on site audit.

The CEO or Medical Director verifies that the external stakeholder requesting the audit has signed a Business Associate Confidentiality Agreement that mandates compliance with consumer PHI confidentiality.
The Medical Records staff that receives the audit notification or records request will forward the notice/request to the Medical Director and CEO.
Upon receipt of the notice/request, the Medical Director and CEO will notify all departments who will be involved in the audit.
If necessary, the Medical Director and CEO will call a departmental or multi-departmental meeting to discuss the notice/request, coordinate, and assign tasks and dates of completion.
The Medical Director and CEO will follow up with assigned staff regularly and report progress at the Clinical Committee meetings, if time allows.
Upon completion of the audit, the Medical Director and CEO will coordinate the exit meeting to arrange for all applicable departments to have a representative at the exit meeting.
Upon receipt of the information in the exit meeting, the Medical Director and CEO will notify all departments who need to be involved in the development of any required corrective action plan.
If necessary, the Medical Director and CEO will call a departmental or multi-departmental meeting to discuss the corrective action plan, coordinate, and assign tasks and dates of completion.
The Medical Records staff will remain present or available in the event the auditor/surveyor has questions or needs assistance.

When the CEO has confirmed the authenticity of the auditing organization and obtained a Business Associate Confidentiality Agreement (though this may be requested, it not required for JC as this agreement is already established via the survey agreement), s/he will await request for medical records from the auditing body’s lead auditor/ surveyor.
Once the type and number of records has been requested, the CEO and/or Medical Director will collaborate with the Medical Records staff to select the records to be pulled for audit.

The Medical Records staff will pull the requested active and/or closed medical records, label each with the requirements that particular medical record meets, and provide them to the auditor/ surveyor requesting the medical records.
The Medical Records staff will remain present or available in the event the auditor/surveyor has questions or needs assistance.
The CEO will review this policy annually and as needed, and submit it to the Clinical Committee for review and approve.
Business Associate Confidentiality Agreement

QBH MAT Filing PHI Complaints.policy  FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: Every individual has the right to file a complaint with QBH or the Secretary of DHHS concerning:
QBH’s PHI/ePHI policies and procedures;
QBH’s and/or a business associate’s compliance with its PHI policies and procedures; or
QBH’s compliance with federal privacy requirements.
Complaints must be submitted to the Privacy Officer (if PHI)/Security Officer (if ePHI), who is designated by law to receive complaints and answer additional questions.
The complaint must be submitted in writing.

The Privacy/Security Officer will review and investigate each complaint to determine if the complaint is valid and to identify an appropriate method for resolving the complaint. Investigation may involve interviews with the complainant, involved staff, policies review, observation or other methods appropriate to the nature of the complaint.
In resolving the complaint, the Privacy/Security Officer will consider the individual’s proposed resolution for the complaint.
If at all possible to complaint shall be investigated and resolved with a written response to the complainant within 60 days of receipt.
QBH will inform the individual in writing of the resolution of the complaint by the Privacy or Security Officer.
QBH will document all complaints and the disposition of all complaints.
QBH will retain all documentation related to complaints for six (6) years from the date the documentation was created.

subpolicies.title: SUBMISSION OF COMPLAINTS TO THE SECRETARY OF DHHS

blocks.text: If an individual desires to file a complaint with the Secretary of DHHS, the individual must submit the complaint in writing to the following address:
At the HHS.gov website
By mail to Secretary of U.S. DHHS, Office for Civil Rights, 200 Independence Ave. SW, Washington DC, 20201
One may go to the website for more information about how to file a complaint             www.hhs.gov/ocr/privacyhowtofile.html
The individual must name QBH as the subject of the complaint and describe his/her complaint against QBH.

QBH will investigate all complaints and any other documentation containing credible information or evidence that QBH’s workforce or business associates violated QBH’s PHI/ePHI policies and procedures or the federal privacy requirements. QBH will appropriately resolve all such complaints and act on such information, as appropriate.
QBH will not threaten, intimidate, discriminate, or retaliate against an individual who exercises his/her rights to complain to QBH or to the Secretary of DHHS.

This Policy will be reviewed by the Privacy/Security Officer annually and revisions made when necessary.  The Policy will be forwarded to the Clinical Committee for review and approval when revisions are made and at a minimum of annually.

sections.title: QBH MAT FINANCIAL PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT.policy  FINAL  7 17

blocks.text: Support and meet established outcomes for consumers by providing adequate staff, resources, and facilities for efficient, cost-effective, quality-focused services.
Provide resources to achieve QBH’s performance objectives.
Implement a financial system that avoids waste, is flexible to adapt to both predictable and unexpected needs and is as fraud-preventive as possible.
Maintain QBH as a viable service delivery organization.
The CEO, clinical and administrative staff collaborates to develop statements of expected revenues and expenses for each program component, and also capital expenditures, each fiscal year.
Revenues are categorized by source
Expenses are categorized for each program, cost center and reporting unit.
Documentation of methods employed to arrive at estimated costs are kept by the CEO. Some of those methods include:
An annual historical budget comparison and analysis
Input from various stakeholders, when applicable
Consideration of necessary cash flow
Consideration of external environment information
Projections of revenues
Projections of expenditures.
Assumptions used to formulate the budget include:
Historical data, including relevant trends and patterns in over and/or under expenditures
Increases of more than 5% in expenses can occur without corresponding increase in revenue
A 3% salary adjustment is calculated to continue being competitive in the job market
The need for improvements, expansion, remodeling, new programming, etc. that require capital budget planning.
Calendar of budget preparation is:

March – request administrative and clinical leadership, with input from their staffs, to submit written requests for program modification that will change financial revenue or expenditures, including any capital purchases.  The Clinical Committee formulates overall Company capital expenditures anticipated
July – CEO estimates year-end total expenditures for each expense line item
August – Accountant prepares the revenue portion of the budget based upon negotiated contracts
September – CEO finalizes operating and capital budgets
September – CEO submits both budgets to the Board of Directors for approval.
Annual written operating and capital assets budget statements are submitted to the Board for review and approval at a meeting before the beginning of the fiscal year to which they will be applied.
Any revisions in the operating or capital budgets that occur during the fiscal year must first be approved by the Board of Directors and documented in their minutes.
Once approved, the budgets are shared with clinical and administrative leadership, and any stakeholders that require the budget to sustain their alliance with QBH.
Each month an updated budgetary performance report is prepared by the Accountant showing actual revenues and expenditures and any variances form the approved budget.
Distribution is to the Board, CEO and Clinical Committee.
Significant variances are investigated and reasons noted in the report.
Each quarter the Accountant submits to the Board, CEO and Clinical Committee a consolidated balance sheet showing total assets and liabilities of QBH.
The Clinical Committee does a quarterly review of internal data including:
Financial trends of QBH relative to the approved budget
Financial challenges that the data my reflect
Financial opportunities that have been recognized since the last review and how QBH can tap those opportunities
Management information, particularly relative to staffing problems that impact budget and any other unexpected situations, occupancy rates, caseload size, billable to non-billable hour ratios, etc.
The Clinical Committee also looks externally at factors that might impact the budget such as:
Financial trends locally, regionally and nationally that might affect the budget
Financial challenges in these same arenas, any unexpected changes in contacts with stakeholders, changes in laws that impact payments negatively, etc.
Percentage of private pay versus public funds such as Medicare/Medicaid
Financial opportunities such as new service possibilities, expanded contract options, changes in laws that impact payments positively, etc.
Industry trends both regionally and nationally
Changes in programming best practices
If there is the potential for financial crisis or solvency issues, the Clinical Committee, possibly in collaboration with the Board, develops remediation plans.
If any reports are required by stakeholders per contract agreement, the reports are distributed to the appropriate contact of those entities.
QBH maintains fiscal policies that guide fiscal operations and establish internal control practices. [See policies within the Leadership section of QBH Policy Manual.]
Training on these policies is provided by their supervisor to pertinent staff as a part of their initial orientation to their job and at least annually.
Fiscal policies are reviewed at least every three years and as needed by the Clinical Committee
When a donation of cash is made to QBH, the money will be sent to the Accountant for recording into the cash receipts ledger.
A donation acknowledgement letter that includes the person’s name, address, the date and amount of the donation will be included as well as an expression of thanks for the donor’s generosity.
The CEO will sign and mail the donor letter
The original letter is sent to the donor and a copy is filed in the “Donations” file.
An in-kind contribution is handled similarly to a cash donation.
The staff receiving the donation will forward an itemized list that includes the donor’s signature, estimated financial worth of the donation, and date
Items such as furniture or clothing are assessed value as a “garage sale” item.

A donation acknowledgement letter that includes the person’s name, address, the date and a copy of the signed list of the donated item(s) will be included as well as an expression of thanks for the donor’s generosity.
The CEO will sign and mail the donor letter
The original letter is sent to the donor and a copy with the original signed donation list is filed in the “Donations” file.

Determination of Validity:  All transactions shall be reviewed by the Accountant and a determination made to their validity (i.e. appropriate approval has been obtained and/or comparisons have been made to the original documentation).
Check for Accuracy:  Documents supporting transactions shall be checked for mathematical accuracy.  The individual performing the check shall initial or sign documents.

Record in Appropriate Journals:  As transactions are completed (and/or matched with other supporting documentation), they should be entered into appropriate journals for accuracy.  The individual performing the check shall initial or sign documents.
Safeguarding of All Accounting Records:  All assets and the accounting records shall be properly safeguarded to prevent theft.

Bank balances, as shown by the bank statements are to be reconciled on a monthly basis with data from all cash receipts and disbursements journals.  Items that cannot be reconciled shall be listed for investigation by the Accountant.  The person who prepares the reconciliation shall receive the unopened bank statements directly from the bank and retain them until the reconciliations are complete.

Discrepancies between general ledger cash balances and closing balances reported on bank statements usually result from transactions recorded in cash journals but not processed and recorded by banks (such as deposits in transit and outstanding checks) and items on bank statements not yet processed and recorded by QBH (such as bank service charges, interest, or returned checks).  Most of those items do not require investigation.
Generally, personnel who do not have access to cash and are not involved in processing and recording cash transactions shall investigate all significant:
Unreconciled items in cash receipts and disbursements journals that fail to clear bank within a reasonable period of time
Unreconciled items on bank statements unanticipated or judged erroneous by QBH
Unreconciled items in cash receipts and disbursements journals and bank statement items.
Bank reconciliation and proposed adjustments to general ledger cash balances and cash detail files shall be reviewed and approved by the Accountant.
A representative sampling of consumer records is reviewed in conjunction with billing submitted to identify if:
Dates of service provided coincide with billed episodes of care
Billing accurately reflects services provided
Any corrective action is needed.
These reviews are done quarterly by the Accountant
Reports of findings are reported to the Clinical Committee quarterly for analysis and decision making.

An audit is done annually at the end of the fiscal year by a qualified independent accountant to assess whether there is evidence of fairness and reliability on the accounting system of QBH in adherence to generally accepted accounting principles.
The CEO selects the independent accountant for this audit
The audit is off all Company accounts
A written management letter is generated by the auditor that addresses the results of the audit and any unusual findings; this is submitted to the CEO.
The letter is available for review by regulatory and accrediting bodies and, if part of the contract, to contract stakeholders.
The management report of the auditor and any necessary corrective actions taken, or why none was taken, is reported to the Board of Directors.
Fee schedules are reviewed at least annually and/or as required by stakeholder contracts by the Clinical Committee; however, the fee structure is set at the state level.
Consumers are informed of the fee structure during the admission process.
The consumer is informed of all fees for which they will be responsible
The sliding scale fee structure, which is based on the consumer’s ability to pay, is explained; a copy is provided to the consumer upon request
Informed that they will be notified at least thirty (30) days in advance of any proposed changes in the fee schedule.
QBH follows the state’s sliding fee scale for consumers without insurance.
Intake staff reviews QBH’s sliding fee schedule and how it applies to the consumer during the intake interview and after appropriateness for service has been determined.
A determination is made by the intake staff of the consumer’s financial status and identifies what fees, if any, will apply to the consumer accordingly; the customer is informed.
Copies are made of proof of income and expenses and retained in the consumer’s record, if available.
A Sliding Scale Form is completed with appropriate information and submitted to the therapist.  It is retained in the consumer’s medical record.
The consumer signs the Sliding Scale Form, indicating they understand and are in agreement with the assessed fee.

Each program is responsible to notify the consumer annually of the need for a reassessment of income and expenses; however, due to the nature of QBH’s programs, consumers rarely have a long stay of treatment.

If the consumer is still in treatment, and cannot be contacted within 10 days after the lapse date, they will be notified by letter at their last known address that they need a reassessment completed to stay in treatment.
An updated Sliding Scale Form is completed by the therapist, provided by the CEO for review and placed in the consumer’s medical record.
Any consumer that denies third party payment coverage is informed by intake staff of the full rate fee that they may be responsible for paying.
A Sliding Scale Form is completed and submitted to the CEO for review.
The CEO is responsible to monitor that MI Sliding Fee Schedules are current and available to the clinical programs for consumer intakes.
Copies of the current MI Sliding Fee Schedules are kept on file in each of QBH’s program areas for reference by staff as needed.
A request to adjust a consumer’s fee may come from the consumer, the consumer’s agent or a family member.  All requests must be documented on the Request for Adjustment Form.
The request may be processed by the intake worker, at the time of initial intake, or by the consumer’s primary therapist.
All requests for adjustments are subject to review by the CEO.
When adjustments are made, the new consumer fee will be posted to the ledger and a new Financial Agreement Form will be given to the consumer.
The Request for Adjustment Form will be kept on file in the clients’ records.
The following factors are considered with respect to third-party reimbursement:

Customer Eligibility – It will be the responsibility of the intake staff to get authorization from the third-party payers prior to rendering services to the consumer.  On the first of each month eligibility is reconfirmed.  Documentation of this reconfirmation only goes into the consumer’s record if there has been a change in eligibility.

Service Package – It will be the responsibility of the primary therapist to monitor that only those services designated for reimbursement by the third-party payers are provided to the eligible customer.

Reimbursement Rates – Rates are set in accordance with the State fee schedule and all services we bill will be at that rate or greater.  If a reimbursement by a third-party is less than Company rates, the consumer will be responsible for the difference, except in instances of specific contracts between QBH and third-party payers that designate a lower rate.  If the third-party rate is higher than our rate, the consumer will not have to pay a fee unless it is required by the third-party.  It is the responsibility of the intake staff to monitor that this information is received as part of the authorization so that the Billing Services can bill properly.
Billing Efficiently – It is the responsibility of the contracted Billing Services to monitor that all claims to third-party payers are submitted accurately and promptly.

If a consumer has insurance, it is the responsibility of the program where the customer is to receive services to oversee that they have the appropriate authorization or denial from the insurance company for services to be rendered.
Provide the insurance company with all the correct answers to avoid denial of payments at a later date.
If the insurance company denies services, the intake staff should determine if the consumer qualifies with one of the State contracts.
Document the denial in the consumer’s record for future reference and place the consumer on the appropriate State contract.
The customer must fill out the necessary documents for the State contract, including a financial intake with sliding fee schedule agreement.
It is the contracted Billing Service’s responsibility to bill all authorized services in a timely manner.

Aging reports (uncollected consumer fees) that indicate no activity for four (4) months are written off as uncollectable after review, unless prior arrangements have been made with the consumer or alternate payee.

The contracted Billing Company reviews aging reports to be certain the account was billed monthly for the past 4 months and to assess that every effort to bill and collect from third party payers occurred.
The uncollectable file is marked with the date non-collectability was validated and filed in a separate uncollectable file.
A listing is made of the consumer’s or alternate payee’s name and amount uncollectable
The listing is presented to the Clinical Director and then the CEO for approval to write it off.
QBH does not manage consumer’s funds for any consumer enrolled in any QBH facility.

The plan is reviewed by the CEO at least annually, with interim reporting of progress points quarterly to the Clinical Committee and the Board; updating of the plan occurs as needed. The plan is reviewed and approved by the Clinical Committee and the Board annually.

sections.title: QBH MAT Fire Extinguisher Testing and Maintenance.policy FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Quality behavioral Health (QBH) provides for patient and staff safety by establishing mechanisms to minimize risk.

The Safety Officer or designee, shall inspect each portable fire extinguisher on a monthly basis and document findings on the Maintenance Log (available from the Office Manager or from the Administrative Assistant..

To inspect fire extinguisher, visually assess that: 1) the pin is secure and has not been removed; 2) that the extinguisher is fully charged (arrow is in the green); 3) that the hose is not damaged and is in good shape; 4) that the extinguisher is properly mounted; 5) that the instructions are legible; and 6) there is evidence/documentation that the annual external maintenance has been done.

The annual inspection and maintenance will be performed by a licensed professionally qualified technician. A contract should be initiated with the nearest Fire Equipment Company to inspect and recharge, if necessary.

Any discharged fire extinguishers must be recharged as soon as possible	after discharge, if it is a rechargeable type. It the extinguisher is a disposable unit it should be discarded and replaced immediately.
In extreme instances the local Fire Chief may do the annual inspection of any portable fire extinguishers and record the inspection on the attached inspection tag.

Inspection and Maintenance tags for fire extinguishers can be obtained from any Fire Equipment Company.  Alternatively an Inspection and Maintenance Log (must be posted near each extinguisher) is kept and documented by the Fire Equipment Company.

The monthly inspections by the Safety Officer shall be documented and a copy sent to the Administrative Assistant at the end of each month. The original shall be retained by the Safety Officer for a three year period.

The annual inspection by an outside qualified technician shall be scheduled by the Office Manager. The Office Manager shall confer with the Safety Officer to establish the source for this inspection/tagging/maintenance. The original annual inspection report shall be sent to the Office manager and a copy retained by the Safety Officer for three years.
The Safety Officer shall review and, if needed, revise this policy tri-annually and 	submit to the Clinical Committee for approval.
