sections.title: QBH MAT Fire Emergency Drill.policy  FINAL 6 1

blocks.text: To provide a safe environment for consumer and staff by conducting emergency and fire drills as scheduled to train staff in proper safe handling of fires and emergencies.
To provide training for staff in conducting safe and timely evacuations.
The Safety Officer is responsible for conducting all emergency drills.
Drills in all areas will be conducted at least annually for the facilities are in use.
At least 50% of all fire drills will include evacuation of consumers, visitors, and staff; everyone in the facility must participate in each drill. All drills should be unannounced.
The scenario for the location and size of the fire, and the times conducted, should be varied.

The pull station should be used occasionally to simulate a real fire; however, the Fire Department and alarm company must be notified prior to the drill to prevent paying for a false alarm to the Fire Department.
Periodically, place the mock fire near an exit, thus blocking one exit to cause use of alternate exits.
Action at the Site of the Fire:
If a fire is detected, or drill instigated, the person discovering the fire will:

Alert occupants in the immediate area who are in danger due to fire or smoke. (If wanting to prevent alarming excitable consumer, the organization code word of "Code Red" may be used to alert staff members to the presence of a fire.)
Use the nearest pull station to sound the fire alarm. If no pull station is available, use a verbal
alert.

subpolicies.title: Away from the Site of the Fire

blocks.text: Staff responsibilities when the fire alarm or verbal alert is sounded:
If a fire alarm or alert is sounded while consumer and/or visitors are present, the staff escorting them or the staff present will be responsible for supervision and evacuation of all occupants.
Immediately hang up all phones and leave the phone lines open.
Close any windows.
Move consumers and charts to the nearest emergency exit.

Determine if anyone is absent. (For medical records evacuation, see Emergency Preparedness Plan). Do not evacuate unless there is immediate danger from fire or smoke, or if so instructed by the Administrator in charge. When instructed, evacuate to the designated area.
The designated areas by site are:
At the back of the parking lot.

Use posted evacuation routes and always move away from the location of the fire. Each staff member will have a piece of chalk in his/her desk. As they evacuate their work area, each staff member shall close and mark the door with a check mark designating that the office or room is secure.

Designated staff in each area of the facility will double check bathrooms, offices, and all other areas to monitor that all building occupants have been evacuated. They will turn out lights and close doors behind them, marking doors as they secure the area.
Remain calm. Smoke rises, so stay low. Always feel doors before opening them, and if they are hot, use an alternate route.

Staff that evacuates the building with no identified patient responsibility will report to their supervisor for roll call and duty assignment. Congregate in the designated area, leaving driveways and alleys free for the approach of emergency vehicles.
In the event of an actual fire, no staff or consumer shall re-enter the building until authorized by the Fire Department. NOTE: THE FIRE DEPARTMENT WILL TAKE CHARGE UPON ARRIVAL!

Drills taking over two (2) minutes must be explained on the comment section of the Fire Drill Report. A reasonable amount of time to properly conduct a fire drill will be between 1.5 minutes and 2 minutes.
Times less than 1.5 minutes (90 seconds) are almost impossible, if the drill is conducted properly.
Drills should be taken seriously and conducted in the proper manner in order to keep staff and consumer sharp and safe.
Drill times of less than 1 minute will cause the drill to be questioned by any reporting agency.
For all other types of emergency drills and evacuation procedures, refer to the Emergency Preparedness Plan for conducting drills and evacuations.

The Safety Officer will review policies and procedures annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) and make revisions when needed. Any revisions made will be submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT General Safety Mgmt.plan  FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: It is the policy of Quality behavioral Health(QBH) to establish a mechanism that supports a safe environment and minimizes risk to consumers, visitors, staff, and property.
The scope of the safety program spans:
Pro-active identification and reduction of risk.
Ongoing monitoring of high risk processes to identify variance.
Identification, analysis and correction of events including occurrences, incidents, and               sentinel events.

To assess safety factors associated with consumer care, staff practices, visitors, buildings, and equipment, which may result in harm to consumers and staff or in a financial loss to QBH To reduce occurrences and promote awareness and concern for safety throughout QBH.
To provide resources and education to staff.
To respond to identified problems or opportunities for improvement.
To monitor and evaluate at least annually the effectiveness and/or compliance of the General Safety Management Plan. This evaluation will include review of:
the plan’s objectives
Scope
Whether any new services, programs, or sites added in the past year need to be addressed by the plan or if new hazards have been introduced into the environment that now need to be covered.
Performance
Effectiveness
Review of incident reports and other problems noted
Clinical, administrative and support staff participate in analysis of safety data and use this data to resolve safety issues.
Occurrences:  Events that are at variance with the policy, practice, or usual outcome that, fortunately, do not result in damage to property or harm to a person.

Incidents: Events that are at variance with policy, practice, or usual outcome that do result in damage to property or harm to a person.  Incidents must be reported in accordance with the Incident Report Policy.
Sentinel Events: Incidents that are reportable to the state and/or to The Joint Commission.
The Clinical Committee (CC) reviews and approves safety/risk management related policies and procedures and authorizes their distribution.
Control of Risk Associated with Smoking Practices/Policy
There shall be no smoking in Company vehicles or buildings.
Smoking is allowed outside the building for staff, consumers, and visitors in designated areas that  are at least 25 feet from an entrance or exit.
Risk Identification: Risk Assessment/Hazard Surveillance

All staff is responsible to be alert for risks/hazards in care and/or the physical environment at all times and to report any concerns to the Administrative Assistant/designee immediately. The Administrative Assistant will refer concerns to the Safety Officer.

The Safety Officer will perform a walk-through survey of each QBH facility using the Surveillance Inspection Form as a guideline. This survey will be done at least twice annually for the purpose of identifying any safety related environmental problems or deficiencies.

During these walk through events, the Safety Officer will do and document a Proactive Risk Analysis of all program areas to identify any parts of the facilities and/or equipment that a customer could use for self-harm or suicide.  Bathroom doors should have hardware that is ligature resistant.
Assessment shall include all treatment areas, group meeting areas, restrooms, corridors, common areas, reception area, and any other area where customers might have or gain access.
Any deficiencies must be addressed immediately.
Problems identified during surveillance will be documented on the Surveillance Inspection Reporting Form. Problems will be reported to the Administrative Clinical Director in writing within 48 hours.
Risk Reduction: A risk analysis will be conducted of all new, redesigned, and/or risk prone processes.
Analysis will be conducted on each step of the process to identify any potential risk inherent in that step.
If risks are apparent, the process will be restructured to eliminate and/or reduce the risk as much as possible.
If risks are apparent, the process will be restructured AGAIN to eliminate and/or reduce the risk as much as possible.
Analysis process will continue until it is determined that the process is as risk-free as possible or
Staff and Consumer Education
Staff and consumers will receive training relative to their roles and responsibilities as safety advocates.

Staff and consumers will be trained to report any safety concerns to the Administrative Assistant. The Administrative Assistant will relay the concerns to the Safety Officer. The Safety Officer will review concerns for validity and report any follow up action to the person making the known request.
Ongoing monitoring of staff knowledge and performance of their roles and responsibilities will occur through post-tests and during drills or events.
The 24 hour emergency telephone number will be posted at all public entrances.
Training

Consumers and Families: Consumers and families are oriented to their responsibilities at intake or during program orientation such as asking any questions they may have   regarding safety and their role in reporting any safety concerns to the Administrative Assistant or a staff member. They will also be informed of their right to report safety concerns to The Joint Commission.
Staff
Staff will receive orientation and continuing education regarding their responsibilities, which include:
To monitor the workplace for risks/hazards and to respond by either correcting the problem or reporting it for correction.
To report and properly manage events.
To comply with general safety procedures, area specific safety practices and job-related safety hazards.
Methods for eliminating and minimizing physical risks in the environment of care.
Actions to take in the event of an environment of care incident
How to report environment of care risks.
Documentation of training and competency assessment will be maintained in staff
personnel files.
Ongoing preventative maintenance and testing of equipment will be completed as scheduled and documented on the appropriate maintenance form.
Adequate space needs to be available for the provisions of consumer treatment and activities.
Ongoing Supervision of Grounds and Physical Environment
The Administrative Assistant/designee will maintain ongoing vigilance to sustain the physical environment and grounds in safe conditions.
All staff is responsible to report any variance to their Administrative Assistant immediately.
Consumers/families are oriented to bring any variance they notice to the attention of a staff member or the Administrative Assistant.
The Administrative Assistant will investigate the variance and take corrective action, and report to the Safety Officer.
The CC reviews and approves safety/risk management related policies and 	procedures and authorizes their distribution.
The Safety officer/designee will do problem solving and take action. Action taken will be reported to the Administrative Assistant in writing within 14 days.
Mechanism for Immediate Management/Response to Events: Upon determination of an event needing immediate attention:
The staff member witnessing the event will notify their Administrative Assistant of the     problem.
If necessary, the Administrative Assistant will notify the CEO
If necessary the CEO will contact emergency services to assist.
If the situation is deemed to be threatening the safety of consumers, visitors, or staff, the Administrative Assistant is authorized to take immediate action.
Mechanism for Reporting, Investigating, Analyzing Events
Incident Reporting
Incident reports are to be submitted to the appropriate Administrative Assistant within 24 hours after the event.

The Administrative Assistant will then submit the completed incident report to the Safety Officer and CEO within one working day The CEO will investigate and oversee that problems are resolved. Data will be reviewed to identify trends/patterns needing improvement and will be reported to the CC.
Claims Management
CEO is responsible for review and revisions of contracts, insurance coverage and any claims related to professional liability, visitor, and staff injuries, and property loss.
The CEO will inform the executive staff or governing board of any important issues which have potential legal, financial, or adverse public relations ramifications.
The CEO will work closely with legal counsel, if necessary.
Work related injuries will be investigated and reviewed for problems and corrective actions will be taken, as needed, to oversee that risks are minimized as much as possible.
Leadership
CC members will require a mechanism for agency-wide collaboration of safety/risk management information and improvement.
CC members will identify at least one high-risk problem/prone process for ongoing monitoring and periodic analysis to determine the degree of variance from expected performance.
Staff
All staff is responsible for safety and for reporting of safety issues.
Each staff is responsible for immediately intervening in the event of a condition arising, which would pose a threat to health, or damage to equipment or buildings.
Safety Officer: The CEO will appoint a qualified person to serve as Safety Officer, whose responsibilities include:
Implementation of all the Environmental of Care Plans.
Identification, investigation, of identified problems.
To stay informed of all events and ongoing measurement results related to safety and risk management.
Review related policies and procedures and make recommendations.
Report on environment of care issues on a bi-annual basis to the OOPC.
Develop, review, and provide education of staff.
Act as a resource to staff and management on safety issues, which affect the Company.
Provide periodic reports to the CC.
The Safety Officer will complete a plan evaluation annually (1 year from last event plus or minus 30 days) from the previous evaluation.

The evaluation will include appropriateness of defined scope, whether objectives were  achieved, performance data, the effectiveness of the plan in reducing/preventing risks and events, and any changes in regulatory and accreditation requirements.
The Safety Officer will review and revise the plan annually and submit for approval to the CC.
The CC will review, approve, and submit the General Safety Management Plan to the Governing Board annually for approval.
Performance Standards will be developed and reviewed to assess compliance with the plan annually.
100% of staff will be annually tested on the knowledge of Environment of Care which will cover General Safety Management Plan.
Knowledge of Environment of Care will be indicated with a minimum overall test average of 90%.

sections.title: QBH MAT GENERATOR LOG.form FINAL 8 13
QBH MAT GOV  BOARD BYLAWS.policy  FINAL  7 17

blocks.text: The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation of these Bylaws:
1.01	"Articles" means the Articles of Incorporation of the Corporation as the same may be 	amended, from time to time, on file with the  Michigan Corporation Commission.
1.02	"Administration" means the management of the Corporation headed by the Chief 	Executive Officer.
1.03	"Board" means the Governing Board of Directors of the Corporation.
1.04	"Chair" means the Chairperson of the Governing Board.
1.05	"Corporation" means Quality Behavioral Health, Inc., a not-for-profit corporation.
1.06	"Director" means member of the Governing Board.
1.07	"Clinical Staff" means the medical and clinical staff of the Company.
1.08	"Company " means any health care institution operated by the Corporation.

2.01	Known Place of Business.  The addresses of the MAT Program Administrative offices are 37490 Dequindre Rd, Sterling Heights, MI 48310.   The Corporation may have such other offices either within or without the State of Michigan as the Board may designate or as the business of the Corporation may require from time to time.

2.02	Change of Place of Business.  The Board may, from time to time, change the Corporation's known place of business or its statutory agent by filing a statement with the Michigan Corporation Commission in the manner provided by law.

3.01	Designation and Classification.  The affairs of the Corporation shall be managed by a Board of Directors.  The Board of Directors shall consist of a minimum of two (2), but not to exceed seven (7), regular members selected from the residents of the service area that meet qualifications set forth:
3.01-1	Has professional expertise that is beneficial to the Company and the Board's duties; is
professionally and culturally competent.
3.01-2	Resides and/or works in the community (e.g., Macomb County) of the population served.
3.01-3 	Represents one of the cultures served by the Company.
3.01-4	Other characteristics as may from time to time be decided by the Board as 			reflected in official Board minutes.

3.02	Term of Regular Directors.  Regular Directors shall serve a term of three (3) years and shall be elected in such a manner as to serve staggered terms.  After serving a term, a regular Director shall be eligible for re-election or reappointment to the Board.

3.03	Ex-Officio Members.  The ex-officio members of the Board shall be the Medical Director/MAT Program Sponsor and the Clinical/MAT Program Director.  Ex-officio Directors shall serve so long as they hold the designated position which is the basis for ex-officio membership.   Directors may not serve as elected officers of the Corporation unless they are also owners in the Corporation.  Ex-officio Directors must personally attend meetings of the Board and may not delegate attendance to any other person.
3.04	Resignation.  Any Director may resign at any time.  Resignations are effective upon acceptance by the Board.

3.05	Removal.  A Director may be removed from office as a Director, without cause, by majority vote of Directors.  Ex-officio Directors may only be removed by their removal from the designated position which is the basis of ex-officio membership.
3.06	Vacancies.  The Board of Directors shall fill vacancies occurring between annual elections for the unexpired term of the elected members causing such vacancy.
4.01	General Responsibilities.  The Board shall have general responsibility for management of the affairs of the Corporation.  The Board may, in accordance with the Articles and Bylaws:
4.01-1	Establish policy, maintain safe, quality consumer care, and provide for
institutional management and planning.  Oversee the development and 			operation of a sound safety program and effective quality management 			program for the Company.
4.01-2	Control and manage the property and business of the Corporation.  Require an
annual financial audit from a qualified external source. Use other external advisors as needed.
4.01-3	Take reasonable measures to achieve and maintain licensure and accreditation 			of the Company.
4.01.4	Enter into written contracts, loans, other financial matters extending beyond
their own terms of office.  Determine if there will be and any amounts thereof of expense reimbursement.  Stock ownership does not apply to this corporation.
4.01-5	Elect from their own membership and appoint from their own membership or 		          otherwise, officers of the Corporation.
4.01-6	Fill vacancies on the Board.
4.01-7	Cause the Clinical Staff to conduct an annual review of its written plan.
4.01-8	Cause the Clinical Staff to establish a process of Performance Measurement and
Improvement Management and review the standards and implementation of such process from time to time.
4.01-9	Require the Clinical Staff to provide the Board with written reports of Clinical 		        care evaluation on a regular basis at such time or times as the Board elects.
4.01-10 Cause the Clinical Staff to establish and follow procedures providing due 			process of law in dealing with Independent Professional Staff privileges.
4.01-11 Subject to the remaining provisions of these Bylaws, act in the capacity of final
decision-maker as to the granting or terminating of Independent Professional Staff privileges.
4.01-12 Development of agenda and development and distribution of meeting
materials which may be delegated to the Board President and CEO.
4.01-13 Assign to the President and CEO the responsibility to organize whatever
resources are necessary for governance development and management.
4.01-14 Establish the Chief Executive Officer’s compensation on an annual basis which

shall be based upon review of Company performance versus target, individual performance versus target, and professional development, accomplishments and opportunities achieved. At each evaluation new performance goals shall be determined.
4.01.15 Develop and annually review an executive leadership succession plan.
4.01.16 Require an annual review of Company and Board policies.
4.01.17 Require an annual Evalution of board performance collectively and individually.
4.01.18 Require an annual written and signed conflict of interest declaration and cod of
conduct declaration from each Board member.

4.02	Annual and Regular Meetings.  Regular meetings of the Board may, but need not 		be, held on a fixed day of each month as the Board may, from time to time, 	              select.  If a fixed meeting is selected, no additional notice of any regular meeting 		of the	Board is required.  The Board shall meet at least four (4) times in each 		fiscal year.  The 	Board shall designate one of its regular meetings as the annual 		meeting.

4.03	Special Meetings.  Special meetings of the Board may be held at any time and at 	any place upon the call of the Chair and shall be called upon the written request 	of any two (2) Directors.  Special meetings of the Board may be conducted 	telephonically at the election of the Chair.

4.04	Notice of Special Meetings.  Each Director is entitled to written notice by 	facsimile transmission or ordinary mail, postage prepaid and mailed to the 	Director's last address on file with the Corporation, no later than three (3) days 	prior to the date of any special meeting.  Notice of any special meeting may be 	waived, in writing, by all Directors before, during, or after any special meeting 	and notice shall be conclusively deemed to have been waived by any Director 	who is actually present at the meeting.

4.05	Action Without a Meeting.  Any action required or committed to be taken by the 	Board of Directors may be taken without meeting if all members shall 	i	individually or collectively consent in writing to such action.  Such consent(s) 	shall be filed with the Minutes of the proceedings of the Board of Directors and 	shall have the same force and effect as a unanimous vote of the 			members.  Board of Directors action may be conducted by telephone 	c	conference which shall be deemed to constitute a meeting and Minutes shall be 	recorded of such meeting.

4.06	Quorum.  At any meeting of the Board, a majority of the elected Directors shall 	constitute a Quorum.  In the absence of a quorum, the meeting shall be 		adjourned until a quorum is present. Participation of a member by conference 	telephone shall be considered attendance at the meeting.

4.07	Attendance.  Each Director is expected to attend every regular and special Board 	meeting in its entirety.  Absence by a regular Director from any three (3) regular 	meetings in any single elected term shall constitute a resignation by such 	Director from the Board and create a vacancy.  However, if an absence is 		excused by action of the Board of Directors and entered into the Minutes, that 	absence shall not count as one of the three (3) absences referred to above.
4.08	Minutes.  All activities of the Board of Directors will be maintained in written 		Minutes.

4.09	Confidentiality.  Certain matters of the Board, its consumers and/or staff will be 	confidential, including but not limited to personnel matters; records or matters 	exempt by law from public inspection and disclosure such as QM issues, 		consumer issues and records; deliberations and negotiations regarding issues, 	projects or services that, if disclosed, would impact the Company's competitive 	position; other matters as may from time to time be deemed confidential by the 	Board.  Board members shall maintain such matters as confidential during and 	after their service on the Governing Board.
ARTICLE V
OFFICERS OF THE CORPORATION
5.01	Officers.  The Corporation shall have elected and appointed officers.
5.01-1	Elected Officers.  The elected officers of the Corporation are the Chair, Vice		   Chair, and the Secretary/Treasurer.
5.01-2	Appointed Officers.  The appointed officers of the Corporation are such other		       officers as the Board may deem necessary.
5.02	Election and Tenure.
5.02-1	Qualifications.  Elected officers of the Corporation shall be selected from the 	regular 	Directors.  Elections shall be conducted by secret ballot at the annual
meeting.  Appointed officers may be selected from within or without the membership of the Corporation.  At least one officer elected shall have served on the Board for a minimum of one (1) year.

5.02-2	Term.  Except in the case of resignation or removal, each elected officer 		holds office for a term of one (1) year and until a successor is elected 	and 	qualified. An officer's term commences at the first regular or special meeting 	after the 		officer's election.
5.03	Resignation and Removal.
5.03-1	Resignation.  Any officer may resign at any time by giving written notice to the
Chair or to the Secretary/Treasurer.  Such resignation (which may or may not be made contingent on formal acceptance) takes effect on the date of receipt or at any later time specified therein.
5.03-2	Removal.  Any officer may be removed by the Board (with or without cause)

whenever, in the Board's judgment, the best interest of the Corporation will be served thereby.  An officer may only be removed upon the vote of a majority of the total number of Directors serving on the Board at the time of the vote.  All votes on the removal of an officer shall be conducted by secret ballot.
5.04	Vacancies.  A vacancy in any office may be filled by the Board for the unexpired 		portion 	of the term.
5.05	Duties of Officers.
5.05-1	Chair.  The Chair is the principal officer of the Corporation.  Subject to the 			Bylaws, the Chair shall:
Preside at all meetings of the Board.

Sign on behalf of the Corporation any documents or instruments which the Board has authorized to be executed, except where the signing and execution is expressly delegated by the Board or these Bylaws to some other officer or agent.
Perform such other duties as are incident to the office of the Chair or are assigned by the Board from time to time.
5.05-2	       Vice-Chair.  Subject to the Articles and Bylaws and the directions of the 			        Chair,   the Vice-Chair shall:
In the absence of the Chair or when, for any reason, the Chair is unable or unwilling to perform his duties, perform the duties of the Chair.
Perform such duties as are assigned by the Board or the Chair.
5.05-3	    Secretary/Treasurer.
5.05-3-1     Duties.  Subject to the Bylaws the Secretary/Treasurer shall:
Provide for the keeping of Minutes of all meetings of the Board.
Give or cause to be given appropriate notices in accordance with these Bylaws or as required by law.
Act as custodian of all corporate records and reports.
Keep or cause to be kept a current roster showing the names of the current Directors and their addresses.
Keep or cause to be kept correct and accurate accounts of the properties and financial transactions of the Corporation.
If required by the Board (and at the expense of the 	Corporation), give a bond for the faithful discharge of duties in such sum and with such sureties as the Board shall determine.
Perform any and all other duties incident to the office of ecretary/Treasurer and such other duties as may be assigned from time to time by the Chair or the Board.
5.05-3-2    Delegation.  The Secretary/Treasurer may delegate any duty to 		                    any appointed Secretary or to the accountant for the 	C				    Company.
5.06 	Chief Executive Officer
5.06-1	Appointment.  The Board shall select and appoint a qualified and 		experienced health care administrator (as defined by job description) to

serve at the pleasure of the Board as the CEO and to be the Board's direct executive representative in the management of the Company.  The CEO shall be given the necessary authority and be held responsible for the management of the Company and all its services subject to the policies enacted by the Board. Except at otherwise provided, the CEO shall be an ex-officio member of all committees and of all organizations that are associated or affiliated with the Corporation. The CEO shall act as the duly authorized representative of the Board in all matters except those in which the Board has formally designated some other person or group to act.  The CEO may sign on behalf of the Corporation any documents or instruments which the Board has authorized to be executed.
5.06-2   Executive Compensaion. Annually the Board or an assigned sub-

committee that does not include members related to the CEO shall determine what will be the CEO’s total compensation mix that might include any or all of the following: 1) base pay, 2) incentive plan; 3) benefit plan, and 4) prerequisites.
Total compensation shall be comparable to market compensation data for functionally comparable positions.

Terms of compensation arrangements and performance goals for the year shall be written into a contract signed by the CEO and Board President and shall include the approval date, names of Board members who approved the compensation decision and include a summary of data used for the compensation decision.
The minutes shall reflect any conflict of interest, if any, in the compensation deliberation and decision.
The Board shall conduct an annual review of the CEO’s compensation records.
5.06-3	Authority and Duties.  The CEO shall, subject to the directions of 				the Board:
The CEO must br professionally and culturally competent.
The CEO shall appoint a MAT Program Sponsor, who may or may not also be the Medical Director.
Be responsible for implementing policies established and plans authorized by the Board for the operation of the Company and for advising on the formation of these policies and plans.
Provide liaison among the Board, the Clinical Staff, and the	services of the Company and assist in coordinating the activities of the	Company departments with those of the Clinical Staff.

Send periodic reports to the Board and to the Clinical Staff on the overall activities of the Company, as well as on appropriate federal, state, and local developments that affect the operation of the Company.
Provide the Board with such staff and administrative support and personnel as they may reasonably require.
Provide the Company's Clinical Staff with the administrative support and personnel reasonably required to carry out their review, evaluation, and monitoring activities.
Organize the administrative functions of the Company, delegate duties, and establish formal means of accountability on the part of subordinates.
Develop and submit to the Board a plan for organization of the Company services and other organizational components, showing lines of authority, responsibility, and interrelationships.
Be responsible (except as otherwise provided by the Board) for selecting, employing, controlling, and discharging employees and for 	developing and maintaining personnel policies and practices.
Establish such Company administrative departments as are necessary, provide for departmental and interdepartmental meetings, and attend or be represented at such meetings.

Assist the Board in annually reviewing and updating a capital budget and preparing an operating budget showing the expected receipts and expenditures, and supervise the business affairs of the Company to monitor that funds are expended to the best possible advantage.
ARTICLE VI
BOARD COMMITTEES
6.01	Committees.  There shall be no standing committees of the Board, however, the Chair may appoint AD-HOC Committees as deemed necessary.

6.02	AD-HOC Committees.  The Chair may call for and establish AD-HOC committees when needed. Each committee shall be given a specific task, and its power will be limited to research the formulation of recommendations and presentation to the Board of Directors for action.  Each committee will disband upon completion of its duties.  The nominating committee shall be an AD-HOC committee, established at least 60 days prior to any scheduled or required elections.  The Chair shall appoint a nominating committee of two (2) or more Directors, designating one to be Chair.  The nominating committee shall present candidates for Officers of the Board.
ARTICLE VII
QUALITY MANAGEMENT

7.01	Board Responsibility.  The Board shall establish, maintain, support, and exercise oversight of an on-going quality management process that includes specific review, evaluation and monitoring mechanisms to assess, preserve and improve the overall quality and efficiency of consumer care in the Company.
7.02	Delegation to Administration and the Clinical Staff.
7.02-1	To Administration.  The Board delegates to the Administration and holds it 		accountable for providing the administrative assistance reasonably necessary to

support and facilitate the implementation and on-going operation of the Company's quality management process, for implementing the quality management program as it concerns personnel and technical staffs and consumer services, and for analyzing information and acting upon problems involving technical, administrative, and support services and Company policy.
7.02-2	To the Clinical Staff.  The Board delegates to the Clinical Staff and holds it 		accountable for conducting specific activities that contribute to the
preservation and improvement of the quality and efficiency of consumer care provided by the Company.These activities include:
A systematic evaluation of practitioner performance against explicit, predetermined criteria.
On-going monitoring of critical aspects of service and monitoring unexpected clinical occurrences.
Review of utilization of the Company's resources to provide for their proper and timely allocation to consumers in need of them.
Provision of continuing Clinical education, fashioned in part on the 	needs identified through the review, evaluation, and monitoring activities and on any new state-of-the-art developments.

Definition of the clinical privileges which may be appropriately granted 	           within the Company, delineation of clinical privileges for eligible clinical 	           staff  commensurate with individual credentials and demonstrated ability
and judgment, and participation in assigning consumer care sponsibilities to other health care providers consistent with individual qualifications and demonstrated ability.

Management of clinical affairs, including enforcement of clinical policies and consultation requirements, initiations of disciplinary actions, surveillance over requirements for performance monitoring and for the exercise of newly acquired clinical privileges, and like clinically-oriented activities.
Development and oversight of a system for continuous service improvement through the initiation of improvement teams whose mission is the improvement of selected critical processes.

Such other measures as the Board may, after considering the advice of the Clinical Staff and Administration, deem necessary for the preservation and improvement of the quality and efficiency of consumer services.

7.03	Documentation and Oversight.  The Board of Directors shall require, receive, consider and act upon the findings and recommendations emanating from the activities required by Section 7.02-2. All such findings and recommendations shall be in writing, signed by the persons responsible for conducting the activities, and supported and accompanied by appropriate documentation and rationale upon which the Board of Directors can take informed action, as required or necessary and can exercise effective over-sight of the quality management process.  All reports and supporting documentation shall be prepared and distributed to strict compliance with the confidentiality policies and procedures adopted by the Board so as to protect any legally privileged material contained therein from unauthorized disclosure.
ARTICLE VIII
CLINICAL STAFF
8.01	Organization and Hearings
8.01-1	The Board of Directors shall require the Clinical Staff  to convene a Clinical

Committee to organize the clinical staff for the purpose of accomplishing its assigned duties. The Board shall consider recommendations of the Clinical Committee and privilege those eligible practitioners who meet the qualifications for privileges as set forth in policy and procedure.  Each independent practitioner shall have the authority to carry out those services delineated in their clinical privileges.
8.01-2	The Clinical Committee shall act on behalf of the Clinical Staff and shall serve 		as the liaison between the Clinical Staff, Administration and the Board of
Directors.  The 	Clinical Staff shall define the membership, functions, and meetings of the Clinical 	Committee.
8.01-3	All applicants’ requests for clinical privileges shall be in writing and addressed to 	the Clinical Committee. The application shall contain full information oncernin

the applicant's education, licensure or certification, practice, previous experience, and any unfavorable history, including at least final outcomes of clinical liability claims.  The applicant must specify the clinical privileges being sought with the application.  This information shall be verified by the Clinical Committee.
8.01-4	All initial privileges shall be for no longer than one (1) year and all re-privileging

shall be for no longer than two (2) years, renewable by the Board of Directors upon recommendation of the Clinical Committee. When privileges have been or are proposed to be reduced, altered, suspended, or terminated, the staff member shall be afforded the opportunity of a hearing.  Such hearing shall be conducted under procedures adopted by the Clinical Committee and approved by the Board of Directors so as to afford due process and full opportunity for the presentation of all pertinent information.  The foregoing procedure shall apply to the termination of privileges for any independent pursuant to an employment agreement, contract or other arrangement with this corporation, unless the express terms thereof provide that privileges shall automatically terminate upon the termination of the employment agreement, contract or arrangement.  In the event that the employment agreement, contract, or arrangement is terminated as a result of incompetence or misconduct that poses risk or danger to the well-being of consumers, then the practitioner shall be afforded the opportunity for a hearing.
8.01-5	The appointment for Medical Director shall be made by the CEO and approved 		by the Board of Directors, shall be for two (2) years, and may be renewable

without limit. Duties and responsibilities of the Medical Director shall be set forth in  a job description or employment agreement.  The Medical Director shall be required to maintain qualifications for clinical privileges appropriate to the assignment.  The Board shall conduct a timely evaluation of the Medical Director annually.
8.01-6	No particular clinical privileges shall be denied on the basis of sex, race, age, 		creed, color or national origin, or on the basis of any criteria unrelated to the
delivery of quality consumer care/service.
8.02	Medical and Clinical Care/Service and Its Evaluation

8.02-1	The Board of Directors shall, in the exercise of its overall responsibility, assign to 		the Clinical Committee reasonable authority for providing appropriate clinical 			care/service to the Company's consumers.  The Clinical Committee shall define
the role of each discipline in the diagnosis and care/ service of consumers.
8.02-2	Medical doctors with appropriate licensure, qualifications, and clinical privileges 		at QBH, Inc., shall evaluate, authenticate, and perform medical evaluations.
8.02-3	The Medical Director shall monitor the medical care/service and treatment of 			consumers and shall act as supervisor to the clinical staff and as a consultant to
Contract employees.
8.02-4	The Clinical Staff shall conduct an ongoing review and appraisal of the quality of 	clinical 	care/service rendered in the Company and shall report such activities and
their results to the Board, including recommendations regarding quality issues,
overall organizational functioning, or any other concerns.  These reports shall be submitted in writing to the Board.
8.02-5	The Clinical Committee shall make recommendations to the Board concerning:
granting of clinical privileges; 3) disciplinary actions; 4) all mattersbrelating to clinical competency; and 5) such specific matters as may be referred to it by the Board.
8.02-6	The Clinical Committee shall establish the clinical record requirements for all 			programs of the Company.

8.03	Clinical Policy.  There shall be policies and procedures that set forth the process for credentialing, a hearing process and the organization and duties of the Clinical Committee.  These shall be recommended by the Clinical Committee, subject to approval by the Board of Directors. If any amendment is required to comply with any federal, state or local law or regulation, or with any standard or requirement of any accrediting body, and if the Clinical Committee fails to enact any such amendment within thirty (30) days (or such longer period as may be prescribed by the Board) after a request from the Board, the Board may enact said amendment and the same shall not be dependent upon the ratification by the Clinical Committee.
ARTICLE IX
COMPENSATION

9.01	Board members serve in a volunteer capacity.  No form of compensation, stock ownership, or other form of compensation is offered to Board members with the exception of reimbursement, when receipts are submitted to the Office Manager, of expenses incurred to carry out Board duties such as attendance at a conference or meeting outside the Company for Board purposes.
ARTICLE X
BYLAWS AND AMENDMENTS

10.01	Review.  These Bylaws shall be reviewed in their entirety to assure reflection of current responsibilities of the Board of Directors to the Company and community, and representation of current philosophy and direction.  Review shall occur every three (3) years.

10.02	Amendments.  These Bylaws may be amended or replaced and new Bylaws adopted by a majority vote of the Board Members at any regular or special meeting, provided written notice of this intent has been given by the Secretary/Treasurer to each member at least fourteen (14) days in advance of the meeting.

10.03	Rules and Regulations.  The Board of Directors shall adopt rules and regulations, or policies and procedures as may be necessary to implement more specifically the general principles stated in these Bylaws.  Such rules and regulations or policies and procedures shall be considered of equal dignity with these Bylaws.

sections.title: QBH MAT Hand Washing.policy   FINAL 11 12

blocks.text: Proper hand washing is imperative to prevent or reduce incidence of cross-infections.  Hand washing is the single most effective method of preventing the spread of germs.
Wash hand for approximately 10-15 seconds.
Wet hands under lukewarm running water.
Apply soap to wet hands.
Lather hands using rotary motion and friction being careful not to cause a breakdown of the skin.
Rinse under water.
Pat dry with clean paper towels.
Use papers towels to turn off the faucet and to open bathroom doors.
Properly dispose of used paper towels.
Thorough hand washing is required by all staff:
Whenever hands are soiled.
Before giving injections.
Before and after handling all medications.
Before putting on and removing disposable gloves.
After prolonged contact with consumers.
After handling contaminated tissues or dressings.
After contact with body fluids or secretions and broken skin.
After personal body functions, using the toilet, blowing or wiping the nose, coughing, smoking, or combing hair.
Before and after eating.
Upon completion of work day.
Thorough hand washing is encouraged by consumers who are trained on proper procedure during orientation and training in reinforced as needed during their course of treatment:
Whenever hands are soiled.
Before and after handling all medications.
After contact with body fluids or secretions and broken skin.
After personal body functions, using the toilet, blowing or wiping the nose, coughing, smoking, or combing hair.
Before and after eating.
A liquid antimicrobial soap will be used.  Bar soap is not allowed.
Trash containers will be strategically placed near bathroom exits for disposal of paper towels after opening doors.

sections.title: QBH MAT Hazardous Materials.plan  FINAL  6 17

blocks.text: It is the policy of Quality behavioral health, Inc. (QBH) to establish mechanisms to define, identify, handle, store and dispose of hazardous materials/waste in support of a safe environment.
Criteria were established utilizing state and local regulatory definitions and environment guidelines.
Materials identified for Hazardous Waste/Materials Plan monitoring include:
Infectious waste
Sharps – needles, syringes
Cleaning supplies
Insecticides and rodent control poisons
Any chemical or materials requiring a SDS sheet
Fluorescent bulbs
Batteries
Office Manager will keep a notebook of Safety Data Sheets (SDS) and revise the list as needed.
PPE are available at the facility and are to be used as indicated.
If necessary, the Safety Officer or Infection Control Coordinator will act as an additional resource.
Chemicals, cleaning supplies and any other potential hazardous materials are kept locked
in a storage closet no higher than eye level to promote patient/staff safety.
Universal precautions are utilized, infectious waste is to be doubled bagged and disposed
of per policy.
No chemicals will be stored next to food or near a gas fired hot water heater.
All staff will receive training about this plan at orientation and annually.
Staff will demonstrate knowledge on how to handle hazardous materials and waste as evidenced by their post-test results for this plan.
Evidence of staff education will be kept in their personnel files.
Handling and Use

Spills or exposures will be handled according to OSHA guideline; recommendations will be reported to the IC Coordinator. The exposed staff will complete an incident report within 24 hours of the incident.
Staff will report exposure to the Administrative Assistant who will share information with the Safety Officer and/or Infection Control Coordinator.
Any safety hazards may be reported to the Safety Officer without fear of   retribution by their supervisors and/or the Company.
The supervisor will assess potential harm caused by exposure and take appropriate actions as needed.
The Safety Officer is responsible for implementation, review of the Plan, and    follow-up on corrective actions taken.
The Office Manager will keep SDS sheets and all relevant data in a notebook for reference this will be kept in an area that is easily accessible by others.
The Safety Officer collects and reports information about the Hazardous Waste/Materials Plan and any follow up needed to the Clinical Committee (CC).
This policy will be trained on during orientation of new staff and annually by the Safety Officer.
The Safety Officer will review this plan annually and make revisions when necessary; they will be submitted to the CC.
100% of staff will be annually tested on the knowledge of Environment of Care which will cover the Hazardous Materials Plan.
Knowledge of Environment of Care will be indicated with a minimum overall test average of 90%.

blocks.text: *Investigation is not necessary if, upon initial discovery, it is identified that one or more of the following situations exists:
Access or use was by another staff and was unintentional, made in good faith and does not result in further use or disclosure

It was an inadvertent disclosure by a staff authorized to access PHI/ePHI to another staff/person so authorized and the information received as a result of the inadvertent disclosure is not further used or disclosed
A disclosure where there is good faith belief that an unauthorized person to whom the disclosure was made would not reasonably have been able to retain such information

Initial investigation supports a low probability that the PHI/ePHI has been compromised based upon a general risk assessment of 1) the nature and extent of information involved and likelihood of re-identification; 2) the unauthorized person who used or to whom the information was disclosed; 3) whether PHI/ePHI was determined to have actually been acquired or viewed; and 4) the extent to which the risk to the PHI/ePHI has been mitigated

sections.title: QBH MAT HIPAA COMPLIANCE POSTER.form  FINAL 7 17  POST THRU FACILITIES

blocks.text: ALL consumer information is CONFIDENTIAL, no matter what its form…oral, written, electronic – treat it accordingly.

Failure to follow HIPAA confidentiality and security requirements will result in disciplinary action, even termination.  Additionally, you may incur a substantial federal fine or imprisonment for purposeful violations.
Follow the “minimum necessary” rule when exchanging consumer information with other providers – provide only what is essential to the situation.
Never leave written or electronic consumer information unattended…lock it, log off it, shut it off are your options.
All electronic media with access to confidential information must be password protected…
NEVER SHARE YOUR PASSWORD WITH ANYONE!
Change your password at least every 90 days.
Make your password complex…combine letters, characters and numbers.
Never write your password down.  If you need a reminder, use a phrase or word that means something only to you.
If it is not web-based, encrypted and password protected it must be backed up and securely stored.  The back-up source must be encrypted and password protected too.
Anti-virus, malware and firewall protections are a MUST for any media that stores or accesses confidential information.
Consumer information disclosures are done ONLY by Medical Records at the Home Office.
Use of at work and/or involvement with current or former consumers on any social interaction sight is not ever allowed.

sections.title: QBH MAT HIPAA Education.policy FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: The Privacy Officer/Security Officer will each conduct privacy and security training programs for QBH staff annually and as needed.

Privacy training will be conducted for new staff as part of QBH’s general orientation program. General orientation shall consist of privacy and security regulation information with a general test of the information given at the end of the session.
The Privacy Officer/Security Officer will each conduct any specialized training programs for QBH staff related to the staff’s particular roles in implementing QBH’s privacy policies and procedures.

Staff receives training at orientation and annually about the importance of confidentiality and security of any information related to our patients, staff and business documents.  Staff training covers, minimally:
PHI, ePHI and IIHI definitions and what confidentiality practices are at QBH as regulated by HIPAA/HITECH.
What the civil and criminal penalties are for failing to protect PHI no matter what form it is in; personal accountability is emphasized.
Privacy Officer/Security Officer are introduced, their roles identified and contact information is provided.
The procedures and timeframes for reporting unauthorized disclosures/breaches, virus or malware infection, need for maintenance or repair of electronic media whether Company or personally owned.
Informed that regulatory, accreditation and other governmental agencies can and will audit compliance and/or breaches, including the US Secretary or Health and Human Services or designee.
Instructed on procedures for disaster recovery and emergency mode operation in situations which might interfere with PHI/ePHI/IIHI security and/or access as appropriate to their job.
Instructed on Company policies and practices related to oral, paper and electronic security.

Trained in proper disclosure practices including when release is not required, when release is required, mandatory reporting, duty to warn reporting, what constitutes a legal release of information, minimum information necessary guidelines.

Managers/administrators are additionally trained on their specific roles in reporting, record keeping required by HIPAA, investigation procedures as applicable to their job, Business Associate Agreement requirements, and their specific roles in the security, disaster recovery, and emergency mode operations plans.

The Privacy Officer/Security Officer and appropriate QBH staff shall be responsible to see that the content of the privacy/security training program is updated, as appropriate, to reflect any material changes in QBH’s privacy and security policies and procedures. If material changes are made in privacy or security policies and procedures, QBH staff members whose work is affected by the changes shall be trained as soon as possible after those changes become effective.

QBH will document the privacy/security training conducted for its staff. Education and training provided to the staff shall be documented by attendance sheets and/or Virtual Center of Excellence training website reports.  Training and test results are kept on file in Human Resources and in the staff’s personnel file.
QBH will retain for six (6) years all privacy/security training related documentation, including:
Attendance lists or Essential Learning reports for education.
Privacy/Security test results from privacy/security training in general orientation.
All written and/or electronic materials used for privacy training.
QBH shall require annual review and testing of each staff on privacy and security requirements.
Documentation of the annual mandatory training and testing shall be retained by the Human Resources Department and within staff’s personnel files.

The Security/Privacy Officer shall collaborate to design and oversee posting of posters and notices that provide prompts or reminders to staff on key privacy and security practices in regard to both paper and electronic PHI.  You will need to post these (copy in forms for lamination and posting in appropriate areas) before survey.
These shall be posted at workstations in all offices/departments.
The Officer shall monitor that these reminders are still present during scheduled inspections and oversee replacement of any that are damaged or missing.
The Officer shall review these posters and notices at least annually and update as needed.
The Privacy and Security Officer will review this policy annually and as needed and revise when deemed necessary.  Approval will be by the Clinical Committee.

blocks.text: The intent of Quality Behavioral health (QBH) is to provide a mechanism by which unusual incidents are reported to leadership in a timely fashion, and that all QBH safety, consumer rights, and risk management issues are handled in a safe, dignified, and prudent manner.
Compromise to Human Dignity/Human Rights – mistreatment including but is not limited to the
following: racist behavior, harassment, purposeful embarrassment in presence of  others or other
mental/verbal abuse; any intentional, reckless or negligent action or omission which exposes a
client to a serious risk of physical or emotional harm; neglect; exploitation (commercial and
otherwise); mistreatment (incited or encouraged); corporal punishment; unreasonable use of
force/threat of force; threat of transfer/transfer for punishment, retaliatory acts (against a
consumer); other blatant violation of consumer rights.
Misconduct – behavior that is not appropriate or is contrary to Company policy,
Company rules, ethical guidelines (staff), or Company behavioral guidelines
(consumers/visitors).

Occupational Illness – an injury that is incurred by a staff while doing a job-related treatment/procedure such as a back injury while lifting a heavy box, a needle stick while giving an injection, etc. This does not include communicable diseases acquired by exposure to sick staff, consumers or visitors.
Premises – a physical location owned, leased or designated for the sole use of QBH to conduct QBH business.
Property – buildings, equipment, supplies, grounds and like-type possessions of QBH, whether owned, leased, or designated for sole use of QBH.
Staff – persons who are under obligation to provide a service to QBH whether an employee, a contract provider, a student/intern, or a volunteer.
Visitors – persons other than consumers or staff, whether authorized or unauthorized, who 	are present on Maxus premises.
All staff is responsible for completing an “Incident Report” (see attached sample) within one (1) business day of any unusual incident in which s/he is involved.
Failure to report may result in disciplinary action.
Staff is encouraged to assist consumers in completing an Incident Report if it does not unduly stress the consumer, or if the consumer makes this request.
Staff is expected to use good judgment in determining if an Incident Report is 	necessary. In general, the following types of situations would require an Incident  Report:
Injury or Death such as the following:
Any consumer, visitor or staff injury on premises, or while conducting QBH business that requires more than basic first aid (excluding minor scrapes/cuts/bruises) or medical intervention.
Death/suicide of a consumer, visitor or staff on the premises, or while in the custody of
QBH staff, or on QBH business.
Any threat, with obvious intent to follow through, of personal injury to self (e.g. attempted suicide) or others while on the premises.
d.	Any injury (or threat with obvious intent to follow through) off premises, while conducting QBH business.
Consumer deaths  resulting from MAT treatment to include:
Drug related deaths
Methadone or buprenorphine deaths
Unexpected or suspicious deaths
Treatment context deaths that raise individual, family, community or public concern
Staff Illness
Occupationally induced illnesses of staff (this does not include communicable illness such as flu or colds, etc).
Damage to QBH property such as the following:
Occurrence that results in damage (not just cosmetic) to QBH property that poses a risk/endangerment to other consumers, visitors or staff.
Transport incidents including break down, medical emergency, or collision, in company owned or leased vehicle AND in personal vehicle (if occurrence is while conducting QBH business).
Safety or security breaches that jeopardize health or well-being such as the following:

Medication error or adverse reaction requiring medical treatment at in a health care setting.   [These events do not require Incident Report Form completion but rather are to be reported to the Clinical Committee who completes a separate Medication Error Form which is submitted to Human Resources.
Occurrence of misconduct, disruptive or potentially violent behavior by consumer, visitor, or staff.
Occurrence that insults or compromises human dignity or violates human rights.
Occurrence that necessitates a Police Report or Protective Service Report of abuse/neglect/rape or other event.
Occurrence that constricts or prohibits service from being safely  provided such as a security breach; bomb threat; violent person on the property; non-working fire safety equipment;
Physical plant disasters, such as major fire within the service location when consumers were present or which affect consumer service areas.
Consumers who leave treatment (AMA) despite the advice of Company clinical or medical staff.
Special considerations requiring reporting that may be unique to the MAT program include:
Harm to family members or others from ingesting a consumer’s medication.
Selling drugs on the premises.
Medication diversion.
Any other occurrence that is out-of-the-ordinary that administrative staff need to be informed of promptly.
If staff is uncertain as to whether or not an Incident Report is needed, s/he will ask the Administrative Assistant. When in doubt, write an Incident Report.

Psychiatric or crisis emergencies are not by themselves “unusual” at the 	Company. However, if the behavior is extreme (such as actual injury, attempt, or plan of injury in the presence of staff, or evidence of such in the presence of staff), then an Incident Report is necessary.
Completing the Incident Report form:
Write or print very clearly, with black ink.
Complete all sections with an answer or “N/A” for “Not applicable.”
Designate full names of staff or other persons involved.
Include behaviors and all relevant details.

If more space is needed, continue on the back page, or attach an additional sheet to the report with the page number and Incident Report number written on the upper right-hand corner. Sign and date each additional page, with a diagonal line drawn through any unused portion of the page.
Sign and date the report.
Attach any supporting documents needed.
Send the completed Incident Report (and supporting documents) to the Administrative Office.

If the incident is serious or crucial and demands extraordinary attention, the staff will     immediately contact the CEO, or designee, for problem solving assistance. The CEO will be alerted immediately regarding situations that are critical.  Critical situations would be situations of great harm or potential harm. These would include incidents such as:
Any death. Any injury that requires hospitalization.
A building safety issue that creates immediate jeopardy to the safety and/or lives of consumers, staff, or visitors.
Any situation that is extraordinary in its occurrence and/or that has drawn the attention of police or media.
Any situation that is extraordinary in its occurrence that needs the leadership decision-making authority.
Routing Process for Incident Reports – ALL INCIDENT REPORTS, WHETHER 	ORIGINAL OR COPY, ARE HANDLED AS A CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT; INCIDENT REPORTS ARE NEVER FILED IN CONSUMER RECORDS.
The Safety Officer, promptly upon receipt, sends a fax copy to the Human Resources
Department and provides a copy to the CEO.

The HR Coordinator will promptly notify the CEO of the Incident Report at which a point a determination will be made of whether immediate attention to the report is needed or if it will be reviewed and then integrated with other reports for aggregation and trending. If the incident entails a sentinel event, by Joint Commission, CMS or MHHS definitions, a sentinel event process will be initiated (see Sentinel Event Policy).
Upon receiving a copy of the Incident Report and any attached documentation, the

CEO reviews the report within five business days, to ascertain if the situation was handled appropriately and safely. If there are any legal, safety, treatment, policy/procedural, or consumer rights issues, will take steps to remedy the situation, and will include this documentation on the original Incident Report.
Once the CEO has completed their portion of the Incident Report, the original is forwarded, to the Human Resources Department, where all original Incident Report documents shall be filed.
The Safety Officer will retain a copy of the Incident Report with other Incident Reports in a secured file.

After the incident has been reviewed as satisfactorily settled by the CEO, a copy of the Incident Report is distributed by the Human Resources Coordinator or designee within two (2) business days to the following for purposes of review for identification of other action that might be taken to prevent a recurrence of this type event, if possible, and for reporting of trends related to that function:
Safety Officer
Quality Manager
Infection Control Coordinator, only if infection is associated with the incident.

Upon review by the Safety Officer, the Safety Officer may make recommendations and initiate additional action, if indicated, to be included in the next Safety Report to the QBH Clinical Committee (CC)..
The Quality Coordinator will aggregate data on all Incident Reports, will review for possible
trends/patterns, and will report as scheduled to the QBH CC.

Upon review by the Infection Control Coordinator, when applicable, the Infection Control Coordinator may make recommendations and initiate additional action, if indicated, to be included in the next Infection Control Report to the QBH CC.

Each Safety Officer shall fill out the QBH Incident Report Tally Form and send it, during the first five (5) days of the month following the month to which the data refers, to the Human Resources Department. Even if there were no events during the month, the form should be sent indicating there were no events.
This policy shall be reviewed and, when necessary, revised by the CC annually and as changes are necessary.
All staff shall be trained on the Incident Reporting process at new hire orientation and annually by the QBH CC
