QBH MAT INFECTION CONTROL PLAN.policy FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral health, Inc. (QBH) will sustain an active system for the prevention, reduction, early identification and control of infections throughout QBH's facility.  Under the guidance of the Infection Control function of the Clinical Committee, the Infection Control Coordinator is charged with the responsibility for the coordination of the Infection Control System and is responsible for the following:
Establish goals for the infection control program, in collaboration with the Clinical Committee.
Integrate Infection Control with Safety and QI systems. Implementation is under the direction of the Clinical Committee.

Conduct ongoing Risk Assessments. Risk analysis is done annually and as needed, considering current or changing geographic location of services, community environment, patient population characteristics, and services provided, prior infection results of the Company, and treatment modalities used.

Conduct effective surveillance, data collection and analysis. Surveillance will occur for early identification and appropriate management of infections and surveillance of compliance with infection control practices.

Implement effective prevention and control processes. Supervision and management of methods that may require development, and implementation of preventative or corrective processes, policies and procedures, or protocols designed to minimize the incidence of health care acquired infections and to prevent, promptly identify and control the spread of healthcare acquired infections is provided via the Infection Control Coordinator with oversight by the Clinical Committee.
Supervise and manage patient techniques that require development and implement
preventative or corrective programs, policies and procedures, or protocols designed to
minimize the incidence of healthcare acquired infections.
Assist with development of staff policies and oversight of staff health issues.

Educate and collaborate with leaders for their participation. Infection Control information/education is provided to all staff at orientation, re-orientation annually, and as needed. Training aims to develop and maintain a unity of purpose and action within QBH regarding the prevention and control of infection.

Integrate efforts with community and health care leaders for community-wide effort particularly in the reporting of designated infections and communication or assistance with Company-wide or community-wide outbreaks.
Plan for infections that may overwhelm the Company’s resources. See Reporting and Disease Outbreak Control below.
The Company’s leadership will overs that:

An effective system for the maintenance of an environment that is directed toward the identification, and control of infections brought into the Company from the community, and the prevention of healthcare acquired infections is in place.
Involve medical, clinical, administrative, and other staff in a multi-disciplinary effort to develop a system meeting the requirements of accreditation.
Develop and maintain a unity of purpose and action within the Company regarding the control of infections.
Delineate responsibility for the various aspects of the Infection Control System.
Infection Control – Those actions that are related to the prevention and management of infections of either patients or staff.

Environmental Control – Those continuing actions that are related to the surveillance and monitoring of the various areas of the Company in an effort to prevent contamination or cross-contamination of the Company environment with potential agents.

Healthcare Acquired – An infection that was not incubating at the time of admission to the Company.  If the incubation period is unknown and the infection developed more than 48 hours after admission, it is considered healthcare acquired.
Community-Acquired – Any infection with obvious signs and symptoms noted upon admission or within 48 hours after admit.

The Infection Control Plan will be sustained in accordance with current standards and requirements of accreditation agencies, MDHS, WHO, CDC, and OSHA.  The Clinical Committee has determined that the Infection Control Coordinator shall devote at a minimum of 10 hours per month to infection control activities. Infection control cannot be based solely on a number of hours per month but is based on the amount of time it takes to do the job and must be looked at by risk involved, responding to epidemics of emerging and reemerging infections and development of an Companyal wide approach to reducing the risk of acquisition and transmission of infections.

The implementation of the system through the orientation of all personnel, the formulation of practices for the prevention of infection, and the placing of special emphasis on areas of need is the responsibility of Administration, the Clinical Committee, the Infection Control Coordinator, and ultimately all staff and patients. Through the Infection Control Coordinator, a system is established and maintained for reporting infections and communicable diseases to the Clinical Committee and/or the appropriate health department officials.

Current priorities for surveillance, prevention and control activities are determined by the Infection Control function of the Clinical Committee with specific input from the Infection Control Coordinator and Medical Director. Priority risks are identified on the basis of patient demographics and risks, community trends and internal infection patterns, and current scientifically sound risk reduction/prevention practices and surveillance methods.
The following risks are the focus of the infection control system currently:
HIV
Influenza
Coronavirus
HEP C
Priorities may be adjusted if changes occur that pose new risks to the Company.

subpolicies.title: GOALS   (Plan goals are reassessed/established annually by Clinical Committee)

blocks.text: The incidence of infections within our identified high priority risks will decrease from the average incidence of each in 2021. Continue to achieve a zero-percent in the number of exposures associated with the use of medical devices.
Attain at least 85% rate in hand hygiene compliance (see Goal 1 in Hand Hygiene Policy) among staff by the end of 2021.
Demonstrate an improvement of the hand hygiene goals #2, 3 and 4 (see Hand Hygiene Policy for those goals) as evidenced by improved results from the beginning to the end of 2021

Increase the number of staff taking the Influenza Vaccine yearly by 10% each year for the next 3 years to reach a 70% goal by 2018 and 10% each year thereafter until 2021 to reach the goal of 90% on the 1st day of 2022.
The Infection Control function of the Clinical Committee shall:
Monitor all investigations, control, prevention, and reporting of infections within the Company. This applies to both staff and consumer populations.
Develop standards for infection control and environmental sanitation and establish standards for determination of healthcare acquired infections.
Evaluate on a continuing basis the policies and procedures developed within the Company for meeting established standards for asepsis and sanitation.

Develop a workable system for reporting, evaluating, and keeping records of infections among patients and staff to provide indications of the endemic level of all healthcare acquired infections, to trace the source of infection and to identify   potentially dangerous situations.
Provide staff support for periodic statistical/prevalence studies related to Infection Control.
Identify a death/permanent loss of function associated with a healthcare acquired infection as a sentinel event.
The Infection Control Coordinator shall:
Conduct ongoing surveillance of infection, gather and interpret data and keep accurate records of all infections.
Compile and present Infection Control Reports to the Clinical Committee
Inspect the environment and monitor staff activities for the purpose of detecting infection hazards.  Monitor and evaluate compliance with standards set forth by the Clinical Committee.
Monitor and evaluate aseptic and patient care techniques to support optimum care.
Monitor and update all policies and procedures important to infection control principles.
Investigate all “exposure incidents” and oversee post-exposure evaluation and follow-up process in order to recommend appropriate actions to be taken.
Notify designated administrative staff and appropriate health department authorities of all reportable communicable disease.

The Infection Control Coordinator, in collaboration with the Medical Director, will gather data on geographic/population infection demographics and consider that data in relation to length of stay, intensity, of contract, and the number of staff to determine what areas should be monitored, decide on prevention and control activities and formulate new polices. This will be an ongoing process which is reviewed at least annually and any other time needed and presented to the Clinical Committee for decision.

The Infection Control Coordinator will regularly monitor key websites such APIC, CDC, OSHA, WHO, and JC to maintain an Infection Control System that is scientifically sound and current with best practices.

subpolicies.title: STRATEGIES TO MINIMIZE, REDUCE AND ELIMINATE INFECTION RISKS

blocks.text: Infection control starts with each individual member of QBH. When hired all personnel are trained in proper hand hygiene techniques, blood borne pathogens and proper use of barrier equipment. This is reviewed as a part of yearly continuing education.  For use routinely and on an admission status report, Nursing and Direct Care staffs are taught to recognize and document any signs and symptoms of infectious disease including tick borne illnesses, influenza and respiratory illnesses, head lice, scabies, fungal infections, open wounds, fever, redness, and swelling on the skin surface.  Any such occurrence is reported to the Nursing Department for evaluation and treatment as warranted.  An infection needing further medical evaluation will be directed to the Medical Director.

As a part of the intake process, each consumer completes a health screen which is later followed by a History and Physical Exam.  This evaluation includes assessment for signs and symptoms of external infections and possible internal infection. A physical inspection is done for external signs and symptoms of infectious organisms. They will be referred to their primary care physician for any treatment needed.  If there are restrictions to their participation in the program, the physician will discuss this with them and write orders accordingly.

Consumers coming to MAT from institutional settings will be inspected for lice and may receive or be instructed to undergo treatment for head lice as a matter of routine. Those consumers found to have evidence of lice or eggs will undergo, or be instructed to undergo, a follow-up treatment in 7 days.  Consumers coming directly from their homes will be inspected for evidence of lice and treatment given or instructed to be done, if necessary. During flu season (September through March) flu vaccine will be encouraged for all consumers admitted for treatment.  Documentation of vaccination, if given at the program, shall be documented in the MAR.
Consumers and families are informed of standard infection control practices and their responsibility in preventing infections. This is to be documented in the clinical record.

Staff/consumers/volunteers are informed of standard infection control practices and their responsibility in preventing infections and the spread of infections during orientation and, for staff, annual training.

Visitors and consumers attending the program will wear masks and be monitored for signs of illness at check in, by a staff, and, if any symptoms of illness are noted, will be asked to cooperate in their responsibility to cooperate with necessary infection control measures. This may include hand hygiene, covering a wound and may be asked to wear a mask if coughing/ sneezing is present.

A consumer shall not attend activities while afflicted with any contagious or infectious disease/virus, or while liable to transmit such a disease/virus after being exposed, unless the MAT Medical Director or other Licensed Independent Practitioner has determined, based on medical evidence, that (1)  the consumer is no longer infected or liable to transmit the disease; or (2) the consumer is afflicted with a chronic infectious disease which poses little risk of transmission in the public environment where reasonable  precautions are taken.

Consumers with contagious or infectious disease/virus and their families have a right to privacy and a need for confidentiality. Only staff members who need to know the identity and condition of such consumers to determine fitness to attend program activities or to provide proper health care will be given information concerning a specific consumer. This includes nurses and persons who are most likely to be called on to administer first aid to such consumers. Willful or negligent disclosure of confidential information about a consumer’s medical condition by staff members will be cause for disciplinary action.

Reporting and disease/virus outbreak control measures will be implemented in accordance with federal and state laws and Department of Health rules governing the control of communicable strains and other diseases dangerous to public health.

All consumers shall be encouraged to be in compliance with the state laws and regulations requiring immunizations against poliomyelitis, rubella, mumps, tetanus, pertussis, diphtheria, and hepatitis B.

Everyone, including physicians, consumers, nursing personnel, advisor/ technicians, visitors, and volunteers, are responsible for complying with the standard precautions and for complying with isolation precautions.
Everyone is responsible for tactfully calling observed infractions to the attention of the offenders.
Universal Precautions procedures are to be followed at all times.

All staff will use disposable gloves and masks supplied by QBH when handling bodily fluids.  If gloves are not readily available, any available barrier, such as clothing or paper will be used to minimize direct contact.
All staff will wear disposable gloves and masks if open lesions are present on the caregiver’s hands.
Any open lesion will be covered and the bandage dry.
Proper hand hygiene after exposure to blood or body fluids will be observed and followed by antimicrobial hand sanitizer.
Soiled surfaces will be promptly cleaned with soap and water and followed by a disinfectant (bleach diluted 1:10 to 1:100 with water) or by using a blood spill kit.
Disposable towels or tissues will be used whenever possible.
Mops will be rinsed in disinfectant after cleaning floors and stored with the mop head up.
Soiled disposable materials that do not require being placed in a sharps container will be discarded in plastic bags.
Cleaning personnel will be aware of the risk of exposure to diseases when handling any blood or body fluid and how to protect open skin lesions (gloves).
All sharps materials (needles and syringes) will be disposed in special hazardous waste container.  This container will be closed when ¾ full.
Antimicrobial gel will be kept in all first aid kits at each building and in all Company-owned vehicles for consumer transport.
Housekeepers will attempt to maintain an environment that is sanitary and promotes infection control standards (refer to Housekeeping Policies).
Continuing input will be provided into the content and scope of the staff health related policies and procedures.
Monitoring and surveillance of staff for infections or communicable diseases.
Providing communicable disease testing as indicated.

To obtain a 70% Goal of direct care/clinical staff obtaining the flu vaccine by the year 2018 and a 90% Goal by 2021.  This will be accomplished by a 5% yearly increase in direct care/clinical staff obtaining the vaccine beginning with the year 2022.
Task to obtaining the above Goals:
Step up training on importance of obtaining the flu vaccine.
Keep posters regarding the flu vaccine in all areas of operation during months of September through March.
Track and trend reasons that direct care/clinical staff do not obtain the vaccine.
Annually review all data to see if yearly goals are met
Reporting coverage levels of data to Quality Management on an annual basis.
Reports of vaccination coverage levels on different areas of the facility/categories of staff.
Use of signed refusal statements by direct care/clinical staff that refuse the vaccine.
Annual report to Clinical Committee and the Board on progress or lack of progress in meeting the goals.
Consultation related to the purchase of all equipment and supplies used for disinfection purposes and/or invasive procedures will be provided by the Infection Control Coordinator.
Infection Control orientation will be provided for all new staff.
Continuing infection control education will be provided for all staff/consumers.
The Infection Control Coordinator will provide ongoing assistance or consultation for staff/consumers as the need arises.
All consumers will receive age appropriate information about the prevention and control of communicable diseases, to include the use of universal precautions.

The Infection Control Coordinator will continually pursue continuing education to enhance knowledge/skills in infection control and best practices and will document and report this training in at least one Infection Control Report to the Clinical Committee annually.

Reporting and disease outbreak control measures will be implemented in accordance with the state and local law and Department of Health rules governing the control of communicable diseases dangerous to public health, and any applicable rules distributed by the appropriate county or city health department.

In case of infection that overwhelms our resources, consumers will be discharged. Additional admissions will not be accepted by the Company during the outbreak. The physician will perform a case by case review of consumers to determine risk versus benefit of discharge.  If risk is greater than the benefit of returning the consumer home, these consumers will be transferred to other facilities. (See Pandemic Plan).
The Infection Control Coordinator will investigate and suggest corrective actions if needed.
The Infection Control Coordinator will give periodic reports to the Clinical Committee and Board about the system status.

Policies and procedures will be reviewed and revised annually (yearly every twelve months plus or minus thirty days), or when significant risk changes by the Infection Control Coordinator and submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval. Formal evaluation shall include:
Evaluation of the degree to which program goals were achieved.
Changes in the scope of the program.
Any emerging/re-emerging infection problems in the community.
Success or failure of program strategies in preventing and/or controlling infections.
Any concerns raised by leadership, staff, consumers, or others.
An evolution of the standards/best practices.

The adequacy of resources needed and provided by leadership for achieving IC system objectives, including whether regular reports on program effectiveness were provided and timely, resources for information access were sufficient, lab support was adequate, sufficiency of equipment/supplies for IC, and whether policies and procedures were adequate for guiding program activities and methodologies.

QBH MAT Interim Maintenance Treatment.policy  FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: The MAT program in Sterling Heights provides interim maintenance treatment as so authorized by both the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) and by the chief public health officer of Michigan, where the program operates.  QBH is committed to compliance with the federal interim maintenance treatment requirements [42CFR 8.11 (g)] and understands failure to do so, or failure of the state of MI to do so, could result in revocation of this authorization.
Comprehensive maintenance treatment is maintenance treatment provided in conjunction with a comprehensive range of appropriate medical and rehabilitative services.

Detoxification treatment means the dispensing of an opioid agonist treatment medication in decreasing doses to an individual to alleviate adverse physical or psychological effects incident to withdrawal from the continuous or sustained use of an opioid drug and as a method of bringing the individual to a drug-free state within such period.

Interim maintenance treatment means temporary (maximum of 120 days by law) maintenance treatment provided in an opioid treatment program in conjunction with appropriate medical services while a consumer is awaiting transfer to a program that provides comprehensive maintenance treatment. It is for the consumer that cannot be placed in a public or nonprofit private comprehensive program within a reasonable geographic area and within 14 days of the individual's application for admission to comprehensive maintenance treatment.

Maintenance treatment means the dispensing of an opioid agonist treatment medication at stable dosage levels for a period in excess of 21 days in the treatment of an individual for opioid use disorder.

Medical and rehabilitative services means services such as medical evaluations, counseling, and rehabilitative and other social programs (e.g., vocational and educational guidance, employment placement), that are intended to help consumers in opioid treatment programs become and/or remain productive members of society.

Opioid agonist treatment medication means any opioid agonist drug that is approved by the Food and Drug Administration under section 505 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 355) for use in the treatment of opioid use disorder.

Opioid dependence means repeated self-administration that usually results in opioid tolerance, withdrawal symptoms, and compulsive drug-taking. Dependence may occur with or without the physiological symptoms of tolerance and withdrawal.

Opioid drug means any drug having an addiction-forming or addiction-sustaining liability similar to morphine or being capable of conversion into a drug having such addiction-forming or addiction-sustaining liability.
Opioid treatment program or “OTP” means a program or practitioner engaged in opioid treatment of individuals with an opioid agonist treatment medication registered under 21 U.S.C. 823(g)(1).
Opioid use disorder means a cluster of cognitive, behavioral, and physiological symptoms in which the individual continues use of opioids despite significant opioid-induced problems.

Opioid use disorder treatment means the dispensing of an opioid agonist treatment medication, along with a comprehensive range of medical and rehabilitative services, when clinically necessary, to an individual to alleviate the adverse medical, psychological, or physical effects incident to an opioid use disorder. This term includes a range of services including detoxification treatment, short-term detoxification treatment, long-term detoxification treatment, maintenance treatment, comprehensive maintenance treatment, and interim maintenance treatment.
To receive interim maintenance treatment, a consumer must:
Be fully eligible, meeting all admission criteria, for admission to comprehensive maintenance treatment.
Unable to be placed in an approved comprehensive program within a reasonable geographic area and within 14 days of application for admission to comprehensive maintenance treatment.
Performs a urine drug screen upon admission.
Pregnant women given priority for admission.
Interim maintenance shall be provided in a manner consistent with all applicable Federal and State laws.
All requirements for comprehensive maintenance treatment apply to interim maintenance treatment with the following exceptions:
The opioid agonist treatment medication is required to be administered daily under observation;
Unsupervised or “take-home” use is not allowed;
An initial treatment plan and periodic treatment plan evaluations are not required;
A primary counselor is not required to be assigned to the patient;
Interim maintenance cannot be provided for longer than 120 days in any 12-month period; and
Rehabilitative, education, and other counseling services are not required to be provided to the consumer.
At least two additional urine screens must be performed during the course of treatment up to the 120 day limit.

The Clinical Director, or designee, notifies the state health officer both when a consumer begins and leaves interim maintenance treatment and notifies the state health officer in advance when the consumer is transferred to a comprehensive maintenance treatment program.  These notifications are documented in the consumer record.

subpolicies.title: THE RATIONALE FOR PRIORITIZATION OF PREGNANT WOMEN FOR METHADONE USE DURING PREGNANCY

blocks.text: Methadone is the drug  of  choice  in  the  management  of  the  opioid  dependent  woman.  While Methadone does have the risk of triggering neonatal abstinence syndrome, this is a relative risk  and  overcome  by  the  fact  that  in  this  population  neonatal  caregivers  are  aware of the risk and can monitor more effectively.

In addition to the standard goals in MAT of reducing cravings, and blocking euphoria of opioid use, the desired goal of methadone maintenance during pregnancy is to prevent the mother from experiencing withdrawal, the stress of which may be sufficient to induce spontaneous abortion in first trimester pregnancies and premature labor in last trimester pregnancies.

Methadone maintenance provides a “steady state” of opiate levels, thus reducing the risk of withdrawal for the infant. Methadone also reduces the use of street opiates, and thus decreases the risk of problems such as hepatitis, HIV, other infections, prostitution, criminal activity, and the general life disruption associated with opiate dependence.
Methadone can be taken orally, lacks impurities, costs less, and can be carefully regulated.
Methadone also allows for the engagement of the woman in a treatment program, providing daily contact with a health care provider.

Methadone dispensing for pregnant women should occur in the context of a comprehensive MAT program that includes prenatal care as soon as possible.  In this type of program, women receive almost daily care or contact with their healthcare provider when they receive their methadone dose.

Administration of methadone and determination of methadone dose during pregnancy involves a balancing of considerations for the mother and fetus. While methadone administration reduces many of the risks associated with opioid use, it has also been associated with longer and more severe neonatal abstinence than short acting opioids exposure due to methadone’s longer half- life. Neonatal abstinence syndrome may occur in between 60-80% of babes born to methadone maintained moms. Some authors have reported a relationship between methadone dose and the severity of neonatal withdrawal, while others have not found a similar relationship.

Detoxification from methadone is not generally recommended during pregnancy. Methadone and clonidine should not be used together because of the sedative effect. If detox is going to be attempted, ideally, this should occur during the second trimester, when the pregnancy is the most stable.
Initiation of methadone in the pregnant consumer should be done on an inpatient basis. Dose adjustment should be as follows:

At the first sign of withdrawal, (NAT>4-5) commence 10 mg methadone. Supplement this dose by 5 mg q6h for NAT>5. On day 2, give total of first day’s dose as single AM dose, supplement 5mg q6 h. The pregnant consumer is considered stable when no further supplementation is required (Usually 35-60mg).
Dosage adjustments during pregnancy should occur not more that every 2-3 weeks, 5 mg/adjustment.

There may be a requirement to slightly increase the dose during third trimester as with metabolic changes, women may metabolize methadone at a faster rate. Doses over 100 mg should be administered as a split dose.
Women on methadone who become pregnant should have their dose adjusted downward to as low a dose as possible, remembering it is better to have the consumer at a higher dose than risk relapse.

Breast-feeding is not contraindicated. With doses below 20 mg it is not a concern. With higher doses, the best time to feed is just before the next dose.  Feeding should not take place within two hours of dosing and at around 6 months the infant should be weaned or the methadone discontinued.
The Clinical Director shall review this policy and make any necessary revisions annually and submit it to the Clinical Committee for approval.

blocks.text: POLICY:	INTERIM LIFE SAFETY MEASURES (ISLM)
Quality Behavioral Health (QBH) will provide a safe environment for consumers, staff, visitors, and property.
PURPOSE:
To establish measure to temporarily compensate for the potential Life Safety hazards that could occur from construction activities.
PROCEDURES:
In the event of construction or remodeling activities, the following measures will be
implemented as deem appropriate to the situation:
Determination will be made at on-set of project of feasibility for population
relocation based on risk factors and space availability.
Exits are to provide for free and unobstructed egress.  Staff will receive
training if alternative exits are designated. Areas under construction must
maintain escape routes for construction workers at all times. Means of egress
in construction areas must be inspected daily.
Unobstructed access to external emergency service resources.
Additional fire-fighting equipment and training of staff in its use.
No smoking within twenty-five feet of any entrance or exit of QBH
buildings or and/or construction areas.
Develop and enforce storage, housekeeping, and debris-removal practices to
reduce fire hazard to lowest level possible.
Increase fire drills to two per shift per quarter.
Increase hazardous surveillance of buildings, grounds, and equipment
especially near excavations, construction areas, construction storage, and field
offices.
Train staff to compensate for impaired structural or compartmentalization
features of fire safety.
Further educate staff on Life Safety Code deficiencies, construction hazards,
and interim life safety measures.
The Safety Officer and CEO or designee will determine which of the above
measures will need to be implemented for the immediate situation.
The Safety Officer will monitor and document compliance with the implemented
measures on the ISLM Evaluation Form and report to the Clinical Committee (CC).
Any construction activity blocking an important egress which would compromise
patient or staff evacuation that would be blocked for more than 24 hours will
require implementation of these ISLM and notification of local fire officials by the
Safety Officer or CEO/ designee.
The Safety Officer will train all staff on this policy annually and all staff will be
trained upon hire by the Safety Officer during orientation.
EVALUATION:
The Safety Officer will review this policy and procedures tri-annually and make revisions when necessary; they will be submitted to the CC for approval.
RELATED FORMS/POLICIES:
ISLM Evaluation Form
Life Safety Plan
Smoking Policy
Housekeeping Policy

sections.title: QBH MAT LEADERSHIP MISSION, PHILOSOPHY AND DIRECTIVES.policy FINAL  7 17

blocks.text: The mission if Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. is to provide person-centered, holistic service that reflects innovation, best practices and outcome-based performance that is satisfying and cost-effective to consumers, staff, leadership and other stakeholders.
To provide service that meets the needs of consumers of diverse ages and backgrounds.
The following statements reflect the philosophy of QBH, Inc.:

All actions and decisions of QBH are to be driven by our person-centered philosophy that results in services being delivered in a fashion that is appropriate to the individual consumer and in a manner that demonstrates unconditional positive regard.

Connected to person-centered service is an understanding that a holistic approach to service is required because consumers typically need healing and attention to many or all of the aspects of who they are physically, mentally, emotionally, socially and spiritually.
Consumers are seen as persons with an illness, not a moral deficiency, who need support in a loving, caring environment where they can feel safe and encouraged to heal/recover.
Leadership and staff are expected to conduct themselves and deliver services in a manner that reflects this philosophy.
Leadership’s development of programmatic and service planning is to be guided by this philosophy.
QBH’s philosophy is communicated to consumers, staff and other stakeholders through various means:
Training
Community Outreach
Brochures, pamphlets and/or advertisements about QBH and its services
Observation of staff’s behavior in service delivery that reflects this philosophy
Leaders’ communications that reveal their commitment to this philosophy internal and external to QBH.

Provide, in an integrated manner, the most comprehensive and cost-effective behavioral health and substance abuse services possible to residents of Wayne County and Macomb County, MI, in need of such services.

Preservation of the family unit through provision of services in the least restrictive environment possible based upon the consumer’s needs and level of support available, involvement of the family directly or through a multi-family approach to aid them in problem-solving issues so as to establish a strong, healthy family unit that is supportive to the consumer’s treatment and recovery.

Provide culturally and gender sensitive services with equal access regardless of income, race, religion or disability. Recruitment and retention of bilingual/bicultural staff, staff training on cultural sensitivity and diversity to raise cultural awareness, and to factor culture and gender into treatment and services provided.
Supportive, non-judgmental service and treatment to consumers with disabilities through accommodation and/or provision of home-based outpatient services if needed.
Treatment emphasis on helping consumers to become empowered to become the solution to their own problems through learning and skill building.

Cost effective approaches to service such as brief, solution-focused treatment using cognitive-behavioral strategies in outpatient treatment that fosters time limited and specific problem identification leading to prompt problem identification and resolution
Sensitive and timely response to community need for services through advocacy and/or Company development of those services.
The mission, philosophy and values of QBH are foundational for the Board of Directors and leadership as they guide the various elements of Company operations, as follows:
The Board and leadership, through its Clinical Committee, collaborate in review and, as necessary, revision of QBH’s mission as part of strategic planning.

Direction to the organization is premised on the person-centered service goal and the delivery of service and conduct of operations in a fashion that is cost-effective while sustaining best practices.
Service and program planning promotes value through a utilization and performance improvement model that gives regular feedback to leaders for decision making.

Provide resources and education for staff through a variety of methods (in house training, community and professional conferences, electronic media, field-related publications, etc.) to assist staff to stay current in their field, acquire updated best practices, learn about new research findings and keep abreast of professional experts’ consensus on field issues.

The performance improvement system is structured to provide ongoing feedback relative to the level of achievement of program and service outcomes through structured performance outcome measures and regularly provided summary reports for leadership’s analysis.

Monitoring and adjusting, as needed, budgets, financial policies and practices, and financial decisions based upon an annual internal audit and performance outcomes data to sustain financial solvency.

Managing risk through risk planning; periodic risk assessments; education for managing risk to leaders and staff, both formally and serendipitously, and to consumers as relevant; scheduled surveillance; incident reporting and analysis; sound insurance programs, etc. to reduce and/or eliminate risks to QBH, its staff, and consumers served.

Directing and receiving regular reports on performance improvement system activities and results for the purpose of identifying Company excellence, areas for improvement and success of such improvements, determining performance in many categories of service and operations on an ongoing basis.

Establishment and implementation of corporate responsibilities through Board Bylaws, Company policies, record-keeping and minutes, a variety of performance measures, leadership evaluation processes and corporate compliance guidelines.
Overseeing compliance with all legal requirements of county, state and federal regulatory bodies, service reimbursement bodies, and local legal authorities as relates to QBH’s services and programs.

In addition to annual reviews of various systems and processes of QBH, leadership conducts an annual review of its policies to assess need for revision to reflect current compliance with internal practices; adjustments needed to meet regulatory, external provider and accreditation bodies; changes in best practice guidelines; changes in staff and/or consumer populations; and other indicators. Clinical Committee minutes and, when applicable, Board minutes reflect conduct of these reviews and, when needed, approval of any revisions or new policies.
Reviews and/or revisions will be noted in the footer of the policy indicating each date in which leadership reviewed and/or revised a policy, form, manual within the Policy Manual.

The Administrative Assistant will notify staff of new or revised policies and make them available in hard copy and electronically; s/he will also maintain the official hardcopy Policy Manual and keep it current.

The plan is reviewed by the CEO at least annually, with interim reporting of progress points quarterly to the Clinical Committee and the Board; updating of the plan occurs as needed. The plan is reviewed and approved by the Clinical Committee and the Board annually.

sections.title: QBH MAT LEADERSHIP STRUCTURE, RESPONSIBILITIES, COMMUNICATION AND SUCCESSION.policy FINAL  7 17

blocks.text: QBH, Inc. maintains a hierarchical structure, though an open-door policy exists at each level and among levels.
See the Diagram of the Organizational Chart for an overview of QBH’s structure.
Leadership, individually and collectively are to provide guidance in operations and practices, to include, but not exclusively:
Establishment and at least annual review, during strategic planning, of the mission and direction of QBH
Promotion of value in the services and programs of QBH through orientation and training, supervision and evaluation activities, and by personal modeling.

Foster achievement of Company and program-specific outcomes through provision of adequate resources, ongoing attention to quality system results, setting of strategic and clinical goals annually, ongoing training of staffs, and application of ASPIRE in all realms of service delivery.
Balancing the expectations of care recipients, staffs and other stakeholders through ongoing open communication, satisfaction assessments and other means.

Sustaining financial solvency through setting of fiscal goals, ongoing monitoring in inputs and outputs, continuous attention to changes in service reimbursement trends, and Board oversight of the financial picture on a regular basis.

Managing of risk through ongoing surveillance and regular assessments of risk, consumer/staff/ stakeholder feedback, operating in compliance with policy and protocols of QBH, regular assessments of the physical, emotional, financial and operational environments of QBH.
Ongoing performance improvement, applying the ASPIRE process.
Development and implementation of corporate responsibilities through leadership training, accountability through the committee structure, and periodic assessments.
Ongoing compliance with all legal and regulatory requirements through both internal and external surveillance and prompt response to any legal or regulatory changes.
Annual review of QBH’s policies by leadership itself through committee, or through delegation.
Ongoing enforcement of health and safety policies through education, surveillance, supervision and disciplinary processes, if needed.
Succession planning as set forth in this policy, to be reviewed annually for continuing appropriateness.

The Board has overall responsibility for governance and operation of QBH.  The Board employees and supervises a Chief Executive Officer (CEO) to act on its behalf in providing direction to the operations and functioning of QBH.
Additionally, the Board may appoint committees from time to time to which it will delegate specific aspects of governance.
Bylaws further delineate areas of accountability retained by the Board.
Board member replacement is also addressed in the Bylaws.
Board members must be professionally and culturally competent.
The CEO is accountable directly to the Board of Directors; specific duties are defined in the CEO’s job description.
The CEO is responsible for overseeing all operations, including day-to-day decisions relative to operation of QBH.
The CEO functions as the Administrator and also supervises the Medical Director and Clinical Director.

The Safety Officer, Utilization/Quality Manager, Recipient Rights Advisor and a Program Sponsor (if other than the Medical Director) are appointed and supervised by the CEO as well. A Clinical/ Program Director or Manager will be appointed to assist in daily operations.

The CEO is chairperson of the Clinical Committee and oversees compliance with the committee’s duties and responsibilities as reflected in the committee’s agenda calendar and documented in committee minutes.
Ultimate responsibility for staff recruitment and the provision of quality care rests with the CEO.

In the event that the CEO is unable to fulfill his/her duties, the Board of Directors will temporarily assign the responsibilities of the CEO to the Medical or Clinical Director. The Board of Directors will begin an active search of qualified individuals with the experience, educational qualifications and demeanor suitable to fill the CEO position. QBH employees wishing to apply for this position must submit a resume to the Board of Directors. Qualified individuals will be scheduled for an interview and further background and educational screening will be conducted. The final candidate will receive an offer of employment from the Board of Directors. Upon acceptance of the position the newly appointed CEO will be placed on a one year probationary period and sent to any necessary training to aid in the completion of his/her duties.
The CEO must be professionally and culturally competent.
This position is accountable to and supervised by the CEO.
The Administrator is responsible for overseeing and authorizing day-to-day operation of QBH’s administrative services.
This position appoints and supervises the Accountant, Medical Records and the Administrative Assistant/Office Manager.
Likewise, the Administrator appoints and supervises the Receptionist and Security Officer.

In the event that the Administrator is unable to fulfill his/her duties, the CEO will temporarily fulfill the duties of the Administrator, or temporarily assign another qualified staff. The CEO will begin an active search of qualified individuals with the experience, educational qualifications and demeanor suitable to fill the Administrator position. QBH employees wishing to apply for this position must submit a resume to the CEO. Qualified individuals will be scheduled for an interview and further background and educational screening will be conducted. The final candidate will receive an offer of employment from the CEO. Upon acceptance of the position the newly appointed Administrator will be placed on a six month probationary period and sent to any necessary training to aid in the completion of his/her duties.

This position is available to the Board of Directors and is accountable to them and the CEO for assisting in and overseeing of the delivery of medical and nursing services of QBH; specific duties are delineated in the job description and privileging record.
The Medical Director/Program Sponsor also collaborates with the Clinical/Program Director in delivery of clinical services.
The Medical Director/Program Sponsor directly supervises the physicians and Director of Nursing employed or contracted by QBH to deliver services to QBH, Inc. programs.
The Medical Director is responsible for ALL medical services performed by the program.
The Medical Director is a member of and participant in the Clinical Committee.

This position is responsible to participate in multidisciplinary treatment planning, lends medical expertise as needed to other operations of QBH, participates in peer review activities, and interfaces with internal and external customers and providers to interpret services and to facilitate quality consumer service delivery.
This position participates in the recruitment of physicians and other licensed independent practitioners.

In the event that the Medical Director/Program Sponsor is unable to fulfill his/her duties, the Board of Directors will temporarily assign another qualified medical staff. The Board of Directors will begin an active search of qualified individuals with the experience, educational qualifications and demeanor suitable to fill the position. QBH privileged physicians wishing to apply for this position must submit a resume to the CEO. Qualified individuals will be scheduled for an interview and further background and educational screening will be conducted. The final candidate will receive an offer of employment from the Board of Directors. Upon acceptance of the position the newly appointed Medical Director/Program Sponsor will be placed on a six month probationary period and sent to any necessary training to aid in the completion of his/her duties.
This position is responsible to and supervised by the Medical Director.
The DON oversees all nursing services.
Accountable to plan, manage and evaluate nursing services, assist with clinical support service contracts, provide nursing scheduling, and development and review of nursing protocols and policies.
This position also provides direct nursing care on an as needed basis.
The DON participates in the hire of and supervises nursing staff.
The Nursing Director is a member and participant of the Clinical Committee.

In the event that the Nursing Director is unable to fulfill his/her duties, the Medical Director will temporarily fulfill the duties of the Nursing Director or temporarily assign another qualified nursing staff. The CEO and Medical Director will begin an active search of qualified individuals with the experience, educational qualifications and demeanor suitable to fill the position. QBH employees wishing to apply for this position must submit a resume to the Medical Director. Qualified individuals will be scheduled for an interview and further background and educational screening will be conducted. The final candidate will receive an offer of employment from the CEO. Upon acceptance of the position the newly appointed Nursing Director will be placed on a six month probationary period and sent to any necessary training to aid in the completion of his/her duties.
This position is accountable to and appointed by the CEO; the CEO is the supervisor to this position.
The Clinical/Program Director is responsible for supervision of clinical staff, including Therapists/Counselors, Case Managers and Monitors.
The Clinical/Program Director monitors services delivered by employed and contracted clinical personnel and coordinates program implementation.

This position is a member of and participant in the Clinical Committee, lending clinical expertise and assistance with peer review, credentialing and quality review as well as clinical policy development.
This position participates in the recruitment of clinical staff.

In the event that the Clinical/Program Director is unable to fulfill his/her duties, the CEO will temporarily assign a qualified staff. The CEO will begin an active search of qualified individuals with the experience, educational qualifications and demeanor suitable to fill the position. QBH employees wishing to apply for this position must submit a resume to the CEO. Qualified individuals will be scheduled for an interview and further background and educational screening will be conducted. The final candidate will receive an offer of employment from the CEO. Upon acceptance of the position the newly appointed Clinical/Program Director will be placed on a six month probationary period and sent to any necessary training to aid in the completion of his/her duties.

Appointed and supervised by the CEO, this position oversees the environmental health and safety of QBH with delegated authority to request from medical staff, nursing staff, administrative staff, clinical staff and support service staff clarification re: pertinent reports and follow-up information on problems or actions implemented to resolve identified health, safety and emergency problems.

This position is given authority to: train on, receive and review and verify all data and reports related to operationalization of the Health, Safety and Emergency Plans and implementation of Joint commission (JC) and regulatory requirements related to these areas.
Oversees organization, development and implementation of the Health and Safety and Emergency Management Plans. An overview of responsibilities includes:
Identification, investigation and follow through on identified problems to make sure that corrective or improvement actions have been appropriately taken.
Review related policies and procedures in collaboration with the Clinical Committee.
Keep documentation which supports that the intent of the plans is being carried out.
Report on safety and infection control issues and the plans as scheduled to the Clinical Committee.
Develop, review and provide for education of staff and consumers or families.
Act as a resource to staff and management on safety, emergency and infection control issues and federal, state, or local regulations or laws which affect QBH.
The Safety Officer serves in a consultative role to the following:
Security Officer and Receptionist
Clinical Committee
All staff relative to health, safety and emergency activities.
This position does not supervise any other levels of staff, but liaisons with all departments and programs as relevant to health, safety and emergency issues.
This position is appointed and supervised by the CEO and holds the following authority as delegated by the CEO:
Authority and responsibility for directing and supervising the activities and functions of the Performance Improvement-Quality Management Program, and the Utilization Management Program.

Authority to request from Performance Improvement Task Forces, medical staff, nursing staff, administrative staff, and support service staff clarification re: pertinent reports and follow-up information on problems or actions implemented to resolve identified problems.
Authority to: train on, receive and review and verify all data and reports related to operationalization of the Utilization and Quality Systems and implementation of CARF and regulatory requirements.

This position develops and oversees implementation of an Company-wide performance improvement-quality management program, and a utilization management program consistent with Company-approved plans and regulatory and standard setting agencies.

This position also coordinates activities related to preparation for and facilitation of regulatory and JC inspections/surveys/reports.  Official Policy and Forms Manuals, Committee Minutes, and Quality Data are maintained current and secure by and in the office of this position.
Collaborates regularly with the Safety Officer, Clinical Director, Medical Director, Nursing Director and Office Manager/Administrative Assistant
Serves in a consultative role to the following:
Performance Improvement Task Forces
Clinical Committee
All staff involved in quality and utilization related activities.
This position does not supervise any other levels of staff, but liaisons with all departments and programs as relevant to utilization and quality performance issues.

subpolicies.title: Physician and Other Licensed Independent Practitioner Staff

blocks.text: These positions are supervised by and accountable to the Medical Director.

This staff is responsible for evaluating consumers’ medical/psychiatric condition, implementing needed psychiatric and pharmacologic services, participating in multidisciplinary treatment planning, contributing to peer review, and, upon request, providing medical expertise to the Clinical Committee.
This staff does not supervise other levels of staff, but liaisons with all departments and programs as relevant to delivery of quality medical services.
Comprised of nurses at various levels of training, this staff is responsible to and supervised by the Nursing Director.
Nurses are responsible for providing nursing care to consumers using the nursing process.  Care may include:
Assessments and treatment planning
Medication administration and management
Monitoring and/or treating physical health issues
Therapeutic milieu management, including assisting with group therapy and psycho-education.
This staff does not supervise other levels of staff, but liaisons with all departments and programs as relevant to delivery of quality nursing services.
This position is supervised by and under the direction of the Clinical Director.

Therapists are responsible for the provision of clinically necessary and appropriate assessments, therapeutic treatment services, clinical record documentation and other services as designated in their job description or service contract.
This staff liaison with all departments and programs as relevant to delivery of quality clinical services.
Therapists assist in directing service provision of Case Managers and Monitors.
These positions are supervised by and under direction of a designated therapist.

As assigned by the therapist, this staff is responsible to assist in delivery of treatment services, may assist in group or psycho-educational sessions, aids in facilitating a therapeutic milieu and may have specific documentation responsibilities.
This staff does not supervise other levels of staff, but may liaison with other departments and programs as relevant to their scope of service delivery and as directed by their supervisors.
This position is hired by, supervised by and accountable to the CEO.
This position will receive and acknowledge all reports of and may investigate apparent violations of rights and act to resolve disputes relating to apparent violations.

It is the responsibility of this position to act on behalf of recipients/consumers to obtain a remedy for any apparent violation as well as to endeavor to safeguard the rights guaranteed by the Michigan Mental Health Code (P.A. 258).

Monitoring that The SUMMARY OF YOUR RIGHTS pamphlet and the Recipient Rights poster are continually displayed in all waiting rooms and group rooms of Quality Behavioral Health, Inc., and Business Office is also a responsibility of the position.

The position shall ensure that all recipients/consumers, and others who wish to act on their behalf, have access to forms on which to document alleged violations and is responsible to keep complaint forms and self- addressed envelopes available in all waiting rooms and group rooms.
This position does not supervise other levels of staff, but may liaison with other departments and programs as relevant to the scope of the position and/or as directed by the CEO.
This position is hired by, supervised by and accountable to the CEO.
The Accountant is responsible for recording and reporting on all financial interactions of QBH.
This position assists, as needed, in quality review, budget preparation and financial advisement.
The Accountant is responsible for conducting an annual internal audit for QBH and is responsible for all tax related documentation.
This position does not supervise other levels of staff, but may liaison with other departments and programs as relevant to accounting needs and/or as directed by the CEO.
This staff is hired by, supervised by and accountable to the CEO.
Medical Records Staff is responsible for maintaining the integrity of clinical records and overseeing responses to outside requests for consumer information.
Processing and filing of legal documents and coordinating court-hearing activities for QBH are also responsibilities of this staff.
Additional responsibilities include transcription services, assistance with report development, and, as needed, administrative support.
This position does not supervise other levels of staff, but may liaison with other departments and programs as relevant to clinical records management or as directed by the CEO.
This position is hired by the CEO and is supervised by and accountable to both the CEO and Administrator.
This position provides administrative, secretarial and business office support functions, including handling of sensitive Company information and confidential staff and consumer information.
Interfacing with community and other behavioral health service providers and the Board of Directors is also a responsibility of this position.
The position may be required to assist with marketing and grant writing.

The Office Manager is responsible for processing, management and maintenance of personnel and credentialing files of QBH’s staffs, coordinating staff training calendars, and assisting with human resources issues and projects.
Data accumulation and records management for quality activities, mandatory committee attendance, supervision requirements, and other critical HR information is a responsibility of this position.
This staff does not supervise other levels of staff, but liaisons with all departments and programs as relevant to administrative and HR services.
This position is hired by, supervised by and accountable to the Administrator.

The Receptionist is to clearly convey consumer respect, courtesy, and compliance with consumer rights as the first person consumers and their families as well as other stakeholders see when they enter QBH.
This position greets all who enter QBH to facilitate directing them to the location and/or staff with which they need to meet.
The Receptionist answers all calls coming into QBH, including those inquiring about an intake.
The Receptionist may assist with data collection for the Quality System as directed.
The Receptionist does not supervise any staff but may interface will all departments and programs as necessary to fulfill job duties.

This position is responsible to the CEO for performing Company maintenance and grounds duties including repairs, safety checks, grounds maintenance in a fashion compliant with Company safety, security and hazardous materials policies.
The position assists the Safety Officer in conducting equipment and vehicle inspections and does maintenance as needed or required.
This position does not supervise other staff, though liaison with all departments and programs occurs as relevant to maintenance and repair activities.
Responsible to the CEO for billing and collections transactions and generation of related reports to QBH.
Responsible to the CEO for transport of consumers to and from their residences, appointments, Company activities and other activities as requested in a fashion compliant with Company policy.
Responsible to the CEO for performing Company housekeeping duties including cleaning, washing, following the safety and security procedures and policies of this Company.
Responsible to the CEO for performing internal and external facility security services, following the safety and security procedures and policies of this Company.
The psychologist provides psychological testing and a report of findings for any consumer for whom the Medical Director orders such testing.
Leadership maintains an open-door policy for communication with staff, encouraging staffs’ ideas and feedback.

The Organizational Chart directs communication channels; initial communication should occur with each staff’s direct supervisor.  Should communication at this level not be effective, the staff would then go to the supervisor’s direct supervisor as directed by the Organizational Chart.  This hierarchy is followed until the situation/concern is resolved.
Communication necessary to conduct work activities may go up and down the organizational hierarchy or across laterally, as needed.
No communication in any form is issued to “All Staff” without prior approval of that individual’s supervisor.
Communication formats available to staff include:
Face-to-face such as during informal and/or formal supervision
Direct telephone contact
Voice mail
Email
Fax
Written memos and messages (response should occur timely, even if to simply give notice that a full response will come within 24 hours)
Pay check attachments
Meetings and meeting minutes
Tele-med
Policies and procedures
Newsletter
Requisitions/work orders/purchase orders
Internal Company and UPSO mailings
Communications requiring use of equipment may be limited due to prioritization of use, availability, or Company/program/department protocol.

Consumers are directed to address issues, concerns, and ideas first with their primary service provider.  If necessary, the consumer can go to that provider’s supervisor.  See the Consumer Grievance Policy for more details.

Leadership seeks consumer input through satisfaction surveys, “speak up” ( for feedback and complaints)boxes, community meetings and other formal channels depending upon the need.  Leaders willingly communicate with consumers for ideas and feedback directly or via methods listed here.
Stakeholders are welcome to arrange appointments to speak with leadership staff at any time.
Leaders are also involved in various community and service provider forums, committees, and meetings where they invite ideas, feedback, and conveyance of needs.
QBH periodically invites stakeholders to forums and community input sessions held by QBH.
Company website, newspaper articles, and community service events are also venues for communication with stakeholders.
Stakeholders are offered satisfaction surveys as a venue for providing feedback to QBH.
Communication external to QBH by staff must be pre-approved by the staff’s supervisor.
New Board members receive training as part of their orientation to their roles and responsibilities.
All staff is trained on this policy at hire and whenever any revision occurs.
Staff is trained on use of communication equipment according to need and job responsibility.
Consumers are informed about means they have available for communication as part of their intake and orientation.

The plan is reviewed by the CEO at least annually, (every twelve months +/- 30 days), with interim reporting of progress points quarterly to the Clinical Committee and the Board; updating of the plan occurs as needed. sections.title: QBH MAT LIFE SAFETY EQUIPMENT TESTING.policy   FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: It is the policy of Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. (QBH) to maintain, test, and inspect all life safety components in QBH Facilities.
The purpose of testing life safety equipment is to establish mechanisms to support the proper working order of all fire related devices for the safety of all staff, consumers, and visitors.
Life safety equipment – any equipment designed to protect consumers, staff, visitors, and property from fire.
Fire alarm – any device that will sound an alarm in case of fire, whether activated manually or by smoke and/or heat.
Detectors – any device that sets in motion fire control, such as a smoke detector, sprinkler, automatic door closer, etc.

Each building in which consumers are housed or receive treatment will have a comprehensive statement of conditions (SOC), available to JC, which describes the current condition of the building’s structural features of fire protection.

subpolicies.title: INSPECTION AND TESTING OF FIRE RELATED EQUIPMENT, SYSTEMS, AND COMPONENTS

blocks.text: The Safety Officer or designee shall inspect and test fire equipment according to these guidelines:
Signal devices – quarterly.
Valve tamper switches and water flow devices – semi-annually.
Manual fire alarms, smoke detectors, heat/duct detectors – annually.
Fire alarm pull stations are inspected by looking at the handle in the pull station to see that it is straight up.
Fire detectors are inspected by looking at them and checking that the red light is blinking every 30 seconds. Fire detectors are located in every department lobby and hall.
Audible and visible occupant alarm systems – annually.
Off premises emergency notification transmission equipment – quarterly.
Water-based automatic fire extinguishing system fire pumps – weekly under no-flow condition; annually under flow condition (by contractor).
Water-based automatic fire extinguishing storage tanks high and low water level test – semi-annually (during cold weather, low water level test monthly) by contractor.
Water-based automatic fire extinguishing main drain test – annually at all system risers (by contractor).
Water-based automatic fire extinguishing fire department connections – quarterly.
Portable extinguishers are clearly identified, maintained annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus twenty days) by contractor, and inspected monthly.

Standpipe occupant hoses hydrostatically tested – 5 years after install, then every three years (thirty-six months plus or minus thirty days), with water flow tests every 5 years sixty (months plus or minus thirty days) by contractor.

subpolicies.title: Emergency lighting – The Safety Officer or designee shall test emergency lighting on a monthly (30-day intervals/12 times a year or once per month) basis and document findings on the Inspection, Testing, and Preventative Maintenance Logs.

blocks.text: There is a test button on the lighting unit itself. When the button is pushed, if the light comes on, the unit is working properly.

The monthly (30-day intervals/12 times a year or once per month) test is to be conducted for 30 seconds and the annual (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) test is to be conducted for 1.5 hours. Failed tests will be documented and retest will be performed after resolution of failure.
10% of all emergency light batteries will be randomly tested annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) in addition to the normal tests.
After any storm or power outage, all emergency lights and lighted exit signs must be checked to see that the batteries are working.

subpolicies.title: The Safety Officer or designee shall test battery powered smoke detectors on a monthly basis and replace weak or dead batteries and document findings on a Battery Testing Report Log. ALL smoke detector batteries will be replaced at least annually and documented on the battery testing form.
There is a test button on the smoke detector. If alarm sounds when the button is pushed, the unit is working properly.

To remove the battery, twist the cover in a counter clockwise direction to expose the battery. Simply remove the battery and replace with a new battery at least annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus ten days).

blocks.text: Old/dead batteries are to be disposed of with the other hazmat materials.
The Safety Officer will maintain a manual of schedules and test performance reports for fire-detection equipment.
The location of all manually activated fire alarm pulls are noted on posted evacuation plans.
Training on operational use of fire equipment is provided to staff at orientation and annually as part of the yearly re-orientation.
Ongoing skill and knowledge is evaluated as part of fire drills.

The Safety Officer will review and revise, if necessary, annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days), or as needed when circumstances change. The revised plan and plan evaluation will be submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT Life Safety(Fire).plan  FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health (QBH) has designed a plan to provide a safe environment for consumers, staff, and visitors and to safeguard facility property in the event of a fire. It is the responsibility of all staff to help maintain a hazard-free environment and to be part of the team in preventing or responding in an organized manner to a facility fire.
To comply with state and local fire codes and to maintain an annual inspection record with evidence or problem correction.
To schedule and conduct fire drills on a monthly basis (one time per each month); evaluate each occurrence for identification of problems and opportunities for improvement.
To complete all sections of fire drill analysis monthly.
To conduct fire hazard inspection surveillance tours semi-annually.
To conduct scheduled inspection and testing and annual maintenance of fire protection equipment. Inspections will include monthly testing of lighted exit signs and emergency lighting.
To assess situations where construction may pose fire prevention and evacuation problems. (See Interim Life Safety Measures Policy).
To maintain a smoke-free facility.
To educate staff about fire prevention awareness and the procedure for responding to fire drills or actual occurrences in the new staff orientation program with annual updates.
To oversee that all consumers, visitors and staff are accounted for.

To assess fire extinguishers, emergency lighting, obstruction of sprinkler heads, if critical supplies, equipment and current documentation that has not been received by the Home Office was safely removed if possible.
To assign job duties during fire drills.
To evaluate the plan objectives annually (every 12 months) including:  scope, performance, and effectiveness.

The consultant will be responsible for assessing any new office buildings and completing the E-SOC.  The E-SOC will be turned into the Chief Compliance Officer after completion.  Regional Clinical/Administrative Managers will be responsible for submitting bids and turning the bids in to the CEO for resolution of deficiencies.
Mitigation

All staff members are to assist in providing for the safety of all consumers, staff, and visitors by following the direction of the Charge person. (NOTE: FIRE DEPARTMENT WILL TAKE CHARGE UPON ARRIVAL)
Staff #1- the person noting the fire will alert other staff and assign duties to other staff. Duties will include:
Someone to call 911 and report the fire;
Checking all rooms and evacuating consumers, visitors, families, etc.;
Closing doors after room search is completed.
Accounting for safety of consumers, staff, families, etc. that have been evacuated.
Shutting off gas lines if applicable.
Staff nearest the fire extinguishers is to grab them and carry them with them when doing room checks.
During any remodeling or construction that increases fire risk or impedes usual evacuation egress, Interim Life Safety Measures are initiated.
Preparedness:

Training: Staff is required to review the Life Safety (Fire) Plan at orientation and annually (every 12 months) and to participate in hands-on training and practice in the use of fire extinguishers, and first-aid procedures.
Fire drills and evaluations are the responsibility of the Office Manager and will be held monthly. Drills should vary in time, fire situation, and numbers of consumers/staff present.
Response/Plan Activation
If a fire is detected, initiate:
R - Rescue consumers, visitors, and staff
A - Alert others of fire and call the Fire Department at 911
C - Contain the fire and smoke
E - Extinguish the fire

All staff will assist to provide for the safety of all consumers, staff, and visitors by evacuating. (NOTE: FIRE DEPARTMENT WILL TAKE CHARGE UPON ARRIVAL.) Fire Department will determine when an all-clear return to the building can occur.
When a fire alert occurs, all staff is to:
Immediately hang up all phones and leave phone lines open.
Close all doors to contain smoke and turn off the lights.
Move consumers and charts (if possible) to the nearest evacuation exit.
Be prepared for evacuation but do not evacuate unless there is immediate danger from fire or smoke.
Fire extinguishers should only be used if it is possible to do so without excessive personal risk.
Evacuation:
When evacuating, use posted evacuation routes and always move away from the location of the fire.
Remain calm. Smoke rises so stay low. Always feel doors before opening them, and if they are hot, use an alternate route.
Recovery:
Following any fire, an Incident Report will be filed within 24 hours of the occurrence by the supervisor or staff who first saw the fire.

The Office Manager will complete a Fire/Disaster Drill Report Form indicating any problems identified and corrective actions taken. Forms are to be sent to the Home Office where it will be directed to the Safety Officer for review.
The Safety Officer will review drill reports and investigate, if necessary.  Reports will be made to the Oversight of Operations and Performance Committee (OOPC) periodically throughout the year.

All management staff will have overall responsibility for the implementation of the plan. The Safety Officer will review effectiveness of the plan and report compliance with plan objectives and performance standards to the OOPC.
The Life Safety (Fire) Plan is reviewed and revised annually by the Safety Officer and    approved by the Clinical Committee.
Performance Standards will be designed to measure the effectiveness of the plan.
Staff demonstrates knowledge of Life Safety (Fire) Plan procedures and the ability to
assume leadership in an emergency situation as evidenced by post-tests, answers to         verbal questions, and/or by performance evaluated during drills.
Briefing will occur in the event of an actual fire/emergency with the OOPC.
100% of Staff will be annually tested on the knowledge of Environment of Care which will cover Life Safety (Fire) Plan.
Knowledge of Environment of Care will be indicated with a minimum overall test average of 90%.

sections.title: QBH MAT Lockout Tagout.policy  FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: It is the policy of the Pronghorn Psychiatry to provide a safe environment for staff and patients when equipment servicing and repair are underway.

Appliances/equipment that is unserviceable will be removed to the appropriate storage until they can be replaced or repaired. Equipment or appliances too large to move will have a lockout device such as a tag or lock with a sign affixed to the disconnect switch on a machine or piece of equipment that is to be serviced or is malfunctioning.

The Safety officer will be notified that servicing or maintenance is needed on the machinery or equipment. The Safety Officer will list the piece of equipment on the Maintenance/Repair Log.  The log shall contain the name of the piece of equipment, where it is located, the date of notification that service/repair is needed, a brief description of the problem, and, once repaired/serviced, the date when the equipment went back into service (or if replaced, the date of replacement).
A staff member, upon observing machinery or a piece of equipment which is locked out to perform servicing or maintenance, shall not attempt to start, energize, or use that machinery or equipment.
When the servicing or maintenance is completed and the machinery or equipment is ready for use, the Safety Officer will notify affected staff that the machinery or equipment is ready for use.
Designated staff will remove the lock-out device and re-energize the machinery or equipment as needed.

The policy will be evaluated, reviewed and revised, if needed, annually (every twelve months or once a year test plus or minus thirty days) by the Safety Officer and submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.
