sections.title: QBH MAT Medication Assisted Treatment.policy FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: Procedures specified for the dispensing, administration and accounting of Methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone may not be modified without prior approval in writing from the CEO and with approval of the Governing Body.
Dispensing: Providing medication for consumption in the program facility under the direct observation of   the nursing staff.
Take Home Medication: Providing medication in an appropriate labeled-t tamper/child proof container for consumption outside the clinic.

It is the policy of QBH to use medication in conjunction with cognitive behavioral therapies to treatment mild, moderate, and severe opiate dependence. Methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone, buprenorphine and naltrexone are available based upon medical diagnosis of the severity of the opiate dependence.

Each applicant who is accepted for admission to QBH for severe to moderate opiate dependence shall be determined by the staff to be currently physiologically dependent upon narcotics and shall have first become physiologically dependent at least one (1) year before admission to methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone maintenance and meet 6 or more of the diagnostics criteria in accordance with the DSM V.

An applicant for admission who has been in treatment and subsequently detoxified from methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone maintenance may be readmitted to methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone maintenance without evidence to support a finding of current physiological dependence up to six (6) months or more as determined from the program attended.  The program physician, in their reasonable clinical judgment, may find readmission to methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone maintenance treatment to be medically justified.

The Medical Director/program physician have the sole authority to admit customers to, and discharge consumers from, the Methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone Maintenance Modality and as such shall provide special documentation of the rationale for use of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone (considered to be Schedule II drug) in the consumer’s record.

Methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone are used to address the physiological problems as an adjunct to counseling and/or other substance abuse treatment. Methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone have three major effects: prevention of withdrawal symptoms, prevention of opioid cravings, and blocking the euphoric effects of opioid drugs
A complete physical, which includes laboratory tests, is performed on all consumers upon admission.  Results of this examination are documented in the consumer record.
The program physician completes the criteria for admission for all new intakes.
The Medical Director reviews each consumer record based on medical documentation of initial interview that certifies consumer as meeting the criteria for admission.
See the Referral, Screening and Intake Policy for more specifics on this process.

subpolicies.title: ADVERSE REACTIONS TO METHADONE, BUPRENORPHINE AND NALTREXONE/BUPRENORPHINE NALTEXONE

blocks.text: The nurse administering medication will observe the consumer and report any side effects.
The nurse will report any adverse reaction to methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone to the Medical Director immediately.
The nurse shall not medicate a consumer who appears intoxicated or under the influence of other drugs.
See the Medication Management Policy for more details related to identification and management of adverse reactions.

subpolicies.title: RISKS OF COMPLICATIONS FROM USE OF METHADONE, BUPRENORPHINE AND NALTREXONE

blocks.text: Upon admission, each consumer is informed of the possible adverse reactions methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone may produce.
Each consumer reviews and signs the Consent to Methadone, buprenorphine and/or naltrexone Treatment. This document explains the benefits and side effects of Methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone.
Methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone are prescribed to consumers after the program physician determines the benefits associated with use outweigh the risks.
All pregnant consumers are referred to DMC Hutzel Hospital for prenatal care and substance abuse treatment.
Consumers are seen by the program physician at least once every sixty (60) days.

subpolicies.title: RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH LONG TERM USE OF METHADONE, BUPRENORPHINE AND NALTREXONE

blocks.text: The program physician will provide a justification for continuance of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone for each consumer annually.
The risks associated with the use of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone include:
Risk of inappropriate admission to methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone maintenance.
Risk of adverse reaction to methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone.
Risk of complication from the use of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone and other drugs.
Risk of diversion of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone.
Risk associated with long-term use of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone.

In order to minimize the risks listed above, QBH has implemented the following procedures. These procedures have been reviewed by the Medical Director. These systems and processes are implemented to facilitate safe and effective medication use.
Orders for Methadone, buprenorphine and/or naltrexone may be placed by the Medical Director or Program Sponsor.  See the Medication Management Policy for more details relative to medication orders.

All supplies of Methadone, buprenorphine and/or naltrexone delivered to the program shall be accepted and received by the Medical Director, Physician, Program Sponsor or Nurse. The arrival date, quantity received, lot and bottle numbers are recorded in the stock file by the person accepting the shipment.

A perpetual inventory is kept on the Methadone quart bottles, and buprenorphine tablets, naltrexone doses in the nursing station. When medication is removed from the safe, the number of bottles, doses and quantity is     subtracted from the total. The nurse then identifies each bottle, before opening a new bottle for dispensing, in the computer. The computer automatically computes the total milligrams by multiplying the quantity of each bottle by the total number of bottles. Each consumer’s methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone dose is             automatically subtracted by the computer.  See the Storage, Inventory and Inspection Policy for more specifics.
A daily inventory will be conducted by counting each quart bottle of Methadone, buprenorphine bills, naltrexone, and the empty bottles in the safe.
The inventory is completed at opening, shift change and the close of each day.
The inventory will be maintained on the bottle summary from the computer which is generated each time there is a delivery of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone.
The original of the inventory will remain in the dispensary area and the copy will go to Utilization and Quality Manager.
Persons   qualified to   dispense (administer) methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone in the clinic includes the following:
A fully licensed physician (M.D. or D.O.);
A fully licensed R.N.;
A fully licensed L.P.N.; and
A fully licensed B.Ph.
All such persons must demonstrate their current license to practice in their discipline and such documentation, and primary source verification, can be found in their personnel files.

Physician orders will be written in duplicate on prescription blanks. The order musts include the consumer's name, I.D. number, the dose, the days during which the dose is to be administered (maximum of31 days may be ordered), and the physician's name. One dose level only should be written on a prescription blank.

The order is forwarded in duplicate to the nurse for recording in the computer in the nursing station. The original is filled in the nursing station and the copy is maintained by the physician. Prescriptions are maintained for five (5) consecutive years.
The medication dosage is monitored at least every sixty (60) days by the physician to establish the desired clinical effect.  The goal is:
Prevent the onset of subjective signs of opiate absence syndrome for 24 hours or more
Reduce or eliminate the drug hunger or craving
Block the effects of illicit acquired, self-administered opiates without inducing persistent euphonic or other under desirable affects that are experienced by the consumer or noticed by others.
The consumer continues on a current dose of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone because of the following reasons:
The treatment staff feels maintenance dosage is still necessary
Consumer has continued the use of illicit drugs;
Consumer is not ready to detox at this time; or
Other (be specific).
Dose of medication is adjusted if the program switches from one generic formulation to another and differences in effective dose cause clinically relevant complaints.

The initial dose of methadone is based upon physician examination and history of present condition of consumer. Thirty (30) mg is the initial minimum dose of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone; it shall not exceed 40 mg unless the physician documents that 40 mg does not suppress opiate abstinence symptoms.
A basis pump test is done to assist in accurate dispensing of methadone on a daily basis. Cups with 10 cc measurements are used to aid in dispense of accurate medication amounts.

The initial dose of buprenorphine should be between 2 and 8 mg. The initial dose should not be greater than 8mg. The following factors must be taken into consideration when considering the initial dose of buprenorphine:
The first dose of buprenorphine should be administered at least 6 hours after the last heroin use, or 12 hours after a short - acting prescription opioid use.

Care should be taken by prescribing doctor and nursing staff, not to administer the first dose to a consumer within 6 hours of heroin or opioid use, and especially not to consumers intoxicated on opioids. If they do, the consumer may experience precipitated opioid withdrawal, as the buprenorphine displaces heroin and opioids from the opioid receptors.

Buprenorphine-precipitated withdrawal typically begins 1- 4 hours after the first buprenorphine dose, is generally mild to moderate in severity, and lasts for up to 12 hours. If this happens, consumers may require symptomatic withdrawal medication.
Subsequent doses of buprenorphine (taken the following day) should result in light or minimal withdrawal discomfort if the consumer has not used heroin or opioids during the intervening period.

Consumers who continue to use heroin or opioids between their first and second doses of buprenorphine may have difficulty stabilizing on the treatment, with ongoing features of opioid withdrawal. They should be advised to cease heroin or short-acting opioids use at least 6 hours prior to the next dose of buprenorphine.

Naltrexone (Nalorex, Bristol-Myers Squibb Pharmaceuticals Ltd or Vivitrol, Alkermes) is an opioid antagonist with a high affinity for opioid receptors. This medication can be dosed at 50 mg daily, or may also be taken three times weekly, dosing with two 100 mg doses followed by one 150 mg dose.

The intramuscular injection is housed in a polymer microsphere and is released in phases via diffusion and polymer erosion. The initial phases within the first 24 hours and releases the drug located on the surface at the injection site.

Once the injection site undergoes hydration, which typically happens within 48 hours, the sustained-release phase occurs over the next 30 days. There does not appear to be a weight dependent nor first pass metabolism impact.
The consumer may be prescribed oral naltrexone in the case where they are unable to arrive for the next 30 days of injection.

subpolicies.title: PREPARATION OF METHADONE, BUPRENORPHINE AND NALTREXONE DOSES

blocks.text: The physician prescribes a dose of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone and records the order in the consumer's record. The nurse transcribes the physician order for each consumer into the computer. New doses and changes are recorded in the computer.
On take out days, the nurse prints out the labels, places the labels on the bottle of Methadone medication, and buprenorphine's seals and distributes to consumers.
In accordance with State rules (MAPS) system, Methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone take out doses are periodically notified to the Board of Pharmacy.

Consumers shall be encouraged to medically withdrawal (gradually tapering off dose over time) to achieve the elimination of tolerance and physical dependence to methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone, after resolution of social issues and when desired by the consumer in partnership with the physician and treatment team.
In women of child bearing age, (LMP) last menstrual period will be reviewed before beginning medical withdrawal.

Transferring from methadone maintenance or long-acting opioid treatment: Buprenorphine has a higher affinity for µ opioid receptors than methadone and all other prescribed opioids, but a weaker action (lower intrinsic activity) at these receptors. When methadone/long-acting opioid consumers take a dose of buprenorphine, the methadone/long-acting opioid is displaced from the µ­ opioid receptors by buprenorphine. Consumers on low doses of methadone (e.g., less than 30 mg) generally tolerate this transition with minimal discomfort. However, consumers on higher doses of methadone may find the replacement of methadone with buprenorphine precipitates transient opioid withdrawal.
See the Medically Assisted Withdrawal Policy for more specific guidelines.
When changing a methadone quart bottle:
Measure the amount of methadone remaining in the closing bottle by pouring it into a graduated cylinder;
Input the measured amount into the computer in the field designated for the transfer amount;
Verify the measured transfer amount on the Dispensing Log, and record the amount of methadone measured out of the bottle and sign;
Check the closing bottle number on the computer, making sure it matches the lot number indicated on the bottle; and
Check the bottle number of the opening bottle, making sure both the lot number and the amount of methadone being transferred into the bottle are correct.

If there is any problem performing any of the above steps, do not proceed to dispense medication to consumers. Immediately request assistance from peer staff or a     licensed supervisor. If a problem persists contact the FCO or QAI coordinator.

If   the amount of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone transferred   is     greater   than 500 milligrams, record   it   separately on the Methadone, buprenorphine and    naltrexone   Bottle Transfer (MBT) Log; notify and receive the signature of your supervisor or designee.

If there is breakage, cracking or otherwise a breach of bottle integrity, bypass using the bottle. Write an incident report detaining the description of the problem with the bottle and notify your supervisor and the CEO immediately.
The dispensing process is as follows:
The consumer gives identification to the receptionist and a picture I.D.
The     receptionist reviews the consumer computer ledger
The receipt is approved by the receptionist
The consumer takes the receipt and picture ID to the dispensing window and presents them to the nurse
The nurse pulls up the consumer's medication record on the computer, compares it with the picture ID, engages the computer pump which dispenses the prescribed dose into a       cup
The consumer signs the signature sheet indicating the dose was received
The nurse gives the consumer the medication
The consumer drinks the dose, speaks to the nurse and disposes of the cup in the waste container at the dispensing station
The nurse saves the medication record to the computer file
The nurse files the original dispensing records in the nursing station at the end of the day in addition to the electronic record stored in the data base.
At the close of the business day, a no-show report and a bottle summary report that reports the total mgs dispensed are prepared and filed with the dispensing records for the day.
Once a week, a weekly summary report and termination list is generated of all consumers and maintained in the nursing station.
Spillage of methadone while dispensing to a consumer is documented in the consumer record, on the Spillage Log, and in the computer.
The Spillage Log, consumer record and computer files are monitored and evaluated by Utilization and Quality Manager and/or designee.
Repeated incidents of spillage, regardless of the amount, will result in personnel action.
Spillages of methadone, during non-dispensing action are written on an Incident Report and given to the nurse’s supervisor by the close of the business day.
Failure to comply with policies and procedures will result in personnel action up to but not limited to termination.

In the event of computer failure beyond our control, medication dispensing will be done with the hand pump and/or 10 cc syringes to place the prescribed dose in the cups. The weekly dispensing summary/consumer record will be used to determine the consumer's dosage to be dispensed.

In the event that we are unable to receive a delivery from the distributor, staff will activate the terms of its contingency agreement. The contingency site agreement, available in the administrative files, covers contingency medication services to purchase methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone from another treatment facility.
Only the FCO is authorized to make adjustments/error corrections that have been documented and validated.
Adjustments/error corrections are maintained in a Log that is retained in the safe.

Each adjustment requires the FCO's and the supervisors' signatures; date of error; date of adjustment/correction; and a clear description of the adjustment including, but not necessarily limited to lot number(s) and methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone amount(s).

subpolicies.title: SECURITY RESTRICTIVE USE OF PERSONAL DISPENSING CODES

blocks.text: Dispensing staff is responsible for all dispenses recorded under their personal dispensing code (initials and passwords).
Dispensing achievements and errors are traced to individual dispensing codes and are reported monthly through quality reports to the Clinical Committee.
Errors are confirmed by peer review and when validated, progressive discipline is initiated.
Document and report any unauthorized use of your code to your supervisor, Medical Director, CEO or Utilization and Quality Manager promptly.
To aid in no other staff using your personal code, always log out when leaving the computer.

Under the   supervision of the CEO, an appropriately trained or experienced individual makes at least bi-monthly inspections of all drug storage units, including emergency boxes, emergency supplies in cars, and    stock drug supplies.
Monitoring is an overall responsibility of the Utilization and Quality Manager.

Incident reports are written on the day of the incident, original is attached to dispensing records and copy is forwarded to the Site Supervisor by the close of business. If the Site Supervisor is not available, deliver the Incident Report to the Site Supervisor upon their arrival or immediately upon your arrival the next working day. If the Site Supervisor is not available the morning following the incident, contact the Utilization and Quality Manager immediately.

Upon review of the Incident Report take remedial actions, as appropriate, within your authority. This may include closing the building, restricting staff movement within the building, searching the building, staff’s personal property and may include getting authorization for you or a designee to personally search the dispensing area.
The Site Supervisor writes an addendum to the Incident Report which includes by is not necessarily limited to, observations, actions taken, recommendations, an/or comments about the incident.

The CEO and the Utilization and Quality Manager, upon receipt of the Incident Report, may require an internal investigation, which includes, but is not necessarily limited to: interviewing staff, suspending staff during the investigation, defining the regulations and/or licensing violations, as indicated in QBH’s Personnel Management Policy.
The Utilization and Quality Manager prepares a monthly trended report of incidents.
Findings of internal investigations are completed within 72 hours of incident.
Failure to report incidents in accordance with Company policies may result in personnel action up to and including termination of the involved staff.

Notify your immediate supervisor, preferably in person, or if necessary, communicate via telephone. If your supervisor is not available, leave a voice mail indicating what has happened.  If your supervisor does not respond to your message within one (1) hour, contact your supervisor's supervisor.

subpolicies.title: In the event your supervisor is available, assist in closing the building; restricting staff movement within the building; and searching the building.  If your supervisor is   unavailable, wait for directions from your supervisor's supervisor.

blocks.text: Prepare a written incident report detailing what you know happened; who else knows; and who was near the incident scene in the last twenty-four (24) hours prior to the discovery or recognition of the discovery; and what and/or who was searched.
Delivery of the report to a peer or licensed supervisor for counter signature, preferably the licensed staff nearest you at the time of discovery.

Together, both signers of the Incident Report deliver the report to your supervisor, by the close of the business day. If your supervisor is unavailable, make direct contract with one of the following staff:
President/CEO or
Medical Director
Utilization and Quality Manger and arrange for the Incident Report exchange.
The president/CEO or board member will notify DEA within 24 hours of discovery of theft verbally and in writing.
The report will be submitted on line on DEA form 106 - https://www.deadivers.usdoj.gov/webforms/dtLoginSolicit.do

A sentinel event is an unexpected occurrence involving death or serious physical or psychological injury, or the risk thereof. Serious injury specifically includes loss of limb or function. The phrase, "or the risk thereof" includes any process variation for which a recurrence would carry a significant chance of a serious adverse outcome.  See the Sentinel Event Policy for more details relative to the process.

Such events are called "sentinel" because they signal the need for immediate investigation and response. For this purpose, thereof QBH defines unexpected theft, possible loss of methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone and medication error as an event that would chance a serious adverse outcome. The staff physician will be notified immediately of any medication error.

QBH will utilize the incident reporting process as the indicator to conduct timely, through and credible root cause analysis in developing an action plan designed to implement improvement to reduce risk; implement improvement; and monitor the effectiveness of the improvements.
The root cause analysis will focus on systems and processes, not on individual performance.
The root cause analysis will result in the development of an action plan that identifies strategies that QBH intends to implement in order to reduce the risk.
The plan shall include the responsibility for implementation, oversight, pilot testing as appropriate, time lines and strategies for measuring the effectiveness of the actions.
The root cause analysis and action plan shall be completed within 45 calendar days of the event.
The root cause analysis must be considered acceptable, thorough and credible. Characteristics of an acceptable root cause analysis are:
Focused primarily on underlying systems and processes, not on individual performance
Progresses from special causes in clinical processes to common causes in Company processes
Repeatedly digs deeper by asking 'Why?", then, when answered, "Why?" again and so on

An inquiry into all areas appropriate to the specific type of event such as: consumer identification process, staffing levels, orientation and training of staff, competency assessment/credentialing, supervision of staff, communication among staff members, availability of information, technological support, equipment maintenance/ management, physical environment, control of medications, storage/access and labeling of medications.
An identification of risk points and their potential contributions to this type of event.

A determination of potential improvement in processes or systems that would tend to decrease the likelihood of such events in the future, or a determination, after analysis, that no such improvement opportunity exists
Characteristics of a credible root cause analysis are:
Include participation by the leadership of QBH and by the individuals most closely involved in the processes and systems under review
Be internally consistent (that is, not contradict itself or leave obvious questions unanswered)
Include consideration of any relevant literature
Action plans are considered acceptable if it results in the following:
Identifies changes that can be implemented to reduce risk or formulates a rationale for not undertaking such changes

Identifies, in situations where improvement actions are planned, who is responsible for implementation, when the action will be implemented (including pilot testing) and how the effectiveness of the actions will be evaluated
This process will typically require a measure of success (MOS) or follow -up survey within six months.

Sentinel events are reported to the Detroit Wayne County Mental Health Authority (DWMHA) by the next business day.  A written report of the root cause analysis will be provided to DWMHA within 45 days of occurrence.
QBH is encouraged to report, but not mandated to report the following to Joint Commission:
Unanticipated death
Major permanent loss of function related to the natural course of a consumer’s illness or underlying condition
Suicide

sections.title: QBH MAT Medication Control Storage Inventory Inspection.policy  FINAL 7 17

subpolicies.title: POLICY:  MEDICATION CONTROL: STORAGE, INVENTORY AND INSPECTION

blocks.text: Medications are controlled in compliance with all applicable laws, regulations and standards pertinent to medications and controlled substances, including substances used in opiate treatment.  Medication inspections include monitoring for these compliance requirements.
Keep medication in the container it came in, tightly closed, at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture.
All controlled substances must be stored behind at least two differently keyed locks at all times.

Double locked: This means that two locks must be in place to adequately secure the controlled substances.  A door that is locked when authorized personnel (the nurse or MD) are absent can serve as one of the “locks.”
Within the storage area, controlled substances must be secured within a locked safe that cannot be moved or transported.
For keyed safe:  do not store the keys near the lockbox; and do not store the keys together

For combination lock safe: only the CEO, Medical Director and shift charge nurse shall know the combination and whenever anyone who knows the combination is terminated from employment, the combination(s) must be changed

Opiate medications are stored in a safe of substantial construction that has an inner and outer door with the locks for each door keyed differently.   The safe is equipped with an alarm system which, upon attempted unauthorized entry, shall transmit a signal directly to a central protection company or local or state policy agency which has the legal duty to respond.  Which is it?

The safe shall remain locked at all times when methadone/controlled substances are not being taken from (for dispensing or administration) or returned to storage.  Please be aware that DEA regulations require that the safe be secured.

Store separately: Controlled substances should be separated from other drugs or other hazardous chemicals.  This practice will help to prevent loss by limiting access to only those who are assigned to work specifically with controlled substances.   Opiate medications are stored separately from other controlled substances.
Never leave unattended: When in use, controlled substances should never be left unattended.

Report loss or theft immediately:  Authorized personnel are expected to report missing controlled substances to their supervisor, the CEO, and the State Public Safety Office as soon as the loss is discovered.  Public safety and law enforcement officials will investigate the diversion, loss, or theft of controlled substances. If any imminent safety threat exists, contact Public Safety directly at 911. In addition, upon discovery of the theft of significant loss of any controlled substance, notify the DEA.

Serious consequences for misuse: It is the position of the DEA that staff who possess, sell, use or divert controlled substances will subject themselves not only to a State or Federal prosecution for any illicit activity, but shall also immediately become subject of independent action by QBH regarding their continued employment. The CEO will assess the violation and determine whether to suspend, transfer, terminate or take other action against the staff member.  Actions may include administrative, civil, or criminal prosecution.  The DEA can impose a fine on a licensed nurse or LIP for each and every violation that it finds.

Security is imperative:  Regardless of the source of the methadone/controlled substance, materials must be securely locked. A two key security system must be in place. Controlled substances must be accessible only to those who passed the background check by the DEA and their authorized personnel and are used only for legitimate methadone treatment purposes.
Order and store only the minimum amount of methadone/controlled substances necessary for planned treatment.

Multiple storage areas: Where several types or classes of controlled substances are handled separately for different purposes (e.g., to be returned/destroyed, awaiting use/administration), the controlled substances may be stored separately, provided that each storage area complies with the requirements set forth in this policy.

Accessibility to storage areas: The methadone/controlled substances storage areas shall be accessible only to an absolute minimum number of specifically authorized staff. When it is necessary for maintenance personnel, business guests, or visitors to be present in or pass-through controlled substances storage areas, the CEO shall provide for adequate observation of the area by a staff specifically authorized in writing.

Disposal: For a patient at home, flush any methadone tablets or solution that is outdated or no longer needed down the toilet. For QBH, follow the disposal of methadone medication method directed by the dispensing pharmacy.
Follow all other additional storage guidelines as applies for any medications as spelled out in the various medication related policies.

No on-site pharmacy services are provided at QBH, Inc.  Medications used on-site in programs are purchased through authorized, contracted pharmacy services that are available 24/7. Medications are delivered by the pharmacy 1-2 times a day or as quickly as possible if need for the medication is urgent.

When pharmacy delivers the medications, the deliverer and the nurse go through the manifest for each consumer and check it against the consumer’s medication orders for accuracy. Any bulk medications are also reviewed against the order.  Each party gets a copy of the signed manifest once this inspection is completed; nursing retains these manifests in a designated binder.
If there has been an error, it is noted on the manifest and the pharmacy corrects the dispensing error as soon as possible.  The correction is noted on the new manifest.
If there has been a dispensing error, an Incident Report is completed by the nurse and submitted according to Incident Reporting Policy.

subpolicies.title: MEDICATION STORAGE OF NON-OPIATE TREATMENT MEDICATIONS

blocks.text: Storage methods shall promote availability of medications when needed, minimize the risk of medication diversion and reduce the potential for preparation and/or administration errors.  Sound-alike and look-alike medications shall have the name of the medication color highlighted on the MAR to alert the administering nurse of this high-risk situation.

Any medications stored on Company property shall be stored in the Nurses’ office, which is a locked area, to which only nursing staff has a key, with the exception of samples which are stored in a locked closet in a separate area, to which only the CEO has a key.

Storage is at room temperature unless refrigeration is needed.  Medications needing refrigeration are kept in a refrigerator in the Nurses’ Office dedicated to that use.  If they are for a specific consumer, as opposed to multi-use medications, the medications are placed in a plastic bag with the consumer’s name on it.

Daily temperature recordings are taken of the refrigerator to maintain the medications at a temperature between 37- and 45-degrees F.  If there should be a refrigerator temperature failure, the medications will be stored in an ice chest until the Nurses’ Office refrigerator is repaired.
Food products, other than juices, pudding or applesauce that are to be used to help a consumer swallow medication, shall not be stored in medication refrigerators.
Lab specimens shall not be stored in a refrigerator designated for medications.

All medications are kept locked in a designated area. Any medications delivered to the program shall be received and accepted by a nurse and delivered to the secured, designated area immediately. Any medications stored on-site shall be correctly labeled according to legal and regulatory requirements.
Oral medications are stored in each consumer’s individual medication box within the Nurses’ Office, in a designated storage area, unless refrigeration is required.

Narcotics, sedatives and Suboxone are stored separately in a locked safe in the Nurses’ Office.  A count of these drugs is made and documented by both nurses when there is a change of nursing staff.  These documents are kept in a binder designated for that purpose.
Topical medications are stored in the Nurses’ Office within a plastic bag with the consumer’s name and then stored in the consumer’s individual medication box.

Eye drops are also stored in the Nurses’ Office within a plastic bag with the consumer’s name and stored either in the refrigerator or in the consumer’s individual medication box, as appropriate to the medication.
Multiple-dose vials for injection shall be dated when opened and shall not be used past the expiration date recommended by the manufacturer.
Over the counter medications, such as Tylenol, Mylanta, MOM, aspirin and cough syrup, are kept in a separate box within the medication storage area.

Stock medications shall only be used when the medication orders originate from within the program so that only properly labeled medication is removed and it is removed only in amount sufficient to meet immediate therapeutic needs.
Medications brought to QBH by consumers shall not be stored at QBH MAT program facilities.  Consumers are instructed at orientation to not bring medications with them to the program.

subpolicies.title: MEDICATION STORAGE OF OPIATE TREATMENT MEDICATIONS

blocks.text: Storage methods shall promote availability of medications when needed, minimize the risk of medication diversion and reduce the potential for preparation and/or administration errors.
Any medications stored on Company property shall be stored in the Nurses’ office, which is a locked area, to which only nursing staff has a key.
Storage is at room temperature.  If they are for a specific consumer, as opposed to multi-use medications, the medications are placed in a plastic bag with the consumer’s name on it.

All medications are kept locked in a designated area. Any medications delivered to the program shall be received and accepted by a nurse and delivered to the secured, designated area immediately. Any medications stored on-site shall be correctly labeled according to legal and regulatory requirements.
Opiate medications are stored in a DEA approved safe that is constructed to withstand the following:
30 man-minutes against surreptitious entry,
10 man-minutes against forced entry,
20 man-hours against lock manipulation, and
20 man-hours against radiological techniques
The safe must weigh over 750 pounds or be bolted or cemented to the floor or wall in such a way that it cannot be readily removed.

The safe must be equipped with an alarm system, which upon unauthorized entry will transmit a signal directly to a central station protection company, a police department, or a 24-hour control station operated by the program. The program’s safe has been determined by the local DEA diversion office to require an alarm system.

As additional security the program Site Administrator shall change security codes and dispensing area locks/keys and lock combinations when dispensing personnel resign or are terminated from employment.

Staff administering and consumers taking medications are instructed in sanitary, safe handling of medications, of whatever form.  Consumers are monitored for proper handling of their medications and given re-instruction as needed.
HAZMAT containers are available for disposal of biohazardous materials associated with medication administration.  Needles are not to be re-capped; whenever possible self-sheathing needles are used.
Any mishandling of medications that causes injury, including finger sticks, is reportable on an Incident Report as per policy.

Outdated non-opiate medications or non-opiate medications to be disposed of or returned to a pharmacy shall be placed in a grey tote box and kept in a separate, well-marked area till picked up by the pharmacy.  Pharmacy picks up this box daily.  There is no on-site disposal of medications.

Medications left by AMA consumers are stored in a safe in the Nurses’ Office for 72 hours after which time they are disposed of. If medications left by AMA consumers are not collected by the consumer within 72 hours, the destruction is noted on the consumer’s MAR.
HAZMAT containers and red bagged items are picked up by a contracted waste disposal company monthly.  A manifest of the transaction id provided and maintained in a binder designated for that purpose.

The procedures program staff uses when reporting/recording the destruction and disposal of individual doses of medication that are spilled differ from the procedures used when there are accountable losses of bulk inventory.
When spillage of an individual consumer dose occurs, the following should take place:
The staff who spilled the medication or who witnessed a consumer spilling the medication should immediately report the incident to a supervisor.
After the spilling of medication has been reported to a supervisor, the medication should be properly disposed of.
Documentation of spillage should be completed, indicating the drug, its strength and amount, and the date of spillage and signed by both the staff involved and a supervisor.
Documentation of spillage should be maintained in a readily retrievable manner and reviewed periodically to determine if a pattern is developing.
Documentation of spillage does not need to be sent to the local DEA diversion field office, but should be available for inspection by DEA.

Any liquid or dust resulting from a spill or from the process of compounding diskettes should not be sent to DEA. Rather, these materials should be disposed of immediately in a manner that will prevent any further use of the medication, and should be witnessed by the staff involved and the supervisor.
This disposal is documented by the program and maintained in our records in a readily retrievable manner.

Controlled substance bulk inventory lost through breakage, damage, or spillage (other than an individual consumer dose) is considered an accountable loss. Disposal of such controlled substances must be in accordance with DEA requirements and must be reported on a DEA Form-41 (Registrants Inventory of Drugs Surrendered). [21 CFR 1307.21(a)]. General procedures for such disposal are reviewed in the section, "Disposal of Liquid or Solid Medication."

subpolicies.title: Disposal of Liquid or Solid  Medication

When the program has medication requiring destruction, the CEO or designee should contact their local DEA diversion field office for authority and instructions related to the disposal of the substances.
Procedures related to destruction and disposal include the following:

blocks.text: Any medication, regardless of form, should be destroyed if contaminated or beyond expiration date.
When medication in solid form is being used, the staff member should gather and retain all recoverable chunks or chips of the medication.

Medication to be destroyed must be listed on the DEA Form-41. The Special-Agent-in-Charge (SAC) at the local DEA diversion field office has the discretion to authorize the destruction of medication by the program, in a manner determined by the SAC.

If the local DEA diversion field office approves of the disposal, the office will instruct the program staff in the procedures to be followed. These may include the transfer of the medication to a registrant authorized to dispose of controlled substances, or by destruction in the presence of an individual from DEA or another authorized person.
When empty, methadone bottles should be rinsed out by the dispensing nurse before being disposed of in an appropriate manner.
All medication destroyed must be done with the CEO (or designated witness) present. The DEA form is completed by the nursing supervisor with the total number of milligram units and bottles destroyed.
Rationale for destroying medication is as follows:
Spillage/waste
Unidentifiable medication (no label or dose/batch record number)
Empty Methadone, documented and recorded on destruction log to deter
All methadone to be destroyed must be done with the CEO or a designated witness present.
The DEA Form 222 is completed by the Nursing Supervisor with the total number of milligram units and bottles destroyed recorded.
The only acceptable rationale for destroying methadone is in the event of spillage or related waste.  See instructions in section above.

A monthly documented inspection of drug storage area(s) for correct storage, identification of outdated medications and accurate record keeping regarding medications shall be conducted and documented by a nurse.
A documented inventory is maintained and checked as part of this inspection of all OTC medications.  Inventory of Schedule II medications is done with each change of nursing personnel.
All medication-related inventory records shall be retained for not less than five years.
The contract pharmacy also does an annual inspection of medication storage.

Each MAT program shall conduct an initial inventory of all stocks of controlled substance medications on hand on the date that the program begins operations, in conformance with DEA regulations. In the event that no controlled substance medications are on hand at this time, this fact must then be noted in the NTP’s initial inventory.

DEA also requires that after the initial inventory is taken, the program shall conduct a new physical inventory of all stocks of controlled substance medications on hand at least once every two years, which is identified as the official DEA biennial inventory. The biennial inventory may be conducted on any date within two years of the previous biennial inventory date.
QBH shall conduct inventories at least every six months as an extra safety precaution.

All supplies of Methadone or other opiate medications delivered to the QBH MAT Program shall be accepted and received by the Medical Director, a program physician, or a nurse.  The arrival date, quantity received, lot and bottle numbers are recorded on the stock file by the person receiving the shipment who shall sign; the file shall also be co-signed by the delivering party.
A perpetual inventory is kept on the Methadone quart bottles at the nursing station.
The bottles are stored in a DEA approved safe.
When removed from the safe, the number of bottles, doses and quantity is subtracted from the total.
The nurse then identifies each bottle before opening a new bottle for dispensing, in the computer.
The computer automatically computes the total milligrams by multiplying the quantity of each bottle by the total number of bottles.
Each consumer’s methadone dose is automatically subtracted by the computer.
In accordance with the MI state rules (MAPS) system, methadone take-out doses are periodically notified to the Board of Pharmacy.
A basis pump test is done to oversee accurate dispensing of methadone, on a daily basis.
cc cups are used to facilitate accurate medication dispensing.
A daily inventory is conducted by counting each quart bottle of Methadone and the empty bottles in the safe.
Inventory is counted at opening of the office and the end of the day.
Inventory is maintained on the bottle summary from the computer which is generated each time there is a delivery of Methadone.
The original of the inventory remains in the dispensary area and a copy is given to the Utilization and Quality Manager.
