sections.title: QBH MAT MEDICATION MANAGEMENT RECORDKEEPING.protocol  FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: The MAT program shall keep a record of all medication received, dispensed, administered, and destroyed. All records shall be retained for two years from the date of execution, or longer if so, stipulated by the state of MI Methadone Authority.

The program shall conduct an initial inventory of all stocks of controlled substance medications on hand on the date that the program begins operations and at least once every two years, the program shall conduct and document a physical inventory (called a "biennial inventory") of the medication on hand. These inventories must include all forms of medication on hand (i.e., liquid, tablet, diskette, or powder) as well as the quantity and strength of each medication.  As additional security, QBH’s programs shall conduct these inventories at least every six months due to the high-risk location of the program and community diversion history.

During a DEA accountability investigation, the beginning inventory used in the audit must be an actual physical inventory taken by the program. The beginning inventory selected could either be the program’s initial or biennial inventory.

The following sections summarize DEA recordkeeping and inventory requirements and recommended strategies for maintaining complete and accurate records in accordance with DEA regulations which our MAT program shall abide by.   This protocol includes information found in other medication management policies and, if there is ever discrepancy between policies and this protocol, the protocol shall supersede the policy.

subpolicies.title: The QBH MAT program does not currently compound a bulk narcotic solution from bulk narcotic powder to liquid for on-site use; however, if that should ever become a practice, the program staff shall keep a separate batch record of the compounding.

The QBH MAT program does not currently compound a bulk narcotic solution from bulk narcotic powder to liquid for on-site use; however, if that should ever become a practice, the program staff shall maintain records which include the following information:

Bulk Form: Records for each narcotic controlled substance in bulk form to be used in, or capable of use in, or being used in, the compounding of the same or other non-controlled substance in finished form must include the following information:

blocks.text: Name of the substance;
Quantity compounded in bulk form by the program staff person, including the date, quantity, and batch or other identifying number of each batch compounded;
Quantity and date received, including the name, address, and DEA number of the registrant from whom the substance was received;
Quantity used to compound the same substance in finished form, including:
Date and batch or other identifying number of each compounding;
Quantity used in the compounding;
Finished form (i.e., 10 mg tablets or 10 mg concentration per fluid ounce);
Number of units of finished form compounded;
Quantity lost during compounding and the causes, if known;
Total quantity of the substance contained in the finished form;
Theoretical and actual yields; and
Any other information necessary to account for all controlled substances used in the compounding process;

Quantity distributed in bulk form to other programs, including the date and quantity of each distribution and the name, address, and registration number of each program to whom a distribution was made; and
Quantity disposed of by destruction, including the reason, date, and manner of destruction.
Finished Form: Records for each narcotic substance in finished form must include the following information:
Name of the substance;
Finished form and the number of units or volume in each commercial container (i.e., 100­ tablet bottle or 3 ml bottle);
Number of containers of each such commercial finished form compounded from bulk form;

Number of units of finished forms and/or commercial containers received from other persons, including the date or number of units and/or commercial containers in each receipt and the name, address, and DEA registration number of the person from whom the units were received;
Number of units and/or commercial containers compounded by the program registrant from units in finished form received from others, including:
Date and batch or other identifying number of each compounding;
Operation performed (i.e., repackaging or relabeling);
Number of units of finished form used in the compound, the number compounded, and the number lost during compounding, with the causes, if known; and
Any other information necessary to account for all controlled substances used in the compounding process;

Number of containers distributed to other programs, including the date, the number of containers in each distribution, and the name, address, and DEA registration number of the program to which the containers were distributed; and
Number of units of finished forms and/or commercial containers destroyed in any manner by the program registrant, including the reason, the date, and manner of destruction.

subpolicies.title: An initial inventory is done of all stocks of controlled substance medications on hand on the date that the program begins operations. In the event that no controlled substance medications are on hand at this time, this fact must then be noted in the initial inventory.

After the initial inventory is taken, the program shall conduct a new physical inventory of all stocks of controlled substance medications on hand at least once every two years, which is identified as the official DEA biennial inventory. The biennial inventory may be conducted on any date within two years of the previous biennial inventory date.
QBH’s MAT program shall conduct an inventory at least every six months in addition to the biennial inventory.
The initial, every six months, and biennial inventory shall include the following information:

blocks.text: Date the inventory is conducted,
Time of day inventory is conducted, i.e., at the open or close of business, and
Name, dosage form, strength, and quantity of each medication on hand at the time of the opening or closing inventory.
The initials of the individual who conducted the inventory.

subpolicies.title: The program shall maintain a record of medication dispensing which contains the following information:

blocks.text: Name of substance;
Strength of substance;
Dosage form;
Date dispensed;
Adequate identification of patient (consumer);
Amount consumed;
Amount and dosage form taken home by patient; and
Dispenser's initials.

The program shall maintain these records in a Dispensing Log or use an automated/computerized data processing system for the storage and retrieval of the program’s dispensing records, that meets the following conditions:
The automated system maintains the information required in 21 CFR 1304.24(a)
The automated system has the capability of producing a hard copy printout of the program’s dispensing records
The program prints a hard copy of each day’s Dispensing Log, which is then initialed appropriately by each person who dispensed medication to the program’s consumers
The automated system is approved by DEA.
The program shall use the consumers’ names and addresses for identification in medication dispensing records.

subpolicies.title: Computer Software Requirements for Maintaining  Dispensing  Records

blocks.text: When the program uses an automated data system to maintain dispensing records, the computerized dispensing records must contain the information outlined above.

The program’s computer software program must be capable of producing accurate summary reports for any time frame selected by DEA personnel during an investigation. Further, if these summary reports are maintained in hard copy form, they shall be kept in a systematically organized and centrally located file.

subpolicies.title: REPORTING THEFT AND LOSS OF CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE MEDICATION

Immediately upon discovery of a theft or significant loss of a controlled substance medication, the program Site Supervisor or the CEO shall contact the local DEA diversion field office by telephone, facsimile, or with a brief written message explaining the circumstances. Further, a DEA Form-106, “Report of Theft or Loss of Controlled Substances”, must be filed.  The local police shall also be notified.
Issues Related to Reporting Theft and Loss

blocks.text: It is the responsibility of the program staff to use its best judgement to take appropriate action. What would constitute a significant loss for one program may be viewed as comparatively insignificant for another program.

The loss of a small quantity of controlled substance, repeated over a period of time, may indicate a significant problem for the program even though the individual amounts of missing controlled substances are not, in and of themselves, significant.
The program shall be alert for suspicious or unexplained losses. Any signs of a break in, physical entry, or armed robbery should be reported.
The burden of responsibility is on the program to identify a significant loss and make the required report to DEA.  Some factors to consider for determining significant loss include:
The quantity missing (i.e., one tablet vs. one bottle)
The name and schedule of the missing medication
The abuse potential of the missing substance in your area
Is this the first time this loss has occurred?  Has a similar loss occurred before?
Was this loss reported to local law enforcement authorities?

subpolicies.title: The final decision regarding reporting shall rest with the CEO.
DEA Form-106 (Report of Theft or Loss of Controlled Substances)

The program Medical Director or CEO shall complete a DEA Form-106 to formally document the actual circumstances of a theft or significant loss and the quantities of controlled substances involved.  However, in many cases, determining the actual circumstances may require some evaluation, review, and possible investigation.
Issues and procedures related to the determination of whether and how to use DEA Form-106 include the following:

blocks.text: If, after reviewing all the available information, it is determined that no theft or significant loss occurred, no DEA Form-106 need be filed. However, the CEO or Medical Director shall notify DEA of the results of the investigation and maintain a record of the occurrence in its loss and theft file for future reference.
If there is a question as to whether a theft or a significant loss has occurred, the Medical Director or CEO shall contact the local DEA diversion field office.
The program shall not use a DEA Form-106 to adjust inventory.

When a report is deemed required, the Medical Director or CEO shall contact the local DEA diversion field office to obtain a DEA Form-106. A completed theft and loss form should include the following information:
Name and address of program;
DEA registration number;
Date of theft;
Local police department notified;
Type of theft (night break in, armed robbery, etc.);
Listing of symbols or other identifying markings (if any) used by the program to mark containers; and
Listing of controlled substances missing from theft or significant loss (name, quantity, and strength).
The form shall be prepared in triplicate, keeping the third copy for program records, and sending the first and second copies to the local DEA diversion field office.
A DEA accountability investigation is an unannounced investigation conducted by DEA personnel of the program’s records and security measures of all controlled substances on hand.

Upon entering the premises, DEA personnel must (1) present their credentials, (2) state the purpose of their visit, and (3) present a written notice of their inspection authority (DEA Form 82 – Notice of Inspection of Controlled Premises) to the owner, operator, or agent in charge of the program.

Wherever possible, informed consent must consist of a written statement signed by the owner, operator, or agent in charge of the program, and witnessed by two persons. The written consent includes the following information:
That the owner, operator, or agent of the program:
Has been informed of his/her constitutional right not to have an administrative inspection without an Administrative Inspection Warrant (AIW),
Has the right to refuse consent to such an inspection,
Has been presented with a Notice of Inspection,
Has given his/her consent voluntarily, without threats of any kind,
May withdraw his/her consent at any time during the course of the inspection, and
Has been informed that if anything of an incriminating nature is found, it may be seized and used against him/her in a criminal prosecution.

In those cases, in which informed consent is not given, or where consent is withdrawn, DEA personnel must obtain an AIW.  If the owner, operator, or agent of the program refuses to permit the execution of an AIW, or impedes DEA personnel in the execution of an AIW, he/she is to be advised that such refusal or action constitutes a violation of the Controlled Substances Act of 1970.
Once DEA personnel have begun an accountability investigation, the owner, operator, or agent of the program must provide them with the following information by law:
The initial inventory (if the program has been open for business less than two years, or upon request of DEA Investigators);
The latest biennial inventory conducted (if the program has been in operation more than two years);
Receipts (DEA Form-222s) of the medication received since the inventory was conducted; and

Documentation of the amount of medication dispensed, spilled, returned to manufacturer, transferred to another program, missing due to theft or unexplained loss, destroyed since the inventory was conducted, or awaiting destruction.
The most recent physical inventory.

Also, during an accountability investigation, a “closing inventory” will be conducted. A closing inventory is a physical count of all of the program’s-controlled substance medications on hand as of that date. The closing inventory will be verified by an official of the program, and should be done prior to or after the day’s dispensing hours. In addition, it should be noted on the paperwork whether the closing inventory was taken at the opening or close of business hours.

DEA maintains a strict accountability policy regarding the reconciliation of all narcotic inventory medications. All registered programs must provide an accurate and complete accounting of all narcotic medication that has been received, dispensed, returned, destroyed, reported lost/stolen, or otherwise disposed of.  DEA is aware that in dealing with liquid controlled substance medications, absolute accountability is not always attainable. The program’s overall processes, procedures, and results will be taken into account in the evaluation of the outcomes of an investigation.

DEA and other federal and state regulation and policy, as well as JC standards, require that our program provide complete and accurate records. In an effort to assist staffs in their attempt to comply with these requirements, QBH employs the following strategies:
Training of staff to assist them in understanding how to operate relevant equipment, including computers;
Maintenance of appropriate back-ups for computer and other recordkeeping systems; and
Establishment of appropriate shut-down procedures to be used both at the time of dispenser shift changes and at the end of the work day.
Beyond the documentation discussed in this protocol, QBH policies address other documentation requirements associated with Medication Management.  See those policies for specifics.

sections.title: QBH MAT Medication Management.policy FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: Procedures for the dispensing, administration and accounting of methadone may not be modified without prior approval, in writing, from the CEO with approval of the Governing Board.

subpolicies.title: Cascading Order:  An order allowing a very short cascading of medication, incorporating a clinical opiate withdrawal scale (COWS) score or other objective measure in order to titrate the dose of a specific consumer only if appropriately trained and qualified, Company credentialed staff is available to evaluate the ongoing appropriateness of the physician’s treatment plan and recognize the need for the consumer to be re-evaluated prior to completion of the full course of the order.
Dispensing:   Providing medication for consumption at the MAT Program site under the direct observation of the nursing staff.

blocks.text: Guest Dosing: Guest dosing involves providing medication to a “guest consumer” in a program in which the consumer is not enrolled, such as when a consumer travels to another city for a period of temporary employment and needs to receive medication. Guest dosing is recommended for consumers who do not meet the criteria outlined in 42 CFR § 8.12 (i) (2) (i–viii). Guest dosing may prove helpful when a consumer will be remaining in an area for a protracted period, and it is impractical to return to the consumer’s home program routinely to pick up a supply of take-home medication.

High Alert/High Risk Medications: High alert medications are those involved in a high percentage of medication errors and/or sentinel events, as well as those with a higher risk for abuse or other adverse outcomes.  Typically these include investigational medications, controlled medications, medications not approved by the FDA, medications with narrow therapeutic range, psychotherapeutic medications, and look-alike/sound-alike medications.    http://www.ismp.org/Tools/highalertmedications.pdf
Methadone Risks: The risks associated with the use of methadone. The most common ones include:
Risk of inappropriate admission to methadone maintenance.
Risk of adverse reaction to methadone.
Risk of complication from the use of methadone and other drugs.
Risk of diversion of methadone.
Risk associated with long-term use of methadone.
PRN Order: An order acted on based on the occurrence of a specific indication or symptom, as needed.
Range Order: Orders in which the dose or dosing interval varies over a prescribed range, depending on the situation or status of the consumer served.

Standing Order: A prewritten medication order and specific instructions from the prescriber to administer the medication to a consumer in clearly defined circumstances as specified in the instructions.
Taper Order: Orders in which the dose is decreased by a particular amount with each dosing interval.
The phone number of the Poison Control Center is posted in the following locations:
Nurses’ Office
Medical Practitioner Offices
At each phone
At the office waiting area
On each emergency kit
The Safety Officer is to monitor for continued compliance at each safety inspection.
An Approved Abbreviation List and Do Not Use Abbreviation List will be maintained and kept posted in the Nurses’ Office/Medication Room and in the Medical staff’s office at all times.

A medication history is obtained for each consumer served by QBH, Inc.  The medication history will specifically provide a written record of prescribed medication, OTC medication, herbals, and nutritional supplements, and any illicit drug use that each consumer is currently taking as well as any known drug allergies.  This information is documented on the Medication Record in the Electronic Medical Record (EMR).  Drug allergies are also noted on the Medication Administration Record (MAR) in red ink and on the Medication Record in the EMR.  The Medication Record, if not initially entered into the EMR, will be included in the EMR at discharge but shall be retained in the Nurses’ Office until discharge.
Specific information to be obtained from the history includes, not exclusively:
Past medication use, including effectiveness and side effects
Identification of tobacco, alcohol and other drug use, caffeine use, and over the counter medication or homeopathic supplement use
For pregnant or childbearing women, any medication use
Special dietary needs or restrictions related to medications
History of medication errors, medication compliance, adverse reactions, allergies
Any medical co-morbidity

The medication history will be done at the time of intake or before the initial treatment plan. The nurse and/or counselor will be responsible for obtaining medication history information.  The nurse and/or counselor shall maintain a current list of medications prescribed during the course of treatment.

Once the intake assessments are completed, the physician is given a list of the medications that the consumer is currently taking and information regarding any existing medical co-morbidity.  The physician reconciles the list and documents on the Medication Reconciliation Form. As part of reconciliation the physician evaluates the potential impact of any medical co-morbidity on medication effect and the potential for any drug interactions, including with OTC or homeopathic supplements.

Likewise, the nurse and/or assigned counselor shall provide a list of those medications the program physician wants continued at discharge on the Medication Reconciliation Form.  At discharge the consumer, the consumer’s Primary Care Practitioner (PCP), if known, and any provider continuing care of the consumer after discharge shall receive a copy of the Medication Record with consumer consent.

The nurse will be responsible for obtaining medication history information at a regular interval (at least quarterly) for MAT consumers, in addition to urine drug screening according to the schedule planned for that consumer.  If the consumer reports no medication changes this will be documented in a progress note.

If the consumer leaves against medical advice (AMA) before the nurse and/or counselor can provide the final Medication Record, it will be mailed to the last known address, unless the consumer is homeless in which case provision to the consumer is not possible.

The following information about the consumer shall be accessible in the medication administration area and in the consumer’s record for all staff who participate in any aspect of the medication management process:
Age
Sex
Diagnoses/conditions
Allergies and sensitivities
Height and weight, as applicable
Drug and alcohol use and abuse specifics
Current medications
Pregnancy and lactation information, as applicable
Any additional information pertinent to a particular consumer

subpolicies.title: A list of high alert/high risk medications shall be maintained visible in the physician’s office and in medication administration areas.  This list is reviewed and recommended by the Medical Director and is approved by the Clinical Committee at least annually.  Management of these medications is addressed in the Medication Storage Policy.

blocks.text: A state-defined formulary is maintained in the Electronic Medical Record (EMR) that reflects all medications authorized for prescription by prescribing staff.  The Medical Director shall review the formulary periodically.  Prescribers may occasionally use medications outside the formulary but shall attempt to keep such use minimal.  Whenever possible generic forms of medications shall be prescribed; if a generic version is unavailable and an alternative generic is not an option, or if the generic version is insufficiently effective, the non-generic version may be employed; justification must be documented in the physician’s notes.

subpolicies.title: At this time, methadone and the buprenorphine products, Subutex and Suboxone, are approved for use in the MAT program. Such treatment is not subject to the “30-consumer limit” placed on physicians certified under the Drug Addiction Treatment Act (DATA) of 2000 or to the 100-consumer limit placed on physicians under The Office of National Drug Control Policy Reauthorization Act of 2006. In addition, the special credentialing and 8-hour training requirements under that law do not apply to methadone and buprenorphine treatment for consumers admitted to the MAT program.
Persons who are qualified to dispense (administer) methadone include:
These persons must maintain a current license in their personnel files to be qualified to dispense (administer).

blocks.text: The clinical and nursing staff shall receive periodic education on medication assisted treatment as well as on other medications commonly used in the MAT program either from the pharmacy instruction sheets, The Physicians’ Desk Reference (PDR) or nursing medication handbook, and/or the contracted training service to include, but not exclusively:
Medication assisted treatment (see Personnel Management Policy for more details)
Commonly prescribed medications, including their uses and side effects
Detox protocol medications and side effects, if applicable to job
Adverse drug reaction symptoms
New research findings related to medications being prescribed at QBH, Inc.
Information on new medications added to the formulary and being prescribed at QBH, Inc.

At hire and at least annually, medication education that covers the content listed above for consumers/guardians is provided to staff if applicable to their job duties.  Training is documented in the Human Resources (HR) personnel file.

Education may be provided formally through the staff development system, by disbursement of written information, by video or other available educational aids.  In addition, staff is expected to take initiative for becoming educated on medications as relevant to their job duties.

When a consumer is placed on a new medication to which staff is unfamiliar, nursing staff will provide education face-to-face with counselor staff.    A Certificate of Training is completed and submitted to the Office Manager to include in each staff’s HR personnel file.
Reconciliation of the current medication list is completed each time medication is being ordered by the physician.
Decisions about the use of medication as part of treatment are made in conjunction with the consumer and/or guardian, if applicable.

Medication orders are not considered complete unless the physician includes the name of the medication; the dose and strength to be used; the route for medication administration; dosage frequency and/or timing for each dose; the purpose, diagnosis or indication for use of the medication.
Verbal orders can be accepted on by a nurse and should be used as infrequently as possible.
Verbal orders must be signed by the ordering physician within 72 hours.
The verbal order has documentation that the nurse recorded, read back, and verified each verbal order received.
Nursing staff shall not administer a medication if an order is incomplete, illegible, or unclear until first clarified with the ordering physician and corrected in the consumer’s record.
Any pre-printed order sheets are monitored to see that they support clarity, accuracy and safety.
Blanket orders to resume a medication are not allowed.

Program physicians will start high-risk medications at the lowest dose to control the consumer’s signs and symptoms of their diagnoses.  Increases will be made slowly in small increments until the desired effect is obtained.  Dosages will not exceed manufacturers’ recommendations. Physicians will not start any high-risk medications until the consumer has been weighed unless it is an emergency situation.
For look-alike or sound-alike drugs the following applies:
Maintain awareness of look-alike and sound-alike drugs.
Clearly specify the dosage, drug strength, and complete directions on prescriptions.
Include the purpose of medication on prescriptions.
Red stickers will be put on look-alike or sound-alike drugs.
Encourage consumers to question nurses about medications they are not familiar with or look or sound different than expected.
Give verbal or telephone orders only when truly necessary.
A sign of look-alike and sound-alike drugs will be placed in view of Nurses’ Workstation.

Standing Orders are ordered by the physician; if there are any contraindications, nursing staff identifies and documents the contraindications. Standing orders are not used in regard to the dose, schedule or re-administration of methadone because of the unique pharmacologic properties, the well-established potential for fatalities in the induction period, and the risk of relapse during medically supervised withdrawal.

Verbal and/or telephone orders shall be used as infrequently as possible.  When use is necessary, only a nurse shall receive/accept the order.  S/he shall document the order and read it back to check for accuracy of understanding.  S/he shall denote with the written order WRB which reflects that s/he has written the order and read it back for accuracy.  The prescribing doctor shall sign and date the verbal/telephone order within 72 hours.

subpolicies.title: Medication monitoring is conducted ongoing by the nursing staff and by the physician for consumers that have been prescribed medication, other than MAT medications (see specific monitoring schedule below for MAT medication). Frequency is as recommended by state-of-the-art guidelines currently available and/or at the physician’s discretion.  During monitoring, effectiveness and degree of side effects of each medication is assessed and documented on (at least monthly) the nursing or medical progress note.  Each consumer who is prescribed psychotropic and/or neuroleptic medication will receive an ADS and/or AIMS assessment to assess for abnormal involuntary movements (tardive dyskinesia) at the initiation of medication treatment and at least every six months while the consumer continues in treatment.

The physician and other authorized MAT health care providers shall register to use the MI prescription drug monitoring program and query it for each newly admitted consumer prior to initiating dosing.
Orders for Methadone may be placed by the Medical Director/program physician.

blocks.text: Each medication order and dosage change is written on an acceptable order sheet signed by the physician.
Physician orders are written in duplicate on a prescription blank.

subpolicies.title: The order must include the consumer’s name, ID number, the dose, the days during which the dose is to be administered (maximum of 31 days per order), and the physician’s name.
One dose level only is written on a prescription blank.
The order is also recorded in the consumer’s record by the physician.
The nurse transcribes the physician order for each consumer into the computer; new doses and changes are recorded in the computer as well.

On take out days, if applicable, the nurse prints out labels, places the labels on the bottle of methadone, and distributes the labeled bottles to consumers.  (See Take-Out Policy for more information.)
If administered by the nurse, measures are taken to monitor for adverse reactions.
The nurse observes the consumer and promptly reports any side effects to the Medical Director.
If a consumer appears intoxicated or under the influence of other drugs the nurse will not administer the methadone and will inform the physician.
Dosage is monitored at least every 60 days by the physician to accomplish the desired clinical effect, to include:
Prevent the onset of subjective signs of opiate absence syndrome for 24 hours or more.
Reduce or eliminate the drug hunger or craving.
Block the effects of illicit acquired, self-administered opiates without inducing persistent euphoric or other undesirable effects that are experienced by the consumer or noticed by others.
CONSUMER MEDICATION EDUCATION AND INFORMED CONSENT

blocks.text: The consumer and/or guardian shall participate in all decisions related to medication assisted treatment as evidenced by their signed informed consent to the medication and their signing of the treatment plan where medication-based treatment is addressed.

Consumers that receive medication assisted treatment and any other medications, and guardians or family, if applicable, shall have been previously educated about the medication(s) and the consumer and/or guardian shall have signed an Informed Consent; documentation of both shall be retained in the consumer’s record.    This information shall be reviewed again with the consumer within 30 days post-admission by a designated staff and documented in the consumer’s record.
The physician, nursing and/or counselor will educate the consumer about the medication they will be taking.  The physician documents education provided in his medical notes.
Nursing staff educate MAT program consumers on their medication assisted treatment before administration of the first dose and repeat as needed.  This education is documented in the nursing notes.
One to one training with the consumer is done and documented then reinforced during each administration of the medication and as needed during counseling sessions.
Education shall include, at a minimum, the following:
How the medication works and the rationale for the medication
Risks and benefits
Possible side effects and contraindications
Any drug-drug and/or food-drug interactions
Potential implications between medications and diet and/or exercise
Risks associated with pregnancy, if applicable
The importance of taking medications as prescribed – any potential obstacles to adherence should be identified and discussed where applicable – and signs of non-adherence
The need for lab monitoring, if applicable
Early signs of relapse related to medication efficacy
Potential drug reactions when combining medication assisted treatment with other prescription or OTC and alternative medications and/or with alcohol, tobacco, caffeine, illegal drugs
Instructions for self-administration, when applicable, and the role of medication in wellness management and recovery planning
Financial resources to help with the cost of medications, when relevant.

At discharge the consumer/guardian and family, if involved and available, is given a medication information sheet for any medications the consumer may continue, which is gone over with them by the nurse.

There are precautions that must be considered in Methadone dosing.  For example, many medications can act to increase the QT interval seen on an electrocardiogram (EKG) and potentially lead to torsades de pointes, a potentially life- threatening cardiac arrhythmia.
The physician shall monitor for potential QT-prolonging effects of methadone, especially with high doses.
In addition, the physician shall watch for interactions between methadone and other medications that also have QT-prolonging properties, or with medications that slow the elimination of methadone.

The medical assessment will specifically cover the symptoms and risk factors for torsades de pointes, and any indicated follow-up tests that may include an EKG or a more comprehensive electrophysiological assessment.
The treatment plan should also address concerns related to the discovery or risk of torsades de pointes.

The physician shall assess the impact of induction onto the treatment drug. Methadone has well documented impacts on several organ systems, including the respiratory, nervous, liver, and cardiac systems. Therefore, the medical exam should consider whether the treatment drug will be methadone, buprenorphine, or another medication, or whether the treatment indicated is induction, detoxification, or maintenance.

This assessment shall occur upon entry into the program and includes documenting a list of medications the consumer is currently taking with the actual (rather than prescribed) doses, any diverted or illicit substances the consumer is taking, potential adulterants sometimes contained within illicit substances that are in themselves medically active (e.g., quinine), and medically active over-the-counter (OTC) or natural remedies.
The physician shall check on and consider interactions between these medications and the medication ordered to treat opioid addiction prior to initiating treatment.

Dosage accuracy is critical. The MAT program has a procedure for calibrating medication-dispensing instruments, consistent with manufacturers’ recommendations, to aid in accurate consumer dosing and substance tracking.

Consumers’ Outside Prescriptions: The MAT program has specific directives in regard to medications that consumers may receive while in treatment, including OTC medications and medications—some of which may contain controlled substances that physicians outside the treatment program prescribe for acute and chronic illnesses.

The consumer shall show all medications, including OTC medications and prescribed medications, to the program’s medical staff. The consumer should explain the purpose of the medication as the consumer understands it.

If the consumer presents a medication containing a controlled substance or other medication that may be considered dangerous in combination with opioids, the program physician shall meet with the consumer and discuss the reason for the prescription. It is strongly recommended that the program physician only conduct this meeting in order to facilitate consumer trust and to obtain the consumer’s consent to contact the outside prescribing physician.

Because the use of multiple controlled substances may have the potential for producing respiratory depression or other life-threatening effects, the physician shall request that the consumer agree to permit the physician to review all outside prescriptions, especially for the benzodiazepine class of drugs.

The physician may decide to contact the outside prescribing physician and make a recommendation to the consumer about whether a prescribed drug is appropriate while the consumer is in opioid treatment.
The coordination of the consumer’s care is paramount, and the physicians shall consult with one another to determine the appropriate medications.

The program physician also shall discuss with the consumer dependency and withdrawal issues resulting from continued use or abrupt discontinuance of controlled substances and modify the treatment plan if necessary.

The physician employs clinical judgment to determine the individual dose of opioid medication. The physician shall have MAT program treatment privileges and is knowledgeable about, and experienced in addiction medicine, including medication-assisted treatment.
Maintenance medication doses are to be sufficient to produce the desired response in the consumer for the desired duration of time, with allowance for a margin of effectiveness and safety.

When necessary to withdraw the consumer from opioid treatment, the medically supervised withdrawal protocol will be of sufficient duration for consumer safety.  (See the Medically Assisted Withdrawal Policy.)

Program-wide dose caps or ceilings are contrary to the principle of individualized treatment, and the MAT program does not establish them. Consumer-specific dosage adjustments will be made whenever indicated.
Effective therapy involving medication-assisted treatment is sought, as evidenced by the following desired outcomes:
Preventing the onset of subjective and/or objective signs of opioid abstinence syndrome for at least 24 hours.
Reducing or eliminating the drug craving routinely experienced by the consumer.
Blocking the euphoric effects of any illicitly acquired, self-administered opioids, without inducing undesirable effects experienced by the consumer or noticed by other observers.
A medical evaluation, including documented history and physical examination, support the judgment by the physician that the consumer is a suitable candidate for opioid therapy.

The initial full-day dose of medication is based on the physician’s evaluation of the history and present condition of the consumer. The physician shall also take into account local conditions, such as the relative purity of available drugs and the source of the drugs, whether the consumer illicitly purchased or obtained them from friends or family members. Medication dosage is also based on the physician’s assessment and evaluation of other medications that the consumer reports taking, including OTC drugs, prescription medications, and prescription medications containing controlled substances.

There are no limits on the duration or the dosage level of medication, unless clinically indicated. Likewise, there are no limitations on psychosocial services offered even when consumers are receiving “0” dose levels.

The first dose of any opioid treatment medication shall be low if a consumer’s opioid tolerance is believed to be low, the history of opioid use is uncertain, or no signs of opioid withdrawal are evident.
Methadone shall be administered or dispensed only in oral form and shall be formulated in such a way as to reduce its potential for parenteral abuse.
Regulations stipulate that the initial dose of methadone should not exceed 30 mg.
The physician considers carefully the reasons for exceeding an initial dose of 30 mg and documents these reasons in the clinical record.  See Initiation/Stabilization Guidelines below.

The total amount of medication administered should not exceed 40 mg per day, unless the physician documents that 40 mg did not suppress opiate abstinence symptoms after a 3-hour period of observation.
Consumers abusing diverted, prescribed opioids alone may also require a low initial dose of methadone.

The physician should calculate the dosage based on standard dose conversion tables and the consumer’s recent amount of opioid intake. Any deviations from package inserts are documented in the consumer’s record.
During the induction phase, caution should be exercised regarding an overly rapid increase in dosage because of the long half-life of methadone.

Once the consumer reaches a dose of 60 mg per day, it may be medically indicated to maintain a stable dosage amount for 3 to 5 days before further increasing the dosage, depending on the consumer’s clinical status and symptoms.

Initial doses of buprenorphine or LAAM (if reintroduced for dispensing) and other approved medications should be based on the package insert. The physician documents the justification for any deviations from this principle.

The total dose of medication and the interval between doses may require adjustments for the consumer who has concurrent health conditions or atypical metabolic patterns, or if the consumer takes other prescribed medications that alter rates of opioid medication metabolism.

The MAT program shall not adjust medication doses to reinforce positive behavior or to punish negative behavior. For example, a consumer’s noncompliance with a treatment plan, including a positive toxicology screen, should not necessarily result in a decreased dosage. In fact, in certain circumstances this may indicate the need for an increased dosage.

The MAT program shall continue medication-assisted treatment as long as the consumer derives benefit from treatment and desires treatment. There shall be no fixed length of time in treatment. In fact, indefinite medication-assisted treatment may be clinically indicated. The physician should also be prudent in considering other medications during the course of treatment, as clinically indicated.

If the MAT program switches from one generic formulation to another and differences in effective dose cause clinically relevant complaints, the physician may decide to adjust the medication dosage. Additionally, the physician should exercise caution when a consumer has missed several doses, because consumer tolerance may have changed over time.
The MAT program has the capability to obtain medication blood levels when clinically indicated.
10-30 mg of methadone/day is typical for the first 3 days, unless the physician documents       justification for a larger initial dosage.
Starting at a low dose puts the consumer at increased risk for ongoing use of illicit substances due to inadequate methadone levels and prolongs both the withdrawal and/or stabilization period.
It must be acknowledged that with starting doses in the above range, the consumer will most likely need to "top up" their dose and accommodation should be made for this initially.
Signs and symptoms of withdrawal (objective and subjective)
Amount and/or frequency of opioid use not decreasing
Persistent cravings for opioids
Failure to achieve a dose that blocks the euphoria of short acting opioids
Dose adjustment should not be made more frequently than every 3-4 days
The optimal dose of methadone is that dose which relieves withdrawal symptoms, blocks the euphoria from short acting opioids and drug cravings without sedation or other significant side effects.
The optimal dose for the majority of consumers can be established within 2-6 weeks.

A dose above 100 mg is considered in the high range. Should a physician have difficulty in stabilizing the consumer's dose below this level, a second physician involved in methadone will be consulted. In doses above 150 mg, strong consideration shall be given to obtaining a methadone serum half -life (or peak/trough ratio).

Drug craving alone is an inadequate reason to increase doses above 120 mg.  The requirement for further dose increases should be manifested by the presence of a constellation of withdrawal symptoms, both physiological and psychological, that occur at a predictable time at the end of a dosing interval.
Once the optimal dose is reached, further dosage adjustment should not be necessary. Factors that may cause a consumer to complain of a recurrence of withdrawal symptoms are:
Relapse to opioid use.
Increased metabolism of methadone; may occur in the third trimester of pregnancy, or when another medication is added to the therapy.
Withdrawal of other drugs such as cocaine or benzodiazepines.

“Pseudo-withdrawal” - depression, anxiety, and situational crises can also lead the consumer to experience withdrawal symptoms. Increasing the dose in this situation may give the consumer the message that more methadone is the solution to their problems. The next time they are in crisis, they will be conditioned to ask for another increase.
More than daily dosing may be clinically indicated in consumers who:
Are rapid metabolizers.
Are on medications known to increase methadone’s rate of metabolism.
Pregnant consumers in their last trimester, on doses > 100 mg.
In instances where rapid metabolism is suspected, consideration is given to obtaining methadone serum 	half-life or methadone peal-trough levels.

subpolicies.title: Missed Doses and Loss of Tolerance

blocks.text: A clinically significant loss of tolerance to opioids may occur with as little as three days without 	methadone.  These dosing guidelines will be followed.  If not followed, the physician shall document the 	reason in the consumer’s record.
Missed 1-2 doses: give usual dose.
Missed 3-5 doses: give 1/2 usual dose, assess tolerance, increase 15 mg /day back to usual dose.
Missed >5 doses: start over @ 30 mg or less, assess tolerance, increase 15 mg/day back to usual dose.

subpolicies.title: Unless extenuating circumstance is known and documented in the consumer’s record, the consumer is 	considered to have withdrawn from the program after 3 consecutive missed doses.
If a consumer is hospitalized or incarcerated, particularly if they are on relatively high doses, extra care 	must be taken in dispensing their medication if there have been any missed doses.

blocks.text: If a health professional or member of staff witnesses emesis, the dose may be replaced as follows:

subpolicies.title: Dosage For Pregnant Women In Methadone Treatment

blocks.text: Consumers who become pregnant during treatment shall be maintained on the pre-pregnancy dosage, if effective, and the same dosing principles shall apply as are used with any other non-pregnant consumer.

The initial methadone dose for a newly admitted pregnant consumer and the subsequent induction and maintenance dosing strategy shall reflect the same effective dosing protocols used for all other consumers.

The methadone dose is monitored carefully, especially during the third trimester when pregnancy-induced changes in the rate at which methadone is metabolized or eliminated from the system may necessitate either an increased or a split dose.

In general, detoxification during pregnancy is not recommended or considered the best practice. If a pregnant consumer elects to withdraw from methadone and stays in the program, a physician experienced in addiction medicine supervises the withdrawal process with regular fetal assessments, as appropriate, for gestational age, as part of the withdrawal process. The physician should not initiate withdrawal before 14 weeks’ or after 32 weeks’ gestation.
Intoxicated consumers should not be medicated with methadone until they have been reassessed and 	found to be unimpaired.
QBH’s Medical Director shall establish protocols with the local hospital/ER so as to aid in continuity of 	care and treatment philosophy for MAT Program consumers.

Nurses who administer medications shall follow professional practices of administration and sanitation/infection control.  Injectable equipment shall be disposable, used only once and shall be disposed of in designated red sharps containers.  Full sharps containers will be picked up for disposal by a contracted HAZMAT Agency.  The nursing staff shall keep a record of each pick up.  Such records shall be maintained for three years.
All medications shall be stored in the original container with an affixed label as required by law.

All medications shall be administered immediately to the intended consumer after poured; no pre-pouring is allowed and only the nurse who poured the medication may administer it to the intended consumer.

Medication administration shall be done by licensed nurses and recorded on the MAR for each consumer. If a consumer refuses medication that shall be so noted with a circle around the letter “R” in the box where the nurse would otherwise initial that the medication was given.  Prior to medication administration, the nurse shall check at least two forms of ID (see further description of this process under the section below).
A designated area in each MAT program is used for medication passes; consumers come to receive their medications one at a time.
Vital signs are done and documented on the Vital Signs Sheet prior to medication administration, if indicated.

Nurses check vital signs results, the MAR, and the medication label before administering a medication.  The consumer ingests the medication in front of the nurse and a cheek check is done to ensure the medication was ingested or, if the medication is in liquid form, the consumer must speak to the nurse before leaving the administration area; nurses reinforce medication education during medication administration with each consumer.  The nurse then initials the MAR for each medication given, or writes “R” and circles it if a consumer refused a medication.  A nursing note is written describing why the consumer refused the medication and actions taken to encourage and educate the consumer about why they should take the medication.  If the medication refused is part of the MAT protocol, the physician and a counselor are notified immediately.

If a medication is spilled or dropped, the consumer is given another.  If the spilled/dropped medication is the opiate treatment, see the section describing the proper procedure below.  The dropped medication, if other than the opiate medication, is placed in the pharmacy return box for the pharmacy to dispose of it and the spilled or dropped medication is documented in a nursing note.

Consumers in need of an OTC or PRN (per request/need) are brought to the medication administration area for the medication.  This administration, including use and benefits of the prn dose, is noted on the consumer’s MAR.  After an hour the nurse inquires of the consumer regarding the effectiveness/ benefit of the medication and documents this on the MAR.

All medications administered, including OTC medications, are recorded on the MAR.  The MAR shall be maintained in the Nurse’s Office until the end of each month and/or the consumer’s discharge, whichever occurs first.  At that time, the MAR will be given to the Medical Records Clerk for filing and entry into the EMR if entry has not already occurred.
An MAR is maintained for each consumer receiving any medications.  The MAR contains, minimally, the following information:
Name of the medication
Dosage
Frequency
Instructions for use, including route/method of administration
Prescribing professional
Any known drug/food allergies of the consumer.

Any medication errors that may occur or any medication reactions observed or reported by a consumer are documented in a nursing note, including action taken and outcome of the action.  An Incident Report is also completed per policy.
Mishandling of medications may result in immediate dismissal of employment.

QBH, Inc. has developed procedures to support the administration of correct dose of medication(s) and that appropriate actions are taken if a medication error is made. Procedures include a mechanism for reporting untoward incidents to appropriate program staff.

State of the art procedures shall be maintained that are adequate to support that each opioid agonist treatment medication used by the program is administered and dispensed in accordance with its approved product labeling.

Dosing and administration decisions shall be made by the program Medical Director who is familiar with the most up-to-date product labeling. These procedures shall provide that any significant deviations from the approved labeling, including deviations with regard to dose, frequency, or the conditions of use described in the approved labeling, are specifically documented in the consumer's record.

QBH, Inc.’s MAT program shall use only those opioid agonist treatment medications that are approved by the Food and Drug Administration under section 505 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 355) for use in the treatment of opioid addiction.  Currently the following opioid agonist treatment medications are considered approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use in the treatment of opioid addiction and may be used in the MAT pr
Methadone;
Levomethadyl acetate (LAAM); and
Buprenorphine and buprenorphine combination products that have been approved for use in the treatment of opioid addiction.

Each dosage dispensed, prepared, or received is recorded and accounted for by signed notation, in a manner that creates a perpetual and accurate inventory of all medications, including controlled substances in stock at all times.
Every dose is recorded on a Medication Administration Record, at the time that the dose is administered or dispensed, and recorded on the consumer’s individual medication dose history.
The qualified person administering or dispensing medications signs his or her name or initials at each notation.
If initials are used, the full signature of the qualified person administering or dispensing appears at the end of each page of the medication sheet.
The following information is maintained in the Dispensing Log for each consumer receiving MAT dosages:
The name of the substance
The strength of the substance
The dosage form (liquid, capsule, tablet, granules, injection, etc.)
Date dispensed
ID used to verify the consumer’s identity
Amount of the substance consumed by the consumer
Dispenser’s initials or signature
The medication dose is totaled in milligrams daily.
The consumer shall provide two forms of ID (one must be picture ID) to the receptionist.
The receptionist reviews the consumer computer ledger.
The receipt is approved by the receptionist.
The consumer takes the receipt and picture ID to the dispensing window and presents them to the nurse.

subpolicies.title: Dispensing by the nurse proceeds as follows:
The nurse verifies the identity of the consumer using a picture ID and Quality Behavioral Health receipt; once verified return the ID to the consumer.
Use the consumer receipt to type in the consumer’s last name or ID to locate and select the consumer in the M4 system.
The nurse asks the consumer to sign the signature sheet.
The nurse pulls up the consumer’s medication record on the computer, compares it with the picture ID, and the signature sheet.
After verification is complete, go to the Dose Folder and click on the dispense box, following the directions to dispense in Method One.
Again the nurse verifies the receipt and the computer screen the consumer’s identity and then engages the computer pump which dispenses the prescribed does into the cc cup.

blocks.text: The nurse adds water to the dose and gives the consumer the medication.
The consumer drinks the dose, speaks to the nurse and disposes of the cup in the waste container at the dispensing station.
The nurse returns the receipt to the consumer.
The nurse saves the medication record to the computer file.
The nurse files the original dispensing records in the nursing station at the end of the day, in addition to the electronic record stored in the data base.

subpolicies.title: At the end of the business day, no show and bottle summary reports, and total mgs dispensed, are prepared and filed with the dispensing records for the day.
Once a week, a weekly summary report and termination list is generated of all consumers and maintained in the nursing office.
When a methadone quart bottle is changed, the following steps are taken:
Measure the amount of methadone remaining in the closing bottle by pouring it into a graduated cylinder.
Input the measured amount into the computer in the field designated for the transfer amount.
Verify the measured transfer amount on the Dispensing Log and record the amount of methadone measured out of the bottle and sign.
Check the closing bottle number on the computer and check that it matches the lot number indicated on the bottle.
Check the bottle number of the opening bottle and check that both the lot number and the amount of methadone being transferred into the bottle are correct.

If there is any problem performing the above steps, do not proceed to dispense the medication to consumers, but immediately request assistance from a peer nursing staff or a licensed nursing or medical supervisor. If the problem persists, contact the FCO or QM Coordinator.

If the amount of methadone transferred is greater than 500 mgs, record it separately on the Methadone Bottle Transfer (MBT) Log and then notify and receive the signature of your supervisor or designee.

If there is breakage, cracking or any other breach of bottle integrity, bypass using that bottle.  Write an Incident Report detailing the description of the problem with the bottle and notify your nursing supervisor and CEO immediately.
SECURITY RESTRICTIVE USE OF PERSONAL DISPENSING CODES
Dispensing staff is responsible for all dispenses recorded under their personal dispensing code (initials and passwords).
Dispensing achievement and errors are traced to individual dispensing codes are reported monthly through Quality Management.
Errors are confirmed by peer review and when validated, progressive disciplinary action is initiated.
Document and report any unauthorized use of your code to your supervisor, the Medical Director, the CEO, or designee promptly.
To make sure that no other staff uses your personal code, always log out when leaving the computer.

blocks.text: Spillage of methadone, while dispensing to a customer, is documented in the consumer’s record, on the Spillage Log, and in the computer.
The Spillage Log, consumer record and computer files are monitored and evaluated by Quality Manager and/or designee.
Repeated incidents of spillage, regardless of the amount, will result in disciplinary action.
Spillages of methadone, during non-dispensing activities are written on an Incident Report and given to your supervisor by the close of the business day.
Failure to comply with policies and procedures will result in disciplinary action up to, but not limited to, termination.

subpolicies.title: In the event of computer failure associated with methadone dispensing that is beyond QBH’s control, medication dispensing will be done using the hand pump and/or a 10 cc syringe to place the prescribed dose in a cc cup.  The weekly dispensing summary and consumer record will be used to determine the consumer’s dosage to be dispensed.
In event of a power failure and/or hazardous working conditions, dispensing will be arranged for consumers at a different QBH treatment site.
The nurse from the affected site will go to the alternate site to dispense the medication to their consumers and to oversee that no medication errors occur.
This site move must first be authorized by a designated administrative staff.
All records will be maintained in accordance with state, federal and Company rules.
All consumers involved will be instructed to bring take-home boxes in situations where the Detroit Public Schools are closed.

blocks.text: In the event that a delivery cannot be received from the distributor, QBH will activate the terms of a pre-established contingency site agreement.  The contingency site agreement is available in the administrative files and covers contingency medication services for purchase of methadone from another treatment facility.
Only the FCO is authorized to make adjustments/error corrections that have been documented and validated.
Adjustments/error corrections are maintained in a Log that is retained in the safe.

Each adjustment requires the FCO's and the supervisors' signatures; date of error; date of adjustment/correction; and a clear description of the adjustment including, but not necessarily limited to, lot number(s) and methadone amount(s).
Only one (1) consumer can be at the medication window at a time.
All consumers must speak to the nurse after ingesting the methadone.

Drug screens are conducted at least twice monthly, or as ordered (See Drug Screening Policy). It is expected that the urine screen will reveal the presence of methadone. Consumers must submit urine on a random basis in order to minimize diversion. When clinically indicated, blood levels will be obtained.
Consumers must bring in a locked box to receive take-home bottle(s) of medication, when applicable.
The safeguarding of medication will be reviewed monthly with each consumer by the primary counselor and the nurse; the review is documented in the consumer’s record.
Staff my not take purses or bags into the medication area.
No consumer loitering is allowed around the building and surrounding area within a one block radius of Quality Behavioral Health.
The site supervisor serves as the Community Liaison to accept any report of unlawful activities around the area of the MAT Program.
Continuous monitoring of clinical and administrative activities is done through a Daily Clinical Log and periodic inspection by management staff and administrative/QM staff.
Consumer identified diversion problems are documented through Incident Reports and resolved during treatment team conference.
QBH will accept consumers for guest dosing that are currently enrolled in a methadone treatment program out of the state of Michigan.
The consumer, home program, and guest program shall arrive at an agreement to provide the consumer with clinical services, such as counseling, if the period for guest dosing exceeds 30 days.
The consumer must provide QBH, through fax or mail, on the Treatment Program’s letterhead, the following information, which will be verified by phone prior to the consumer’s arrival for dosing:
Name
Driver’s License/State ID #
Date of birth
Social Security Number
Sex
Age
Height and weight
Race
Color of hair and eyes
Additional helpful identification information
Admit date to their treatment program
Medication dates
Reason for the request
Methadone dosage
Take home bottles received
Other prescribed medication
Consumer’s signature
Nurse’s signature from treatment program
Prescribing physician’s signature from the treatment program

If a consumer remains long-term in the MAT Program, a program physician shall document a clinical justification for continued administration of methadone in spite of potential side effects associated with long-term use.
Justification of long-term use might include:
The treatment staff feels maintenance dosage is still necessary
Consumer continues the use of illicit drugs
Consumer is not ready to detox at this time
Other (be specific)
Doses of medication had to be adjusted because the MAT Program switched from one generic formulation to another and differences in effective dose caused clinically relevant complaints

subpolicies.title: DETERMINATION OF REDUCTION IN VISIT FREQUENCY

blocks.text: Before frequency of visits to the MAT Program can be authorized, the decision and associated rationale must be recorded in the consumer’s record by a program physician or counselor.
Factors considered in making the decision to reduce visit frequency include, but not exclusively:
Background history of the consumer, such as:
Actively employed
Actively seeking employment as evidenced by a sign off sheet from potential employers
Disability preventing the ability to work as evidenced by a Social Security Income, Social Security Disability Income, or Workman’s Compensation checks
Evidence the consumer has appropriately handled off-site dosing in the past on Sundays/Holidays or other off-site dosing privileges.
General or specific characteristics of the community in which the consumer resides.
Absence of any recent history of abuse of non-narcotic drugs, including alcohol.
Absence of serious behavioral problems in the MAT Program.
Regularly attends MAT Program as scheduled.
Absence of recent known criminal activity.
Length of time in opioid substance abuse treatment with methadone.
Assurance that off-site dosing can be safely stored at home.
Rehabilitative benefits to the consumer of decreasing frequency of attendance outweigh the potential risks, including diversion.
Health needs or pain treatment.
Consumer’s work, schooling or daily activity schedule.
Hardship experience to consumer in traveling to the program.

In cases in which the consumer’s treatment needs require an exception to the regulations found in 42 CFR Part 8, the MAT physician may complete an Exception Request and Record of Justification, SAMHSA Form SMA-168. Frequently, these exceptions may be granted even if the consumer has not followed all clinic rules, because without such an exception, the consumer would have to choose between employment and treatment.

For a consumer who does not satisfy the Federal time-in-treatment criterion to receive take-home medication, the MAT physician must complete, sign, and submit an SMA-168 Exception Request and Record of Justification. Without Federal approval of an Exception Request, the MAT physician may not dispense the take-home supply of medication to the consumer for unsupervised use. The most important aspect of the exception request is to explain in detail the purpose and justification and to give a clear explanation of hardship—i.e., distance in miles, hours of employment, conflict with employment, and/or medical issue—so that the DPT reviewer is able to understand clearly the consumer’s situation and can make a decision.
The mechanisms for submitting SMA-168 follow:

The preferred method of submission is through the Internet. The program director may apply for the account by calling 1–866–687–2728. Once an account has been set up, the staff and physicians receive access to the Web site and a specific, individual signature password for signing and submitting the electronic form SMA-168. The processing time for a response is the same day, usually within hours.

In case of emergency, program staff may submit an SMA-168 through facsimile (fax) to 1–240–276–1630. The form may be downloaded from the DPT Web site at www.dpt.samhsa.gov, or e-mailed or faxed if a verbal request is made, by calling 1–240–276–2700. The processing time for a response for a fax transmission may exceed 24 hours.

When medication is prescribed by sources outside QBH, QBH medical and nursing staff coordinates with these sources to maintain accurate information and to provide feedback on effectiveness and/or issues.

If medication is being prescribed both by outside sources and Company medical personnel, the information is shared by QBH with the outside source and, likewise, the outside source’s information is sought by QBH with appropriate information release from the consumer.
When information is received by QBH from outside sources, it is reviewed by QBH’s medical staff, signed to indicate review, and any issues or course of action are addressed in a progress note.
Consultation, if needed for the customer’s needs, is referred as follows:
Referrals, generally, are made by the counselor who, in most cases will also make the appointment and arrange for transport.
If the issue needing referral is medical or neurological, it is referred by the physician.
If the issue needing referral is for psychological testing, it may be referred by either the counselor or physician.
In all cases, the referring practitioner will document the referral and arrangements in a progress note and generate a pass request form for the consumer.

When referral results/reports are received back, the physician reviews and signs off on the results and, if any orders are needed as a result of the report, will write those orders.  Likewise, if the results indicate a need for transfer or discharge to a different level of care, the physician will write those orders.
