Performs the work in a manner consistent with job description and the terms and conditions of these policies.
Works effectively with supervisors and observes rules and regulations.
Respects the property and interests of QBH.
Reports for work promptly and regularly.
Has a positive attitude toward advancement and the assumption of additional responsibility.

Does not have any impairment (physical, mental, or medical) which would interfere with ability to do the job for which being considered. Appropriate and affordable modifications may be offered to a person with a handicap who qualifies for the job.
Maintains constructive working relations with co-workers.
The CEO shall have the responsibility for the hiring, employment or contracting and termination of all staff on an AT WILL basis.

Job Posting: When a staff vacancy occurs, it may be advertised for at least seven calendar days within QBH at the CEO’s discretion.  Simultaneously, the job may be posted at the Detroit-Wayne Country Community Mental Health Board contract agencies.  Advertisement in local papers and other medial within the counties and neighboring counties of QBH will occur.  The announcement will include a general summary of the major duties of the position.  When necessary, QBH will utilize other accepted means of recruitment (e.g., universities, colleges, schools, placement agencies, job fairs, etc.)

All applicants shall make application for the advertised job in writing and deliver the application to the office of the CEO or designee for that purpose during the posting period.  After screening to identify eligible applicants, job interviews are conducted, and the applicant’s qualifications are checked.  If a decision is made to offer employment or contract, the applicant’s job offer is contingent on satisfactory results from primary source verification, references, and other hiring requirements as addressed elsewhere in this policy.
Staff will be given a written AT WILL contract signed by the CEO setting forth the conditions of employment or contract.
The appointee will confirm in writing acceptance of the offer of employment or contract by the first day of work by signing the contract.
The appointee will be given six months to successfully perform their job.  At the end of six months, seniority shall be established retroactive to the entry date.
This probationary period may be extended as described within this policy.

An applicant must provide proof of level of education as it relates to the requirements of the position for which the application is made.  Prior to employment or contract, three written peer and/or employer references, documenting the applicant’s past experience and qualifications, must be secured.  These will become part of that individual’s personnel record.

The employment /contract materials and resumes of all individuals who have applied for positions at QBH but who have not commenced employment or contract will be retained in a file held by the Office Manager for a period of one year following the date of that individual’s application.

Each new staff member of QBH is responsible for obtaining a required Tb test and to provide a document of test results, in addition to a letter from their physician declaring their physical and mental ability to do the job they are seeking.  QBH will provide a Health Clearance Form for the physician’s use if desired.  Immunizations for Hepatitis A/B/C are encouraged and, if obtained, results should be provided to the Office Manager for inclusion in the staff’s health record.  This requirement must be met within 30 days after the effective date of hire.
Retaining staff is important for several reasons:
Stability of treatment staff may affect treatment outcomes.
High staff turnover can undermine relations with the community, funders, and others.
Investment in recruitment and training is lost when staff members leave.
Unfilled staff positions result in longer consumer waiting lists.
Reducing staff turnover minimizes disruption to consumers' treatment.
Accreditation standards place importance on the stability of MAT program staff.

Efforts to achieve staff retention are one of the most cost-saving measures a Company can have in place.  QBH desires to retain qualified staff with sound performance as long as possible.  Therefore, the following measures are routinely employed in our attempt to retain staff:

Ongoing feedback that goes both directions is encouraged between staff and their supervisors as well as Company leadership, to facilitate shared participation in problem identification and resolution in the work environment.
In addition to formal supervision and performance evaluations and periodic staff surveys, staff is encouraged to utilize leadership’s open-door policy.

Likewise, leaders and supervisors are to continually look for positive performance and recognize it, providing ongoing feedback besides the formally scheduled times for feedback; supervision is provided in a caring and supportive manner.
Ongoing efforts are made by leadership to increase job benefits and salaries to stay competitive with the marketplace.
Due to the nature of the environment of the workplace and the increase in threats with the depressed economy of the area, extra measures are in place to avail staff of extra security and safety.
Periodic special events or rewards are provided to staff that go the extra mile and/or for staff in general to express appreciation for their work and dedication to QBH.
Efforts by leadership and supervisors to treat staff with respect and dignity.
Internal advancement is encouraged and offered whenever possible to provide for job advancement and professional development.
Internal and external training, in addition to job orientation, is encouraged and provided to help staff stay up to date in their practice and to advance their professional growth.
Clear policies and procedures are established and applied consistently.

Avoid excessive caseloads. Managers are urged to monitor the number of counseling hours a caseload requires, which can differ dramatically from the number of cases assigned per counselor, depending on the requirements of individual consumers.

A team approach is encouraged. Staff members usually feel less isolated and overwhelmed when a team makes treatment decisions. When a lack of cohesion exists, staff members risk burnout, disillusionment, or cynicism. A well-coordinated team also reduces the level of intra-staff disagreements about consumer care and decreases the likelihood of “staff splitting,” when consumers pit staff members against one another.

A culture of mutual respect is encouraged through team cooperation, clear and effective communication, and inclusive, interdepartmental decision making. Managers are encouraged to hold regular staff meetings. Staff cooperation also can be fostered through training and retreats. The program’s Clinical Director is responsible to mediate disputes among staff members.
Leadership monitors that job descriptions clearly delineate roles, responsibilities, and lines of communication; job descriptions are reviewed annually with staff during evaluations.
Objective performance standards are established derived from job descriptions and conduct of regular performance evaluations that include feedback based on consumer outcomes is policy.
Supervisors are sought who are well trained and supported.
Encourage professional development by supporting staff certifications.
Establish personnel policies that demonstrate concern for staff well-being, including flexible work schedules to reduce stress.
Other measures, as identified by staff as helpful, may be introduced whenever possible.

When staff leaves QBH they are encouraged to provide feedback as to the reason(s) why they are leaving.  This information is tracked to identify turnover trends that QBH can address to reduce turnover.
At least annually the Clinical Committee visits the subject of turnover, looking at trends and seeking action options to sustain and increase staff retention.

A major trend that is reflected year after year is the geographic location of QBH’s services.  The location, however, is perfect for the consumer populations being served, but is nonconductive to retention of staff.  The location cannot be changed; however, every effort is made to provide staff with a sense of safety and security and to listen and respond to their needs in this area.
DETERMINATION
Job competencies are determined based upon the job position, job description, and QBH’s general requirements as set forth by policy, regulation and/or accreditation standards.
The CEO or supervisor shall determine the critical competencies to be validated at the time of hire, by the six-month probationary evaluation, and those to be maintained, demonstrated and
improved on an annual basis for each job position.
Skill Competency Checklists exist for each job in addition to knowledge-based written testing.
Competencies are intended to:
Provide for staff that can help consumers achieve their defined treatment outcomes.
Support QBH’s achievement of its strategic mission and goals.
Determine initial and ongoing competency development of staff.
Help identify areas of training and development, or other resources, that are needed to foster competence.

Staff competency shall be determined for specific critical skills at hire and at least annually as a part of the performance evaluation process.  Verification of competence shall be documented on a Skill Competency Checklist specific to the job position.  Job performance will be documented on the Performance Evaluation and Planning Form.
In conjunction with the ongoing evaluation process, the staff will be provided with the opportunity to demonstrate required competencies.
Demonstration may be in the form of a written test, physical demonstration, a sampling review as directed on the Skill Competency Checklist.
The person doing the observation/verification must have previously demonstrated competency in the same skill.
The Skill Competency Checklist shall be completed (i.e., items so designated on the form) at hire and prior to the first job assignment, at the end of the probationary period, and then annually.
Skills to be validated at evaluation points shall be completed before or during the evaluation.  The evaluation will not be considered complete until validation has occurred.
All staff providing direct service shall have competency assessments related to:
Special populations: if working with special populations the staff will be required to develop and maintain specific competencies relevant to service delivery to that special population.
Special population competencies for MAT program staff include minimally:
Understanding the benefits and limitations of toxicological testing procedures.
Strategies for treating alcohol, cocaine, and other drug abuse.
Staff responsible for coordinating medical and psychiatric care is knowledgeable about medication assisted therapy.

Staff responsible for establishing referrals with other health care organizations and practitioners is knowledgeable about pharmacotherapy (drug interactions, acute withdrawal, and overdose), actively seek customer consent to talk with other providers, and check their state's prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) regularly.
Special needs: required to develop and maintain competencies relevant to adapting services to special needs of consumers served.  For MAT program staff this will include, minimally:
Understanding of the specific needs and characteristics of women participating in the MAT program.
Knowledge of all forms of viral hepatitis and their effects on the health of consumers.
Person centered care: required to develop and maintain competencies relevant to development of person-centered care planning.
Interviewing skills:  required to develop and maintain competencies relevant to age and development appropriate interviewing.
Evidence-based treatment: required to develop and maintain competencies relevant to changes in treatment approaches based upon new research and best practices.
Clinical skills: required to develop and maintain competencies relevant to the clinical skills applicable to the job/position.
Certifications: required to be currently certified in first aid, CPR and the use of emergency equipment.
Special Interventions: required to be competent in de-escalation techniques, risk assessment, and use of trauma-informed approaches.
These competencies are defined in the Skill Competency Checklist and, when applicable, in privileging requirements.

The results of staff skill competency and performance results shall be monitored by the Office Manager and reported to the Clinical Committee and the Board at least annually.  Any trends or patterns denoting educational/orientation modifications shall be reflected in orientation and in-service education activities.

Probationary staff’s competence and performance is evaluated on or before the end of six months.  They are evaluated again at the end of one year of employment/contract and at least yearly thereafter.
Non-probationary staff shall have their performance formally reviewed on an annual basis.
All personnel who are not granted independent privileges shall have ongoing evaluation and feedback regarding their performance as a part of the supervision process.
Following promotion, reassignment, lateral move, or demotion, competence and evaluation is the same s for probationary staff because the staff member is assuming a new position.

The performance evaluation, completed fully or in part by the staff member and their supervisor, shall include a personal interview and discussion with the staff member to discuss performance, possible changes in job content, salary, and other matters of concern to the staff member and administration.
Performance factors are described in the duties/responsibilities section of the position description for each job position.
Besides the numbering, each area of evaluation must be accompanied by comments based upon observations/test scores/quality data that support the reason for the score assigned.
The evaluation shall be in writing, signed by the staff, the supervisor, and the CEO and filed in the staff’s personnel file.
The staff may request a copy of the evaluation report.
A staff member may provide an addendum to express his/her agreement or disagreement with the evaluation if the staff member deems such an addition necessary.
The evaluation will also include an assessment of performance objectives set at the last evaluation period and will establish performance objectives for the next year.

If a staff member’s overall performance is evaluated below 3.0 and therefore determined to be “marginally effective” (2.1-2.9) or “ineffective” (1.0-2.0) on the Personnel Performance and Planning Form, it is the position of QBH that these levels of performance merit a specific plan of correction action which is incorporated into Part I of the Personnel Performance and Planning Form.
QBH reserves the right to implement a probation period of six months during which time specific goals and objectives will be established to improve the “marginally effective” performer.

If a probation period is initiated, at the completion of this period, another Performance and Planning Form will be completed to determine if the level of performance has improved to at least {effective” (3.0-3.4).
If a satisfactory level of performance is not obtained, the CEO may issue a notice of discharge.
If a staff member is evaluated as “ineffective” QBH may terminate the staff member immediately.
Each staff member’s job description identifies the job position that supervises them.  Likewise, if their job position entails supervision of others, it is so delineated on their job description.
Supervision is to occur informally for all staff on an ongoing basis, but with clinical staff a face-to-face exchange should occur at least monthly.

The HR Manager, in collaboration with the Clinical Director, conducts at least an annual review of individual licensing, scope of practice and supervision requirements of MI with regard to the duties of authorized health professionals within the MAT program.
Medical and clinical staff’s participation in the peer review process and group staffings is another form of supervision.

Formal, documented supervision occurs semi-annually for clinical staffs.  The documentation of the supervision on a Supervision Form is submitted to the Office Manager for inclusion in the staff’s personnel file.  Supervision of clinical staff shall include, minimally:
Accuracy of assessment and referral skills, as applicable to job duties.
Appropriateness of treatment or service interventions with regard to each consumer’s specific and/or special needs.
Treatment/service effectiveness as reflected by the consumer meeting his/her individual goals.
Provision of feedback that enhances the skill of direct service personnel.
Issues of ethics, legal aspects of clinical practice, and professional standards, including boundaries.
Clinical documentation issues identified through ongoing peer review and chart audits.
Cultural competency issues.
Ability to model fidelity, when implementing evidence-based practices.
Formal supervision shall also occur following any reportable incident involving a staff member.
All staff receives initial orientation to QBH, its policies, and to their specific job upon hire and before assuming the duties of their job.
Orientation is the responsibility of the new staff’s supervisor, in collaboration with the CEO and other key staff of QBH.
Orientation shall include, as relevant to the job position, the same categories of content that is included in the training section in addition to job-specific elements.

An Orientation Checklist records the orientation and, upon completion, at which time it is signed by both the new staff and their supervisor, is submitted by the new staff’s supervisor to the Office Manager for placement in the staff’s personnel file.
The Office Manager provides the new staff member with a copy of the Personnel Manual, a job description, and then confirms hire and starting date with the appropriate supervisor.
The Office Manager arranges for the new staff member to complete QBH orientation.

The new staff member, once oriented, signs an Orientation Checklist verifying the content and completion of their orientation activities (see details in section above). This form is filed in the staff member’s personnel file.
Ongoing staff training is provided by QBH staff and through a contracted training company.
Internal training is provided as needed and/or as prompted by quality, competency and performance data, and for orientation.

Health and Safety policies, including staff responsibility and the process for incident reporting, their roles during emergencies, and their roles to promote safety, is done by the CEO or appropriate designee.
Company mission and strategic goals.
Policies and procedures – where they are accessed, notice when changed, feedback process if outdated, and requirements to read them.
Company/program rules, if applicable to job.
Transportation manual, if applicable to job.
Job specific documentation requirements and use of related forms.
CPR and First Aid, if applicable to job.
Health, safety, and infection control practices as pertinent to job.
Personnel manual review.
Contracted training occurs at least monthly and more often as needed.
Training by the contractor is individualized to QBH, using QBH’s policy, forms, etc., within the training content.

In the MAT program, it is important for administrative, financial, clerical, maintenance, security and custodial staffs to be recognized as part of the team.  Receptionists are often the first to speak to consumers and play an important role in the first impressions consumers establish about the program.  Their orientation should include education about how the MAT program operates so they develop positive attitudes about consumers.  They, as for clinical staffs, shall receive annual training on confidentiality requirements, cultural competence, prevention of workplace violence and consumer rights.
Training provided by the contractor include, minimally:
Competencies identified as needed by Company personnel in general and job specific.

For clinical staff this includes clinical skills applicable to their job, development of personalized treatment plans, interviewing skills, research, and best practices, based treatment modalities used, and other job specific skill requirements.
Confidentiality and HIPAA requirements.
Customer oriented service and consumer-centered services.
Cultural sensitivity and diversity.
Ethical codes of conduct.
Promoting consumer wellness and recovery as part of treatment.
Patient rights and personal privacy.
Reporting duties and process when suspected abuse, neglect or assault is identified.
Reporting duties and process when the rights of consumers being served and/or staff are violated.
Addressing the unique, person-centered needs of consumers served.
Training provided internally by QBH shall follow these guidelines:
An In-Service Record is used for internal training.  The record shall include:
Date, time, and length of in-service.
In-service topic and brief summary of content.
Name and qualifications of the instructor.
Teaching methods used and mechanism for evaluation.
Signatures of all staff who attended the full training.

The Office Manager is responsible to maintain a training calendar of training available each month and to post it where staff can see it.  Training is posted a month in advance of when it is scheduled.
All training for each staff is recorded in their personnel file; training beyond the current year may be kept in a separate file that is also considered part of the personnel file.

It staff attends job relevant workshops, conferences or seminars, they are responsible to turn in evidence of that training and the date(s) to the Office Manager for placement in their personnel file.

Any staff that takes formal courses at a college or university or online is responsible to turn in evidence of that training and the date(s) to the Office manager for inclusion in their personnel file.
Job descriptions for all positions are prepared in writing by the CEO or designee.
Staff will be classified in accordance with general duties, qualifications and special responsibilities. The description shall be made available to applicants and staff.
Continuous review of all positions for the purpose of adjusting allocations to positions, where duties and responsibilities are substantially changed, shall be made by the CEO.
Positions may be part-time or full-time.
Staff is paid on a salaried or hourly basis at a rate established for the position.
The full-time work week is forty hours minimum, and the part-time work week is anything less than forty hours.
Job descriptions are reviewed annually and updated as needed and shall contain, at a minimum:
Position title.
Department assignment, if applicable.
Supervisor’s title.
Positions this job supervises, if any.
Degree of supervision to be provided.
Tasks/responsibilities.
Scope of authority.
Qualifications for the position.
Physical/emotional demands of the job, including any specific capabilities essential to do the job.
Opportunities for promotion are somewhat limited within QBH but is provided when a promotion option exists for staff whose performance and length of service justify such opportunity.
All promotion decisions are made by the CEO, though consultation with other leadership may be employed in the process.
Promotion is based primarily upon:
Merit as determined by quality of performance, loyalty, and service motivation.
Length of service with QBH.
Demonstrated competency and qualifications for the position available for promotion consideration.
At no time shall there be any type of discrimination; the position is available to the most qualified person, with priority given to existing staff who meet the requirements listed here.
The work period is defined as eighty hours of work, minimum, scheduled over a two-week period (14 days) and ideally not to exceed forty hours per week.
Hours of work include a ½ hour paid lunch break.
This two-week work period shall constitute one bi-weekly pay period.  In certain situations supervisory pre-approved hours worked by staffs over forty hours shall be considered as compensatory time.
The workday shall normally consist of an assigned shift, with the exception of workers on call and supervisory back-up.
Scheduled hours and days of service and shift hours may vary depending upon service needs and at administrative supervisory discretion.

In the event any staff falls behind with regularly assigned work, the appropriate supervisory staff person may schedule a staff member to work regularly unscheduled hours or days to remediate this poor job performance.

Staff shall make requests for changes in work schedule in writing.  Temporary, short-term (not to exceed one bi-weekly pay period) and/or emergency scheduling changes may be made when mutually agreed upon between a staff and the supervisor.

In the event that a staff member is required and approved to work beyond their regularly scheduled hours in a given week, they will be compensated as follows: (The exception to this is when a staff member is working a modified schedule to remediate poor job performance.)
Salaried supervisory staff will be compensated with compensatory time at a rate of one hour for each hour worked in excess of forty hours per week.
Accumulated compensatory time must be utilized within the next pay-period unless otherwise approved by the CEO.
Accrual of compensatory time will be limited to 25 hours, unless extended at the discretion of the CEO.
“On call” compensation will be arranged and agreed to by contract or other supplementary agreement on an individual basis between the CEO and any given staff.

The CEO will determine all salaries within the annual budget as approved by the Board of Directors of QBH.  The annual budget may include an increase for salaries as determined by availability of funds.  Increases will be distributed to all staff on a merit basis as determined by an annual evaluation.

Pay Days: Compensation shall be paid monthly on the 10th of the month for the prior month’s work. Payroll checks will be distributed to staff upon receipt of the individual’s Staff Work Record for that work period.  Under extenuating circumstances, advances may be granted at the discretion of the CEO.

Deductions: Federal and State income tax deductions will be withheld from each paycheck.  Local taxes will be withheld where applicable.  Personnel may arrange with the accountant to have additional deductions for United Fund and tax sheltered annuities.  Deductions will be withheld for FICA (Social Security) through participation as required by law.

Expense Reimbursement: On the job travel requiring a staff member to incur expenses shall require approval of the CEO and shall be reimbursed by QBH.  Unusually large expenditures anticipated by a staff member may be submitted for a cash advance.  Mileage will be paid to staff using their own vehicle at the IRS approved rate.  When professional conference attendance is approved, meals, lodging, and other expenses may be allowed.  The amount will be determined by the CEO. Expense reports showing destinations, mileage and expenditure receipts shall be itemized and submitted monthly to the CEO for approval prior to payment.

No staff shall have a second job that interferes with the performance of the duties of their contract or which creates a conflict in loyalties, obligations or public image to QBH.  Staff contemplating supplemental employment shall discuss their intentions with the CEO; staff shall keep the CEO informed of contemplated changes in such employment.

QBH only assumes professional liability responsibility for staffs’ work during scheduled QBH work hours.  Staff who work for other agencies, or work privately on their own time, assume their own responsibility for any work or consumer contact that is separate from business conducted on behalf of QBH.

If in professional contact with a QBH consumer during non-QBH work hours, the staff member cannot represent themselves as working for QBH and must advise the consumer that they are not working for QBH during that time.
Conflict of interested by any staff or Board member must be revealed.

No staff or consultant of QBH shall have direct or indirect financial interest in the assets, leases, business transactions, or professional services of QBH unless such financial interest is disclosed and, in the judgment of the CEO, such financial interest is not detrimental to QBH’s best interests.
Political activity has restrictions in the workplace.

Personnel are encouraged to participate as citizens in the formation of public policy and election of candidates to public office.  The rights of each person to take a public stand on issues is respected, but staff is responsible to make clear, when so doing, that they act as individuals and not as representatives of QBH.   The premises shall not be used for political activity, including the positing or distribution of partisan literature or material, circulation of petitions, speeches, organizing political meetings, levying, solicitation, collection or payment of political assessment.
All appointments are subject to probationary periods of six months unless otherwise stated by employment contract.  During this probationary period, employment is AT WILL.

Within thirty days of the last day of the probationary period, the immediate supervisor shall prepare a written evaluation of performance together with recommendations regarding permanent employment and submit them to the CEO.  A probationary period may be extended at the discretion of the CEO.

During the probationary period of a newly hired staff, fringe benefits of permanent employment will accrue to the staff’s credit.  The entitlement to such benefits shall be limited to the express terms of any policy or contract through which the benefits are acquired by QBH (e.g., health, life insurance, etc.)

Personal leave may be used before the end of the initial probationary period.  Annual leave may not be used unless or until the initial probationary period is completed satisfactorily.  If termination notice is given by or to the staff during the probationary period, accrued annual leave will not be paid at the staff’s termination.
All staff (administrative, clinical, and support) will receive holiday compensation as outlines for staff in this policy.
QBH is of the opinion that the best way to avoid instances of disciplinary action is to make clear which behaviors lead to clear and unavoidable consequences.
Management reserves, among other things, the right to take disciplinary action for just cause for the purpose of correcting and/or modifying inappropriate job performance and/or behavior.

The disciplinary actions may include, but shall not be limited to, oral reprimands, written reprimands, and placement of disciplinary probation, suspension with or without pay, detention, and/or discharge.

subpolicies.title: RESIGNATION IN LIEU OF DISCIPLINARY ACTION

blocks.text: Where QBH decides to permit a staff member to resign in lieu of dismissal, the staff member must submit a resignation; the staff member shall be entitled to the same provisions stated previously in this policy.
Progressive discipline describes a system in which a staff member sustains a series of disciplinary actions which increase in severity as the number of offenses continues or increases.
This procedure provides the staff member with the opportunity to be cautioned of future discipline and to correct the inappropriate or problematic behavior.
Progressive discipline will be monitored on a Progressive Disciplinary Action Form.
The following infractions will lead to progressive discipline with predetermined disciplinary probation periods to be exercised at the discretion of the CEO:
Poor attendance and/or tardiness (6 months).  Absences for medical reasons do not necessarily excuse a staff member from discipline.
Poor job performance (6 months).
Rude or offensive behavior (6 months).
Inappropriate dress (3 months).
Carelessness resulting in loss, damage, or injury to QBH or QBH staff (12 months). Penalties will be levied in ascending order except when the CEO directs, at his/her discretion.
Performance determines a more severe response is indicated.

With the exception of probationary staff, staff shall be given notice as detailed previously before discharge for unsatisfactory performance.  QBH may pay him/her salary in lieu of notice except those staffs dismissed for abandonment of work site, misconduct involving moral turpitude, or substantially and adversely affecting the best interest of QBH, dishonesty, or gross misconduct.  In those cases, QBH is not required to give notice.
Demotion is defined as the transfer of a staff member from a position in one class to a position in a lower classification level.  A demotion may be made under any one of the following conditions:
Unsatisfactory service or misconduct.
Requested by the staff member.
The position occupied is discontinued for lack of funds or lack of work.
Reduction in work force.
Any staff may be demoted or placed on up to six months of probationary time after evidence of unsatisfactory performance consistent with the Disciplinary Action section of this policy.
In the event a newly hired probationary staff has their probation extended by the CEO, employment status can be terminated with or without notice during this extended probationary period.

A permanent staff’s employment may be terminated for just cause unless otherwise stated in an employment contract.  In the event QBH deems it necessary to terminate the staff for unsatisfactory performance, QBH shall pay his/her salary in lieu of notice.
No prior notice or payment of salary in lieu of notice shall be required for those staff dismissed for misconduct involving:
Reporting to work or remaining on duty while under the influence of or impaired by alcohol or current use of drugs.
Possession, sell or distribution of alcohol or illegal drugs on Company property or on Company time.
Theft or misappropriation of Company funds or belongings.
Violating confidence of information relating to consumers serviced by QBH or sensitive information relating to administrative concerns.
Any form of physical altercation with any individual while performing Company duties.
Abandonment of work site or leaving office without permission during scheduled work hours.
Sexual harassment (See Sexual Harassment within this policy.)
Insubordination.
Abusive or disrespectful behavior while performing Company business.
Substantially and adversely affecting the best interest of QBH.
Poor job performance that is rated as ineffective (between 1.0-2.0 on a performance evaluation).
Additionally, under these circumstances, there will be no pay out of accrued leave.

In the event of termination for unsatisfactory job performance or resignation, staff in all job classifications will be offered or expected to give four weeks’ notice, four weeks’ pay in lieu of notice, or a combination of notice and pay totaling four weeks.  This notice shall also be prerequisite for pay out of accrued annual leave.  The length of notice required may be waived at the discretion of the CEO.
All staff shall be informed in writing of the reasons for the termination of employment or contract.
Resignation also must be in writing.
A discharged staff member will be allowed to discuss his/her discharge with the CEO.

A staff member who abandons the work site during a scheduled shift, who fails to report for regularly scheduled hours without notification of the immediate supervisor, or who fails to return to work after an authorized leave of absence shall be considered to have abandoned their position and shall be subject to immediate termination at the discretion of the CEO.
There shall be no entitlement of payment for accrued annual vacation and personal leave under any of these conditions:
Insufficient notice of resignation.
Failure to return Company property (e.g., keys, books, etc.)
Poor job performance (e.g., failure to complete work, documentation of work or services).

In the event of a necessary layoff, QBH shall provide ten weekdays’ notice of layoff.  In case of layoff or re-hiring following a layoff, previous performance and seniority will be considered.  External regulatory requirements will also be considered.  Five working days’ notice of recall will be provided by registered or certified mail.
Under no circumstances shall a staff member be entitled to more than eighty hours of payment for accrued annual vacation and personal leave upon termination.
Staff is required to adhere to the Code of Conduct Policy.  This section elaborates on some specific issues of conduct only.
Under no circumstances shall the possession, use, sell or distribution of alcohol or drugs be allowed on the premises of, or during the delivery of service for, QBH by any staff or contract provider.

To prevent drugs and alcohol and other contraband from being brought onto QBH’s premises, QBH may, at its discretion, inspect any locker, package, desk, purse, toolbox, vehicle, or other personal belonging brought onto QBH premises in connection with the investigation of any rule violations or in the maintenance of a safe workplace.  Staff will cooperate in all investigations of suspected rule violations or workplace safety.
QBH reserves the right to require applicants to submit to drug testing, and staff to submit to reasonable suspicion drug testing at its discretion, or alcohol testing where appropriate.
Staff suspended or discharged under this policy will be sent home by means of available transportation with a driver.

QBH prohibits any form of harassment, joking remarks, or other abusive conduct directed at staff because of their race, color, sex, religion, national origin, age, handicap, height or weight, arrest record, veteran status, marital status, or membership in another protected group.

It is QBH’s policy to maintain a working environment free from inappropriate, disrespectful conduct or communication of a sexual nature.  Furthermore, it is this Company’s aim to prohibit sexual harassment among its staff, including discriminatory sexual advances or harassment that may affect a staff’s terms or conditions of employment/contract.  QBH prohibits sexual harassment of its staff in any form.  Such conduct may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination.

No supervisor shall threaten or insinuate, either explicitly or implicitly, that another staff’s refusal to submit to sexual advances will adversely affect the staff’s employment/contract, evaluation, wages, advancement, assigned duties, shifts, or any other condition of employment, contract or career development.

Other sexually harassing conduct in the workplace, whether committed by supervisors or non-supervisory personnel, is also prohibited.  This includes repeated, offensive sexual flirtations or contact, advances, propositions; continual or repeated verbal abuse of a sexual nature; graphic verbal commentaries about an individual’s body; sexually degrading words used to describe an individual; and the display in the workplace of sexually suggestive objects or pictures.
Staff is alerted this if they experience any type of harassment or discrimination, they should report it to their supervisor or to the CEO.
Sexual harassment, by definition, can take the following forms:
Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of an individual’s employment/contract.
Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as a basis for employment or contract decisions affecting such individual.
Such conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an individual’s work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive working environment.
Steps to follow if a report of discrimination or harassment occurs:

Supervisors should discuss any concerns with a staff member who feels that s/he is the victim of discrimination or harassment.  If possible, the compliant should be resolved at that time.  If the staff member is not comfortable discussing the matter with his/her supervisor, the matter may be discussed with another supervisor.  Supervisors should oversee that discrimination complaints are resolved promptly and effectively.

If the staff member is not satisfied with the results of this discussion, the supervisor should advise the staff member to bring the complaint to the CEO in writing, in person, or by telephone, with in-person or telephone conversations to be followed up in writing by either party.

The complaint will be investigated by the supervisor or CEO and the staff member will be advised of the findings and conclusion.  Should the decision be adverse to the staff member, s/he may file a grievance pursuant to the Formal Grievance Procedure section in this policy.
All actions taken to resolve complaints through internal reviews are conducted in the strictest confidence.

No individual shall be intimidated, threatened, coerced, or discriminated against for filing a complaint, furnishing information or for participating in any manner in an investigation, compliance review, hearing or any other activity related to the administration of the laws and regulations to employ and advance staff.

Any supervisor who receives a copy of a discrimination complaint from any government Company should immediately inform the CEO.  Once a formal complaint to a government Company has been filed by a staff member, a supervisor may not discuss the complaint with the staff member without the specific approval and presence of the CEO.
It is the policy of QBH to see that the consumer’s rights as specified in Public Act 258 shall be protected conscientiously.
To achieve this each consumer is to receive the appropriate brochures regarding their rights and the grievance process at the initial face-to-face interview.
The staff conducting this interview will oversee that all provisions are interpreted at the level of the consumer’s comprehension.
A form indicating receipt of the brochure and interpretation is to be included in the record of the consumer.
Stamped on the brochure shall be the name and phone number of the Recipient Rights Advisor.
If a consumer alleges a violation of their rights, they may make a report to QBH’s Recipient Rights Advisor who is responsible for investigating and resolving (where possible) the complaint.
The outcome is made available to the consumer, QBH and the appropriate regulatory body.

If the consumer is not satisfied with the resolution of the complaint, it can be appealed to the Central Office of Recipient Rights, Lewis Cass Building, Lansing, MI; the Department of Social Services; or any other regulatory body as appropriate to the concern.
In the event the dispute occurs in a program not covered by the regulations of the preceding governmental units, the case will be presented to the QBH Governing Board for resolution.

It is required by law that any person employed, licensed, certified or registered to provide mental health services report any evidenced or suspected adult or child abuse, neglect or exploitation to the Michigan Department of Social Services
All staff must immediately notify, by telephone, the Department of Social Services and the Recipient Rights Advisor of any evidenced or suspected abuse, neglect or exploitation.
If criminal activity is suspected, notify the police.

Any staff found, after appropriate investigation, to have abused the rights of consumers as outlined in Public Act 258 shall be subject to discipline up to and including discharge.  Likewise, any staff member who is aware of abuse committed by another staff and who does not report this to the CEO or Recipient Rights Advisor shall be subject to discipline up to and including discharge.

Pursuant to Michigan Compiled Laws (MCL) 750.1946 of Public Act 258 and consistent with section MCL 330.1750 of Public Act 350, public funded mental health agencies and their staffs have a “duty to warn” a third person of a threat of violence against them.
The factors to consider whether, or not, there is an affirmative “duty to warn” are:
The consumer must have communicated the threat of violence to a staff member.
The threat of violence must have been against a reasonably identifiable third person.
The consumer must have the ability to carry out the threat in the foreseeable future.
The staff is deemed to have met the “duty to warn” if the staff:
Hospitalizes the consumer or initiates proceedings for hospitalization.
Makes a reasonable attempt to communicate the threat to the third person and communicates the threat also to the local police, sheriff, or state police.
Communicates the threat to the Department of Social Services, or the third party’s guardian or caretaker, if the threatened third party is a minor or incompetent other than by age.

All staff is expected to consult with their respective supervisor in order to fulfill their individual and Company requirements of “duty to warn.”  Any staff person found not having done so is subject to discipline up to and including discharge.  Likewise, any staff member who is aware of a situation where “duty to warn” has not occurred by another staff and who does not report this to the CEO or his/her designee shall be subject to discipline up to and including discharge.
All records, plans, consumer associations and policies are strictly confidential.
No information about a consumer may be released to anyone unless written permission from the consumer or their guardian is obtained.  See the Consumer Medical Record Policy for more specifics.
Relatives of Board members, Company administrators and/or supervisors, and all other staff shall not be afforded favored treatment with respect to obtaining consumer services at QBH.
All staff, regardless of classification, is eligible for the following benefits effective June 1, 2017:
Coverage for Worker’s Compensation and Unemployment Insurance as provided by law.
FICA payments in accordance with provisions of the Social Security Act.
Public and professional liability (malpractice) insurance is carried by QBH.
For any staff carrying their own professional liability coverage, QBH policy is a secondary, excess limit policy.
Contract staff must carry their own professional liability insurance coverage.
In addition, QBH does provide excess limit personal injury and property damage liability for staff that transport Company consumers or use their personal vehicles for Company business.
This coverage is secondary to the staff’s personally held liability coverage as required by the state of Michigan.
Additional benefits are available to staff as follows, subject to the restrictions noted:
Health Insurance
All staff shall be entitled up to full family coverage, exclusive of coverage for sponsored dependents, under a health insurance plan approved by QBH if they meet the following criteria:
Staff must be regularly scheduled to work 24 hours per week or more to be eligible for coverage.
Staff scheduled and working full-time is entitled to have 80% of their premiums paid by QBH.

Staff scheduled to work less than full-time but 24 hours or more weekly is entitled to a pro-rated portion of the premium to be paid by QBH; the balance will be deducted from their payroll check monthly, based upon the number of work hours scheduled and worked.
Temporary staff is not eligible for this benefit.
Staff may elect not to receive the Health Insurance Benefit and receive, in lieu of the benefit, the Health Insurance Waiver of Premium.
In the event a staff member elects to accept the Health Insurance Premium Waiver of Premium, the following procedures must be followed:
Staff that elects to not participate in QBH health insurance benefit will sign a waiver agreement.
Staff may sign the waiver agreement during their initial processing meeting after hire or before the 20th of any month.

A staff must be out of the health insurance plan for a full 3 months/quarter in order to receive the full waiver premium.  Staff that sign up or become eligible for the health insurance waiver premium in the middle of a period will receive pro-rata share of the premium.
The premium is paid four times a year at the last day of every calendar quarter.
Part-time staff that elects to sign the waiver agreement, and work 24 hours or more per week, will receive a pro-rata share of the premium based upon the number of hours worked.
The amount of the waiver premium may be subject to change as the program is periodically evaluated by QBH.
Holidays
The following holidays are recognized by QBH:
Nationally observed Martin Luther King Day
Presidents Day – 3rd Monday in February
Good Friday – 4 hours
Nationally observed Memorial Day
Veteran’s Day
National Election Day
Thanksgiving Day and Thanksgiving Friday
Christmas Day
For holidays falling on Saturday, the previous Friday will be granted as the holiday; when a holiday falls on Sunday, the following Monday will be granted as the holiday.
A holiday falling within a scheduled vacation will not count as a vacation day.

Part-time staff and contract staff in any position are NOT eligible to receive holiday pay.  If required to work on holidays, temporary or contract staff is paid their regular hourly rate unless they are eligible for overtime compensation.
Vacation Leave
All staff, exclusive of temporary staff, with a weekly schedule of 24 or more hours shall be entitled to annual vacation leave.

Leave will accrue from the date of employment.  However, staff will not be eligible to use or receive payment for such accrued leave until after removal from probation at the completion of six months of continuous and satisfactory employment.
A staff member rendering a resignation prior to six months shall not be eligible for, or entitled to, payment of accrued annual leave.
Non-fulltime staff may receive payment for more than eighty hours of annual leave and requests for annual leave should be made to the immediate supervisor for approval by the CEO or designee.
Approval shall be based upon the work load of QBH.
The preference of the staff shall be considered whenever possible.
Full-time staff will accrue leave at the following rate:
Part-time staff will accrue annual leave pro-rated by the percentage of time worked.
Temporary and contract staff are not eligible to accrue vacation leave.
Non-vacation leave will accrue for compensatory hours of personal leave upon notice and termination of employment
Personal Leave
All full-time staff is eligible to be awarded personal leave.
Temporary and contract staff are not eligible to be awarded personal leave.
Newly hired probationary staff that resign or are otherwise terminated during the probationary period will not be eligible to be paid for unused personal leave.
At the end of each year of employment (as indicated by anniversary date), unused personal leave hours will be converted to annual leave.
When using personal time for reasons of illness, staff must notify supervisory staff at least one hour before their scheduled shift.

This notification must be by telephone contact by the staff themselves or, if the staff is unable to contact QBH him/herself, the notification of illness given by a third party may be accepted by the CEO.

For extended illness, over three consecutive days, a medical report may be requested to be submitted to the CEO or designee at their discretion; the CEO may request a medical report regarding ability to work after any sick leave.

After the use of all accrued personal leave and annual leave, QBH will allow each staff member up to one month (30 calendar days) of leave of Absence without Pay upon presentation of proof of illness.
The CEO may grant an extension of additional leave of absence without pay upon receipt of a written request by the staff.
The staff’s seniority remains at the same level during this period of leave of absence without pay.
The policy will be practiced consistent with QBH’s plan for Short and Long Term Disability and the policy for Leave of Absence without Pay.
Upon termination of a period of disability, every effort will be made to reinstate the staff.
The level of seniority that had been attained at the commencement of leave will be reinstated.
In the event that no vacancy exists, the staff’s leave will be converted to layoff status upon termination of disability with full rights of recall.
Bereavement Leave

Each staff shall be granted three days annually for Bereavement Leave.  This is excused time off work for death in the immediate family (grandparents, parents, siblings, natural or legally adopted children and children for whom legal guardianship is held).
Parental Leave
The following conditions apply to requests for and granting of parental leave:
After the sixth month of pregnancy, a physician’s certificate will be necessary stating that the staff member’s fitness for work in order to continue active employment.
A staff must have completed at least one year of continuous employment to be eligible for this leave.
A physician’s certification that the staff is physically unable to perform their regular job duties as a result of the pregnancy is required to substantiate the disability of a staff.
If a staff member requests parental leave beyond the period of disability s/he must use appropriate accrued leave before a Leave of Absence without Pay will be approved.

A total of up to one month of Leave of Absence without Pay will be granted upon written request.  A full extension of up to four months parental leave without pay may be granted under the same terms and conditions applicable to annual leave requests upon receipt of written request from the staff.

Upon termination of parental leave, every effort will be made to reinstate the staff member.  The level of seniority that has been attained at the commencement of the parental leave will be reinstated. In the event that no vacancy exists,  the staff’s leave will be converted to layoff status upon determination of parental leave with full rights of recall.
Educational Leave for Professional Purposes
The CEO may grant leave with pay for attendance at seminars, institutes and conferences which will enhance the skills of the staff.
QBH may provide an allowance for travel and living expenses with the amounts determined by the administration.
Leave of absence without pay may be allowed for educational or other purposes with the approval of the CEO.
Leave of Absence without Pay
The CEO may grant leave of absence without pay to staff that request it.

During the leave of absence, the staff will not accrue additional leave or other benefits and must use accumulated annual vacation leave, personal leave and banked compensatory time before the leave of absence begins.  If a vacancy exists, the staff that is granted the leave of absence without pay shall be reinstated upon termination of such leave to a position at the level of seniority s/he had attained at commencement of his/he unpaid leave of absence.
The payment of health, life and disability insurance premiums is the responsibility of the staff during the period of unpaid leave of absence.
Military Leave
Leave will be granted in accordance with law.

The staff’s position, or a position of like classification and pay, will be restored if the staff reports to work within ninety days of discharge and presents proof of discharge under honorable conditions.
Jury Duty
In the event of being called for jury duty, staff has two options:
They may take jury duty leave for up to two weeks and continue to receive their regular salary and return the jury duty reimbursement to QBH; or
They may take annual vacation leave, receive their regular salary, and retain the jury duty reimbursement.
Benefits for Staff in Non-Pay Status
Staff on indefinite layoff: if the staff’s anniversary date follows the layoff date, the staff shall not be entitled to any of the fringe benefits that would have accrued to that anniversary date.

Rehiring of laid off staff: Staff that is recalled from a period of indefinite layoff and who accept re-employment with QBH.  At the time of rehire, such staff will be given personal leave and any applicable longevity leave pro-rated according to the new employment schedule and the number of months remaining before their next anniversary date.
Worker’s Compensation Disability
QBH is insured for Workman’s Compensation Disability under the State of Michigan Worker’s Compensation Law.
Bodily injury by accident - $100,000 each accident/$500,000 policy limit
Bodily injury by disease - $100,000 each staff

A grievance is a written complaint of a violation of these Personnel Management Policies, procedures, conditions of employment or contract, or claim of discipline without just cause.  The grievance must contain the following:
The date of the alleged violation.
The nature of the alleged violation.
The person against whom the grievance is filed.
The citation of the violation of the personnel policies, procedures, rules, regulations, or conditions of employment or contract, or discipline administered without just cause.

Staff shall have the right to present formal grievances in person at the appropriate steps of the grievance procedure.  Any individual staff may at any time present a grievance(s) to his/her supervisor and/or have the grievance adjusted.

Grievances which by nature cannot be settled at a preliminary step of the grievance procedure must be filed at the step where the action giving rise to the grievance was initiated and where the relief requested by the grieving party could be granted.

Group grievances are defined as, and limited to, those grievances which cover more than one staff and which arise out of substantially the same set of facts and circumstances for the grieving party involved.  Group grievances shall be so designated at the first appropriate step of the grievance procedure, although names may be added prior to the hearing date.  Grievances may, upon mutual agreement of the parties, be submitted or converted to group grievances under this provision.
When an individual grieving is satisfied with a stipulated resolution or a grievance, processing of the grievance will end.
Submission

Step 1: This step may be omitted if the grievance is filed at an agreed upon advanced step as described above.  Upon receipt of a formal written grievance, the supervisor will schedule a meeting with the grieving party to discuss the grievance.
This meeting will occur within five business days from the date of receipt of the formal written grievance.
A written response to the grievance, with a discussion of the reasons and/or rationale for the response, will be given to the grieving staff within five business days of the meeting.
Step 2: This grievance must be appealed to the CEO within five business days from the date of receipt of the written response addressed in Step 1.
The appeal must contain a statement responding directly to the supervisor’s Step 1 response.
The CEO shall, within seven business days, schedule a Step 2 meeting with the grieving party to consider the merits of the appeal.

A written response to the appeal will be returned to the staff within five business days of the Step 2 appeal meeting.  The answer will be responsive to the grievance and shall indicate the basis for the determination.
The parties involved in the grievance situation recognize the authority of QBH to suspend, demote, discharge, or take other appropriate disciplinary action against a staff for just cause.
A staff member who alleges that such action was not based on just cause may appeal a demotion, suspension or discharge taken by QBH beginning with Step 2 of the Grievance Procedure.
Step 3: The grievance must be appealed to the Board of Directors within five business days of receipt of the Step 2 written response.
The Step 3 appeal shall also contain a statement responding directly to the Step 2 response.
The Board of Directors shall schedule a Step 3 hearing with the grieving party within fifteen calendar days from the receipt of the Step 3 appeal request.
The Board will consider the merits of the appeal.
A written response will be returned to the grieving staff by certified mail, return receipt requested, within ten calendar days of this hearing.
The answer will be responsive to the appeal and shall indicate the basis for the determination.

Grievances may be withdrawn without prejudice at Step 1 of the grievance.  In such cases, it may be reinstated based upon evidence not previously available to the grieving party.  Failure to reinstate within one year of withdrawal voids the grievance.

Grievances not appealed within the designated time limits of the Grievance Procedure will automatically result in the grievance being considered fully resolved and terminated on the basis of QBH’s written response at the previous step.  The time limit at any step or for any hearing may be extended by written mutual agreement of the parties involved at that particular step.
Grievance Filing/Responding by Mail

If a staff member files a written grievance or appeal at a location other than the assigned worksite, the mailing of the grievance appeal form shall constitute timely appeal if it is postmarked within the appeal timelines addressed in Steps 2 and 3.

When an Company written response must be forwarded to a city other than that in which QBH Representative works, the mailing of the written response shall constitute timely response if it is postmarked within the response timeframes addressed in the Steps.

Settlement of grievances may or may not be retroactive, depending upon the circumstances of the particular case.  In no event shall retroactivity extend to a situation occurring in period greater than 180 days preceding the filing of the grievance.
The grievance procedure set out above shall be exclusive and shall replace any other grievance procedure for adjustment of any dispute.
Grievance meetings may be held during the regularly scheduled hours of employment of the grieving party and as mutually agreed between the parties involved.

All staff shall, throughout the grievance procedure, treat each other with courtesy and respect.  A staff member who files a grievance following the procedure set forth above, shall not be discriminated against during or after the grievance process.
A copy of the staff member’s grievance(s) and any responses to it shall be filed in the staff’s personnel file.
A staff member shall have the right, upon request, to review his/her personnel file, excluding any confidential documents, at reasonable intervals.
The file review shall normally take place at the location of the personnel file and during QBH’s normal office hours.
The staff member shall review the file in the presence of the CEO or his/her designee, in compliance with the Bullard-Plawecki Act of 1979.
A staff member may request QBH to remove information from the staff’s personnel file which has been placed there in error.
Such request shall be in writing and shall specify with particularity, what document or part of the file contents is in error and how the staff proposes to correct the file.
The staff must demonstrate to QBH’s satisfaction that the information is in fact incorrect.
If the information is in error, the incorrect information will be expunged from the file.

In the absence of an agreement between QBH and the staff about the accuracy of the information, the staff has the option of submitting comments about the item to QBH and of having it included in their personnel file.
Such staff statement(s) shall remain in their personnel file so long as the original information, accompanied by the statement reporting the disagreement, is part of the file.

With the exception of verifying the dates of employment or contract and termination date, QBH will not release information from a staff member’s personnel file without a signed Release of Information Form specifying the information to be released.
This policy does not prohibit the releasing of such information where:
The staff has waived the right of written authorization as part of a written, signed and dated employment application with another Company; or
The disclosure is ordered by a subpoena in a legal action or arbitration at the request of a party in that legal action or arbitration; or
The information is requested by and provided to a governmental center as a result of a claim or complaint by a QBH staff with such government center.
Access to individual personnel files shall be restricted to authorized persons and the staff member themselves.
This policy shall not be construed to expand or diminish a right of access to records as provided for in Act 442 of the Public Act of 1976, or as otherwise provided by law.
The privileging/credentialing file is a separate folder within the personnel file and under differing procedures than for personnel files.  However, it is stored with the personnel file.
QBH maintains individualized personnel files as a record of employment
The personnel file shall be maintained by the Office Manager and shall contain, minimally, the contents listed below:
Date of employment
Company application
Fingerprint (if applicable) and criminal check results and authorizations
MVD report of driving records and authorizations, if applicable
Evidence of primary source verification  of licensure, certification, experience, training/education
Three references, including verbal as documented by the Office Manager, or designee
Wage, salary and benefits information
Performance appraisals, including competency verifications
Health clearances (stored in a separate secure health file within HR, but not with the personnel file as per OSHA requirements)
