It shall be the responsibility of the Office Manager to maintain a tickler file (manual or computerized) for the purpose of keeping personnel file/health file contents current.
The tickler file shall be accessed on the first working day of each month to note what items are due to expire during the following month.

The Office Manager shall alert the staff/contract provider and their supervisor, if applicable, by written memorandum of the item due to expire and direct the staff/contract provider to provide the updated information by the first business day of the next month or to immediately complete a Release of Information Form, if primary source verification is required to be done by the Office Manager.

Once the information is returned and/or validated, if necessary, the tickler system will be updated by the Office Manager and the information placed in the staff member’s personnel file or health file.
Any staff/contract provider who fails to provide the updated information within thirty (30) days may be suspended from providing service until the information is provided, at the CEO’s discretion.
The person may also be allowed to work but in a different position.  The action decision is made on a case by case basis by the CEO who factors the issue and the position into his/her decision.
A STAFF MEMBER CANNOT WORK UNLESS OR UNTIL QBH HAS A RECORD OF VERIFICATION OF CURRENT LICENSE/CERTIFICATION, IF APPLICABLE TO THE JOB POSITION.
The tickler file shall track, minimally:
All professional license/certification numbers and expiration dates
When CPR and First Aid certificate updates are due
Tb skin test due date
When criminal check updates are due each year
When MVD record updates are due each year
Re-privileging dates (30 days before expiration of current privileges) for privileged staffs
Performance evaluation/competency verification due dates at end of probation and annually
Supervision due dates
Primary source verification is the responsibility of the Office Manager or, if a contract exists, by a Credentials Verification Organization (CV0).

Any verification unsuccessfully completed by the CVO must be followed up on and completed by the Office Manager.  (If this occurs frequently, the Office Manager shall notify the CEO so that contract performance may be assessed.)

Primary source verification may be done by printing a verification form from an official electronic website (for example, if a licensing board has a program for electronic verification of individual’s licenses, a copy of the verification in the staff’s personnel file will suffice), by a written verification on official letterhead of the primary source organization, or by verbal confirmation received by the Officer Manager, or designee, that is notated in the personnel file.

When done by verbal verification, the Office Manager shall not give the information to the primary source but rather asks the primary source for the information and verifies it against the information the applicant provided.

Verbal verification shall be documented on the Personnel File Checklist, including signature of who, from QBH, verified, the name and title of the person from the primary source that provided the information, and the date the verification was done.
Any discrepancies in what the applicant reported and what the primary source provided shall be reported immediately to the CEO.
Whatever the method of verification, it shall be maintained and kept current within the individual staff’s personnel file at all times.
The verification shall be added to the tickler system by the Office Manager, including when the next verification is due, if applicable.

QBH may engage an independent contractor to provide specific services over a designated period of time.  All terms and conditions of the contractual relationship, including length of contract; the services to be provided; the procedures for payment; the payment plan; benefits, if applicable; and where applicable, definition of the consumers serviced; and a requirement to comply with applicable Company policies and JC standards, are to be addressed in the purchase of service agreement.

As these individuals are not employees of QBH, obligations, responsibilities and rights are covered by their purchase of service agreement and not by these policies, except where specifically noted in the agreement or these policies.

QBH may contractually engage the clinical services of individuals with an existing Company-staff relationship to provide services in QBH’s program(s).  These individuals will be considered as employees for withholding purposes.
Contracted personnel shall function under a job description or a written list of responsibilities shall be included in the purchase of service agreement.
Performance under the contract shall be evaluated annually, using the Contract Evaluation Form, and consider, minimally:
Compliance with applicable policies and procedures of QBH;
Conformance to JC standards that apply to the services provided;
Quality and completeness of services provided;
Consistency of performance with contract agreement.

Two months prior to contract renewal, the Contract Evaluation Form will be distributed by the Office Manager to three persons that are familiar with the contract provider’s activities and performance.

At the time of the contract renewal, the results of these evaluations will be reviewed with the contract provider and any improvement activities will be documented and included in any contract renewal.
Each renewal shall be maintained in the contractor’s contract and/or personnel file.

The Office Manager shall maintain a contract file (this may be in addition to a personnel file if the person is providing clinical services at QBH) and a tickler system for each contract provider.  The contract file shall include, minimally:
The signed purchase of service agreement.

Copies of and/or verification of all required licenses, certificates or registrations, if applicable; fingerprint, criminal record, and MVD reports or authorizations, if applicable; letters of reference, as applicable.
Copies of verification of license or certification, if applicable (contract staff providing services must meet the same requirements as for employee staff for the same job position).
Copy of professional liability insurance and documentation by insurance company of any past, pending or current activity.
Signed and dated job description (unless spelled out in the agreement/contract).
Performance and competency validations.
Funding contracts are addressed under separate policy.
Volunteers are defined as those persons who perform tasks on behalf of QBH without remuneration.
Volunteers are recruited from among staff, other human service agencies, religious/fraternal /business agencies, and the general public.
The requirements for use of, education of and rules of conduct for, volunteers shall be approved by the Board of Directors.
The CEO or designee is responsible for the overall recruitment, selection, and orientation/training of volunteers.  All volunteers must be mature, reliable, and able to meet specific Company needs.
Each volunteer receives direct supervision by the staff to which s/he is assigned, unless otherwise specified.

Written qualifications, duties and scope of responsibility are formulated into a job description for each volunteer; the volunteer must provide documentation that demonstrates the qualifications for the position are met.  The supervisor is responsible for the evaluation of the volunteer at the end of the period of service or annually.

Should a volunteer violate Company policy, fail to perform their job, or otherwise behave in a manner unacceptable at QBH, they will be disciplined in the same fashion as staff, up to and including dismissal before the end of their contract.

Volunteers are subject to Company policies and JC standards, rules and regulations relating to all other staff; however, specific procedures and conditions of volunteer participation, as identified below also pertain to volunteers:
Screening: the person offering volunteer services shall follow employment application procedures, meeting the same requirements, including background checks, as an employee in the same/similar role.

Placement: placement of a volunteer shall be decided jointly between the volunteer, CEO or designee, and the professional staff person under whose supervision the volunteer will work.  Placement is determined based upon appropriate skills and qualifications of the volunteer and QBH’s need for the assignment.

Orientation and Training: Volunteers shall be provide with basic written materials regarding QBH and shall be given sufficient orientation and instruction to perform as required.  The volunteer’s training will be documented and maintained in the office of the Office Manager in the same fashion as personnel files of employed/contracted staffs.
Contract: There shall be a clear and written understanding between the volunteer and QBH regarding:
Time commitment
Duties/scope of responsibility
Insurance coverage/non-coverage
Promised effort
Job related risks and liabilities
Confidentiality requirements

Students are defined as those persons who serve at QBH through agreement between QBH,  student/intern, and an institution of higher learning in a placement for which the student/intern will receive some form of academic credit for satisfactory completion of given tasks or assignments over a specified period of time.
Students will be supervised and evaluated in the same manner as professional staff, in addition to the evaluation process the learning institution has in place.

Should a student/intern violate Company policy, fail to perform their job, or otherwise behave in a manner unacceptable at QBH, they will be disciplined in the same fashion as staff, up to and including dismissal before the end of their contract.

Students/interns are subject to Company policies and JC standards, rules and regulations relating to all other staff; however, specific procedures and conditions of student/intern participation, as identified below also pertain to students/interns:

Screening: the person offering student/intern services shall follow employment application procedures, meeting the same requirements, including background checks, as an employee in the same/similar role.  If the student/intern has already met some of these requirements through the training institution, the training institution is required to provide copies of this information to QBH for the student/intern’s personnel record.

Orientation and Training: Either the training institution or QBH staff shall provide necessary orientation to students/interns, as set forth in the agreement with the student and training institution with QBH.
Contract: There shall be a clear and written understanding between the student/intern, the training institution, and QBH regarding:
Time commitment
Duties/scope of responsibility
Insurance coverage/non-coverage
Promised effort and reimbursement, if any
Job/training related risks and liabilities
Confidentiality requirements

Pursuant to the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) the following procedure and practice will serve as the means for QBH and all staff to arbitrate any dispute which may arise during the period of employment/contract with QBH.

This policy covers all terms, aspects and potential disputes that may arise as a result of employment/contract between QBH and all staff unless otherwise stated and includes claims that may be brought toward a third party such as a fellow staff.
This policy specifically covers all disputes that may occur that relate to the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA).  This policy does, however, exclude all workers’ compensation claims.
In as much as this policy binds the staff to arbitrate claims against QBH, it also obligates QBH to arbitrate the staff’s claims.

It is clearly understood between all parties that no dispute may be litigated in a court of law and that arbitration of all issues covered by this policy shall be final and binding.  This policy binds both parties to waive all rights to a jury trial with regard to employment/contract disputes covered by the agreement.

The American Arbitration Association Commercial Rules regarding final and binding arbitrations published by the American Arbitration Association (AAA) will be utilized in the settlement of all disputes covered by this policy.
The arbitrator involved in the settlement of a dispute may not add to, subtract from, modify any contract between the parties, or award punitive damages.
Pre-hearing “discovery” including an exchange of relevant documents and lists of witnesses and the taking of depositions will occur, where needed.

It is the intent of this policy to allow for a full and fair hearing, including adequate notice, the right to present evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and the right to legal counsel of which is the financial responsibility of each party to pay their own associated legal fees.
The arbitrator shall issue a written decision.

All disputes will be presented for binding arbitration within six months of having pursued all administrative relief as outlined in the Human Resources Personnel Management Policies of QBH; otherwise both parties forfeit their right to make claim.
The cost of arbitration would be shared between all parties on an equal basis unless otherwise decided by the arbitrator as part of their written decisions outlined above.

This Policy will be reviewed by the Personnel Manager annually and revisions made when necessary.  The Policy will be forwarded to the Clinical Committee for review and approval when revisions are made and at a minimum of yearly.

sections.title: QBH MAT PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT MANAGEMENT.policy  FINAL  6 17

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. shall use and maintain its facilities and physical environment in a manner that is consistent with standards of service delivery considering the safety and wellbeing of all consumers, staff, and visitors.

To provide guidelines for safe, efficient and sanitary use of the physical environment. The Organization shall provide a comfortable, protected environment against the spread of disease and infection and be appropriately equipped by:
Monitoring compliance with all pertinent aspects of the Michigan Department of Health Services facility licensing standards and other applicable laws, regulations, and requirements.
Providing the availability of adequate maintenance and janitorial services for the Organization.
Maintaining written records of all inspections conducted and of the necessary corrective actions taken.
Controlling the purchase, storage, distribution, and inventory of Pronghorn Psychiatry equipment and supplies.
Staff responsibility:
Observe appropriate standards of cleanliness and safety.

Report in writing any problems or deficiencies in the use or maintenance of Organization facilities and physical environment to their immediate supervisor in a timely manner so that appropriate corrective actions may be taken.
Maintain a safe workplace environment by:

Keeping filing cabinet drawers closed when not in use, opening only one drawer at a time, placing heavier items in bottom drawers, not stacking heavy items on top of file cabinets, and closing overhead cabinet doors when not in use to prevent injuries.

Using handles/knobs when closing drawer/doors; using a ladder or step stool to reach high shelves; using correct body mechanics when moving, lifting, or reaching; having another staff member present to steady the ladder or step stool if possible; and asking for help when it would make the task easier and safer.
Cleaning up spills immediately. Broken glass or sharp objects are to be placed in special containers. Do not pick up glass with fingers.  Contact Housekeeping for assistance if needed.
Avoiding clutter in work areas; keeping floors and counter tops free from paper clips, staples, pencils, rubber bands, and all unnecessary items.
All furnishings shall be kept free from dirt, in good repair, and shall contribute to creating a positive therapeutic and/or work environment.

Entry to or exit from the Organization shall be conducted according to security policies.  Pronghorn Psychiatry shall be accessible to handicapped persons by providing accommodations that facilitate parking, building entry, bathroom access, and counseling area access.

All areas of the building shall be climatically controlled at a temperature of at least 70 F. during waking hours. The building temperature shall not exceed 85 F.  Electrical fans, except ceiling paddle fans, are not permitted. Ceiling fans shall have a regular cleaning schedule. The use of vented or open-flame space heaters is prohibited.

Garbage containers with lids are to be large enough for waste needs and must be rodent and insect proof. Containers must be in good condition without cracks, holes, and be leak proof. All food products and food containers will be kept off the floor.  All spilled food will immediately be cleaned up.
All trash is to be bagged and tied.  Trash is gathered up during daily cleaning rounds.  Bagged trash is put in city dumpster.
When lifting heavy objects:
Look over the object to be lifted; make sure it is not too heavy or too clumsy.
Stand close to the object with feet apart for balance; make sure footing is secure.
Bend knees.  Keep back as straight as possible.
Get a good grip and keep the weight close to your body.
Lift gradually.  Straighten knees and stand.  Use leg muscles.  Avoid quick, jerky motions.
When the weight is too heavy or the object is too bulky to lift safely, get help.
Pushing and pulling objects:
Get a good grip on the object; hands inside handles.
Keep your back as straight as possible.
Brace your feet for maximum leg power.
Bend your knees to get the best use of your body weight.
Carrying an object:
Keep the load close to your body.
Make sure your vision is clear and the load does not obstruct your view.
Don’t change your grip while carrying the load.
Face the spot on which the load will rest.
Safety Officer, or designee, responsibility:

Oversee that the Organization is clean, free of hazards, such as cracks in the floors, walks, ceilings; warped or loose boards or tile, linoleum, hand rails or railings; broken window panes; and any similar type of hazard.
Interior and exterior building surfaces shall be appropriately maintained and repaired.

Surveillance inspections of the surrounding grounds and landscaping, patios, and parking lots will routinely be conducted to locate potentially dangerous conditions, obstructions, sharp edges, burned out lights, etc.
Findings will be documented in the appropriate inspection/maintenance logs that are kept in the EOC Manual. A Maintenance Request will be completed as necessary as a result of the inspections.
Administration Responsibility
Drinking water shall be readily available through the provision of water cooler in the waiting room areas and day rooms will have water jugs.
Indoor areas shall be available for group social and therapeutic gatherings and private areas for conversation and therapy.
Clocks and calendars shall be available to promote awareness of time and day.
Telephones that allow a consumer to conduct private conversations shall be available in accordance with Consumer Rights.
Lighting shall be adequate to promote clear perceptions of people, functions, reading, and activities.
Books, magazines, arts and crafts, and television shall be available in accordance with all consumers’ educational, cultural recreational background, age, and needs.
Each consumer shall be provided with adequate storage space.
Personal items may be displayed in accordance to Organization policy.  Items deemed dangerous are sent home or held in storage.
Secure storage is provided at the Nurses’ Station when required.

Staff assigned shall maintain bathrooms in a clean, odor-free manner with adequate ventilation.  There shall be enough hot water for hand washing all day.  The temperature of the hot water supply for consumer care areas shall be kept between 90 F. and 120 F. as measured at the outlet.
The dining area shall seat small groups and be supervised by staff at all times.  The area shall be lighted, ventilated, and furnished.  The dining room may never be used as a sleeping area.

Garbage and trash shall be removed from all areas at a minimum of every 24 hours.  Wet garbage shall be collected and stored in waterproof, leakproof containers.  All garbage storage areas shall be kept clean and free from insects, rodents, and dirt.  A contracted vendor shall provide scheduled, periodic garbage collection.  Contaminated garbage shall be disposed of according to Infection Control policies.

Exterminating services are scheduled monthly to provide routine pest control.  All outside openings will be protected against the entrance of rodents and insects by using tight-fitting, self-closing doors, and controlled air vents.  Holes in walls will be sealed where utilities enter the building.  The Infection Control Coordinator will monitor this service.  Any occurrence with pests or insects is to be reported by staff to the Infection Control Coordinator or Housekeeping.
Recreational areas shall be provided and consist of no less than 75 square feet.  The area shall be free from hazards and kept free from litter, trash, and standing water.
All potentially dangerous objects or toxic substances shall be stored in a locked cabinet or enclosure, away from food or other areas that could constitute a hazard to consumers or staff.
A copy of the Organization’s plan of evacuation in cases of fire or other disaster shall be conspicuously posted throughout the Organization.
QBH is a non-smoking facility.  Smoking is permitted on the facility grounds in designated areas only.  Ashtrays shall be provided in these areas.  Wastebaskets are not to be used as ashtrays.

Grounds will be maintained clear of litter and in a state of good repair.  Lawns will be kept neatly mowed, trimmed, and watered as needed.  Flower and shrub beds will be maintained weed free and be fertilized as needed.

Curbs, parking areas and handicapped parking areas will be kept clearly marked at all times using appropriate colored traffic paint.  Curbs, gutters and parking lots will be swept no less than once per month.

All extension cords must be less than 10 feet in length, except for those used for construction and maintenance power tools, and for those used in temporary emergency conditions.  Extension cords shall not be used:
As a substitute for the fixed wiring of a structure;
Where they run through holes in walls, ceilings, floors, doors, windows or similar openings;
Where attached to building surfaces;
Where concealed behind building surfaces;
Two and three prong adapters will not be used under any* circumstances.

Multiple outlet strips may be used in place of extension cords and are subject to the same yearly inspection.  Outlet strips will be protected by an internal circuit breaker.  The total load attached to the outlet strip will not exceed the rated amperage of the circuit.  Multiple outlet strips will be purchased and installed by the Safety Officer. They will have a maximum of six outlets.

The Safety Officer will review and revise if necessary annually (once a year every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) or as needed when circumstances changes. The revised plan and plan evaluatio0n will be submitted to the Clinical Committee approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT Privacy and Security Officers Authority.policy  FINAL 7 17

subpolicies.title: PRIVACY OFFICER AND SECURITY OFFICER APPOINTMENTS

blocks.text: QBH shall designate a Privacy Officer to oversee the development and implementation of QBH’s privacy policies and procedures related to oral, visual and paper security, in accordance with applicable Federal privacy requirements.  Likewise, a Security Officer is designated to oversee the development and implementation of QBH technological/ electronic security policies and procedures, in accordance with applicable Federal privacy requirements.
It is the CEO’s prerogative to have one person appointed who fills both positions.

The Privacy Officer shall be responsible for the development and implementation of QBH’s privacy policies and procedures related to oral, visual and paper privacy and for regular monitoring of staff’s compliance with the related Federal privacy requirements.

The Security Officer shall be responsible for the development and implementation of QBH’s technological/electronic security policies and procedures related to all forms of electronic storage, transmission and/or receipt of personal health information and individual identifiable health information and for regular monitoring of staff’s compliance with the related Federal privacy and security requirements.

Each officer shall be the initial source for receiving immediate notice of any complaints, problems or breaches in privacy information within the area of their accountability.  Likewise, each is responsible to develop a report of any breach that they themselves discover in the course of their compliance monitoring or that is received in the form of a complaint.
These officers are responsible to promptly inform the Chief Executive Officer.
These officers must always be part of the report and investigation process, as appropriate to their area of accountability.
Management of the investigation and resolution of any HIPAA related concern or complaint shall be by the appropriate officer, given the nature of the concern or complaint.
Both positions may be assigned to a single person due to the small size of QBH.

Both officers shall be responsible for participation in internal investigation of any noted or reported breaches in management of privacy information (PHI, IIHI) or security of privacy information (ePHI) and shall engage as needed in any audits or investigations conducted by the Secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

Each officer shall provide education as needed to any assigned deputies, staff and/or managers related to their areas of accountability for privacy practices. Education, whether formal or informal, is included in quarterly reports to the Clinical Committee.

Quarterly reports shall be submitted as calendared to the Clinical Committee (CC) describing, minimally, all activities and findings/trends related to testing of systems, compliance inspections, any unauthorized disclosures/breaches with any investigative findings or conclusions and status of each, any education provided, any recommendations for privacy system improvements and/or changes to policies or forms related to these systems.
The Privacy Officer’s and Security Officer’s specific duties shall each be defined in a job description.  They shall be appointed and supervised by the CEO.
The Privacy Officer and Security Officer appointments shall be approved by the Chief Executive Officer (CEO).

The selection of the Privacy Officer and Security Officer shall take into account each candidate’s qualifications, educational background, work experience, and Clinical skills, including, but not limited to:
Knowledge and experience in health information privacy laws, access, release of information and information controls and security;
Knowledge in and the ability to apply the principles of health information management and project management;
Demonstrated Company, facilitation, communication and presentation skills;
Strong commitment to protecting the privacy of patients’ protected health information.
The Security Officer shall have advanced experience with and knowledge of electronic security methods and with the EMR System, QBH electronic medical record program.

subpolicies.title: AUTHORITY OF THE PRIVACY OFFICER AND SECURITY OFFICER

blocks.text: The Privacy Officer and Security Officer have the authority to enforce federal laws set forth by HIPAA, HICECH, FTC, and HHS as well as related state or accreditation requirements.

The Privacy Officer and Security Officer each has the authority and responsibility to write up a report of the circumstances/observations of any violation of the confidentiality and/or security of confidential information by an employee, contractor or business associate of QBH and, if provided, a description of the immediate retraining done with the employee, contractor, intern, or business associate.
The original report shall be maintained in the staff’s personnel file.

In the case of a violation by a business associate, the report shall be submitted by the Privacy Officer or Security Officer to the CEO who shall determine what course of action to take, which may include a requirement of proof of retraining prior to further business affiliation with QBH, termination of the business association or other action deemed appropriate by the CEO based on nature/ severity of the violation.

Each officer has the responsibility to initiate testing of and/or monitor the contingency plan and procedures for response to emergency or other threats to the areas of health information privacy within the scope of their areas of oversight.

Each officer completes evaluations, at least annually, of the aspects of the privacy system for which they have accountability, considering any changes in federal and state regulations and/or environmental or operational changes affecting security of PHI/IIHI.  They collaborate to arrive at any recommended changes in policy or forms.
EVALUATION

The Privacy and Security Officers will review this policy annually and make modifications as needed based upon changes in regulations, changes necessary due to nature of services, etc.   Any revisions will be submitted to the Clinical Committee as scheduled.
