blocks.text: Privileging/credentialing shall be defined as the process in which a professional practitioner is recognized within the scope of their license and/or certification credentials as having achieved a specific level of expertise in an area of therapeutic intervention and thus acquires the “privilege” of providing that service with minimal to no additional supervision or training required by this Company and who is authorized by state and/or federal law to practice independently.
When an eligible practitioner is hired or contracted by QBH to deliver independent clinical services, s/he will be provided with a privileging packet and an Application for Temporary Privileges.
The application for temporary privileges shall be completed and returned to the Office Manager within 48 hours.

The applicant may not provide service for QBH until the temporary privileges application has been returned, specific information verified, and temporary privileges approved by the CEO and Medical Director.  (See section F of this policy for further explanation of temporary privileging.)
The privileging packet is provided and should contain:
Cover Letter
Applications (Temporary and Initial)
Attestation Sheet
Delineation Sheet
Authorization and Release Form

The applicant will be expected to complete the Application For Privileges and return it to the Office Manager at which time the applicant should be prepared to show authorized HR staff their DEA license, if applicable. (This segment in bold italics does not apply for physicians whose DEA is verified by the Medical Board and copy is available to QBH from the Board.)
At this time the applicant should also be prepared to show a government issued picture ID to authorized HR staff to verify identification with the application.
A copy of the picture ID may be made and maintained in the applicant’s privileging file.
The returned packet should contain:
Completed applications
Signed attestation sheet
Signed delineation sheet
Completed Authorization and Release Form
Copies of any items so instructed within the application
Other documentation the applicant thinks supports their training, qualifications or competency.
The Office Manager shall proceed timely with verification of application content, attempting completion within thirty (30) days.
When the Office Manager has gathered and verified all the above information, the fully completed applicant privileging file is submitted to the Clinical Committee for review and recommendation.

In connection with all applications, the applicant shall have the burden of producing accurate and adequate information in a timely manner to allow a proper objective and informed evaluation of the applicant’s experience, background, education, training, demonstrated ability, proof of liability insurance, physical and mental health, compliance with Policies, Rules and Regulations, and all other qualifications and suitability of the clinical privileges requested.

The applicant must assist in resolving any reasonable doubts about these matters, and must satisfy additional requests for information, at the applicant’s expense, if deemed appropriate by the Clinical Committee and/or Governing Board.
The applicant's failure to sustain this burden or the applicant's offering information containing significant misrepresentations or omissions shall be grounds for denial of the application.
The Clinical Committee convenes to review the privileging file information and to make a recommendation as to the action that the Governing Board should take with regard to privileges sought.
The recommendation should be based upon demonstration, upon review of documents that the applicant has provided, of current competencies/ qualifications for each privilege sought.
The Committee may request additional information or interview the applicant to assist in their decision. The Committee’s decision shall be in writing on the Privileging Action Form.
Any negative decision shall include an explanation for the decision.
The Committee’s recommendation and the privileging file will go to the Governing Board for timely action.
The Board members shall review the file contents for completeness and content, consider the Committee’s recommendation, and decide on action.
Their action shall be recorded in Board minutes and documented on the Privileging Action Form.
Any negative decision shall include an explanation for the decision.

Following Board action which is documented on the Privileging Action Form, the Office Manager shall notify the applicant in writing of the Board’s decision, the privileges granted, and the timeframe this action covers.
Completion of verifications is documented on the Privileging File Worksheet.
Verifications include:
Visual viewing of the practitioner’s DEA license (must be actual license, copy will not suffice), if applicable. Visual verification may be done by the Office Manager only.
Visual viewing and copy made of the practitioner’s government issued picture ID (must be actual, copy will not suffice). Visual verification and copying is done by the Office Manager.
Verbal or official (training institution letterhead and seal) written confirmation of degree(s), including informant’s name/position, the type of degree and year received.

Verbal or written confirmation of any licenses, certifications or registrations identified in the application, including the type of license, ID number, expiration date, and the informant’s name/position.
Phone interview or written references from employers (at least past three years).

Written verification of Liability Insurance (applicable for physicians, psychologists, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and all contracted practitioners), including amount of coverage (at least $1 million), expiration date, any previous or current suits/settlements/cases pending, informant’s name/position.
Report of the practitioner’s credentials from the Michigan State Medical Board or Nursing Board, as applicable.
Query and report of the practitioner’s practicing history from the National Practitioner’s Data Bank.
A Copy of the Practitioner’s Certification of Insurance along with a claims history report, if applicable.
Phone interview or written references from three professional peers.
NPDB query.
Verification of current license, registration or certifications, if newly expired.
The re-privileging process occurs every two years for currently privileged practitioners.
The reapplication process follows the same as for new applicants with the following exceptions:
The Reapplication is modified to gain only data that may have changed since initial privileging.
Except if there are new employers or education entries since the last application, previously verified employment and education do not have to be re-verified.
Internal quality and peer review data will be included in the information reviewed to determine if privileges should be renewed or at what level.

Deficiencies identified through quality and/or peer review must be corrected prior to re-privileging or the practitioner will have restrictions imposed until the practitioner has demonstrated competence for a period of time set forth in the restriction decision.
Committee and Board action will be required to remove any restriction once competence is re-established.
Reference sources can be other privileged staff of QBH, including the Medical Director.
The application shall be provided to the applicant prior to the expiration of the current privileges.

Any currently privileged practitioner who wishes to be considered for a change in his/her clinical privileges or who does not desire to be re-privileged, shall so request in writing to the Office Manager at least thirty (30) days before the current privileges expire.
Requisitions for additional/increased privileges must be supported by evidence that would be necessary for such privileges to be granted on an initial application for the same.
The practitioner must specify what privileges, of those available for the professional category, they will practice at QBH and for which they are qualified on the Privileges Delineation Form.
Privileges granted must be specific as to the services that are authorized and will clearly delineate the nature of any supervision that may be required.
Privileges may be either clinical and/or administrative in nature.
Clinical privileges are granted for practitioners who will provide direct consumer care.
Administrative privileges are granted to practitioners who provide administrative medical services that are of a non-clinical nature and do not involve providing direct consumer care.

Privileges for employed practitioners shall terminate with termination of employment.  Privileges for contracted staff shall terminate with the termination of the contractual relationship between QBH and the practitioner.
Pursuant to a request by a practitioner, the Clinical Committee may recommend a change in the status of privileges of a practitioner consistent with the requirements of these policy/procedures.
CATEGORIES OF PRIVILEGES
Full privileges shall be granted to applicants who are fully qualified for all privileges sought.

Restricted privileges may be granted to the applicant who does not have the credentials, licensure, education, training, or experience for a specific privilege requested; however, the applicant does meet the qualifications for some of the privileges requested.

Clinical and/or administrative practice at QBH will be limited to the privileges for which the applicant is qualified and/or practice of the questionable privilege(s) only 	under specifically designated evaluative conditions such as supervision or peer review.

Temporary privileges may be granted for the purpose of authorizing 	 consumer service during the period in which a practitioner’s application is being processed and/or for the purpose of locum tenens.
Temporary privileges for the purpose of allowing the process of privileging to be completed shall be valid for a maximum period of 120 days.
Locum  tenens privileges shall be for a designated period as defined later in these procedures.
A person who receives either restricted or full privileges retains those privileges for no more than two years, at which time reapplication is required.
Application for privileges shall be submitted on the form prescribed by the governing board.
The application shall require detailed information concerning the applicant's qualifications that shall include:

Personal data, education for all time periods from pre-clinical to the present, employed positions, academic affiliations, other post graduate education, private practice data, physical and mental health as it relates to ability to perform privileges requested, staff memberships, board certification, all licensure or certification registrations, drug enforcement administration registration (where appropriate), publications and professional activities, military services, and information pertaining to malpractice litigation and clinical complaints; however, information listed that is provided by the Medical Board Report, for physicians, may not be included in QBH application.

The names of at least three peer practitioners that have had extensive experience in observing and working with the applicant and who can provide adequate information pertaining to the applicant's competence, physical and mental health, experience with various populations, and ethical character.

Information regarding past or pending clinical disciplinary action, previous membership rejections, previous privileges suspensions, licensure or certification limitations, drug enforcement administration actions, clinical liability lawsuits and/or settlements, administrative or court cases involving non-compliance with laws or standards related to consumer care/services, government or third party payer sanctions and/or proceedings, and other related matters.
Information as to whether s/he has ever been convicted of a felony.

A current Certification of Insurance from an Insurance Company licensed or approved to do business in the State of Michigan, (Applicable to Physicians, Psychologists, Nurse Practitioners and/or Physician Assistants, and consulting/contracted Staff only).
Certification of physical-mental health in the form of a signed statement attesting to that fact.

Attestation sheet: every applicant shall make specific acknowledgment of his/her obligation as a privileged practitioner to provide continuous care/services and supervision, if applicable, to all consumers within QBH for whom s/he has responsibility.  Additionally, the applicant shall acknowledge the following:
To accept committee assignments and such other reasonable duties and responsibilities as shall be assigned to him/her;
Receipt of a copy of the privileging and hearing/appeal policies and agreement to be bound by the terms thereof in all matters without regard as to whether or not s/he is granted privileges;

The applicant shall have the burden of producing adequate information for a proper evaluation of his/her competence, character, ethics and other qualifications and of resolving any doubts about such qualifications;
That by applying for privileges with QBH, the applicant:
Signifies his/her willingness to appear for interviews in regard to his/her application;

Authorizes QBH and its duly authorized representative to consult with management and with members of the Privileged Staff of other institutions with which the applicant has been associated and with others who may have information bearing on his/her competence, character and ethical qualifications;

Consents to QBH and its duly authorized representatives inspecting all records and documents that may be material to an evaluation of his/her qualifications and competence to carry out the privileges s/he requests;
Releases for any liability all representatives of QBH and its staff for acts performed in good faith and without malice in evaluating the applicant and his/her privileging, and;
Releases from any liability individuals and organizations who provide information to the character and other qualifications for privileges including otherwise privileged or confidential information.
The applicant's duty/responsibility to inform QBH via the Office Manager of any changes in the information provided through the application form during the application period, or any subsequent time.
The applicant shall be notified of any problems in obtaining the information required, and it shall be the applicant's obligation to obtain the required information.

Any applicant whose application is not completed within three (3) months after receipt by the Office  Manager as a result of failure on the part of the applicant to obtain or provide the required information, shall be automatically removed from consideration for clinical privileges.

Such an applicant's application may, thereafter, be reconsidered only if all information therein, which may change over time, including, but not limited to, reports from other health facilities and personal references have been resubmitted.
Favorable Recommendation:  When the recommendation of the Committee is favorable to the applicant, it shall be promptly forwarded, together with supporting documentation, to the Governing Board.

Adverse Recommendation:  When a final recommendation of the Clinical Committee is adverse to the applicant, the Governing Board and the applicant shall then be informed of his/her procedural rights as provided in the Hearing and Appeal policy/procedure.
The Governing Board will take no final action until all the applicant's rights are waived or exhausted.

The Governing Board may accept the recommendation of the Clinical Committee or may refer the matter back to the Clinical Committee for further consideration, stating the purpose for such referral and setting a reasonable time limit for making a subsequent recommendation.
The following procedures shall apply with respect to action on the application:
If the Clinical Committee issues a favorable recommendation, and the Governing Board concurs in that recommendation, the decision of the Board shall be deemed final action.
The applicant shall receive written notification of the Board's action.

If the Clinical Committee issues a favorable recommendation, and the Governing Board disagrees with that recommendation even after redress of the recommendation with the Clinical Committee, the applicant will be informed of the adverse consideration and of his/her procedural rights as provided in the 	Hearing and Appeal policy/ procedure.
The Governing Board will take no final action until all the applicant's rights are waived or exhausted.

Persons who receive an adverse decision for disciplinary reasons shall not be eligible to reapply for privileges affected by the previous action for a period of at least two (2) years from the date the adverse decision became final, the date the application or request was withdrawn, or the date the former Privileged Staff member's resignation became effective, whichever is applicable.

Further, for the purpose of this section, an adverse decision shall be considered final at the time of completion of all hearings, appellate review, and other quasi-judicial proceedings conducted by QBH bearing upon the decision which are filed and served within thirty (30) days after the completion of QBH proceedings as described in the hearing and appeal process.

Upon receiving an eligible applicant ‘s application for 	privileges, the Office Manager shall, based upon information then available, verify license(s) /certification, malpractice insurance, if applicable, and last employer which may reasonably be relied upon as to the competence, health and ethical standing of the 	applicant.
Verification by verbal contact at a minimum should be documented prior to granting temporary privileges.
Once satisfactory verification has occurred, and upon recommendation of the Medical Director, the CEO may authorize specific temporary privileges to the applicant.
The applicant will be notified in writing of the granting of temporary privileges.
Temporary privileges shall be in effect for up to 120 days.

Upon receiving an application for temporary privileges  from the practitioner desiring locum tenens status, the Office Manager shall, based upon information then available, verify license(s)/ certification, malpractice insurance, if applicable, and last employer which may reasonably be relied upon as to the competence, health and ethical standing of the practitioner.
Verification by verbal contact at a minimum should be documented prior to granting temporary privileges.
Once satisfactory verification has occurred, and upon recommendation of the Medical Director, the CEO may authorize specific temporary privileges to the practitioner.
The practitioner will be notified in writing of the granting of temporary privileges.
Locum tenens privileges to cover for a privileged practitioner’s absence shall not exceed twelve (12) days in a given year, nor for more than 72 consecutive hours.
The privileged practitioner shall document review of any orders written by the locum tenens practitioner within 72 hours after return.
If appropriate, special requirements of review and reporting may be imposed by the CEO or Medical Director on any individual granted temporary privileges.

Temporary privileges with requirements shall immediately be terminated by the CEO, after consultation with the Medical Director, upon notice of any failure by the individual to comply with such special conditions.

On the discovery of any information or the occurrence of any event of a nature which raises a question about a practitioner's qualifications or ability to exercise any or all of the temporary privileges granted, or non-compliance with any Company policies and procedures or special requirements, the CEO or Medical Director may terminate any or all of such practitioner's temporary privileges, provided that where the life or well-being of a consumer is determined to be endangered by continued treatment by the practitioner, the termination may be effected by any person entitled to impose summary suspensions.

In the event of any such termination, the practitioner's consumers, then being treated by QBH shall be assigned to another practitioner by the Medical Director.  The wishes of the consumer shall be considered, where feasible, in 	choosing a substitute practitioner.

Practitioners shall be entitled to the procedural rights afforded by the hearing and appeal process if their requests for temporary privileges are refused or because all or any portion of their temporary privileges are terminated or suspended.

If at any time a privileged practitioner from any discipline 1) fails to comply with QBH’s policies and procedures, 2) conduct is lower than the standards of QBH or disruptive to the operation of QBH, or 3) conduct is detrimental to the community's confidence, any practitioner or staff member of QBH may request a review by the Medical Director.
The request must be in writing and document the specific reasons for the request.  The request shall be delivered to the CEO.
The CEO shall notify both the Clinical Committee and the Governing Board.
If the Clinical Committee concludes an investigation is warranted, it shall direct an investigation be undertaken.
The Clinical Committee, or designated members, will itself undertake the investigation.
The investigation shall proceed in a prompt manner with a written report of the investigation available to the CEO within thirty (30) days.

The practitioner shall be notified in writing within forty eight (48) hours that an investigation is being conducted and shall be given an opportunity to provide information in a manner and upon such terms as the investigating body deems appropriate.
The individual or body investigating the matter may, but is not obligated to, conduct interviews with persons involved.
Such investigation shall not constitute a "hearing" as that term is used in the hearing and appeals process, nor shall the procedural rules with respect to hearings or appeals apply.
Despite the status of any investigation, at all times the Clinical Committee shall retain authority and discretion to take whatever action may be warranted by the circumstances, including:

Determining no corrective action need be taken and, if the Clinical Committee determines there was no credible evidence for the complaint in the first instance, removing any adverse information from the practitioner's file.
Deferring action for no more than sixty (60) days where circumstances warrant.

Issuing letters of admonition, censure, reprimand, or warning, although nothing herein shall be deemed to preclude a supervisor from issuing written or oral warnings outside of the mechanism for corrective action.
In the event such letters are issued, the affected practitioner may make a written response that shall be placed in the practitioner's privileging file.

Recommending the imposition of terms of probation or special limitation upon the exercise of privileges, including, without limitation, requirements for co-admissions, mandatory consultation, and supervision or monitoring.
Recommending reduction, modifications, suspension or revocation of privileges.
Taking other actions deemed appropriate under the circumstances.
When corrective action is recommended by the Clinical Committee, that recommendation shall be transmitted to the Governing Board.

If the recommendation of the Clinical Committee is adopted by the Board, it stands as the final action, unless the practitioner requests a hearing, in which case the final decision shall be determined as set forth in the Hearing and Appeals policy/procedure.
If any action is taken, the practitioner will be notified by the CEO with ten (10) days by certified mail, return receipt requested.
The practitioner will have ten (10) days from receipt of notification to request in writing to the CEO a hearing if s/he wishes to contest the decision.

If the Clinical Committee fails to investigate, or takes disciplinary action contrary to the weight of the evidence, the Governing Board may direct the Clinical Committee to initiate investigation or disciplinary action, but only after consultation with the Clinical Committee.

If the Clinical Committee fails to take action in response to that Governing Board direction, the Governing Board may initiate corrective action, but this corrective action must comply with this policy.
Criteria for initiation shall be:

Whenever a practitioner's conduct appears to require that immediate action be taken to protect the life or well-being of consumer(s) or to reduce a substantial or imminent likelihood of significant impairment of the life, health or safety of any consumer, prospective consumer, or other person, the CEO, Clinical Committee, the Medical Director, or the Governing Board may summarily restrict or suspend the practitioner’s privileges.

Unless otherwise stated, each summary restriction or suspension shall become effective immediately upon imposition and the person or body responsible shall promptly give written notice to the practitioner, the Governing Board, the Clinical Committee, the Medical Director and the CEO.

The summary restriction or suspension shall be for no longer than fourteen (14) days while investigation into the need for further action is taken.  Unless otherwise indicated by the terms of the summary restriction or suspension, the practitioner's consumer(s) shall be promptly assigned to another practitioner by the Medical Director, considering, where feasible, the wishes of the consumer in the choice of a substitute practitioner.
As soon as practical after such summary restriction or suspension has been imposed, a meeting of the Clinical Committee shall be convened to review and consider the action.

Upon request, the practitioner may attend and make a statement concerning the issues under investigation, on such terms and conditions as the Clinical Committee may impose, although in no event shall any meeting of the Clinical Committee, with or without the practitioner, constitute a "hearing."
The Clinical Committee may modify, continue, or terminate the summary restriction or suspension, but in any event it shall furnish the practitioner with notice of its decision.
Unless the Clinical Committee promptly terminates the summary restriction or suspension, subject to Governing Board approval, the practitioner shall be entitled to the procedural rights afforded.

In the following instances, the practitioner's privileges may be suspended or limited as described, which action shall be final without a right to hearing or further review, except where a bona fide dispute exists as to whether the circumstances have occurred.

Revocation and Suspension:  Whenever a practitioner's license or other legal credential authorizing practice in this State is revoked or suspended, privileges shall be automatically revoked as of the date such action becomes effective.

Restriction:  Whenever a practitioner's license or other legal credential authorizing practice in this State is limited or restricted by the applicable licensing or certifying authority, any privileges which the practitioner has been granted which are within the scope of said limitation or restriction shall be automatically limited or restricted in a similar manner, as of the date such action becomes effective and throughout its term.

Probation:  Whenever a practitioner is placed on probation by the applicable licensing or certifying authority, his/her privileges shall automatically become subject to the same terms and conditions of the probation as of the date such action becomes effective and throughout its term.

Controlled Substances:  Whenever a practitioner's Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) Certificate is revoked, limited, or suspended, the practitioner shall automatically and correspondingly the divested of the right to prescribe medications covered by the certificate, as of the date such action becomes effective and throughout its term.  Likewise, whenever a practitioner's Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) certificate is subject to probation, the practitioner's right to prescribe such medications shall automatically become subject to the same terms of the probation, as of the date such action becomes effective and throughout is term.

Professional Liability Insurance:  Failure to maintain professional liability insurance, if required, shall be grounds for automatic suspension of a practitioner's privileges, and if within ninety (90) days after written warnings of the delinquency the practitioner does not provide evidence of required professional liability insurance, the practitioner's privileges shall be automatically terminated.

Physician, psychologist, Nurse Practitioner or Physician Assistant suspensions cumulatively totaling thirty (30) days in any twelve (12) month period shall be reported to the appropriate Board of Examiners and the National Practitioner Data Bank.

Clinical Committee minutes, files and records, including information regarding any staff members or applicants collected or prepared for the purpose of achieving and maintaining quality consumer care/services, reducing morbidity and mortality or contributing to clinical research, shall be confidential to the fullest extent permitted by law.
Dissemination of this information and these records shall only be made when expressly required by law or with the express approval of the Clinical Committee.
This confidentiality shall also extend to information of like kind that may be provided by third parties.
The information shall be part of the practitioners’ privileging files and shall not become part of any particular consumer’s file or of the general Company records.

Inasmuch as effective peer review and consideration of the qualifications of Professional Staff and applicants to perform specific procedures must be based on free and candid discussions, any breach of confidentiality of the discussions or deliberations of the Clinical Committee, except in conjunction with another Company, Professional society, or licensing authority, is outside appropriate standards of conduct for this Professional Staff and will be deemed disruptive to the operations of QBH.
If it is determined that such a breach has occurred, the Clinical Committee may undertake such corrective action as it deems appropriate.

Each representative of the Professional Staff and Company shall be exempt, to the fullest extent permitted by law, from liability to an applicant or member for damages or other relief for any action taken or statements or recommendations made within the scope of his/her duties as a representative of the Clinical Committee or QBH.

Each representative of the Clinical Committee and QBH and all third parties shall be exempt, to the fullest extent permitted by law, from liability to an applicant or member for damages or other relief by reason of providing information to a representative of the Clinical Committee or QBH concerning such person who is, or has been, an applicant to or member of the staff or who did, or does, exercise privileges or provide services at this Company.

The confidentiality and immunity provided by this policy shall apply to all acts, communications, reports, recommendations or disclosures performed or made in connection with this or any other health care/services facility's or organization's activities concerning, but not limited to:
Applications for privileges
Corrective action
Hearings and appellate reviews
Utilization review
Other committee or medical activities related to monitoring and maintaining quality consumer care/services and appropriate professional conduct
Peer review; quality assessment/improvement and review; privileging organizations (Professional Licensing Boards, National Practitioner Data Bank) and similar reports.

Each applicant or privileged staff shall, upon request of the Clinical Committee or QBH, execute general and specific release in accordance with the express provisions and general intent of this policy and procedure.  Execution of such releases shall not be deemed a prerequisite to the effectiveness of this policy.
If adverse action is taken or recommended regarding the granting or denial of clinical privileges, the applicant must exhaust the remedies afforded by this policy before resorting to legal action.

QBH’s remedies and the hearing and appellate review bodies provided for in this policy are strictly quasi-judicial in structure and function and said bodies shall have no power or authority to hold legislative, notice and comment type hearing or to make determinations as to the substantive validity of Company policies.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Governing Board may entertain challenges to the substantive validity of Company policies and in all proper cases shall hear and decide those questions.
Where the substantive validity question is the sole issue, the petitioner shall be permitted a direct appeal and hearing, in the first instance, before the Governing Board.
The final determination by the Board shall be a condition precedent to petitioner's right to seek judicial review in a court of law.

The rules of law relating to the examination of witnesses and presentation of 	evidence shall not apply in any hearing conducted hereunder.  Any relevant evidence 	including hearsay, shall be admitted by the Chairperson if it is the sort of evidence which responsible persons are accustomed to rely on in the conduct of serious affairs, regardless of the admissibility of such evidence in a court of law.

Each party shall have the right to submit a written statement in support of his/her position and the Review Committee may request such a statement to be filed 	following the conclusions of the presentation of oral testimony.
The Review Committee may interrogate the witnesses or call additional witnesses if it deems such action appropriate.

At the hearing, the Clinical Committee shall have the initial duty to present evidence for each case or issues in support of its action or recommendation.  The petitioner shall be obligated to present evidence in response.

When the hearing involves an applicant, the applicant shall bear the burden of persuading the Review Committee, by a preponderance of the evidence of his/her qualifications by presenting information which allows for adequate evaluation and resolution of reasonable doubts concerning his/her current qualifications for privileges.

An applicant shall not be permitted to introduce information requested by the Clinical Committee but not produced during the application process unless the applicant establishes that the information could not have been produced previously in the exercise of reasonable diligence.

Except as provided above for applicants, throughout the hearing, the Clinical Committee shall bear the burden of persuading the Review Committee, by a preponderance of the evidence, that its action or recommendation was reasonable and warranted.
Expect  as otherwise specified in this policy any one or more of the following or recommended actions shall be deemed actual or potentially adverse action and constitute grounds for a hearing:
Denial of requested clinical privileges
Involuntary reduction of current clinical privileges
Suspension of clinical privileges
Termination of all clinical privileges
Involuntary imposition of significant consultation or monitoring requirement, excluding monitoring incidental to Provisional status.
Any other action which requires a report to be made to the Professional Board of the practitioner and/or National Practitioner Data Bank.

In all cases in which action has been taken or a recommendation made as set forth above, the Chairperson of the Clinical Committee (if a recommendation) or the CEO, as Board representative (if an action) shall give the petitioner prompt, within fifteen (15) days, written notice of the recommendation or final proposed action and that such action, if adopted, shall be taken and reported to the appropriate Professional Board and/or National Practitioner Data Bank pursuant to Title IV, P.L. 99-660 and amendments; and notice of the right to request a hearing pursuant to this 	policy, and that such hearing must be requested within thirty (30) days.

The petitioner shall have thirty (30) days following receipt of notice of such action to request a hearing.  The request shall be in writing, addressed to the Chief Executive Officer, with a copy to the Governing Board.

In the event the petitioner does not request a hearing within the time and in the manner described, the petitioner shall be deemed to have waived any right to a hearing and accepted the recommendation or action involved.

Upon receipt of a request for hearing, the Chief Executive Officer shall schedule a hearing and, within thirty five (35) days of the hearing, give notice in writing to the petitioner of the time, place and date of the hearing.

Unless extended by the Review Committee, the date of the commencement of the hearing shall be no less than thirty (30) days, nor more than sixty (60) days from the date of receipt of the request by the Chief Executive Officer for a hearing; provided, however, that when the request is received from a petitioner who is under summary suspension the hearing shall be held as soon as the arrangements may reasonably be made, but not to exceed forty-five (45) days from the date of receipt of the request.

Together with the notice stating the place, time and date of the hearing, the Clinical Committee shall state clearly and concisely in writing the reasons for the adverse final proposed action or recommendation, including the acts or omissions with which 	the petitioner is charged, or the reasons for the denial of the request of the petitioner.

When a hearing is requested, the Clinical Committee shall oversee appointment of a Review Committee which shall be composed of not less than one (1) currently privileged independent practitioner who shall gain no direct financial benefit from the outcome, and who have not acted as accuser, investigator, fact finder, initial decision maker or otherwise have not actively participated in the consideration of the matter leading up to the recommendation or action.
Knowledge of the matter involved shall not preclude a applicant of the independent practitioner staff from serving as a member of the Review Committee.

If a privileged independent practitioner employed or contracted by QBH is not available, the CEO may arrange for the participation of a practitioner of the same profession, privileged in a similar type Company, to sit as the independent practitioner for the Review Committee.

The Clinical Committee shall appoint one (1) of the Review Committee members and one (1) shall be selected by the petitioner. Membership on a Review Committee shall consist 	of at least one (1) physician member.
The Clinical Committee shall designate the chairperson of the Review Committee.

subpolicies.title: PROCESS IF THE PETITIONER FAILS TO APPEAR OF PROCEED

blocks.text: Failure, without good cause, of the petitioner to appear and proceed at such a hearing shall be deemed to constitute voluntary acceptance of the recommendations 	or actions pending which shall then become final and effective immediately.
Under no circumstance shall the hearing be conducted without the personal presence of the petitioner unless s/he has waived such appearance.

Once a request for hearing is initiated, continuances beyond the times permitted in policy may be permitted by the Review Committee, upon agreement of the parties, or by the Chairperson on a showing of good cause.
Prehearing Procedure

If either side of the hearing requests in writing a list of witnesses, within fifteen (15) days of such request, each party shall furnish to the other a written list of the names and addresses of the individuals, so far as its reasonably known, who are anticipated to give testimony or evidence in support of that party at the hearing.

The petitioner shall have the right to receive, at least thirty (30) days prior to the hearing, a copy of the evidence forming the basis of charges which is reasonably necessary to enable the petitioner to prepare a defense, 	including all evidence which was considered by the Clinical Committee in determining whether to proceed with the adverse action, any exculpatory evidence in the possession of QBH, and all evidence which will be made available to the Review Committee.

The Clinical Committee shall have the right to inspect and copy, at Company expense, any documents or other evidence relevant to the charges which the petitioner has in his/her possession or control as soon as practical after receiving the request.
The failure by either party to provide access to this information at least thirty (30) days before the hearing shall constitute good cause for a continuance.
The right to inspect and copy by either party does not extend to confidential information referring solely to individually identifiable clinical staff, other than the petitioner under review.
The Chairperson shall consider and rule upon any request for access to information and may impose any safeguards the protection of the peer review process and justice requires.
In so doing, the Chairperson shall consider:
Whether the information sought may be introduced to support or defend the charges;
The exculpatory or inculpatory nature of the information sought, if any;
The burden imposed on the party in possession of the information sought, if access is granted; and
Any previous requests for access to information submitted or resisted by the parties to the same proceeding.
The petitioner shall be entitled to a reasonable opportunity to question and challenge the impartiality of Review Committee applicants and the Chairperson.
Challenges to the impartiality of any Review Committee member or the Chairperson shall be ruled on by the Chairperson.
The hearings provided for in policy are for the purpose of intra-professional resolution of matters bearing on professional conduct, professional competency, or character.

The petitioner shall be entitled to representation by legal counsel in any phase of the hearing, should s/he so choose, and shall receive notice of the right to obtain representation by an attorney at law.

In the absence of legal counsel, the practitioner licensed or certified to practice in the State of Michigan who is not also an attorney to present the action or recommendation, the materials in support thereof, examine witnesses, and respond to appropriate questions.
The Clinical Committee 	shall not be represented by an attorney at law if the petitioner is not so represented.

subpolicies.title: THE CHAIRPERSON OF THE REVIEW COMMITTEE

blocks.text: The Chairperson at the hearing shall be a Hearing Officer as described herein or, if no such Hearing Officer has been appointed, the Chairperson of the Review Committee.

The Chairperson shall act to assure that all participants in the hearing have a reasonable opportunity to be heard and to present all relevant oral and documentary evidence, and that proper decorum is maintained.  He/she shall be entitled to determine the 	order of or procedure for presenting evidence and argument during the hearing.

S/he shall have the authority and discretion, in accordance with this policy to make all rulings on questions which, with reasonable diligence, could not have been raised prior to the hearing and which pertain to matters of law, procedure or the admissibility of evidence.

At the request of the petitioner, the Clinical Committee, the Review Committee, the Governing Board, the CEO or his/her designee may appoint a Hearing Officer who may be an attorney at law qualified to preside over a quasi-judicial hearing and, preferably with experience in professional staff matters, but an attorney regularly utilized by the 	Company for legal advice regarding its affairs and activities shall not be eligible to serve as Hearing Officer.
The Hearing Officer shall gain no direct financial benefit from the 	outcome of the hearing.
S/he must not act as a prosecuting officer or as an advocate for QBH, Governing Board, Clinical Committee, the body whose action prompted the hearing, or the petitioner.
If requested by the Review Committee, s/he may participate in the deliberations of such body and be a legal advisor to it but s/he shall not be entitled to vote.

The pre-hearing proceedings as well as the hearing proceedings shall be recorded either by the services of a shorthand reporter, if requested by either party or deemed appropriate by the Chairperson, or by a tape recorder.
The cost of the shorthand reporter, if used, and the cost of the transcript, if any, shall be borne by the party requesting it.
The Review Committee may, but shall not be required to, order that oral evidence shall be taken only on oath administered by any person 	lawfully authorized to administer such oath.

At a hearing, both sides shall have the right to call and examine witnesses, to introduce exhibits, to cross-examine any witness on any matter relevant to the issues and to rebut any evidence.  If the petitioner does not testify in his/her own behalf, s/he may be called and examined as if under cross-examination.

After consultation with the Chairman of the Review Committee, the Presiding 	Officer may adjourn the hearing and reconvene the same without special notice at such times and intervals as my be reasonable and warranted, with due consideration for reaching an expeditious conclusion to the hearing.
Both the Clinical Committee and the petitioner may submit a written statement at the close of the hearing.

Upon conclusion of the presentation of the oral and written evidence, or the receipt of closing written arguments, if submitted, the hearing shall be closed.  The Review Committee shall thereupon, outside of the presence of any other person, except the Chairperson, conduct its deliberations and render a decision and accompanying report.

subpolicies.title: BASIS FOR A DECISION OF THE REVIEW COMMITTEE

blocks.text: The decision of the Review Committee shall be based on the evidence introduced at the hearing, including all logical reasonable inferences from the evidence and the testimony.

Within thirty (30) days after final adjournment of the hearing, the Review Committee shall render a decision which shall be accompanied by a report in writing and shall be delivered to the Clinical Committee.
If the petitioner is currently under suspension, however, the time for the decision and report shall be fifteen (15) days.
A copy of said decision also shall be forwarded to the Chief Executive Officer, the Governing Board, and to the petitioner by registered mail.

The report shall contain a concise statement of the reasons in support of the decision, including findings of fact and a conclusion articulating the connection between the 	evidence produced at the hearing and the conclusion reached.
Both the petitioner and the Clinical Committee shall be provided a written explanation of the procedure for appealing the decision.

The decision of the Review Committee shall be subject to such rights of appeal or review  as described in this policy, but shall otherwise be affirmed by the Governing Board as the final action if it is supported by substantial evidence, following a fair procedure.
APPEAL
Within ten (10) days after receipt of the decision of the Review Committee, either the petitioner or the Clinical Committee may request an appellate review.
A written request for such review shall be delivered to the Chief Executive Officer, and the other party in the hearing either in person or by registered mail.

If a request for appellate review is not requested within such period, that action or 	recommendation shall be affirmed by the Governing Board as the final action and 	shall be 	effective immediately.
A written request for an appeal shall include an identification of the grounds for appeal, and a clear and concise statement of the facts in support of the appeal.
The grounds for appeal of the hearing decision shall be:
Substantial failure to comply with the hearing procedures required by this policy or applicable law  which has denied due process of a fair hearing;
The decision was not supported by substantial evidence based upon the hearing record, if any, or such additional information as may be permitted pursuant to section A of this policy;
Action taken arbitrarily, unreasonably, capriciously, or with prejudice.

If an appellate review is to be conducted, the Governing Board shall, within fifteen (15) days after receipt of notice of appeal, schedule a review date and cause each side to be given notice of the time, place, and date of the appellate review.

The date of the appellate review shall not be less than thirty (30 days no more than sixty (60) days from the date of such notice; provided, however, that when a request for 	appellate review concerns a petitioner who is under suspension which is then in effect, the appellate review shall be held as soon as the arrangements may reasonably be made, not to exceed fifteen (15) days from the date of the notice.
The time for appellate review may be extended by the Governing Board for good cause.
Knowledge of the matter involved shall not preclude any Board member from participating in the appellate review, so long as that person did not take part in a prior hearing on the same matter.
The Governing Board may select an attorney to assist it in the proceeding, but that attorney shall be entitled no vote with respect to the appeal.

The proceeding by the Governing Board shall be in the nature of an appellate hearing based upon the record of the hearing before the Review Committee, provided that the Governing Board may accept additional oral or written evidence, subject to a foundational showing that such evidence could not have been made available to the Review Committee in the exercise of reasonable diligence and subject to the same 	rights of cross-examination or confrontation provided at the Review hearing; or the Governing Board may remand the matter to the Review Committee for the taking of further evidence and for decision.

Each party shall have the right to be represented by legal counsel, or any other representative designated by that party in connection with the appeal, to present written statement in support his/her position on appeal, and to personally appear and make oral argument.
The Governing Board may thereupon conduct, at a time convenient to itself, deliberations outside the presence of the appellant and respondent and their representatives.

Except as provided in the next paragraph, within thirty (30) days after the conclusion of the appellate review proceedings, the Governing Board shall render a final decision and shall affirm the decision of the Review Committee if the Review Committee's decision is supported by substantial evidence, following a fair procedure.

Should the Governing Board determine that the Review Committee decision is not supported by substantial evidence; the Board may modify or reverse the decision of the Review Committee and may instead, or shall, where a fair procedure has not been afforded, remand the matter to 	the Review Committee for further review and recommendation.
The Committee shall promptly conduct its review and make its recommendations to the Governing Board.

This further review and the time required to report back shall not exceed thirty (30) days in duration except as the parties may otherwise agree or for good cause as jointly determined by the president of the Governing Board and the Review Committee.

The decision shall be in writing, shall specify the reasons for the action taken, and shall be forwarded to the Clinical Committee, the subject of the 	hearing (by registered mail), and the Chief Executive Officer.
No petitioner shall be entitled to more than one evidentiary hearing and one appellate review on any matter which shall have been the subject of adverse action or recommendation.

Privileged petitioners who are directly under contract with QBH or are employed by QBH, or petitioners whose staff membership is contingent upon a granting of privileges, shall be subject to the procedural rights specified in the policy:
To the extent that any contract modifications, termination or restrictions of clinical privileges proposed by QBH deal with issues related to professional character, performance, or competence, or
To the extent that the clinical privileges which would otherwise exist independent of the contract are to be limited or terminated.
Contractual or employment issues or grievances are not covered by any provisions of the appeal process or mechanism.
No hearing is required when a petitioner’s license or legal credential to practice has been revoked or suspended.
Expunction of Disciplinary Action
Upon petition, the Clinical Committee may expunge previous disciplinary action upon 	showing a good cause or rehabilitation subject to approval of the Governing Board.
This Policy will be reviewed by the Clinical Committee annually and revisions made when necessary.  The Policy will be forwarded to the Board for review and approval when revisions are made.

sections.title: QBH MAT Program Emergencies.policy  FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: TREATING MAT CONSUMERS FROM AREAS AFFECTED BY EMERGENCY CLOSURE OF PROGRAMS IN THE EVENT OF A DISASTER
Should QBH, Inc. be in a position to receive displaced consumers due to a disaster requiring evacuation from the area where they live, every effort will be made to contact the home treatment program.
Information about the program may be obtained from the SAMHSA Substance Abuse Treatment Facility Locator at: http://dasis3.samhsa.gov.
In an emergency, program personnel may disclose information to the program Medical Director, program physician, registered nurse, or dosing nurse without a consumer’s signed consent.
If unable to contact the consumer’s home program, the following procedures shall be followed, along with existing emergency plans:
The emergency guest consumer should show a valid picture identification that includes an address near the area affected.

The consumer should show some type of proof that indicates the consumer was receiving services from a clinic located in one of the affected areas, for example, a medication bottle, program identification card, or a receipt for payment of fees, etc.

In cases in which the consumer does not have any items of proof including picture identification, the physician should use his or her best medical judgment, combined with a stat drug test for the presence of methadone (lab test with quick turnaround, dipstick, or similar procedure).

MAT program staff may administer the amount of medication that the consumer reports as his or her current dose; however, each consumer is to be reminded that the dose that is reported will be verified with the home program as soon as possible.

The consumer will be required to remain at the program facility for several hours post-administration for close monitoring to see that the dosage decision was correct or take appropriate medical action in the event the dose was too high.
In cases in which the reported dose appears questionable, good medical judgment will be applied in determining the dose level.

In certain cases, in which the consumer can demonstrate no prior enrollment in treatment or medication dosage amount, the medicating physician may decide to treat the consumer as a new admission and follow initial dosing procedures for a routine admission.

Emergency guest consumers should be medicated daily with take-home doses provided only for days that the program is closed (Sundays and holidays). The MAT will be administered appropriately and safely on days or at times when the program is closed as per policy.
If the consumer’s current take- home status is verified, take-home doses will be provided in accordance with State and Federal regulations (42 CFR Part 8).

In the case of a consumer who is unable to receive daily treatment at the program location due to medical hardship, travel restrictions, or other hardship, take-home medication for unsupervised use may be considered using the SMA-168, “Request-for-Exception” process.
Documentation of services provided to a displaced consumer is a priority for MAT program staff.
The staff should assign a program identification number and maintain a temporary medical record for each guest consumer.

Reasonable efforts are made and documented to contact the consumer’s home program periodically to verify consumer information prior to dispensing medication. The results should be recorded in the temporary chart.
Program staff shall record the day, date, and amount of medication administered to each consumer along with any observations made by the staff.
As time passes and affected MAT programs reopen, some consumers may elect to remain in treatment at the QBH, Inc. facility and change from guest to permanent status.
On conclusion of the emergency treatment, the QBH, Inc. MAT program may be asked to report the number of consumers treated and the types of services provided to the SMA and/or SAMHSA.

subpolicies.title: OPIOID-DEPENDENT DISPLACED CONSUMERS NOT CURRENTLY IN TREATMENT

blocks.text: There are individuals dependent on opioids, including heroin or prescription drugs, that may arrive at QBH, Inc.’s guest treatment program seeking help due to the disruption in the supply of street drugs. The QBH, Inc. MAT program may admit, treat, and dose these consumers under existing guidelines and regulations. Initiation on buprenorphine products may be appropriate for consumers new to medication-assisted treatment.

subpolicies.title: DISPLACED CONSUMERS TREATED BY PAIN CLINICS

blocks.text: Consumers who were being treated for pain with methadone by a physician may contact QBH, Inc.’s MAT program when they run out of medication and have no access to the former treatment setting. The program’s response shall be to refer the consumer to a local physician, particularly a pain management specialist.

The Clinical Director and Safety Officer shall collaborate to review this policy at least annually, submitting any recommendations or revisions to the Clinical Committee for review and approval.  Review shall include consultation with federal and SAMSHA regulations for any changes in their policies.

sections.title: QBH MAT Program Staffing.policy FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: MAT programs are complex, dynamic environments, and their staffing and management are challenging. Program leadership influences consumer outcomes positively by providing sound leadership and staff management. Managers are responsible for keeping staff members focused on consumer care and improved treatment outcomes. Conflict or misunderstanding about treatment goals can increase the stress of working in MAT program.  Managers shall set clear staff guidelines, supply the needed resources, and create a culture that nurtures professional growth and staff retention in QBH’s MAT program.

Staffing capabilities are determined based upon the budget which is greatly determined through third party contracts.  It is the aim of QBH to always sustain enough of these contracts to allow for the numbers and types of staff necessary for the operation of QBH programs and support and administrative services.
Staff productivity expectations are set and periodically reviewed to facilitate appropriate use of staff and is a consideration in determining the need for adjustments in staffing.
Staffing, in terms of numbers and types, is heavily based upon the nature of the needs of the consumers served by QBH and to meet the performance expectations of QBH.
Staffing adjustments are made as needed to accommodate unplanned absences of staff.

Whenever a job vacancy occurs due to a leave of absence, vacation, extended period of illness or other cause whereby the absent staff maintains full seniority status, the vacancy shall be filled by the Chief Executive Officer.
The job will not be posted and the staff placed on the job shall continue to accumulate seniority on his/her regular job.
Staff may be laterally reassigned to jobs without loss of current pay rate for the following reasons:
In the event continued performance of the staff member’s present job may injure the health of the staff member.
Supervision and evaluation purposes.
In the event injuries or physical limitations cause staff to be unable to do the work of their current classification, but are qualified and able to do the work of another classification.
In the event of a staff member’s request for reassignment to an available vacancy, if not inconsistent with the contractual rights of another staff member and when approved by QBH.
As a result of lack of money (funding or revenue) or lack of work or other proper cause.

In the event there are changes in schedules or changes in the method of doing the job, which either eliminates or materially changes the work performed by the staff member to such an extent that the majority of the work performed by the staff member falls within the job description of another job.  The staff will be given two weeks’ notice of job transfer.

A lateral move could be the result of a transfer from one job to another with degree or responsibility being essentially unchanged.  Lateral moves will require an evaluation and qualification period of six months.  A written evaluation of the staff’s performance in the changed position will be prepared at the end of the six month period and annually thereafter.  If the staff proves unsatisfactory, every effort will be made to place him/her in the last position in which their job performance was satisfactory or a similar position if one is available.  This cannot be guaranteed.

Sufficient numbers of trained, qualified substance abuse counselors are maintained to meet the needs of consumers and to provide reasonable, prompt access by consumers to counseling during MAT treatment.

Clinical flexibility is considered in staffing so as to assign female consumers to counselors who are sensitive to and trained to address their individual needs (e.g., domestic violence, sexual abuse).
Staffing considers the option of single-sex groups for consumers, as needed.

subpolicies.title: COMPANY DIRECTIVES FOR MAT PROGRAM STAFF

blocks.text: Staff is expected to pay close attention to their interactions with other staff and consumers in the MAT program, particularly attitude of staff towards these consumers, as this is, based upon research, considered the next most important determinant of treatment effectiveness after an adequate dose of methadone.

Successful treatment outcomes depend on staff competence, values, and attitudes. This Company strives to recruit qualified, capable, culturally competent people; offer competitive benefit packages; and provide careful supervision and ongoing training, but you must do your part by continually increasing your understanding of medication-assisted treatment for opioid addiction (MAT).

The complexities of treating consumers who are opioid addicted demand highly trained caregivers who can provide direct consumer care and coordinate access to other services that their own program cannot provide. To adhere to these qualifications, QBH strives to hire individuals who are licensed or credentialed under MI regulations and have a record of working effectively with the types of consumers served by the MAT program.

Independent practitioner staff shall be privileged according to the credentialing and privileging processes of QBH which stipulates the specific experience, education licensing, and skills the practitioner must have.

In addition to hiring qualified licensed or credentialed staff, leadership seeks to employ people with empathy, sensitivity, and flexibility, particularly regarding consumers in MAT. Empathic staff members create a therapeutic milieu. In addition, staff members shall maintain appropriate professional boundaries with consumers.

Staff working in the MAT program must be able to understand the emotional dynamics of the consumers they treat without internalizing and responding to consumers in a nontherapeutic manner.  These emotional exchanges are referred to as transference and countertransference. Some consumers with addictions project feelings or emotions onto their treatment providers or cast providers in unintended roles, a phenomenon known as transference. Countertransference occurs when treatment providers project their feelings onto consumers, which can interfere with treatment and be destructive to therapeutic relationships. Program supervisors shall monitor that staff members avoid countertransference (e.g., displaying anger toward consumers or disappointment with them).

Sensitivity to cultural, gender, and age issues is another characteristic sought in MAT program staffs. In a review of the literature on culturally relevant health care interventions and their effect on treatment outcomes, it has been found that treatment provider knowledge of cross-cultural principles significantly improved outcomes for consumers with drug addictions. Prospective program staff will be assessed to determine their willingness to work with people from diverse backgrounds, explore and accept other value systems, and understand how culture and values can relate to consumers' behavior. Reception and other support staff is expected to be accepting and understanding of consumers from diverse groups because these staff members often are the first people a new consumer sees at the program and those with whom the consumer interacts most. When possible, QBH recruits staff that reflects consumer demographics and will also consider hiring people who are recovering from addiction.  It is generally recognized that when program staff generally reflects the demographics of the population served, consumers are more likely to feel comfortable in the program.

Staff working with diverse groups is trained to remember that diversity also exists within cultures. It is important to be sensitive to cultural differences but to avoid acting on cultural assumptions. Understanding both a consumer's cultural influences and his or her individuality requires taking time to know the consumer.

Treatment staff is encouraged to be sensitive to other factors that can affect recovery, such as consumers' sexual orientations or ages, but should avoid generalizing about consumers based on these factors. Correctly identifying such factors requires an effort to see the world through each consumer's eyes. Information on cultural competence and diversity is part of initial and annual staff training.

Flexibility in thinking, behavior, and attitudes is also encouraged of QBH’s MAT program staffs.  Staff attitudes about MAT and opioid addiction can affect consumer outcomes. Leadership seeks staff members who are free of rigid biases, are not judgmental, and do not have punitive attitudes toward consumers.  Studies have shown that MAT program staff with negative or punitive attitudes is associated with lower rates of consumer retention and poorer consumer outcomes. QBH program supervisors are instructed to be vigilant about monitoring staff attitudes and to provide training to create or sustain appropriate attitudes about consumers and MAT.

The verbal expressions used by MAT program staff members can reflect how they feel toward consumers. Treatment staff members, who might have absorbed society's antipathy toward people in MAT, sometimes use counter-therapeutic language, for example, the phrase “dirty urine” to describe an unsatisfactory urine drug test (“positive test” is less judgmental). Staff is instructed to avoid terms suggesting the criminal justice system, such as “probation” or “probationary,” to refer to the status of consumers doing poorly in treatment. “Termination” should be avoided in reference to consumer discharge. Other preferred expressions in MAT include “consumers” not “clients” and “dose tapering” or “medically supervised withdrawal” not “detox” in reference to withdrawal from treatment medication. Applying words derived from “toxin” to treatment medication suggests that the medication is a toxin; “detoxification” should refer only to withdrawal from substances of abuse.
