subpolicies.title: POLICY:    SAFE MEDICAL DEVICE ACT REPORTING/RECALL PROCEDURE

blocks.text: Medical device – an instrument, apparatus, contrivance, implant including any component, part or accessory, that is:
Intended for use in the diagnosis of disease or other conditions, or in the cure, 	mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease, or;
Intended to affect the structure or any function of the body and which does not achieve
its primary intended purposes through chemical action within or on the body and which is not dependent upon being metabolized for the achievement of its principal purpose.
Examples of medical devices include consumer restraints, wheelchairs, and syringes/ 	needles.

The Quality Manager will be responsible for overseeing an investigation and reporting of any incident that reasonably suggests that a medical device or medication has caused or contributed to the death of a consumer, staff, or visitor, or has caused a serious injury or illness of a consumer, staff or visitor.

The Quality Manager will report any such occurrence to the manufacturer on the Medical Device Reporting form.  If the manufacturer cannot be determined, then the report goes to the Federal Drug Administration (FDA).

Reports must be submitted within ten (10) working days of the organization becoming aware of the incident.  FDA Form 3500A is available online; sections A-F should be completed.  Obtain forms and booklet reviewing instructions for completing the form from the Quality Manager.

Staff shall preserve the suspected medical device.  The Safety Officer shall remove the medical device and impound it.  Place or cover with a plastic bag to preserve the evidence.  The medical device shall be inspected and a report submitted to the CEO by the Safety Officer.

All product recall notices from the manufacturer are to be sent to the Safety Officer.  The Safety Officer will immediately notify all appropriate parties, determine the need to remove the product from use and arrange for a replacement, if necessary.  Replacement must be approved by CEO.
The recalled product will be returned to manufacturer, if requested.
If necessary, the product will be replaced with another comparable product, if approved by the CEO.

The Safety officer will review and revise if necessary annually (once a year every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) or as needed when circumstances changes. The revised plan and plan evaluation will be submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.

blocks.text: Protected Health Information (PHI):  individually identifiable health information, including whether an individual is in treatment or has died, that can be used to identify and individual, that is:
Orally communicated;
In hard copy format such as the traditional medical record;
Transmitted by electronic media (ePHI);

Maintained in any mode of electronic transmission, including the Internet (wide-open), Extranet (using Internet technology to link a business with information only accessible to collaborating parties), leased lines, dial-up lines, private networks, and those transmissions that are physically moved from one location to another using any type of storage media;
Transmitted or maintained in any other form or medium.
Protected health information does not include:
Education records covered by the Family Educational Rights; and

Educational records, files, documents and other materials which contain information directly related to a student and which are maintained by an educational Company or institution or by a person acting for such Company or institution; and
Employment/contract records held by QBH in its role as an employer/contractor.

Privacy is the right of the individual to decide how much, to whom, when and in what manner personal information can be shared with others.  Privacy is an essential ethical principle of mental health professionals, as well as a standard of care.
Use means sharing, employment, application, utilization, examination, or analysis of PHI/ePHI by the health professional or Company that maintains the PHI/ePHI.  Use includes uses within the Company.

Disclosure means the release, transfer, provision of access to, or divulging in any other manner of PHI/ePHI by the health professional or outside of the Company holding the information.  In some cases disclosure does not require prior authorization by the patient/guardian; in most cases such written authorization is required.

Minimum Data Necessary means that only that confidential information absolutely necessary to continuation/management of care shall be shared with another source, whether or not a release of information by the patient/guardian is required.

subpolicies.title: SANCTIONS FOR SECURITY INCIDENTS/BREACHES OF PRIVACY INFORMATION

blocks.text: COMPANY SANCTIONS

Whether or not federal level action occurs, violations of confidentiality and security by an employee, contractor or business associate are grounds for corrective action up to and including immediate dismissal.  Should a security incident/breach of privacy information occur, a report is submitted to the Clinical Committee by the Privacy or Security Officer who observed or received report of the incident; shall determine the sanction if anything beyond what the Privacy or Security Officer already carried out is determined necessary.
Clinical Committee’s determination of sanction shall be based upon the risk associated with the circumstance and whether or not the violation is a repeat violation.
Actions with staff may entail, individually or severally:
UNINTENTIONAL INITIAL VIOLATION

Verbal reprimand by the Privacy or Security Officer and immediate retraining on area of HIPAA/HITECH, FTC, HHS, JC confidentiality requirement that was violated.  The reprimand is written up by the involved Officer as a warning; this documentation and documentation of the retraining shall be submitted to HR for inclusion in the individual’s personnel file.

Requirement for formal retraining in HIPAA/HITECH security and confidentiality policies and practices of the Company within 2 weeks of written notice from the Clinical Committee.  Training should be arranged with the HR Manager.  Documentation of the retraining must be contained in the individual’s personnel file.

Disciplinary action as set forth by Clinical Committee, which shall be documented in the individual’s personnel file.  Clinical Committee shall consider factors as addressed under federal sanction considerations in the following section of this policy.

subpolicies.title: Intentional and/or Repeat of a Prior Violation

blocks.text: Intentional violation shall result in immediate job dismissal and report to the HIPAA Division of the Department of Social Security and to the Secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services.

A repeat of an unintentional prior violation may result in job dismissal at the discretion of the Clinical Committee after investigation is complete, depending   upon the nature of the violation and the degree to which it created risk to consumers.  Clinical Committee shall consider factors as addressed under federal sanction considerations in the following section of this policy.

Any disclosure of unauthorized information is grounds for legal action at a federal level.  There may be civil fiscal penalties and/or criminal penalties depending upon a number of factors.  The type and amount of the penalty is accelerated for each violation. Civil penalties can range from $100 to $50,000 per violation, not to exceed $1,500,000 cumulative penalty per year.
Violations where violator did not know or would not have known may be $100-$50,000 per violation, not in excess of $1,500,000 for identical violations in the same calendar year.
Violations with reasonable cause without willful neglect may be $1000-$50,000 per violation, not in excess of $1,500,000 for identical violations in the same calendar year.
Violations with willful neglect which is corrected within 30 days may be $10,000-50,000 per violations, not in excess of $1,500,000 for identical violations in the same calendar year.
Violations with willful neglect not corrected within 30 days may be $50,000 per violation, not in excess of $1,500,000 for identical violations in the same calendar year.
Factors considered in establishing a penalty include:
Nature and extent of the violation
Number of consumers affected
Time period during which the violation occurred
Nature and extent of harm resulting, including physical harm, financial harm, harm to a patient’s reputation, hindrance to patient’s ability to obtain health care
History of prior noncompliance
Whether attempt was made to correct any noncompliance
Response to prior complaints/investigations
Whether financial difficulties affected the provider/associate’s ability to comply
Whether imposition of penalty would jeopardize the ability of the Company or business associate to continue to provide and/or pay for health care
Size of the provider entity or business associate.
Criminal penalties, if determined to be indicated, are not issued by the HHS, but by a federal law enforcement Company and may involve imprisonment for six months or longer.
COMPLAINTS OR DISCOVERIES – SUSPECTED OR KNOWN

Anyone may report a complaint or a discovery of a security incident or of a breach with unauthorized disclosure of PHI/IIHI/ePHI to the Company or to the Secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

No one who files a complaint, testifies, assists or participates in compliance or investigation reviews, proceedings or hearings, or who refuses to do an unlawful act in an investigation may be threatened, intimidated, coerced, harassed, discriminated against or receive any other retaliatory action by the Company or its representatives.

Whether a complaint is being filed with the Company or the HHS, the complaint must be in writing or submitted electronically, if secure, and include the name(s) of the person(s) who are the subject of the complaint, the date of suspicion or discovery, and the details, to the extent known, of the act or omission involved.
TO THE COMPANY

If the complaint or breach is related to a Business Associate, they shall notify Chief Executive Officer (CEO) directly as soon as known or discovered but no later than 60 calendar days after discovery.  Notification, by the CEO or designee, shall include written identification of each patient whose unsecured PHI is believed to have been accessed, acquired, used or disclosed during the breach and any other available information as it becomes available.

If the complaint is by a patient or guardian, the complaint should be in writing to the attention of the Privacy and/or Security Officer, or, if given orally, shall be followed by a written complaint describing the circumstance under which they believe their privacy was jeopardized; the date when it occurred or was discovered; the staff involved, if known; and what they consider satisfactory resolution of the complaint. The receiving Officer shall promptly notify the CEO.

If the complaint or discovery of a breach is by staff, it shall be reported IMMEDIATELY to the Privacy Officer (if the issue was with oral, visual or paper violations) or to the Security Officer (if the issue was of an electronic nature).  The Officer shall promptly notify the CEO by phone or in person.
All complaints shall be retained by the Company for a period of six years from the date of notice to the complainant of completion of and conclusions from the investigation.
TO THE SECRETARY OF DHHS

The complaint must be filed by the complainant in writing or electronically to the Secretary of DHHS within 180 days of when the complainant knows of the act/omission, unless waived by the Secretary. The complaint must include the name of the person that is the subject of the complaint and a description of the act or omission believed in violation.  A link is available on the HHS website.

subpolicies.title: MANAGEMENT OF COMPLAINTS, SECURITY INCIDENTS AND BREACHES OF PRIVACY INFORMATION

blocks.text: Timeliness and thoroughness of investigation is imperative in these situations.
COMPANY INVESTIGATION OF COMPLAINTS OR DISCLOSURES

The Privacy Officer and/or Security Officer shall do a preliminary review of the facts to determine if there is evidence to support an investigation and whether the violation, if it occurred, was a willful violation or not.
The Privacy Officer and the Security Officer shall each keep a log of all alleged security incidents and complaints. The log shall identify, minimally:
What is the nature of the violation
The date it was discovered and, if it can be discerned, the date it occurred
The date the complaint or report of a security incident was received
The staff involved, if applicable
Whether or not a full investigation is indicated and, if so, includes the following:
The names of all consumers whose privacy information is involved
The extent to which any privacy information was accessed
An assessment of whether the source that accessed the information would what it was or what they could do with it
Whether any exposure occurred and, if so, how it has been used or disbursed, if possible
If any harm of any sort has occurred at the time of this investigation and prior to employment of mitigation activities
Date when mitigation activities, if applicable, were initiated and completed
Whether any notice outside the Company is indicated and, if so, what notice has been initiated, by what means, and on what date
Any other pertinent information

While this initial exploration is to be documented on the log, a full investigation would not be necessary if, upon initial discovery, it is identified that one or more of the following situations exists:
Access or use was by another staff and was unintentional, made in good faith and does not result in further use or disclosure

It was an inadvertent disclosure by a staff authorized to access PHI/ePHI to another staff/person so authorized and the information received as a result of the inadvertent disclosure is not further used or disclosed
A disclosure where there is good faith belief that an unauthorized person to whom the disclosure was made would not reasonably have been able to retain such information

Initial investigation supports a low probability that the PHI/ePHI has been compromised based upon a general risk assessment of 1) the nature and extent of information involved and likelihood of re-identification; 2) the unauthorized person who used or to whom the information was disclosed; 3) whether PHI/ePHI was determined to have actually been acquired or viewed; and 4) the extent to which the risk to the PHI/ePHI has been mitigated

The Privacy Officer and/or Security Officer shall oversee initiation and implementation of a prompt investigation of the alleged complaint or breach if merited from the preliminary review. Every step of the investigation shall be documented in specific and clear detail by the Officer.  Interviews shall be conducted as appropriate, reports and inspections evaluated, equipment inspected as relevant, and all other actions necessary to ascertain if the complaint is founded and/or an unauthorized disclosure occurred and, if so, to what extent exposure occurred and to what degree there is risk of harm to consumers.  The investigation shall be completed as quickly and as thoroughly as possible given the event and circumstances involved.

The Company, with oversight by the Privacy and Security Officers, shall conduct an annual risk analysis of potential risks/vulnerabilities to confidentiality, integrity and availability of PHI and ePHI, using the proactive risk analysis process.  Findings from this analysis shall be addressed to minimize and/or eliminate potential vulnerabilities.

To avoid harmful effects of violations in use or unauthorized disclosure, the Security and Privacy Officers will, promptly upon validation that a breach did occur, conduct a risk analysis to determine what may have contributed to this breach and action needed to prevent such a breach in the future.
All mitigation activities shall also be documented by the Privacy and/or Security Officer and, if indicated, the IT Consultant.

Should it be concluded that patient health information was inadvertently or willfully disclosed, patient(s) involved will be notified by the CEO or designee without delay and in no case more than 60 calendar days of the discovery.  The notification shall be in plain language and shall include:
A description of what happened, including the date of the breach, if determinable, and date of discovery
A description of the types of unsecured PHI that was involved in the breach
Steps the patient(s) should take to protect themselves from potential harm as a result of the breach
A brief description of action taken to investigate the breach, mitigate harm to patient(s) and protect against further breaches
Contact procedures for patient(s) to ask questions or learn more, including a toll free phone number, email address, Web-site or mailing address.

Notice shall be written using first class mail to the patient at their last known address, or, if the patient agrees to electronic notice, by electronic mail.  More than one mailing may be necessary as investigation reveals additional information pertinent to the patient.  If the patient is known to be deceased, the notice should be sent to the next of kin or guardian.

If contact information is insufficient or out of date, precluding written notification, a substitute form of notice calculated to reach the patient shall be used if the number of consumers involved is fewer than 10.  If more than 10, the notice must be by conspicuous posting for a period of 90 days on the home page of the Web-site or in a major print or via broadcast media in a geographic area(s) where affected consumers likely reside.  Notice includes a toll free phone number that is active for at least 90 days.
In cases where providing notice is deemed urgent, phone contact or other means may be used in addition to written notice.

In cases where unsecured breach involved more than 500 consumers or a state or jurisdiction, prominent media outlets serving the state or jurisdiction shall be notified to issue an alert that includes a toll-free phone number that consumers can call to gain information.  Media notification shall be completed by the CEO or designee.

subpolicies.title: Notification Activities – Secretary of DHHS by the CEO or Designee

blocks.text: If the breach involved less than 500 consumers, maintain a log of such breaches and, not later than 60 days after the end of the calendar year, provide notification as directed on the DHHS Web-site.
If the breach involved more than 500 consumers, notification should be immediate and according to the instructions and using the forms available on the HHS Web-site.

If the Company or Business Associate is notified by law enforcement that notification, notice or posting as required above would impede criminal investigation or cause damage to national security, the Company or Business Associate shall do the following:
If notification occurred in writing, delay for the time period specified by the law official.

If notification was given orally by a law official, document the oral statement, including identification of the official making the notification statement, and delay temporarily but no longer than 30 days unless written notice is provided before the end of the 30 days.

The Company and/or Business Associate, if applicable, have the burden of demonstrating that all notifications were made as required OR that the complaint and/or alleged use or disclosure of PHI did not constitute a breach.

subpolicies.title: INVESTIGATION BY THE SECRETARY OF DHHS

blocks.text: An investigation is conducted much the same way as an audit or compliance review.  One objective of this investigation is to determine if a violation actually occurred and, if it did, whether the violation was willful or intentional.  The investigation may include any of the following and may occur onsite or offsite:

The Company or Business Associate will receive a written communication regarding the complaint, including a description of the act or omission that is the basis of the complaint, prior to initiating the investigation.
Review of pertinent policies, procedures, practices of the Company or Business Associate, as applicable.
Determination of circumstances surrounding the alleged violation.
Conduct of a compliance review of the Company’s or Business Associate’s records and required compliance reports/inspections.
The Company or Business Associate must:
Keep such records and submit them at such time, in the manner and containing such information as the Secretary requests
Cooperate with investigation and compliance reviews/inspections
Permit access to information (if held by another entity, the Company must demonstrate and certify efforts to obtain the information)
Provide written testimony if so subpoenaed

If the Secretary’s conclusion is noncompliance, an attempt is made to reach resolution by informal means such as a demonstration of compliance or a completed corrective action plan. In this case resolution will be provided to the Company or Business Associate in writing.

If not resolved by informal means, the Company or Business Associate will be given an opportunity to submit written evidence of any mitigating factors or affirmative defenses. These will be considered by the Secretary within 30 days.

If, after review, the Secretary finds a civil penalty should be imposed, the Company or Business Associate will be informed. If no violation was found and no further action is warranted, the Company or Business Associate will be informed in writing.

This policy will be reviewed by the Privacy and Security Officers annually and revisions made when necessary.  The Policy will be forwarded to the Clinical Committee for review and approval when revisions are made and at a minimum of annually.

blocks.text: Weapons are not allowed anywhere within the Organization. A secure weapon locker will be provided for law enforcement officers.
Identification of staff and visitors’ entry into the organization:
Signs will be posted prohibiting loitering, drug related activities, and unauthorized persons on site.
Visitors will sign a visitor's sheet.
Staff will wear identity badges for identification.
Visitors will wear a visitor identification badge.
Staff, consumers, and visitors are encouraged to lock their vehicles.
The following aspects of security are identified as sensitive and have specific policies and procedures for prevention, control, and response to breaches:
Secure management of all sensitive or confidential information.
Storage of hazardous materials.
Medication storage and control.
Domestic violence, threats and stalking.
Ask consumers about restraining orders or threats; staff has a duty to warn if danger is imminent.
Provide counseling that assists consumers to break harmful associations; help them develop
a safety plan.
Presence of gang members or drug dealers on or near the property.
Weapons and contraband.
Grounds security.
Locked areas including entrances and exits and associated key control.
Working with law enforcement personnel.
Alarm key pad security codes.
At determination of a violent situation, or threat to consumer, visitor, or staff, or of any other security related incident:
Staff person witnessing the incident initiates action, intervening early to de-escalate potential violence, if appropriate, and/or notifies the Safety Officer of the problem.
If necessary, contact local law enforcement to assist.
Place violence related information in the consumer’s record and help the consumer create a personal safety plan.
Require consumers to sign a no-contact agreement that forbids contact with a stalker or abusive party.
Assist consumers in obtaining civil protection.
Connect consumers with community services.
Weapons are not allowed within the Organization unless carried by law enforcement officers who have been contacted for security assistance.

Post signs prohibiting loitering, drug-related activity, and unauthorized persons on site. Some clients may be reluctant to break ties with substance-using acquaintances and may need the clinical staff’s encouragement and program’s rules to end harmful associations.
Authority for security:
If the situation is deemed to be threatening to the safety of consumers, visitors, or staff, any person is authorized to take immediate action.
If the situation is of less severity, the Safety Officer will determine actions to be taken.
If the media is involved, only the CEO may give out information.

Persons deemed to be “celebrities” or considered to be “very important persons” (VIPs) are to have their identities protected, unless they give permission to be otherwise treated, at all times. Confidentiality is to be strictly enforced. If deemed necessary by the CEO, a Jane or John Doe designation may be assigned to the consumer name on the record to protect identity. In the event of more than one record, a number will also be assigned. Only the CEO will have a list with actual names for the consumer records.
Violations of proper procedures by staff are reported immediately to the CEO.
All incidents involving security are recorded on an Incident Report form within 48 hours and given to the Safety Officer.
An alarm system is maintained at the main reception area and in the nursing station on the opiate
medication storage vault/safe of the MAT programs.  Components of the alarm system must
include:
Contact  switches on the door of the opiate medication storage vault/safe;
A device designed to detect illegal entry into the vault (i.e., electrical lacing of walls, 	floors, and ceilings; sensitive ultrasonic equipment within the vault; or sound 	accumulator system); and

Safes and steel cabinets, if necessary, depending on the quantities and type of controlled 	substance medications stored, must be equipped with an alarm system, which upon 	unauthorized entry will transmit a signal directly to a central station protection company, a 	police department, or a 24-hour control station operated by the program.  The program has 	verified with the local DEA Diversion Field Office that the  program’s safe/steel cabinet requires an 	alarm system.

Vaults must be equipped with an alarm system, which upon unauthorized entry will transmit 	a signal directly to a central station protection company, a police department, or a 24-hour 	control station operated by the program.
A perimeter alarm system covering doors and windows of the program; and
Holdup alarms in strategic areas (i.e., the reception and dispensing areas).

The system is tested on a regular basis by testing the different sensors locally to make sure they are functioning and the sensitivity is appropriate. On a quarterly basis, the system is tested in conjunction with the central station. This is accomplished by notifying the alarm company that testing of the alarm is occurring, and verifying that the central station received a signal from our location.  This is documented on the Equipment Testing Log.
Once the security breach has been resolved, the CEO will:

Oversee initiation of a debriefing for consumers and staff to address any stress related effects of the event. The debriefing may occur before releasing consumers and staff back to their regular activities or scheduled at a later time within 24 hours of the event.
If indicated, the CEO will collaborate with law enforcement personnel to determine any changes in procedure that are indicated to prevent a repeat of the security event.
The event will be reviewed by the Safety Officer to determine if there are any permanent changes to policies and procedures needed.
Security incidents will be reviewed to determine areas of risk reduction or prevention; proactive risk analysis of at least one aspect of security will be conducted annually.
The Safety Officer is responsible for the development of the plan.
The Safety Officer submits to the Clinical Committee (CC) at least one aspect of security for proactive risk analysis annually and initiates the analysis after approved by the CC.
All staff is responsible for security. The Safety Officer has authority to make decisions related to security issues at the Organization.
The Safety Officer will monitor that the plan is implemented and that corrective actions are taken.
The Safety Officer will report as scheduled to the CC about security. The CC reviews all security-related Incident Reports for trends/patterns that indicate a need for improvement.

The Safety Officer will complete a plan evaluation annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days). The evaluation will include appropriateness of the defined scope, whether objectives were achieved, performance data, the effectiveness of the plan in reducing/preventing risks and events, and any changes in regulatory and accreditation requirements.
This plan will be reviewed and revised by the Safety Officer annually (every twelve months or once a year test plus or minus thirty days) and approved by the CC and Board of Directors.
Performance Standards have been developed to assess plan compliance.
100% of Staff will be annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) tested on the knowledge of Environment of Care which will cover the Security Management Plan.
Knowledge of Environment of Care will be indicated with a minimum overall test average of 90%.

QBH MAT Smoking Cessation Information.ed doc FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Studies over the past twenty years have tracked individuals who tried to quit smoking “cold turkey” (just stop and never smoke again) and/or by “gradually decreasing the amount of nicotine ingested per day.”  These studies reveal, on average, there is only a 4%-7% of people are able to quit smoking for more than ten months on any given attempt without medicines or other help.

"Cold turkey" is abrupt cessation of all nicotine use. While the success rate is not very high, it is a successful method for some people.  It is more likely successful for the occasional smoker or fairly new smoker.  There will be some side effects as the person’s body withdraws from the nicotine addiction.

subpolicies.title: Health care provider and system interventions

blocks.text: Interventions related to health care providers and health care systems have been shown to improve smoking cessation among people who visit those providers.
A Task Force on Community Preventive Services determined that provider reminders alone or with workplace education are effective in promoting smoking cessation.
Quit rates also increase when persons receive advice from their doctor to quit smoking.  This advice is often associated with health conditions that will become serious if the person does not quit.

For person-to-person counseling sessions, the duration of each session, the total amount of contact time, and the number of sessions all correlated with the effectiveness of smoking cessation. A session of forty (40) minutes over 8-12 sessions produced the highest success rates.

The training of clinicians in smoking cessation methods may increase abstinence rates among staff; however, a studies show "no strong evidence" that such training decreased smoking in patients. Reducing or eliminating the costs of cessation therapies for smokers increased quit rates. "Multi-component" interventions were defined as those that combined two or more of the following strategies known as the "5 A's
Ask — Systematically identify all tobacco users at every visit
Advise — Strongly urge all tobacco users to quit
Assess — Determine willingness to make a quit attempt
Assist — Aid the staff or patient in quitting (provide counseling and medication)
Arrange — Provide follow-up contact

Various methods exist that allow a smoker to see the impact of their tobacco use, and the immediate effects of quitting. Using biochemical feedback methods can allow tobacco-users to be identified and assessed, and the use of monitoring throughout an effort to quit can increase motivation to quit.

Breath carbon monoxide (CO) monitoring: Because carbon monoxide is a significant component of cigarette smoke, a breath carbon monoxide monitor can be used to detect recent cigarette use. Carbon monoxide concentration in breath has been shown to be directly correlated with the CO concentration in blood. The value of demonstrating blood CO concentration to a smoker through a non-invasive breath sample is that it links the smoking habit with the physiological harm associated with smoking. Within hours of quitting, CO concentrations show a noticeable decrease, and this can be encouraging for someone working to quit. Breath CO monitoring has been utilized in smoking cessation as a tool to provide staff/patients with feedback, similar to the way in which other diagnostic tools such as the stethoscope, the blood pressure cuff, and the cholesterol test have been used by treatment professionals in medicine.

A metabolite of nicotine, cotinine is present in smokers. Like carbon monoxide, a cotinine test can serve as a reliable marker to determine smoking status. Cotinine levels can be tested through urine, saliva, blood, or hair samples.
Single medications include:
A 21mg dose Nicoderm CQ patch applied to the left arm.  This method has shown the highest success rate of all techniques.

Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT): Five medications approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) deliver nicotine in a form that does not involve the risks of smoking.  Several forms exist:

Trans-dermal nicotine patches deliver doses of the addictive chemical nicotine, thus reducing the unpleasant effects of nicotine withdrawal. These patches can give smaller and smaller doses of nicotine, slowly reducing dependence upon nicotine and thus tobacco. A Cochrane review found further increased chance of success in a combination of the nicotine patch and a faster acting form. Also, this method becomes most effective when combined with other medication and psychological support.
Gum
Lozenges
Sprays
Inhalers

Bupropion is an antidepressant that has been found effective; however, there are a number of disease for which its use is contradicted, including persons with seizure disorders, persons with eating disorders, and persons who are taking MAO Inhibitors.
Nicotinic receptor partial agonists:
Cytisine (Tabex) is a plant extract that has been in use since the 1960s. It was the first medication approved as an aid to smoking cessation, and has very few side effects in small doses.

Varenicline Tartrate is a prescription drug marketed by Pfizer as Chantix in the U.S. (under FDA approval). It decreases the urge to smoke and reduces withdrawal symptoms.  It has fairly high success; however, in 2008, the FDA issued a warning about possible suicidal thoughts and suicidal behavior associated with Varenicline.
Three combinations of medications are considered effective:
Long-term nicotine patch and NRT gum or spray
Nicotine patch and nicotine inhaler
Nicotine patch and bupropion (the only combination that the FDA has approved for smoking cessation)

Gradual reduction involves slowly reducing one's daily intake of nicotine. This can be done in four ways: (a) by repeated changes to cigarettes with lower levels of nicotine, (b) by gradually reducing the number of cigarettes smoked each day, (c) by smoking only a fraction of a cigarette each time lighting up, or (d) applying NicoBloc drops on the cigarette filter which absorbs up to 99% of tar and nicotine. Some studies have found that gradual nicotine replacement therapy was effective in smoking cessation. A 2010 study found that abrupt cessation and gradual reduction with pre-quit NRT produced similar quit rates whether or not pharmacotherapy or counseling was used.

Studies have shown that there was "limited evidence" that community interventions such as mass media campaigns, increasing tobacco product prices, public education, or competitions and incentives, using "multiple channels to provide reinforcement, support and norms for not smoking" had an effect on smoking cessation among adults. Specific methods used in the community to encourage.
Great American Smokeout is an annual event that invites smokers to quit for one day, hoping they will be able to extend this forever.
The World Health Organization's World No Tobacco Day is held on May 31 each year.

Smoking-cessation support and counseling is often offered over the internet, over phone quitlines (e.g., the US toll-free number 1-800-QUIT-NOW), or in person. Studies have concluded that telephone cessation counseling is effective when compared with minimal or no counseling or self-help, and that telephone cessation counseling with medication is more effective than medication alone.

Group or individual counseling can help people who want to quit. Counseling is effective alone; counseling and medication is more effective than medication alone (and conversely, medication and counseling is more effective than counseling alone); and the number of sessions of counseling with medication correlates with effectiveness. The types of counseling that have been effective in smoking cessation programs include motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy.
Studies have found that self-help materials may produce only a small increase in quit rates and are basically ineffective.
Substitutes such as the electronic cigarette have not proven to be successful aids to quitting.

Acupuncture. Studies do not support that acupuncture helps smokers who are trying to quit.  Nevertheless, acupuncture has been called a "reasonable option" for smoking cessation because of its low risk.

Hypnosis. Clinical trials studying hypnosis and hypnotherapy as a method for smoking cessation have been inconclusive; however, a randomized trial published in 2008 found that hypnosis and nicotine patches "compares favorably" with standard behavioral counseling and nicotine patches.
Herbs. No herbs are currently considered safe or effective for smoking cessation.
Methods used with children and adolescents that have shown some effectiveness if done together include:
Motivational enhancement
Psychological support
Smoking during pregnancy can cause adverse health effects in both the woman and the fetus. This does not seem sufficient motivation for most women to stop smoking.

Studies to date support that, if used together, "group behavioral support" and "medication" can quadruple the chances that a quit attempt will be successful.   Smokers using a combination method of pharmacological and psychosocial approaches have the most success compared to those who use pharmaceutical or psychosocial approaches in isolation.
Quitting can be harder for individuals with dark pigmented skin compared to individuals with pale skin since nicotine has an affinity for melanin-containing tissues.

There is an important social component to smoking. Studies have found that smoking cessation by any given individual reduced the chances of others around them lighting up by the following amounts: a spouse by 67%, a sibling by 25%, a friend by 36%, and a coworker by 34%.
Smokers with major depressive disorder are less successful at quitting smoking than non-depressed smokers.

Relapse (resuming smoking after quitting) has been related to psychological issues such as low self-efficacy or non-optimal coping responses; however, psychological approaches to prevent relapse have not been proven to be successful.

The symptoms listed in the box above are typical and last from 1 day to 4 weeks depending upon the individual person. In contrast, constipation, cough, dizziness, increased dreaming, and mouth ulcers are typically not symptoms of withdrawal.  Nor were complaints such as dry mouth, flu symptoms, headaches, heart racing, skin rash, sweating, and tremor symptoms of withdrawal.

People who successfully quit smoking may gain weight (average 8 lb for women and 6 lb for men).  However doctors and researchers agree that weight gain is not likely to negate the health benefits of smoking cessation, but its cosmetic effects may interfere with attempts to quit.

When people with a history of depression stop smoking depressive symptoms or actual depression may result. This side effect of smoking cessation may be particularly common in women, as depression is more common among women than among men.
Many of tobacco's health effects can be minimized through smoking cessation. The health benefits over time of stopping smoking include:
Within 20 minutes after quitting, blood pressure and heart rate decrease
Within 12 hours, carbon monoxide levels in the blood decrease to normal
Within 3 months, circulation and lung function improve
Within 9 months, there are decreases in cough and shortness of breath
Within 1 year, the risk of coronary heart disease is cut in half
Within 5 years, the risk of stroke falls to the same as a non-smoker, and the risks of many cancers (mouth, throat, esophagus, bladder, cervix) decrease significantly
Within 10 years, the risk of dying from lung cancer is cut in half, and the risks of larynx and pancreas cancers decrease
Within 15 years, the risk of coronary heart disease drops to the level of a non-smoker
TBH shall attempt to maintain a current list of smoking cessation programs available in the local community.  This list shall be posted in the staff areas.

sections.title: QBH MAT Smoking.policy  FINALr   6 17

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral health Inc. MAT recognizes that smoking has been directly associated with increased health risks.  It is therefore the Company’s policy to discourage smoking, to provide appropriate resources to assist consumers and/or staff to stop smoking, and to maintain a smoke-free/tobacco-free workplace and clinical setting.

Our policy is to uphold the existing law and Joint Commission recommendations; to protect the rights of non-smokers and smokers; to provide consumers, visitors and staff with an example of responsible health behavior; to maintain a clean and healthful environment; and to reduce the discomfort of consumers, visitors and staffs whose tolerance for tobacco products is limited.

Premises – includes any grounds, buildings, doors, vehicles that are designated as belonging to QBH and/or are located on QBH property, whether owned or leased by QBH. Inclusive of QBH premises, by definition, is the adjacent 25 feet next to the premises in order to maintain QBH property free of secondhand smoke and fumes.
Service Site – is defined as anywhere that QBH services are provided, whether on QBH premises or not.

Smoke-free – is defined as: “no tobacco or other plant smoke and freedom from inhaling environmental tobacco smoke (ETS) or passive smoke, including secondhand smoke generated by an active smoker or side stream smoke or fumes from any such burning material, device or ashtray that continues to emit such tobacco smoke or fumes from lighted or extinguished smoking materials”.

Smoking – is defined as “carrying or possessing any lighted tobacco products including cigarettes, cigars, and pipes, E-cigarettes (vapor), smokeless tobacco products (i.e., dip, snuff, and chew) or e-cigarettes.”
Tobacco-free – is defined as: “no tobacco or other plant used for smoking or chewing.”
There shall be no smoking and/or chewing on the premises of QBH, including any adjacent non-QBH area within 25 feet of the QBH premises.  QBH shall be smoke-free and tobacco-free.
Smoking or chewing of tobacco in any form is prohibited.
Staff that smokes must take a break to smoke and leave the premises.
The following three (3) times are approved for taking a smoke-break: one break before noon, during the lunch break, and one break in the afternoon (1 pm to close of office).
A smoke break shall not exceed fifteen (15) minutes.
Staff must clock in and out when taking a smoke break just as for a lunch break.
Office staff cannot all take a lunch or smoke break together.  The office must be manned during all business hours.
Staff is not to smoke or chew with consumers anywhere, on or off the premises or service site.
Staff must wash hteir hands after smoking.

Consumers shall be oriented to this policy and given information on Smoking Cessation as part of the intake process.  Consumers already in the QBH system will be informed by their MHP and/or MHPP at the next appointment and offered Smoking Cessation information. This shall be documented in the consumer record.

“No Smoking on this Property” signs shall be posted at all QBH entrances.  If the office has a private or designated parking area, a sign shall be posted in a highly visible location in the parking lot as well. It is the Safety Officer's responsibility to acquire and maintain these signs.
There shall be no smoking appliances such as ash trays or bins anywhere on the premises.
Smoking cessation information shall be available and posted at each office for reference by staff and consumers.
Staff that violates this policy shall receive discipline through their Administrative Assistantr as follows:
First violation – a verbal warning will be given.
Second violations – a written warning will be given and a copy of the warning will go in the staff member’s personnel file in the HR Office.
Repeat violations – the staff member shall be terminated.
Consumers that violate this policy shall be reported to their MHP who

will address the violation with them and remind them of their  responsibility to comply with Company rules. Repeated violations will be handled the same way as repeated violations of other consumer rules.
This policy shall be reviewed annually by the Safety Officer and, as needed, revised and reported to the Clinical Committee for review.

The Administrative Assistant and staff shall monitor for updated smoking   cessation materials, resources, and programs available in the locale of each office and have the Safety Officer to update office postings and materials as needed.

sections.title: QBH MAT STANDARD PRECAUTIONS.policy FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Standard Precautions combine Universal precautions with Body Substance Isolation features.  The Standard Precautions are designed to reduce the risk of Transmission of microorganisms from both recognized and unrecognized sources of infection.  Standard Precautions are to be used on all consumers regardless of diagnosis or presumed infection status.
Standard Precautions apply to the following:
All body fluids, secretions and excretions regardless if whether or not these contain visible bloody fluids.
All blood or bloody fluids
Mucous membranes
Non-intact skin areas.

In addition to Standard Precautions, Transmission Based Precautions may also need to implement on consumers diagnosed with highly transmissible or epidemiological pathogens. Transmission Based Precautions would include airborne, droplet and contact.
Running water and soap will be used to wash hands (refer to Exposure Control Plan, section 3- hand washing) for specifics for Hand washing as defined by The Hand Hygiene Policy.
Hands will be washed after touching blood, body fluids, secretions, excretions and/or contaminated items, whether or not gloves have been worn.
Wash hands immediately before and after gloves are used, between consumer contact and any other appropriate time as stated in exposure control plan.

Clean, non-sterile gloves will be worn touching dressings, blood, body fluids, secretion/excretions, etc and clean gloves will be put on before procedures, touching mucous membranes, and/or non-intact skin as in open wounds.
Gloves will be promptly after touching any contaminated area and hands washed immediately.
Masks, eye protection, and face shield will be used to protect mucous membranes of the employee while during procedures that might generate splashes of blood, body fluids, etc.

The Infection Control Coordinator will evaluate, review, and revise the policy annually (once a year, every twelve months, plus or minus thirty days), if needed, and submit to the Clinical Committee for approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT STRATEGIC PLANNING.policy  FINAL  7 17

blocks.text: The strategic plan is viewed as a guide to focus Company efforts, position QBH to take advantage of future opportunities, as well as to counter potential external threats.

Planning commences with a careful review of the current mission, philosophy and core values; internally and externally generated performance data from the past three years; current demographics of QBH’s service area; current relationships with external stakeholders and other valuable information; evaluation of QBH’s status in achieving the previous years’ goals and objectives; feedback on needs and expectations from customers, staff and various stakeholders through satisfaction surveys  and other input mechanisms; adequacy of Company technology to produce efficient operations, effective service delivery, performance improvement and data analysis capabilities.

A SWOT process is employed that looks at Company strengths and capabilities; Company weaknesses or improvement needs; internal and externally identified opportunities, particularly financial opportunities, positive features of the current and projected regulatory and/or legislative environment, and service area needs QBH might address; and internal and external threats of a financial nature, degree of competitiveness in the provider environment, the nature of the regulatory and legislative environments, etc.
This review provides the foundation for the development of the strategic plan.

Based upon the priorities set by the leadership as a result of this analysis, corporate goals and objectives are established to act upon and maximize the opportunities and strengths identified and to reduce the actual or potential threats to and weaknesses of QBH and its services.
The CEO in collaboration with the Clinical Committee and Board members is responsible to develop the written plan.

Current and projected financial position of QBH is a serious consideration in developing the plan as this situation will impact what resources are available for allocation of resources needed to support achievement of the plan.
The plan sets goals, priorities and an implementation plan (including what is to be done, broken into steps, by whom and by when).
The plan may be for one year of multiple years with yearly achievement points, considering QBH’s current financial position and financial planning for the future as well as other resources available.
The Strategic Plan, once approved, is communicated to staff at staff meetings by the department or program leadership.
A copy of the plan is posted in the consumer community rooms to avail interested customers of the information.
The plan is shared with other stakeholders as required per contract agreement or upon request.

The plan is reviewed by the CEO at least annually, with interim reporting of progress points quarterly to the Clinical Committee and the Board; updating of the plan occurs as needed. The plan is reviewed and approved by the Clinical Committee and the Board annually.

sections.title: QBH MAT Take Home.policy  FINAL 7 17

subpolicies.title: Take Home or Off-Site Dosing:  Providing medication in an appropriately labeled, tamper/child-proof container for consumption outside of the MAT Program site.

blocks.text: QBH’s Take Home Policy will provide alternative programs for eligible consumers to promote high morale, the maximum opportunity for consumer use of counseling services, employment, educational, vocational, home making activities and the successful attainment of drug free state and personal growth enrichment in compliance with State, FDA, and QBH regulations and guidelines, as appropriate.

Request for take home/off-site dosing medication privileges will be reviewed and approved by a licensed staff physician or authorized designee, in compliance with Company, state, federal and FDA regulations.

The FDA regulation requires that new consumers attend the MAT Program for drug treatment six days a week.  Consumers in program for less than 90 days are required to comply with this regulation.  Transfer consumers with uninterrupted treatment from another licensed program who have over 90 days or a continual 90 days may be eligible for take home/off-site dosing with appropriate documentation.

All consumers who are dispensed methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone for off-site dosing will be deemed responsible for handling methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone based upon the reasonable clinical judgement of the program physician. The rationale for the decision will be recorded in the consumer's chart by a program physician or a designated staff.

The consumer is expected to secure the methadone, buprenorphine or naltrexone in a locked box and to store it out of the reach of children and others who could be harmed by accidental use and/or to prevent diversion by third parties.  A locked box is defined as a secure metal, plastic, or wood box that has the consumer’s name inside and which locks with a key or combination.

Because the MAT Program is closed on Sundays and Holidays, off-site dosing medication is distributed to all consumers on Saturday and the day prior to a holiday.  All warnings regarding the care of medication are found on the label.  Consumers must present a container with a lock and key or combination each pick-up day.

QBH’s staff is to provide documentation in each consumer’s record of the individual and group counseling directed at promoting the safeguarding and prevention of sale of medication. Consumers are also informed about potential interactions with and adverse reactions to other substances, including those reactions that might result from interactions and adverse reactions to alcohol, other prescribed or OTC pharmacological agents, other medical procedures, and food.
No medications shall be dispensed to consumers in short-term detoxification treatment or interim maintenance treatment for unsupervised or take-home use.

Take-home medication is a valuable therapeutic tool and is part of an individualized treatment plan. Providing medication for unsupervised use is a reflection of the physician’s judgment and staff’s assessment of a consumer’s behavior while in treatment. Time in treatment is also an important factor. Take-home medication often becomes a critical issue for consumers who are deciding whether to enter and remain in treatment. Program staff members use discretion in customizing medication schedules for each consumer, according to that consumer’s best interests. Physicians and staff members must consider public health issues in approving take-home medication (e.g., preventing diversion, ensuring safe storage and security of medication, preventing overdoses). Staff shall monitor that policies for approval of take-home medication do not create barriers to consumers’ continuing in treatment. Our MAT program policies foster decisions about entering and remaining in medication-assisted treatment based on medical factors.

subpolicies.title: TEAM DETERMINATION OF TAKE HOME/OFF-SITE ELIGIBILITY

blocks.text: A multidisciplinary team, led by the primary clinician, provides recommendations and essential input for review, while the program physician makes the final decision about approving take-home medication. Physicians and staff members review decisions periodically, as clinically appropriate, and document them in the consumer record. The review considers the eligibility criteria and other relevant clinical factors at each review. The physician notes conclusions reached in this review in the consumer’s record.

Suboxone is the preferred medication for take-home dispensing (or prescriptions) unless otherwise clinically indicated. Treatment with Suboxone may follow guidelines described in CSAT’s Treatment Improvement Protocol 40 (TIP 40) and other related CSAT publications. In following these guidelines, take-home medication decisions may differ if the consumer is receiving Suboxone instead of methadone. Programs should use the CSAT consumer exception process to justify take-home medications for Suboxone.

The MAT Program Treatment Team shall meet, as needed, to monitor, review and approve consumers for continuing eligibility for take home methadone, to review disciplinary cases, and to determine indication for medication changes.
The Treatment Team will consider the following in making decisions:
FDA criteria
The consumer’s progress
Attendance record
Adherence to program rules
Financial status
Medical condition
Counselor recommendations
Employment/vocational/education/home-making  situation
Any documented special circumstances
Treatment Team composition shall be, minimally, three staff representing:
Medical/Nursing
Counseling
Administration
The team will provide written documentation in each consumer’s record of the approved and disapproved determinations.  Documentation shall also include the team members present.

Take home/off site dosing medication for more than Sunday and/or holiday use, is given only to a consumer who, in the judgment of the program physician and counselor, is responsible in the handling of methadone, buprenorphine or naltrexone. Before reducing the frequency of program visits, the rationale for this decision is recorded in the consumer's record by the physician and the counselor.  Address the following:

Background and history of consumer: the consumer is employed, actively seeking employment as evidenced by a sign off sheet from potential employers, disabled and unable to work as evidenced by a Social Security Income or Social Security Income Disability or Workmen's Compensation checks; and the consumer has appropriately handled off-site dosing in the past such as Sunday's and Holidays or other off-site situations.
General and special characteristics of the consumer and the community in which the consumer resides;
Absence of recent abuse of non-narcotic drugs, including alcohol;
Absence of current abuse of non-narcotic drugs, alcohol and narcotic drugs, including methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone;
All other consumers who are eligible and who receive a medical prescription order from the Medical Director may qualify for reduced program treatment services as appropriate.
Request for take home medication privileges will be reviewed and approved by the program physician.

The following criteria should be assessed prior to initiating off-site dosing in excess of the Sunday/holiday take home policy.  These criteria shall be re-assessed regularly with regard to continuing off-site dosing and/or increasing or decreasing the level of off-site dosing.

The FDA regulation requires that new consumers attend the MAT program for drug treatment service six (6) days per week- consumers in programs less than ninety (90) days are required to comply with this regulation.

Transfer consumers with un-interrupted treatment from another licensed program who have over ninety (90) days or a continued total of 90 days may be eligible for take-home privileges with appropriate documentation.
Clinical stability: The consumer demonstrates clinical stability when:
The consumer’s dose has reached their optimal level.

The consumer demonstrates the social, cognitive and emotional stability necessary to assume responsibility for the care of the medication and to use it as prescribed. Social stability can be demonstrated by stable housing, stable support system and activities and regular attendance at pharmacy, counselling and doctors’ appointments.
Consumers must be demonstrating no evidence of problematic use of any drug or alcohol.
Medical Disability: Consumers showing sustained use of medications with abuse potential may receive more than one off-site dosing per week if the following conditions are satisfied:
A specific medical diagnosis has been made that has evidence-based substantiation for the use of that medication to treat the symptoms of the condition.
The consumer is clinically stable and meets other off-site dosing criteria.

The team may decide to initiate or increase off-site dosing to a consumer who otherwise does not qualify if they suffer from a medical condition that significantly interferes with their ability to attend the MAT Program for dosing.
Every effort should be made to have some supervision of the methadone consumption in these cases.
For medical conditions of a temporary nature, the requirements for off-site dosing should be re-assessed once the consumer’s ability to attend the MAT Program is established.

It should be recognized that the medical condition that necessitates off-site dosing might involve pain and clinical situations that trigger increased substance abuse. The physician and team must carefully decide whether the benefits of off-site dosing for the consumer outweigh the risk of further destabilizing the consumer.
Compassionate Basis:
Consumers who have not satisfied all of the other criteria may be provided short term off-site dosing on a compassionate basis in cases of personal or family crises or bereavement.
The physician should verify the extenuating circumstances and be satisfied that there is no other way to have the consumer’s dosing observed.

Additionally the physician should assess the mental status of the consumer to be satisfied that the provision of off-site dosing though the crisis will not compromise the safety of the consumer or other persons.
Job or Vocation:

Consumers who have been deemed appropriate for a high level of off-site dosing (i.e. attends the MAT Program once or twice weekly) may be granted a higher number of off-site dosinga for reasons such as travel and employment opportunities. In certain circumstances, temporary arrangements for MAT Program or pharmacy dispensing can be made. The consumer should provide the physician with verification of the travel plans (e.g. plane ticket, letter from work).
Other Criteria:
Must have been in the program for at least 90 days continuously
Regular program attendance
Has had continuously clean urine samples
Absence of serious behavioral problems at the program
Absence of recent criminal activity, including no drug dealing
Stability of the consumer's home environment and social relationships
Length of time in comprehensive maintenance treatment
Assurance that take-home medication can be safely stored within the consumer's home
Whether the rehabilitative benefit derived from decreasing the frequency of program attendance outweighs the potential risks and diversion potential
Criteria Exceptions
Exceptions to the criteria above include only the following and can be utilized for only a temporary period of time, not to exceed two days.  These exceptions include:
Illness
Personal or family crisis
Inability to conform to the applicable mandatory schedule
If a longer period is required, prior authorization must be sought from the state and FDA, at least 7 days in advance of the absence
Consumers with unstable living arrangements, such as those living on the street or in hostels without storage facilities may not be appropriate to receive off-site dosing.

Consumers selected for take-home dosing shall be instructed regarding and sign a Notice of Off-Site Dosing Responsibility Form that spells out their responsibilities relative to take-home medications and shall be monitored as they provide a urine sample for drug screening.
Consumers should be asked to demonstrate to the physician the locked box that they have agreed to keep off-site dosing secured in.

subpolicies.title: OPIOID TREATMENT CONSUMERS AND TEMPORARY RESIDENTIAL TREATMENT

blocks.text: Periodically, opioid treatment consumers may require temporary residential treatment, long-term care, incarceration, etc. Other portions of this guideline address chain of custody for take-home supplies, and other issues that permit consumers to continue maintenance during these periods. Occasionally, due to unforeseen circumstances, there are unused medication supply issues that need to be resolved.

Because an individual consumer may not return unused controlled substance prescription medication to the MAT program facility, the program shall have a procedure to oversee that medications are disposed of in a manner that does not allow the controlled substances to be easily diverted for illegal use.

subpolicies.title: What will this be for you all?

blocks.text: All exceptions to the off-site dosing schedule must have clear documentation of their necessity.  Off-site dosing exceptions should most commonly be seen as a trial and, as such, require frequent reassessment.  See Exception Request Procedure Addendum.

The risk of abuse of any drug is increased in someone with a known history of substance abuse or dependency.  Caution must be exercised when contemplating the awarding of off-site dosing to anyone known to be using other chemicals regularly, or sporadically. The decision to give off-site dosing must take into account both individual and societal safety.  Rationale must be clearly documented in the consumer’s record.

All other consumers who are eligible and who receive a methadone prescription order from the Medical Director may also qualify for reduced MAT Program treatment services as well, if deemed appropriate by the treatment team.

Medication for off-site administration is labeled as follows:
The name of the medication

Consumer's name or code number

Date to be used
A cautionary statement that the medication should be kept out of the reach of children.

The consumer is expected to secure the methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone in a locked box and store it out of reach of children and others who could be harmed from accidental use and to prevent diversion by third parties.
A locked box is defined as a secure and durable metal, plastic, wood box that has the consumer’s name inside which locks with a key or combination.

Consumers must inconspicuously and safely transport take-home medication from the program to their home. Otherwise the locked container challenges two regulatory issues: (1) if the locked container is publicly visible, it may offer a means to identify someone in treatment and violate consumer confidentiality; and (2) the container’s visibility may identify the consumer possessing take-home medication, and place the consumer at risk for robbery or assault.

For consumers reporting to the program once or twice per month, receiving 15- to 30-day supplies of medication, the program shall, if possible, dispense dry medication diskettes in one single bottle for ease of discrete transport home. The program will also provide, if possible, medication diskettes for consumers using air transportation. Dispensing dry medications will mitigate any potential for bacterial growth in liquid media.

QBH’s staff will oversee that adequate documentation is maintained in consumer medical records and that individual and group counseling and planning promotes the safeguarding and prevention of the sale of medication.

It is the policy of QBH, in accordance with R3256.14415 Part 415[2] of the Administrative Rules for Substance Services that all empty and unused bottles are to be returned to the MAT program in the locked box for proper disposal.

Consumers who fail to return empty bottles and/or bottles with labels will be subject to graduated sanctions for off-site dosing which include, but are not limited to, decreasing and rescinding of all off-site dosing.

During the course of medication-assisted treatment, there may be occasions when a consumer is unable to report to the program for return of bottles. This absence may occur because of illness, pregnancy, incarceration, participation in residential treatment, lack of transportation, and the like. When these situations occur, continuing the consumer’s treatment safely while ensuring appropriate handling and delivery to the consumer is a challenge for clinical staff.

This is accomplished by using a Chain-of-Custody Record, which is a document containing the signatures of all people who have handled the medication. This record shall also contain space for the consumer to initial each day that the medication is administered, as well as space for the initials of the person who administered the medication. The consumer and the person administering the medication should contact the program immediately if the medication seems altered in any way.

When the consumer is unable to report to the program as required, a Chain-of-Custody Record is used to encourage a responsible person to take charge of the medication and place it under lock and key at the offsite location. The same holds true for incarceration facilities and nursing homes that do not have methadone in stock.

For consumers who are homebound, a family member who does not have a history of alcohol or drug abuse and whom the MAT program staff members have met and screened may receive permission to pick up the medication. The MAT program shall request this through the SMA-168 and forward the exception request to the relevant State and Federal Government authorities.

When the Chain-of-Custody Record has been completed, it is to be returned to the program. The original of the record should be placed in the consumer’s medical record, and a copy may be placed in the file maintained by the Utilization and Quality Manager, as needed, for QM monitoring purposes.

subpolicies.title: REASSESSMENT AND/OR REDUCTION OF OFF-SITE DOSING PRIVILEGES

blocks.text: A reassessment and possible reduction of a consumer’s off-site dosing privileges should be undertaken when the consumer engages in risky behavior that is not consistent with recovery from addiction. For example:
Consumer has failed to maintain clinical stability as previously outlined.
Continued problematic drug or alcohol use.

Consumers who are experiencing withdrawal, cravings or continued drug use or who are requesting an increased methadone dose may be at risk of consuming their off-site dosing dose earlier than indicated.
Consumer is not meeting agreed upon goals and objectives.
Consumer has failed repeatedly to leave a urine sample for drug screening in the required manner as agreed upon in the treatment plan.
Consumer has either diverted their methadone or there is a strong suspicion that methadone has been diverted or used in an inappropriate way (not as prescribed).
Consumers have tampered with their urine sample.
Consumers who consume off-site dosing early, report lost or stolen off-site dosing, or vomit off-site dosing should have their level of off-site dosing re-assessed.
Failure to return off-site dosing bottles intact to the MAT Program site.
Upon discovery by a MAT Program staff that a consumer may no longer be eligible for take home dosing privileges, the following shall occur:
The staff believing that eligibility has been breached shall document the rationale for this conclusion in the consumer’s record.

The Nursing Supervisor shall be notified and, based upon delegation of authority if so granted by the physician, may direct that the consumer be given a temporary reduction in their take home dosing status until the Treatment Team convenes.  This action shall be documented in the consumer’s record by the Nursing Supervisor.

The Treatment Team shall convene with the physician to determine the length of the reduction and whether the reduction will be temporary or permanent.  This decision is documented by the physician in a medical note.
The MAT Program Supervisor shall complete a report, on the designated form, of the Team’s decision.  The original report shall be maintained in a log book and a copy is sent to the QM Coordinator.

A consumer may re-apply for off-site dosing after 90 days of consecutive drug screens submitted for all substances except methadone.  There must be a minimum of two drug screens submitted for each month to be eligible for re-application.
The decision regarding off-site dosing reduction is monitored at least every 60 days by the physician.
The nursing staff monitors drug screens to oversee compliance with the off-site dosing policy within 24 hours of receipt of drug screen results.

Upon discovery by a counselor or nurse that the consumer may no longer be eligible for take home privileges, the rationale shall be documented in the consumer record by the staff person responsible that the consumer is no longer eligible for take home privileges

The case shall be given to the nursing supervisor. Based upon the delegation of authority granted by the physician the consumer shall be given temporary reduction in the   take-home status   until   the   treatment team converses again.
The nursing supervisor shall document this action in the consumer record.
During the treatment team meeting the physician shall determine the length of the reduction to temporary or permanent status. This action is documented in the medical note.
The nurse shall complete the treatment team (medication control committee) report form. The original shall be maintained in a log book and a copy must be sent to the Quality Manager.
Consumers may reapply for take-home privileges after 90 days of consecutive drug screens submitted for all substances except methadone, buprenorphine and naltrexone.
There must be a minimum of two (2) drug screens submitted for each month to be eligible for take-home status.
The decision regarding take home is monitored at least every 60 days by the physician.
The nurse monitors drug screens to assess compliance with take-home policy within 24 hours of drug screen results.

sections.title: QBH MAT TB TESTING.policy   FINALr  6 17

blocks.text: EQUIPMENT LIST: Tuberculin Purified Protein Derivative (Mantoux) 5TU, Tuberculin syringe with 27-gauge needle, alcohol and cotton ball.
TB skin testing is required for all new staff, unless the staff can provide proof of a negative test done within the last year.
Testing must be done before the staff is permitted to have contact with consumers.
New staffs who test positive will be referred to the County Health Department for a chest x-ray before beginning work the QBH consumers.
All testing will be done by QBH nursing staff.
Thereafter, TB testing shall be done annually on all previously tuberculin negative staff.
Any staff that allows their test date to expire will not be allowed to work until they are tested and the results are received back as negative.
Personnel will notify the Program Manager/Supervisor who will then notify the staff when his/her skin test is due.
Staff, whether new or continuing, that has previously been tuberculin positive and has had a previous chest x-ray shall complete a questionnaire to determine if they have signs of active disease.
If no indication of active disease, the questionnaire shall be filed in their health file and considered sufficient.

However, if the questionnaire indicates possible active disease, the staff will be referred to their personal physician or the Health Department for further evaluation, the results of which shall be provided to the HR Manager for filing in their health file. If indicated, the staff may be excluded from work until cleared by a physician to return to work.
Obtain history:
A repeat skin test, when the staff is a positive reactor, could lead to discomfort, pain, and possible time off work.

It is not known whether Tubercol can cause fetal harm when administered to a pregnant woman.  If a female staff is or believes she might be pregnant, she should consult with her physician before receiving a TB skin test.
Cleanse skin with alcohol and allow drying.
Inject 0.1 cc Tuberculin Purified Protein Derivative 5 TU intracutaneously into the flexor surface of the forearm about four inches below the bend of the elbow.

Insert the point of the needle into the most superficial layers of the skin with the needle bevel pointed upward.  If the intracutaneous injection is performed properly, a definite white bleb will raise at the needle point.  This will disappear in minutes.
No dressing is required. In the event of subcutaneous injection, the test should be repeated immediately at another site.

Staffs/applicants should return to have test read 48 to 72 hours after administration.  Sensitivity is indicated by induration usually accompanied by erythema.  The widest diameter of distinctly palpable induration should be recorded in millimeters.

Positive reaction: Any palpable induration measuring 10 mm or more.  Staff who have had prolonged close contact with a known TB consumer, or are HIV positive, will be considered to have a positive reaction at 5 mm induration.
Doubtful reaction: Induration measuring 5 to 9 mm.  The test should be repeated in four to six weeks at a different site.
A staff who has a positive reaction should be counseled, and reassured, and given appropriate literature to read:
The staff (if not pregnant) will be referred to the County Health Department for a chest x-ray and preventative therapy. If the staff is pregnant they will be referred to their own doctor.

Staffs that may have been exposed to a potentially infectious TB consumer will have a TB skin test administered (unless they are previous positive re-actors or have had a TB skin test within the last three months).  If the initial skin test is negative, the test is to be repeated 12 weeks after the exposure.
Exposed persons with a test reaction of >5 mm and who are suggestive of tuberculosis will be referred to the County Health Department for a chest x-ray.

Staffs with current pulmonary or laryngeal tuberculosis should be excluded from work until adequate treatment is instituted, and cough resolved, and sputum is free of bacilli for three consecutive smears. A written release from their physician will be required.

The Infection Control Coordinator will evaluate, review, and revise the policy annually (once a year every twelve months plus or minus thirty days), if needed, and submit to the Clinical Committee for approval.
