sections.title: SUBOXONE TREATMENT.policy  FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: DRUG DESCRIPTION

Suboxone (a combination of buprenorphine and naloxone) is a partial-opioid antagonist which is known to be effective in the treatment of narcotic/opioid dependent consumers.  Buprenorphine is an opioid (narcotic) medication while naloxone blocks the effects of opioid medication. Suboxone is not used for the purpose of pain control.
It is available as a buccal film, sublingual film, or sublingual tablet.

In compliance with the Drug Addiction Treatment Act (DATA) codified at 21 U.S.C. 823(g), prescription use of this product in the treatment of opioid dependence is limited to physicians who meet certain qualifying requirements, and who have notified the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) of their intent to prescribe this product for the treatment of opioid dependence and have been assigned a unique identification number that must be included on every prescription.
PRESCRIBING/USAGE GUIDELINES
Refer to the Medication Management Policy for general guidelines of medication prescribing.

Suboxone is typically initiated while a consumer is in opioid withdrawal.  The doctor will order Suboxone tablets/film to begin after five days of detox, when indicated, for opioid dependent consumers within the Detox and/or Residential program.
Suboxone will not be prescribed if the consumer is known to be allergic to buprenorphine or naloxone (Narcan).

The physician shall determine if the consumer has a known history of breathing problems or lung disease; an enlarged prostate or urination problems; liver or kidney disease; gall bladder, adrenal or thyroid problems; spinal curvature that impairs breathing; alcohol addiction or mental illness; a history of brain tumor, recent or current Hepatitis B or C infection; head injury or seizures; the consumer is pregnant.  These conditions may rule out the use of Suboxone or require lower dosage.

Liver function testing is done prior to initial dose and periodically during the course of Suboxone treatment by physician order. Other blood tests may also be indicated depending upon the consumer’s medical history.

Suboxone sublingual tablet is administered sublingually as a single daily dose. Suboxone sublingual tablets are used for consumers who have been initially inducted using Subutex® (buprenorphine) sublingual tablets per physician order.

Consumers being switched between Suboxone sublingual tablets and Suboxone sublingual film should be started on the same dosage as the previously administered product. However, dosage adjustments may be necessary when switching between products. Because of the potentially greater relative bioavailability of Suboxone sublingual film compared to Suboxone sublingual tablets, consumers being switched from Suboxone (buprenorphine and naloxone) sublingual tablets to Suboxone sublingual film should be monitored for over-medication. Those switching from Suboxone sublingual film to SUBOXONE (buprenorphine and naloxone) sublingual tablets are monitored for withdrawal or other indications of under-dosing.

Suboxone can slow breathing and thus is not used in large amounts or for longer than prescribed for opioid detoxification.  Using buprenorphine together with other medications that cause central nervous system depression can lead to serious side effects such as respiratory distress, coma, or even death; the physician shall reconcile the use of Suboxone with other medications the consumer needs. Reduction of CNS depressants, Suboxone sublingual tablets, or both may be indicated in situations of concomitant prescription.

Suboxone sublingual tablet/film is subject to diversion and abuse. When determining the prescription quantity for unsupervised administration, if the consumer must be discharged prior to taper completion, the physician will consider the consumer's level of stability, the security of his or her home situation, and other factors likely to affect the ability to manage supplies of take-home medication.
ADMINISTRATION GUIDELINES
Follow general guidelines for medication administration as set forth in the Medication Management Policy.

Suboxone sublingual tablet or film should be placed under the tongue until it is dissolved. For doses requiring the use of more than two tablets, consumers are advised to either place all the tablets at once or alternatively (if they cannot fit in more than two tablets comfortably), place two tablets at a time under the tongue. Either way, the consumers should continue to hold the tablets under the tongue until they dissolve; swallowing the tablets reduces the bioavailability of the drug. To foster consistency in bioavailability, consumers should follow the same manner of dosing with any continued use of the product.
Proper administration technique is demonstrated to the consumer by the physician or nurse with reminders at each administration; this training is documented in the consumer’s record.
CLINICAL MONITORING
Medication monitoring guidelines as set forth in the Medication Management Policy shall be employed.

Treatment is initiated and carried out with supervised administration by nursing staff. Before administration, the consumer should drink a glass of water to moisten the mouth; they should be instructed to NOT chew the tablet or film and to NOT swallow it whole.

The physician sees the consumer at least weekly during the first month of Suboxone treatment and at least monthly thereafter, based upon the individual circumstances of the consumer;  these medication reviews are documented in the consumer’s record. Periodic assessment is necessary to determine compliance with the dosing regimen, effectiveness of the treatment plan, and overall consumer progress.
Continuation or modification of pharmacotherapy should be based on the physician's evaluation of treatment outcomes and objectives such as:
Absence of medication toxicity
Absence of medical or behavioral adverse effects
Consumer's compliance with all elements of the treatment plan (including recovery-oriented activities, psychotherapy, and/or other psychosocial modalities)
Abstinence from illicit drug use (including problematic alcohol and/or benzodiazepine use)
If treatment goals are not being achieved, the physician should re-evaluate the appropriateness of continuing the current Suboxone treatment.
Respiratory monitoring is ongoing during the use of Suboxone with consumers in either the Detox or Residential programs; the monitoring is documented in the consumer’s record.
TAPERING GUIDELINES

QBH physicians employ tapering of Suboxone, according to manufacturer and medical best-practice guidelines and the consumer’s responsiveness, before discharge of the consumer if at all possible.  If the consumer must leave treatment before tapering is complete, they are referred to a physician for follow-up and completion of the tapering process.  Maintenance dosing is not done at QBH.
The decision to discontinue therapy with Suboxone is made as part of a comprehensive treatment plan involving the physician, nursing staff and therapy staff.
Tapering guidelines as set forth in the Medication Management Policy also apply.
CONSUMER AND STAFF EDUCATION
CONSUMER
The consumer will provide medication consent, and receive education about Suboxone before and during the course of treatment; consent and education are documented in the consumer’s record.
Before initiating treatment with Suboxone, the physician and/or nursing staff shall explain the points listed in Addendum A.

Addendum A summarizes the key aspects of education provided to consumers who will be receiving this treatment and will be provided in writing again at discharge if the consumer is still being tapered from the Suboxone.  The consumer who leaves still tapering from Suboxone is encouraged to read the package insert as new information may be available at any time.
STAFF

Staff that administers or supervises administration of Suboxone must first be trained in its use, proper administration, common side effects and allergic characteristics, and symptoms of overdose and management of these.  Content included in Addendum A is covered in training as well.
General guidelines for medication education as set forth in the Medication Management Policy also apply. Training is documented in each staff’s personnel record.

The most commonly observed adverse events included headache, nausea, vomiting, hyperhidrosis, constipation, signs and symptoms of withdrawal, insomnia, pain and peripheral edema. Additionally, oral hypoesthesia may occur with the sublingual film. Review all the side effects, signs of withdrawal and allergic reaction in the consumer educational section as well.
The Clinical Director, in collaboration with the Medical Director, shall review and, if needed, revise this policy annually and submit to Clinical Committee for approval.

subpolicies.title: POLICY:   		EMERGENCY GENERATOR OPERATING AND TESTING

blocks.text: The Safety Officer or designee in Maintenance will test the emergency generators per manufacturer’s specifications for 30 consecutive minutes 12 times per year and once annually at 25% of manufacturer’s nomenclature for exhaust temperatures for one half hour. Any failed test must be retested immediately per manufacturer's specifications. Testing results are recorded on the Emergency Generator Testing Log and filed in the office of the Safety Officer and the Administrative Assistant.
If the generator  diesel powered it must meet the manufacturers minimum exhaust gas temperature with the monthly test, then it must be tested with the following exercise with supplemental loads of:
25% of nameplate rating for 30 minutes followed by;
50% of nameplate rating for 30 minutes followed by;
75% of nameplate rating for 60 minutes.
Automatic Transfer Switches

Monthly the automatic transfer switch at each generator is tested by the Safety Officer or designee.  The date that the test was done and results are documented on the Generator and Emergency Light Testing Log.

If this test fails, administration and the Safety Officer, if not the one reporting, are immediately notified so that prompt repair can be arranged.  An Incident Report shall be completed by the tester.
If repair cannot take place the same day, the building will be vacated until the repair is completed.
Once the repair is done, the switch should be tested again; the test date and results shall be documented on the Generator and Emergency Light Testing Log.
The Logs will be reviewed at least annually by the Safety Officer to identify any trends or patterns, which may indicate the need for.

There must be a contract in place with an authorized fuel supplier for an assured fuel supply for all generators whether gas, diesel or liquid propane. This includes times of extreme weather or any emergency situation.
Fuel supplies must be maintained at optimum levels at all times and records kept of fuel usage.

The Safety Officer will review this policy annually and make modifications as needed based upon changes in regulations, changes necessary due to nature of services, etc.   Any revisions will be submitted to the Clinical Committee as scheduled.
